title: Inheritance requires a game plan
author: Mary Hunt
content:
Inheritance requires a game plan

 September 18, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mary Hunt | Page: 6 | Section: News 
 
 310
 Words 

 Read News Document

 While not always easy to think about, an inheritance is a part of the financial picture for many baby boomers.Dear Mary: Before reading your book "Debt-Proof Living," I believed we were doing just fine with our money. Recently, my husband's father died and we received a small inheritance.We sat down to decide how to handle this money. I pulled out the book and showed my husband the chapter on the 10-10-80 formula and the information about the Freedom Account.We figured out our expenses. We were shocked to discover we've been spending almost $1,800 more than we make each month. I guess we didn't notice because we would take a little out of savings to cover expenses as needed. At this rate, all of our inheritance would be gone in no time. Needless to say, I became rather depressed as we started reducing the outgo to balance our expenses with our income. We are looking at every area of spending and have already found so many ways we could make the adjustments.My husband actually thanked me this morning for all the work I've been doing on our budget.He always wondered why it seemed we were making good money but never able to save any. Now we know.I am telling you all of this to say thank you! I never would have figured this out if it hadn't been for "Debt-Proof Living." I'll keep you posted on our progress. - Kimberly Dear Kimberly: Your letter reminded me of an interesting statistic I came across recently, which said that it takes an average of 17 months' time for a person to completely spend an inheritance. Aren't you glad you won't be part of that statistic? So am I! Thanks for writing. Your letter made my day.Mary Hunt is the founder of EverydayCheapskate.com, a frugal living blog, and the author of the book "Debt-Proof Living." COPYRIGHT 2023 CREATORS.COM

title: Making your lunch beats buying it
author: Mary Hunt
content:
Making your lunch beats buying it

 September 19, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mary Hunt | Page: 6 | Section: News 
 
 301
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I know people who try to convince themselves they can buy lunch every day for less than they'd spend if they brought a bagged lunch to work.That kind of flawed thinking could well be the reason those same people complain that they do not make enough money to save any of it. Eating lunch out day after day is expensive.Here, let me do the math: $15 x 5 Days = $75 x 50 weeks = $3,750 per year. And that's just a quick estimate.If you could cut that number in half by bringing your lunch to work, you'd still have $1,875 for your savings account. However, I'm certain that with the right incentive (money in the bank is a great one), you could do even better than that.A GOOD CONTAINERFor me, a true brown bag is too flimsy. I want a lunch bag that is insulated, sturdy, leakproof and as attractive as possible. Cruise on over to Amazon, search "lunch bags" and you're sure to find hundreds to choose from that are as practical as they are cute.Look for one made of neoprene and that is insulated with a zipper closure. The test of a good lunch container is how often it is used.BENTO BOXESThese are portable food boxes with compartments that fit inside the lunch box to keep wet things wet, dry things dry and all things visually appetizing. The best bento boxes, in my opinion, have tight-fitting lids.I use a set of four compartment bento boxes and find myself using them for storing leftovers as well as in a lunch bag. While not completely leakproof (I wouldn't fill one with milk, for example), they keep lunch items fresh and tasty, and most are leak-resistant. Mary Hunt is the founder of Everyday-Cheapskate.com, a frugal living blog, and the author of the book "Debt-Proof Living." COPYR IGHT 2023 CREATORS.COM

 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS - Some potential cannabis businesses are criticizing the tight turnaround to obtain new licenses to grow, process or distribute marijuana, after the Maryland Cannabis Administration announced applications will open on Nov. 13, with distribution set to start just six weeks later on Jan. 1.The bill that legalized cannabis for individuals 21 and older in Maryland that took effect July 1 created a timeline for recreational use, including a two-round licensing process for new cannabis businesses that will initially prioritize applicants who qualify for social equity.The application will close Dec. 13, giving the administration less than a month to review applications, enter them in a lottery and begin distribution before the end of this year.Caroline County resident LaKia Harris-Pierce is applying as a social equity applicant and has been advocating for cannabis reform for over a decade."I think their timeline is off because they have a prediction about how many people are applying," said Harris-Pierce, who holds a master's degree in cannabis science from the University of Maryland, Baltimore. "The application should have opened up Oct. 1 to Nov. 1, and that would have given the MCA time to go through them because this is going to be a rushed job."W hile recreational use of cannabis has been legal since July 1, only businesses who had licenses before that time under the medical use provisions could operate. These new recreational use licenses will serve social equity applicants, with Maryland the first state to reserve the first round of cannabis licenses for those businesses.The MCA opened a social equity verification portal on Sept. 8 for applicants to ensure they qualify for this round before they apply, which Harris-Pierce is currently working on. To qualify, an applicant must have at least 65% ownership in their business and meet at least one of the following criteria:. Have lived in a disproportionately impacted area for at least five of the last 10 years. Attended a public school in a disproportionately impacted area for at least five years. Spent at least two years at a four-year institution of higher education in Maryland where at least 40% of attendees are eligible for a Pell Grant.LaWann Stribling, an aspiring cannabis business owner who only recently qualified as a social equity applicant, explains that social equity goes beyond where you live."I have two children whose fathers suffered from the war on drugs," Stribling said. "No one is taking into account any families who have suffered that way, or families who have been incarcerated but didn't live in a disenfranchised area."Following the distribution of Round 1 licenses, the MCA will conduct a disparity study which will determine the criteria for Round 2 applicants, set to launch in the spring of 2024.Jake Van Wingerden, founder and president of SunMed Growers, has been a cannabis business licensee since 2016. He said that while the licensing has set dates for a reason, there will not be enough time between the first and second rounds for these applicants to get established and see how social equity is addressed."To actually think that any cannabis operator can get started in months is not realistic," he said.Despite these hesitations, Del. Jheanelle Wilkins, D-Montgomery, who as chair of the Legislative Black Caucus prioritized adult-use cannabis in the bill and helped assure access for social equity applicants, says the licensing process is right on schedule."The first step is putting out the information so that only qualified individuals take out the time and the effort to apply," she said. "(It's) a perfect timeline to make sure that the applicants are able to have a fair process and that the application period is open as required by law with the ability to award them by Jan. 1."Wilkins added: "We have worked to leave no stone unturned in terms of providing as much support as we can as a state, and making sure that the licenses are distributed in an equitable way that are reflective of repairing past harms and making sure that we're including as many people as possible, so I'm really proud of the bill."For Harris-Pierce, she is not in this business to make money, but because she wants to be one of the first Black female veteran-owned cannabis dispensaries in the state. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the regulatory licensing process for cannabis businesses, including timelines, application procedures, and economic implications for entrepreneurs. While social equity aspects are mentioned, the core subject revolves around business regulations and economic opportunities within the cannabis industry.

title: Despite workers strike, UAW running out of gas
content:
Despite workers strike, UAW running out of gas

 September 22, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 7 | Section: News 
 
 768
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON - Henry Ford, according to corporate legend, said that if he had asked potential customers what they wanted when he founded his company in 1903, they would have said faster horses. The infant automobile industry began by giving people what they did not know they wanted.Twelve decades later, this industry is being discombobulated by government pressure to manufacture products - electric vehicles - that the public does not much want, least of all in the quantities that Washington's central planners deem proper.There has been much commentary about the nation's "new economy" because of all the new devices produced to serve the digital economy, and because of the dominance of finance - the making of deals rather than material things. Yet here we are, invited to be fixated on a partial strike affecting only a portion of a quintessential example of the old economy: the automobile industry.During the strike, much of the industry continues to manufacture vehicles, far from Detroit.In 1979, United Auto Workers membership peaked at 1.5 million, in a national civilian workforce of 98.8 million.Today, the "big three" - General Motors, Ford, Stellantis (Chrysler's parent company) - employ about 150,000 UAW members, and the civilian workforce is about 160 million. Time was, America's auto manufacturing meant those three.Today, they are not nearly as important as they were in May 1950, when the UAW and GM signed the "Treaty of Detroit." No one wanted a repeat of that year's 104-day strike against Chrysler that idled 100,000 in Detroit.The "treaty" improved wages and established pensions and company-paid health care.In the 1950s, Detroit was the nation's fifth-largest city (it is now 27th) and Germany and Japan were still struggling to recover from damage done by U.S. bombers, many with Ford-built engines.U.S. car companies, with 95 percent of the national market share, had negligible competition and could pass along to consumers the costs of labor contracts.Labor strife in Detroit - the automobile industry had supplanted railroads as the emblem of the nation's industrial might - used to be riveting news: Capitalism's big battalions were battling for supremacy. Now, the union and the companies are subordinate to much the biggest battalion: the federal government.In a market economy, labor and management participate in profitmaking, then tussle over carving the profit pie. Now, however, government hovers over the negotiating table, armed with monetary incentives (subsidies) and regulatory coercions (e.g., everstricter CAFE - corporate average fuel economy - standards).The Biden administration is ladling at least $12 billion into the automakers to cushion them against the Biden administration.Against, that is, myriad government pressures to quickly eliminate the non-EVs that the obdurate public prefers.This will require the companies to make tens of billions in capital investments, some of which with money the public will provide.The semi/sort of/once-upon-a-time private companies will pretend this is private enterprise, freshly reimagined.The UAW reasons, not unreasonably, that its job is to seize for its members as much as it can of the billions sloshing around in the name of "industrial policy" subsidies. Meanwhile, non-UAW production lines are still humming along, disproportionately in the South's right-to-work states.The UAW worries that EVs, having many fewer components than internal combustion vehicles, will require many fewer assembly workers. Last year, Ford's CEO suggested 40 percent fewer. The union probably cannot even moderate the Biden administration's climate monomania. It might, however, extort some taxpayer-funded payoffs.The union should also worry that many Americans will keep their gas-powered cars longer than usual, rather than take a leap of faith regarding EVs. How many miles can they go between charges? The government is in charge of guaranteeing an adequate supply of charging stations, so drivers, too, should worry. To understand why this month's inventory of unsold EVs is almost twice that of gas-powered vehicles, start by reading NPR's report on Energy Secretary Jennifer Granholm's misadventures during her planned drive from Charlotte to Memphis, trying to demonstrate EVs' delights. Fortunately, her advance team had a gas-powered car.Regarding one matter, the UAW is too timid, given the nation's increasingly political - very political - economy. The UAW rails against the CEOs' salaries at GM, Ford and Stellantis - reportedly $29 million (362 times a median employee's earnings), $21 million (281 times), and $24.8 million (365 times), respectively, in 2022.The UAW should propose that each CEO be paid $152,771, the highest base pay for GS-15 federal civil servants. This is what the CEOs should be considered, because their companies have become appendages of government, implementing its policies.Reach George Will at georgewill@washpost.com. 
 
 Caption: GEORGE F.WILL
 
People strike at the Ford Michigan Assembly Plant on Sept. 15 in Wayne, Michigan.
 
VALAURIAN WALLER/WASHINGTON POST 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on labor strikes, union negotiations, and corporate responses to government policies in the automobile industry, which are central to business and economic dynamics. While environmental aspects (EVs) are mentioned, they are secondary to the primary economic and labor-related themes.

title: Now is a great time to get into home ownership
content:
Now is a great time to get into home ownership

 September 22, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 15 | Section: News 
 
 668
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - Mortgage rates may be higher today than what buyers have become accustomed, but rates are still lower than they were in 1981 when rates were 18.63%. In other words, rates fluctuate, but owning a home is an investment in your future. So why wait? It is still a great time to buy."I hear clients tell me they think interest rates are too high. They are going to wait to purchase a home when the rates come down," notes Mid-Shore Board President Megan Rosendale. "I respond by saying you don't live in an interest rate; you live in a house, and I suggest they not wait because no one knows if or when this may or may not happen." Buyers need to understand the market is not going to return to the pandemic interest rate levels of 2.65 like they were in January 2021 anytime soon. Just because the rates were low did not mean it was easy to find a house. Buyers had to do all kinds of crazy things in addition to going way over asking price to get a home.It is not ideal to give up contingencies, waive appraisals or accept a home that needs repairs and pay $100,000 over list price, but that was what was happening, Rosendale said.In the end, things even out.It is a better situation today for buyers, they can make an offer in a less chaotic setting where they may have some leverage with a seller when it comes to negotiating terms."If you can afford a home, get in now, five years from now you will be glad you did. It may not be your forever home, but it can be a way to start accumulating equity and when the rates do drop, and they will, you can refinance or even find a different home," Rosendale said.The Mid-Shore and most of the Unites States continue to be in a low inventory market.We have seen the cost for some properties make pricing adjustments; however, the price of homes overall continues to increase. In fact, for our Mid-Shore region, the median price of a home has increased by 13.77% from 2019. Most of the properties that are overpriced for their condition and/or location, need work and don't show that well are the ones seeing price reductions.It is an interesting fact, but when a property is adjusted to the right price, it can actually create a multiple offer situation, Rosendale said.Some thoughts to consider about homeownership: With a fixed-rate mortgage, your monthly principal and interest payments will remain the same for the life of your loan.Your mortgage interest may be tax-deductible.(Property taxes and mortgage points may also be deductible; consult your tax adviser.)If your home increases in value, you could make a profit when you sell.A home could be passed on to children or other family members.Equity built through home ownership can be used to finance educational expenses, home-improvement projects, small-business startup costs or other needs.You decide when and what home improvements to make.A landlord cannot decide to sell your house and force you to move.Home ownership is still an American Dream, it is your land, for your family. The financial benefits are worthwhile, but the home also provides stability and security.Studies indicate that homeowners move less often and are more likely to vote and volunteer in their communities.Children of homeowners tend to perform better in school and attain higher levels of education than children of parents who do not own a home. Dollar for dollar, the rate of return on owning a house is substantial, and it is how many American families begin to accumulate wealth.Owning a home is a good investment, So why wait? Meet with a Mid-Shore Realtor and start the process and see why it's a great time to buy.The Mid-Shore Board of Realtors mission is to advocate for its members and the public to preserve the right to own, transfer and utilize real property. For more news and information check out the website midshoreboardofrealtors.com. 
 
 Caption: SUBMITTED
 
Mid-Shore Board of Realtors President Megan Rosendale.

title: There is risk with 401(k) rewards
author: Mary Hunt
content:
There is risk with 401(k) rewards

 September 27, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mary Hunt | Page: 14 | Section: News 
 
 281
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Dear Cheapskate: This may be the ultimate in stupid questions but it's been plaguing me for a while. Is there any value in converting my existing 401(k) into cash without removing the funds from my 401(k)? Do they even allow that? I hate losing all that lovely money as things dip and swirl. I would continue to contribute at my existing rate, 12%, including the company match of 3% for the 401(k).- SymanthaDear Symantha: Employer-sponsored retirement plans, such as 401(k), typically have a cash option within the list of investments available to plan members. Look for a money market fund. If you move your account assets into that fund (which is perfectly allowable), the money is going to just sit there, not earning. It will be shielded from the wild swings in the market but will begin to lose value because you will not earn enough on your account to even keep up with inflation (reportedly 3.18% at this writing).The very nature of investing is that you expose money to reasonable levels of risk with the expectation of achieving a profit or gain. Not all of the choices in your 401(k) plan carry the same level of risk. Just remember that in order to achieve a reward, you must be willing to take a reasonable level of risk. No risk, no reward.The biggest problem with moving your account into a "cash position" is figuring how you will know when to move it back into investment funds that will give you a chance of achieving a gain. A better idea would be to contact your plan's administrator and make an appointment to meet with an investment counselor to assess all of the options you have in your 401k plan. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Commissioners honor Federalsburg business - Christopher Insurance celebrates 60 years
author: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com
content:
Commissioners honor Federalsburg business - Christopher Insurance celebrates 60 years

 September 27, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com | Page: 17 | Section: News 
 
 308
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - At its Sept. 19 meeting, the Caroline County Commissioners recognized Christopher Insurance Inc. of Federalsburg for "60 years of excellence" and "dedicated service" to the community.Owner Randall Hunt accepted the recognition."I would like to share some of the recognition with Jack Christopher whom I bought the agency from," Hunt said."He got this thing going in 1963. I feel like the relay guy; I took the baton in 2001."Commission President Travis Breeding read the recognition."Your legacy of service, reliability, and insurance solutions made a significant impact, providing peace of mind to our residents and supporting local businesses," he said."The commissioners thank Randall A. Hunt for consistently taking the time to understand and meet the unique needs of his customers and our citizens," Breeding said."Sixty years is a long time, but it's really a pleasure to do what I do in a small town," Hunt said.Hunt recognized two other "businesses on North Main Street that probably share the same longevity that I do," the Sewing Outlet and Meredith's Appliances, "true Main Street businesses," he said."It's an honor to accept this recognition, and I thank everybody for it," Hunt said."Thank you for keeping Main Street alive in these small towns," Breeding said."You see a lot of these small town, Main Street businesses going away, so it's quite the accomplishment and greatly appreciated.""Thank you, Randy, for making Caroline County a better place," Commissioner Frank Bartz said."(We) appreciate your being here and making Caroline County home for your business, and I look forward to another 60 years.""I won't be there, but my daughter works for me, so we'll see," Hunt said.

title: Stop playing Russian roulette with economy
content:
Stop playing Russian roulette with economy

 September 28, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 6 | Section: News 
 
 618
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In a few days, millions of federal employees, including active-duty military, could see their paychecks cut off.If the government shuts down at midnight Saturday, many federal services could be reduced or completely halted, affecting everything from national parks to food safety inspection to passport processing to airport security.Depending on how long the shutdown lasts, it could ultimately deprive poor children of federal nutrition and health care aid.Yet it will cost the taxpayers millions of dollars in lost economic activity - to say nothing of the real threat of downgrading America's creditworthiness, which would add to the national debt going forward.But, hey, Eric Burlison isn't worried."I'm not afraid of a shutdown," the Republican Missouri congressman was quoted as saying recently.Easy for him to say. His paycheck isn't at risk. Meanwhile, many of the U.S. military personnel who would suddenly stop getting paid will nonetheless be required to show up for work.Burlison is a member of the House Freedom Caucus, the misnamed klatch of hard-right extremists who are once again threatening to shackle America's economy.Readers aren't helpless to confront them. Even these bull-headed ideologues cannot entirely ignore the wishes of their constituents and fellow Republicans who, unlike themselves, actually care about the stability of government services. Pressure from the public could help. Contact numbers for Republican House members.The nation has, of course, been here before - earlier this year, in fact, when this same gang of political nihilists threatened to shut down the government over their demands for spending cuts.President Joe Biden and House Speaker Kevin McCarthy, R-Calif., averted a shutdown then with a deal in June that included about $1.5 trillion in spending cuts. But the Freedom Caucus wants more and is once again holding the government at fiscal gunpoint to get it.There are three things to keep in mind about those demands: One, they come from some of the same Republicans who enthusiastically rammed through the GOP's 2017 tax cuts. Those cuts primarily helped wealthy individuals and corporations, issued crumbs to everyone else and are expected to ultimately add close to $2 trillion to the federal debt. Republican debt obsession is, as always, situational - the situation being which party holds the White House.Two, the only ways to achieve significant levels of spending reductions is to deeply cut the defense budget, which the Freedom Caucus won't do; deeply cut Social Security and Medicare, which they'd like to do but won't admit to; or cut everything else - education, health care, basic government services, everything - to the bone. And even that won't come near the reductions the caucus claims to want.And three, this ultimately isn't just about money but about the Freedom Caucus' insistence that McCarthy, their House hostage - er, speaker - shut Democrats out of the process entirely. Caucus members have made clear they have zero interest in any kind of compromise with the opposing party.Which means no plan they would approve will stand a chance in the Senate, which is controlled by Democrats.These extremists don't even represent the majority of their own party, let alone the nation. Yet because of McCarthy's tenuous hold on his speakership, they are once again threatening to "burn the whole place down," as McCarthy himself recently put it.Perhaps he shouldn't have given them the matches in the first place. If there's still some semblance of sanity among the vast majority of House Republicans who aren't members of the Freedom Caucus, they will join with Democrats to take them away.Toward that end, readers who are represented by Republicans in the House can and should pressure those elected officials to quit playing Russian roulette with America's economy.REPRINTED FROM THE ST. LOUIS POST-DISPATCH DISTRIBUTED BY CREATORS.COM 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the economic implications of a potential government shutdown, including impacts on federal services, taxpayer costs, creditworthiness, and political negotiations over spending. While it has national news elements, the core emphasis is on economic consequences and fiscal policy.

title: Broadband internet project ahead of schedule
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Broadband internet project ahead of schedule

 September 28, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: 4 | Section: News 
 
 670
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE - Choptank Electric Cooperative and Choptank Fiber presented the Dorchester County Council last Tuesday evening on the broadband internet project that will bring broadband to about 704 locations in the county."We believe that this entire project will be done by the end of 2024," Valerie Connelly, vice president of government affairs and public relations for Choptank Electric, said. "We are moving much faster than we thought." Choptank Fiber, a broadband internet company, is a wholly-owned subsidiary of Choptank Electric. Its goal is to "serve the unserved." Connelly said a broadband project of this kind is often expected to take about three years."The first year is all engineering and design, the second year they start to do the construction, the third year [is] connecting members," she said. "We've been able to build out most of what we're doing in 14 months or so. We're very pleased." The $8.3 million project, which runs below Federalsburg and into Northeast Dorchester County, builds on a recently finished broadband project in Caroline County. Funding for this Dorchester project comes from the Maryland Office of Statewide Broadband, Choptank Electric and Choptank Fiber and Dorchester County.The Office of Statewide Broadband is contributing $4.08 million, Choptank Electric and Choptank Fiber is contributing $3.7 million and Dorchester County has pledged $500,284 of American Rescue Plan Act funds."The grant money that was contributed by the county and by the state allows us to bring on contractors and keep them working continuously," Connelly said. "So we're moving them from one project to the next trying to get to everybody who is unserved here on the shore." Connelly said construction has started for the project and most of the engineering has been completed. She added that because the project has been divided into zones, some areas are opening up for service as the project continues."We're not waiting until the entire project is built out," she said. "We're, weekly, announcing areas that we're opening for service for members who live there." Connelly said the question everyone asks as soon as they hear about the project is, "How much is it going to cost?" Choptank Fiber offers different speed packages. These include: Up to 100 Mbps for $84.95 per month Up to 450 Mbps for $99.95 per month Up to 1,000 Mbps for $139.95 per month Up to 2,500 Mbps for $279.95 per month Connelly added that there are three affordability programs that could bring down these prices for customers. The first program is a $15 discount per month if the customer qualifies for energy assistance.The second program is a $30 discount per month if the resident is eligible for certain programs, like income programs.Connelly said residents must log onto the Federal Communications Commission website to get qualified for this program.The third program is an additional $15 discount per moth for those that qualify for the second program."They automatically get the state program," Connelly said.Connelly said Choptank Electric thinks these programs are important."We don't want anyone to have to make the decision not to take broadband when we get there because of an affordability issue," she said. "We are doing more this fall to really promote that and make sure that families know that all these options are available." After Connelly's presentation, council member Ricky Travers asked what the company needs from the county to continue moving forward with this project - "other than money," he joked.Connelly said council members should continue to keep track of residents that reach out to say they don't have good service or they don't have any service.Council Vice President Mike Detmer called some of the areas in the county "drastically unserved." "So I know that it's going to be a very welcomed thing for the citizens of this county," he said of the project. 
 
 Caption: SCREENSHOT FROM DORCHESTER COU NTY COUNCIL MEETING
 
Valerie Connelly, vice president of government affairs and public relations for Choptank Electric, gives an update to the Dorchester County Council Sept. 19 on a broadband internet project in the county.

title: Check electricity costs when buying a home
content:
Check electricity costs when buying a home

 September 29, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 15 | Section: News 
 
 798
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Homebuyers' preferences are constantly evolving, but their desire to live in a home with increased energy performance and a more comfortable, healthier, living space has increased.While most newer homes include green features, finding one that meets your clients' expectations can be challenging, especially in a tight real estate market where many of the homes for sale were built 30 or more years ago. For buyers, the solution often involves finding an agent who understands their priorities and can help decide if a home measures up - or can be modified without breaking their budget.High-performance homes have always been in demand, but here are a few trends of recent interest.:1. Electricity costs more.In less than three years, the average price of electricity in U.S. cities has risen over 24%, from 13.6 to 16.9 cents per kilowatt-hour, driving up the cost to heat, cool and power a home's lights and appliances.Already faced with high housing prices and interest rates, many buyers want to know the cost of operating a home before buying it. The answer is not as simple as asking for the owner's utility bills because energy consumption patterns could differ significantly.Instead, buyers can evaluate a home's energy-performance features. For example, a cooling system with a high SEER rating can bring instant relief to homebuyers that may face intense heatwaves. Delmarva Power provides, at a cost, a Home Energy Assessment that will help identify areas in the home that are not an efficient as they could be.Also, look for resources like energy auditors, they can provide an audit in the inspection process. It helps if you are familiar with the auditors' rating systems, like the Home Energy Rating System (HERS), Home Energy Score (HES), and the Pearl Certification.2. New ways to save.Some Realtors are familiar with various rebates and tax credits that can help their buyers in selecting the best properties for making an existing home more energy efficient while enjoying substantial savings on upgrades. The Inflation Reduction Act contains several new tax credits and rebates for 2023 to help households pay for energy efficiency upgrades, electric vehicles, electric heating and cooling systems, and certain electric appliances. If you are considering buying any of the following items or services, you may be eligible for tax credits and/or rebates that can help you pay for them: opc.mary-land.gov/Consumer-Learning/Inflation-Reduction-Act.Maryland Energy Administration has an Energy Storage Income tax credit designed to encourage the deployment of energy storage systems in Maryland. The tax credit is available to residential and commercial taxpayers who have installed an energy storage system on their residential or commercial property in Maryland.Under the enabling statute, the state may award a total of $750,000 in tax credit certificates during a given tax year. Tax credit certificates will be awarded to eligible applicants on a first come, first served basis. This program was so popular it is sold out for 2023 but it will open again in 2024. (energy.maryland.gov/business/Pages/EnergyStorage.aspx)Researching solar panels and the placement is something to consider. Buyers want eco friendly homes but not at the expense of a yard. It is vital to have supporting documents of your solar contracts including roof quality inspection before installing.3. Climate considerations.Majorities of homebuyers and sellers say they are reluctant to move to areas at risk of natural disasters, extreme temperatures, and/or rising sea levels. However, that has not stopped the flow of new residents into numerous disaster-prone areas. We cannot predict the likelihood of a devastating local event, but being on the Eastern Shore we know we have flooding issues and are always watchful for hurricanes.Still, Realtors can help buyers evaluate whether a home includes improvements like a reinforced roof and garage door, impact-resistant glass, or storm shutters in areas where hurricanes threaten.Agents should be able to point buyers to the best climate risk data resources to form their conclusions about the risks they may face. Also, Realtors can recommend buyers research if the home will need flood insurance, especially when just one inch of water can cause roughly twenty-five thousand dollars of damage to a home. To see if the home is in a flood zone, floodsmart.gov.Realtors can support clients in many other ways. For example, they can highlight how a home includes upgraded features like energy-efficient systems, a tight building envelope, or a whole-house air purification system. This will help entice buyers eager to purchase a green home.If buyers and sellers prioritize sustainable home features or want to maximize the eco-aspects of their purchase or sale price, they want a Mid-Shore Realtor who understands the nuances and technical aspects of energy efficient homes.The Mid-Shore Board of Realtors mission is to advocate for its members and the public to preserve the right to own, transfer and utilize real property. For more news and information check out the website midshoreboardofrealtors.com. 
 
 Caption: SUBMITTED
 
Batteries can store energy in state-of-the-art homes. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on homebuyers evaluating electricity costs, energy efficiency, and economic factors like tax credits, which align with Business/Economy. While environmental aspects (e.g., climate risks, energy storage) are mentioned, the core theme revolves around real estate decisions and financial considerations.

title: Earn extra cash for Christmas
author: Mary Hunt
content:
Earn extra cash for Christmas

 October 4, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mary Hunt | Page: 14 | Section: News 
 
 315
 Words 

 Read News Document

 It's still October, but it's not too early to start planning for Christmas. If you're ready to make this year a debt-free Christmas, I've got useful ways to find the extra cash you'll need to do that. And time is of the essence because Christmas will be here before we know it.SWAGBUCKSSwagbucks is an online rewards program that gives users points (Swag Bucks, or SBs) for various tasks. One hundred points equals $1. Points can be traded in for eGift cards for more than 1,500 popular merchants like Amazon, Target, Starbucks and Walmart. Don't want gift cards? Redeem your points for cold, hard cash via PayPal.To get started, create your free Swagbucks account at Swagbucks.com. The opportunities to earn SBs will be endless. Do as little or as much as you want.You can choose to speed up your earnings by searching for online tutorials and following the Swagbucks Facebook page.RAKUTENRakuten is a free rebate site that you've read about here and there. title: Ahoy! It's crony capitalism sailing in U.S. ports
author: George F. Will
content:
Ahoy! It's crony capitalism sailing in U.S. ports

 October 5, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: George F. Will | Page: 7 | Section: Opinions 
 
 779
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON - Wesley Jones, a Republican U.S. senator from Washington, 1909-1932, should be canonized as the patron saint of industrial policy. His contribution to such mischief, which is enjoying a rebirth of respectability, is in its second century of doing damage.His advocacy of the Merchant Marine Act of 1920, a.k.a. the Jones Act, included the usual cant about serving national security and the public interest generally. The act began, however, as garden-variety political parochialism.It survives because it is defended by the "reliance interests" - industries tethered to government favoritism - that industrial policy, a.k.a. protectionism or crony capitalism, invariably produces.Industrial policy involves government supplanting society's myriad private collaborations - i.e., market transactions - to allocate resources and opportunities as government thinks best.Such policy empowers government, which is politics in every fiber of its being, to supplant markets in shaping the future, deciding which industries and products should prosper. Jones wanted Washington state's shipping industry to prosper, with the help of the other Washington. He particularly wanted to protect his state's shippers from foreign competition serving ports in Alaska - over Alaska's strenuous objections.The Jones Act today requires that cargo transported by water between U.S. ports must travel in ships that are U.S.-flagged and are at least 75 percent U.S.-owned and - crewed. The ships also must be assembled entirely in the United States, with all major components U.S.-fabricated.Passed immediately after one war, the act was rationalized by anticipation of another. Supposedly protecting the domestic shipping industry from foreign competition would stimulate merchant marine shipbuilding sufficient for military emergencies.Predictably, however, protecting the shipping industry from competition increased costs of shipped goods (costs passed along to U.S. consumers), decreased pressure for efficiencies and contributed to the shrinking of U.S. shipbuilding.Colin Grabow and Scott Lincicome of the Cato Institute report that two years after the Jones Act was passed, a government report found that a U.S.-built ship cost 25 percent more than a comparable vessel built abroad. And after a century of the act? "A U.S.-built tanker costs 300 percent more than one built abroad while a U.S.-built containership has a price premium of 400 percent." U.S. shipyards have collectively produced fewer than three a year since 2000.The Jones Act's strictures for "U.S.-built" ships include: "major components" of the hulls and superstructures, and at least 98.5 percent of the hull and superstructure components' steel weight must be fabricated in the United States. People acquire expensive law degrees to have careers writing such stuff.The 0.5 tacked onto the 98 does, however, perhaps reveal a sly sense of humor.This, however, is not amusing: The quality of the U.S. merchant fleet has national security implications. In Europe, a large, long war of aggression is raging, with the survival of the aggressedagainst nation depending on U.S. weapons, munitions and other materials. A much larger war could erupt in Asia, especially if the aggressor doubts the U.S. ability to sustain a protracted conflict.Jerry Hendrix, a retired Navy captain and senior fellow of the Sagamore Institute, an Indiana think tank, notes in the Atlantic: "In 1977, American shipbuilders produced more than 1 million gross tons of merchant ships. By 2005, that number had fallen to 300,000." In 2022, it was less than 33,000.Norwegian and Dutch yards delivered about 147,000 and 118,000, respectively.The number of oceangoing cargo ships of at least 1,000 gross tons and meeting Jones Act requirements has declined from "193 to 99 since 2000, and only 78 of those 99 can be deemed militarily useful," wrote Grabow and fellow policy analysts Inu Manak and Daniel Ikenson in 2018."Facing exorbitant replacement costs, ship owners are compelled to squeeze as much life as possible out of their existing vessels. Excluding tankers, the ships in the Jones Act fleet currently average 30 years old, fully 11 years older than the average age of a ship in the world merchant fleet of other developed countries." The authors above were writing for the Cato Institute.The libertarian think tank located near Capitol Hill, where crony capitalism originates, disparages the Jones Act. As does the Mercatus Center, which incubates market-oriented ideas at George Mason University.Cato obtained, through the Freedom of Information Act process, documents related to a 2020 meeting of a committee that advises, on behalf of the U.S. shipping industry, the U.S. Maritime Administration, which oversees the industry. The committee's recommendations included: "Charge all past and present members of the Cato and Mercatus Institutes with treason." Such brainstorming from industrial policy's defenders indicates their assessment of their arguments' persuasiveness.Reach George Will at georgewill@washpost.com. 
 
 Caption: MELINA MARA/WASHINGTON POST
 
With 44 container ships waiting off shore to be unload of their merchandise, a hectic and overcrowded Port of Los Angeles operates 24 hours a day in San Pedro, California, in 2021. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

While national security is mentioned, the core discussion revolves around economic consequences, regulatory burdens, and market efficiency, aligning most closely with Business/Economy.

title: Excellent customer service
content:
Excellent customer service

 October 5, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 6 | Section: Letters 
 
 479
 Words 

 Read News Document

 My wife and I were born and raised in Baltimore. We are in our mid 70s and since our childhood we have always vacationed on the Eastern Shore. Twenty years ago we relocated to Northeast, Tennessee, but still annually come back to the Eastern Shore to get our "seafood and steamed crab fix." However, I am writing to you not about your delicious food but about the kindness shown to us by Brent Spurry, owner of the Spurry Tire Company.Our story: We had just finished four glorious days in St. Michaels and while gassing up the car for the 450-mile return trip home, I noticed the valence (or mud guard) located under my front bumper was hanging down. Concerned that it would completely break away while on the highway, I began looking for a repair shop. It was Saturday, and I learned many repair shops were closed. In desperation I asked a kindly person tending our hotel's lawn for help. He directed me to the Spurry Tire Company on Elliot Road. He said be sure to ask for the owner, Brent Spurry.After a 20-minute ride including through picturesque downtown Easton, I arrived at the Spurry Tire Company. It was a larger business than I anticipated with six bays (all full) and maybe a dozen employees (all very busy). The waiting room was also full of customers which I thought didn't bode well for an out-of-state vehicle with a hanging mud-guard being repaired anytime soon.I reluctantly asked to see Brent Spurry and to my surprise he appeared within a minute. I related my story, and he said his bays were full but when one became available someone would take a look. I walked outside to ponder my next move (should I risk the trip home).Just then I heard a pleasant voice say "We are putting your car in an open bay.Ten minutes later same voice says "all fixed you're good to go." Surprised and grateful I asked, "What do I owe you?"[[---]] see the office was the reply. I return to the waiting room (it was even more crowded)."Hello, I'm Mr. Townsend, you folks were kind to fix my car, what do I owe you?" Nothing was the reply from the counter clerk. I said obviously this is a busy place but can I see Mr. Spurry?Within minutes Brent Spurry appeared. I thanked him and politely insisted that I pay him for the work.He smiled and said, "No charge" [[---]] even though I'm from out-of-state and he will likely never see me again [[---]] He said, "No charge." In a flash he returned to the shop. I turned to leave and said to the crowded waiting room that they were fortunate to have a Spurry Tire Company in their city.A lady remarked for all to hear "we know." I wrote this letter because I wanted others to know about Brent Spurry and his kindness and business practices.He is a perfect example of practicing excellent customer service even to someone from out-of-state.JERRY AND PEGGY TOWNSENDNortheast, Tennessee 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article highlights a business owner's exceptional customer service, focusing on interpersonal interactions and business practices. While not explicitly about economic data or corporate strategies, the core subject is a local business's operational ethos. 'Local Life' is a secondary fit due to the community-centric narrative, but 'Business/Economy' remains the most directly relevant category.

title: Historic Stevensville welcomes Chamber crawl
author: Laura Tayman
content:
Historic Stevensville welcomes Chamber crawl

 October 9, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Laura Tayman | Page: 4 | Section: News 
 
 700
 Words 

 Read News Document

 STEVENSVILLE-Late last month, on a beautiful fall evening in the historic Stevensville area, members of the Queen Anne's Chamber of Commerce were treated to a unique and highly successful networking event. Staying open after hours, business owners and chamber members were able to network and get a peak at each other's storefronts.Chambers across the country have begun sponsoring "crawl" events where members are welcomed into businesses located close to each other, allowing participants drop-in visits to learn more about each participating business, sampling their products and meeting their owners."This was our first such event," said Chamber Executive Director, Linda Friday, of the Sept. 27 event. "We were excited for our members to learn more about this special area of our community.We had nearly 70 participants registered to attend, with some never having even been in historic Stevensville before." The owners of the businesses were excited to share their history and success with Chamber guests as participants made their way through the few blocks on, and just off Main Street.Bill Huffnell, owner, and Amy Francis, director of Marketing and Communications, of Bay Point Wealth were on hand to greet visitors at their Stevensville office, which happens to be the historic Stevensville bank building of 1903. The building was placed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1983 and today still showcases the original ornamental pressed tin ceiling and vault. Huffnell provides the building as a site for the Kent Island Heritage Society to use on their tours for $1 a year.Members of the Historic Stevensville Arts & Entertainment District volunteers also greeted guests as they strolled Main Street; providing information on upcoming events, as well as regular activities taking place in the area, as was the Art East organization that supports local artists with regular meetings, trips, book discussions, and participation in community events.Across the street, Joan McWilliams's My Little Studio displayed the many talents of a shared-space gallery, where local artists and crafters rent space to create, show, and sell their work. Classes ranging from jewelry making to quilting are taught there as well.The sweets lovers were not disappointed. Over at the Tasty Toucan, owner Nikki Neboscynsky greeted chamber members Beth Mosner and Anna Hetzel, both from Miltec UV, who asked about her shop and how business was going.Mosner said, "Lots of members were excited about this event. It's nice to learn more about what these unique businesses have to offer." Across the street at the Peace of Cake bakery, sisters Kirsten and Kim Cate were busy working in the open kitchen and receiving compliments from happy chamber members who were enjoying a variety of their freshly baked items.Owners and sisters Kirsten and Kim Cate started their business in the same location 22 years ago and are still going strong."Business is a challenge," said Kirsten, "but baking is in our blood. For us, it's more than making a living." Chamber member Erich Krach, branch manager of Shore United Bank in Stevensville, said the crawl was his favorite chamber event so far. "I enjoyed seeing their businesses and seeing what we can offer them for support," said Krach.Chamber Board Member Eva Stoops participated as a both a chamber board member and a business located along the "crawl route." Stoops, co-owner of Chesapeake Environmental Lab, Inc., said she wasn't sure how the event would go at first."Right at 5 p.m. everyone started showing up," she said. "It's a fabulous event for both the participating businesses and the chamber.Many people don't how much the chamber does in providing these kinds of services and resources." Jessica Dolbec, who volunteers for both the Historic Stevensville Society and the Arts & Entertainment organization and works for Improvement Zone that is located on Main Street, assisted the chamber with providing regular communication among the participating businesses."It's wonderful to see the businesses open at this time, normally they are closed by now," she said. "I hope that this is a win-win for both groups." 
 
 Caption: LAURA TAYMAN
 
Maureen Wheatley is one of several local artists whose works are sold in My Little Studio in historic Stevensville owned by Joan McWilliams. The studio was open and guests welcomed at the Queen Anne's Chamber of Commerce's recent crawl. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a Chamber of Commerce event promoting local business networking and community engagement. While there are elements of local culture and community life, the primary emphasis is on business interactions, economic activities, and local commerce.

title: Saving on insurance can yield cash boost
author: Mary Hunt
content:
Saving on insurance can yield cash boost

 October 11, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mary Hunt | Page: 14 | Section: News 
 
 292
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Of all the people I know and love, I can't think of anyone who wouldn't welcome a small income boost this month - or any month, for that matter.Whether you're between jobs, figuring out how to cover a bill or hoping to stash more cash into savings, get your creative juices flowing with these ideas.You need term life insurance.The recommended is eight to 10 times the annual income of the single breadwinner; in a two-income family, insure each spouse for six to eight times their annual gross salary. But you can confidently cancel duplicate coverage.The boost: Add up what you're paying for credit card insurance, life insurance for your kids, mortgage insurance and accident insurance.What was offered to you for just pennies a day is probably about $100 a month, or more, that you will save.Caution: Get a term life policy first if you don't have one, then cancel the duplicates.Don't leave even the tiniest gap between coverage.Has your teenage driver brought home a great report card? Most auto insurance companies will knock about 10% off your premium if an insured teen maintains a 3.0 GPA. Is there an educator in the family? Mercury Insurance and other companies give discounts to credentialed teachers and educational administrators. Discounts also apply if you have a bachelor's degree in engineering or a science-related field. Finally, insurers often give discounts of 20% or more when you insure all of your cars with one company.Caution: Don't assume that discounts are automatic - you have to speak up. Ask to see a complete list, since companies offer different ones.The boost: Compound discounts can really add up for a big save.Mary Hunt is the founder of EverydayCheapskate.com, a frugal living blog, and the author of the book "Debt-Proof Living."COPYRIGHT 2023 CREAT ORS.COM 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on insurance cost-saving strategies, financial management, and discounts related to personal economic decisions. While education-related discounts are mentioned, the primary context is economic behavior and business-related financial practices.

title: Historic Armory could be torn down to make way for new boutique hotel
author: Laura Tayman
content:
Historic Armory could be torn down to make way for new boutique hotel

 October 16, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Laura Tayman | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 668
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Despite a new detailed presentation from Washington College President Mike Sosulski, the Chestertown Historic District Commissioners say they need still more information before approving the college's plans for the town's historic Armory building."Though we have come to the commission before, this is essentially a new request that does comply with the original deed," said Sosulski. "The Maryland Department of the Military and the Department of Public Works heartily endorse our position." The College appeared before the HDC at their Oct. 4 meeting.The Armory, built in 1931, was used for seven decades for the Maryland National Guard, as well as community events, and was put on the National Register of Historic Places in 1980. When the state declared the Armory was "surplus," the building was offered to the Town of Chestertown who did not have the resources to develop the property.Washington College bought the property in hopes of renovating the building and using it as an environmental center, right along the river. After a walk through and mold testing, the college withdrew their plans to the commission a year ago to get more information, address public input, and seek investors.Washington College president Sosulski led the new presentation last week.Sosulski said, "The college agrees that the Armory has historical significance. But it's been a constant struggle to find a purpose for this building." The college investigated several plans similar to those done with other armories throughout the state, but the costs were found to be prohibitive.Sosulski said that proposals for just stabilizing the structure cost $4 million and no investment partners could be found.At the October meeting, Sosulski provided details to this new proposal for a boutique style hotel with numerous meeting spaces that can be used by the entire community. If possible, the hotel would keep the facade of the building and keep numerous military memorabilia in prominent displays, he noted. Hersha Hospitality has agreed to partner with the company using this plan.Business leaders have been supportive of the proposal.A hotel/conference center would bring jobs, increase tourism, and help the town and county continue to improve" said Bryan Matthews, Executive Director of Kent Forward. "Our community must seize the opportunity to turn a deteriorating building with major issues into a tremendous asset." Other residents are not so sure. Resident Steven Mitchell, a facilities and environmental manager, wants the commission to have their own independent mold remediation expert to get an unbiased opinion about the mold issue. "I believe the applicant should pay for it, or the town," said Mitchell. "Or if necessary I will pay for it." Jeremy Rottweil, another resident, believed the mold remediation done before the 2005 closing took care of the mold problems, and it returned due to the college not taking proper care of the property. "Two large sump pumps and the HVAC were turned off.This is a textbook example of demolition by neglect," said Rottweil.Commission member Samantha Hollomon said she would like a current condition structural report for the head house, the main hall, and then the additions."I would like to see the cost difference between using the facade and not using it," she said."I would like to have greater clarity on the development team," said Commission member Rebecca Murphy. "If possible, to get their tax credit applications." Commissioner Monica Sella proposed the college come back before the Commission with the infrastructure costs of the project, such as building roads, getting plumbing, and so forth.Another member voiced concerns about environmental impacts from the demolition.Despite all of the questions and concerns voiced, most people in the room were supportive of the idea.Richard Keaveney, chair of the Economic Vitality Committee of Mainstreet Chestertown, told the commission that at his recent meeting, "Every member of the committee was in favor of this latest proposal." Overall, Holomon said she was "really excited" about the amount of agreement in the room. "Stay patient. Let's treat one another with respect," she advised, "This will be a group effort." 
 
 Caption: ERIC SYLVIA
 
The Chestertown Armory was built in 1931. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a redevelopment proposal for a historic building as a boutique hotel, emphasizing economic benefits like job creation, tourism, and community development. While local government approval processes are mentioned, the core discussion revolves around business opportunities and economic impact. Environmental aspects are secondary to the economic redevelopment narrative.

title: 'Thank You Tour' to recognize local businesses
author: Contributed
content:
'Thank You Tour' to recognize local businesses

 October 18, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Contributed | Page: A5 | Section: Business 
 
 223
 Words

 Caroline County Economic Development and Tourism are celebrating their local businesses with a Thank You Tour as part of Economic Development Week in Maryland Oct. 23 through 27.During the tour, the CCEDT team will be visiting Caroline County businesses to show their appreciation and support."This is our chance to honor some of the businesses that are the economic drivers in Caroline County, that bring jobs and vitality to our community," said Debbie Bowden, director of Caroline County Economic Development & Tourism.Starting Oct. 23, the office will visit five businesses in a variety of sectors each day, including those in manufacturing, hospitality, retail, real estate and food service.Throughout the week, the businesses that are visited will be highlighted on the Caroline Economic Development Facebook page."We chose to celebrate Economic Development Week by showing appreciation to a variety of establishments that make an impact in Caroline County," said Kendall Teague, small business coordinator for CCEDT.Economic Development in Maryland Week is designed to increase an understanding of economic development's contribution to the state's business climate, job retention and growth, tax base and the overall quality of life.For more information or to follow along with the Thank You Tour, follow Caroline Economic Development on Facebook, email info@carolinebusiness.com, or call 410-479-4188. title: Hypermilers save cash on cost of gasoline
content:
Hypermilers save cash on cost of gasoline

 October 18, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 16 | Section: News 
 
 290
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Hypermiling may sound like the latest popular adrenaline-inducing extreme sport, but not so, unless you consider extreme gas conservation a sport.Hypermiling is a method of increasing your car's gas mileage by making skillful changes in the way you drive.According to author Matt Bell, one hypermiler he knows routinely gets more than 50 miles per gallon from his 2005 Honda Accord, which is more than twice its Environmental Protection Agency rating.How does he do that?This driver's gas-saving tricks include always trying to park in such a way that he can pull forward instead of wasting gas backing up. Sticking to the speed limit, using cruise control when it's safe and appropriate, and turning off the engine if he's going to idle for more than 10 seconds are other ways this savvy hypermiler wrings every possible mile out of his gasoline.He keeps his tires inflated to their maximum recommended pressure, and if he's running a series of errands, he drives to the farthest destination first to warm the engine to its most efficient temperature, while also increasing gas mileage.Whether you're into the extreme sport of hypmiling or not, all of us can reduce our gasoline costs by simply buying the cheapest gas. Websites like Gas-Buddy.com track local prices every day. A quick log-on will help you take the shortest trip to the station with the cheapest price. Just make sure you start off slowly.And whatever you do, when you see a red light or brake lights ahead, back off that accelerator. Right there, you'll reduce your chances of running out of gas before you get to the station.Mary Hunt is the founder of EverydayCheapskate.com, a frugal living blog, and the author of the book "Debt-Proof Living." 
 
 Caption: MARY HUNT 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on cost-saving techniques for gasoline through efficient driving habits and consumer choices, directly relating to personal finance and economic behavior. While environmental benefits are mentioned, the primary emphasis is on economic savings.

title: Eastern Shore Candle lights up the Shore
author: Tom Mccall; tmccall@chespub.com
content:
Eastern Shore Candle lights up the Shore

 October 19, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom Mccall; tmccall@chespub.com | Page: A1 | Section: News 
 
 673
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE-What happens when you combine wax and scent and glass with evocative branding?Meet the brainchild ofTracie Van Dorpe, who is the founder and creator ofEastern Shore Candle Company.She has a studio in her backyard, where she tinkers, creates and imbues her creations with scent profiles inspired by the Delmarva Peninsula."After a 25-year career at the (global investment firm) Carlyle Group, the stress and a lot of fun, lot ofincredible moments, I always knew by the time I was 55, I wanted to do something different and more creative," said Van Dorpe."I went to a candle making class in Charleston, South Carolina and ended up talking to one ofthe investment bankers about the business,"she said.At the Caryle Group, Van Dorpe worked in branding, experience that came in handy when opening her new business."You create what we call a 'brand voice'or 'brand style.' You create attributes around that brand. Everything you create has something very similar," she said. "So I applied that to the candles for sure.""Each candle has a story and a custom illustration to support that story. We start with timeless fragrances based on the experience and joy and natural beauty ofthe Eastern Shore and the Chesapeake Bay,"said Van Dorpe.The candles have evocative names like Starry Nights and Firelight, Chesapeake Homecoming and The Great Blue Heron.And in them, Van Dorpe celebrates the landmarks ofthe Eastern Shore.One ofthe candles is named for the Wye Oak, Wye Mills' famous 500year-old tree, which collapsed during a severe thunderstorm in2002."I wanted to tell that story because so many ofus visited it when we were kids,"Van Dorpe said. "There is so much history and magic about it. There was an Indian trail that went right by it even before the settlers came along. So I have a candle that smells like oak and autumn and bayberry."Scent can conjure, said Van Dorpe, who took a class in perfumery. She creates all ofher scents from scratch."My favorite part is blending the fragrances. It can take up to seven or eight months because I really want to get it right,"she said.Van Dorpe and her two contract workers can make around 1,500 candles a week. Beyond her creative space behind her house, she has a 1,600 square foot facility in D.C., and she is looking for a much much bigger place close to home as her business grows.All ofher natural candles are produced with no petroleum products."These are coconut soy wax candles,"she said. " In the last ten years, folks in the industry have noticed ifyou use vegetable based wax that is available now, the candles are cleaner to burn. I have found that ifyou add coconut to the wax, then you get the best in all worlds."There are about 15 boutiques on the Shore where Van Dorpe sells.One boutique owner in Easton is Louisa Griffin. She runs Curliecue on Goldsbor-ough Street."These candles go beyond supporting a local maker. I carry them and restock constantly, because they are the best. They fly offthe shelves and it is always fun to hear what inspired someone to take one (or two) home with them. It's a lovely way to gift a bit ofthe Eastern Shore, whether to yourselfor a lucky recipient," said Griffin.Van Dorpe spends a lot of time delivering to wholesalers and boutiques that are mostly on the shore. But she has a larger goal."I would like to be in beautiful boutiques throughout the country and share the story of the Chesapeake Bay and the Eastern Shore with the rest of the country. People are inter-ested. What is that place in the Mid-Atlantic?" 
 
 Caption: TOM MCCALL/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Tracie Van Dorpe, founder and owner of Eastern Shore Candle Company, in her backyard shop where she makes candles and blends scents
 
TOM MCCALL/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
One of the boutiques where you can find Eastern Shore Candles is Curliecue in Easton.
 
TOM MCCALL/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Each box containing one of Van Dorpe's candles is printed with an image of a painting to highlight an aspect of The Shore.
 
TOM MCCALL/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Tracie Van Dorpe tries to tell a Eastern Shore story in every candle. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.
