While it mentions local elements and artistic aspects, the core theme revolves around business operations and economic activity.

title: Partner of oyster company petitions for dissolution - Petition follows history of legal violations by company's other partners
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content:
Partner of oyster company petitions for dissolution - Petition follows history of legal violations by company's other partners

 October 19, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com | Page: A3 | Section: News 
 
 688
 Words 

 Read News Document

 STEVENSVILLE-A majority partner at Orchard Point Oyster Company is petitioning to judicially dissolve the company due to the two other partners' previous legal violations.The petition, filed Oct. 2 in Queen Anne's County Circuit Court by Orchard Point partner Hal McBee, asks the court to dissolve the company, appoint a receiver to take charge ofits assets and operations, and later liquidate these assets.The need for the petition, McBee said, stemmed from his ongoing concerns with the actions ofOrchard Point's two other partners, Scott Budden and Brian Connelly, and the duo's alleged mishandling ofthe company's operations.After Orchard Point's formation in 2018, the three men were appointed to different roles: Budden as president, Connelly as treasurer and McBee as secretary.Budden and McBee each have 40% ofstocks in the company and Connelly has 20%.Both Budden and Connelly share the responsibility ofmaintaining Orchard Point's permits and registration cards.Though McBee was only responsible for Orchard Point's nursery, which is located at his personal residence, his name is on the aquaculture lease used by the whole company.As the lease holder, McBee said he was made aware earlier this year that the company was operating without renewed permits for 2023 and attempted to stop the two other partners from continuing their work.But when McBee headed into the office one day, he heard the fridge running and discovered 3,000 freshly harvested oysters obtained without an up-to-date permit-a blatant violation, which prompted him to approach the Maryland Natural Resources Police in March.In an interview, McBee said he felt reporting his partners was the only thing he could do. And if he didn't report it, he would be part of the problem, he said.All three men were charged with numerous Department ofNatural Resources permitting violations in April, including. Charges were later dropped for McBee.Budden and Connelly were both found guilty ofengaging in aquaculture without a permit on July 6. Each received probation before judgment and several hundred dollars in fines.And on July 7, Budden was again charged by DNR with failing to obtain a permit for not having authorization for wet storage and operating wet storage outside the boundaries ofa lease in connection to issues in 2022.The lease in question was under McBee's and Connelly's names.McBee's petition also asserts that Orchard Point is operating under McBee's Tidal Fish Dealer license, a state-issued license that gives the company the ability to process, pack, resell, market or deal fish caught in tidal waters.In the petition, an attorney for McBee said the continued use ofhis license by the company, especially considering past unlawful oyster harvesting, creates a risk to him and administrative action from the DNR.Damages to property McBee contributed to Orchard Point were also raised as points of contention.According to the petition, McBee allowed the company to use two ofhis workboats, a 3,600 square-foot office space converted into an oyster processing plant with offices, two residential properties in Stevensville and various pieces of aquaculture equipment.The workboats were utilized under the assurance from Budden and Connelly that Orchard Point would purchase the two boats for their original cost - $150,000. However, the boats were never purchased and no rent was paid for the use ofthe two boats, according to the petition. Failure to properly maintain the boats also incurred damages in excess of$30,000.The two other partners of Orchard Point vacated the company's Stevensville office space on Sept. 1 and failed to remit additional rent or remove alterations made to the office, resulting in property damage ofover $25,000, the petition stated.McBee's capital contributions and loans since 2018 totaled over $250,000 in financing and tangible property.According to the petition, the relationship between McBee and Orchard Point's other shareholders has "deteriorated to a point where Mr. McBee is no longer consulted regarding Orchard Point's operations or finances."Budden declined to comment on the peti-tion. The Star Democrat was unable to reach Connelly in time for publication ofthis article.No further documents have been filed in the circuit court at this time. 
 
 Caption: COURTESY oF MPT
 
Orchard Point Oyster Company in Stevensville manages oysters the company grows on a float lease in Eastern Bay. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a business dispute within an oyster company involving legal violations, financial disagreements, and corporate dissolution. While aquaculture is the industry, the core issue revolves around business operations, partnerships, and legal challenges, making Business/Economy the primary topic.

title: Cleaning out the junk in your life
author: Mary Hunt
content:
Cleaning out the junk in your life

 October 24, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mary Hunt | Page: 6 | Section: News 
 
 323
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Is your stuff really worth what it's costing you to store it? There's nothing like a couple of episodes of the reality television show "Hoarders" to make even the biggest clutter bug want to get rid of something.It crossed my mind that, at least in one episode, the subject hoarders were living with their stuff, which is more than we can say for the 14.6 million U.S. households that are paying a public storage facility, every month, to store their stuff.Why is self-storage such a big business in the U.S.?One facility owner told me that the industry counts on - and even capitalizes on - the fact that once renters move in, they're in. Facility owners know that no one likes the idea of spending the day moving all their accumulation of stuff out of storage.Of course, there are situations where self-storage may become a necessary expense.However, the operative word should be "temporary," a stopgap for a specific period, not permanent.Let's say you are paying this small fortune each year to store stuff you truly like. Your enjoyment level is off the charts. When was the last time you actually thought about those items or took the time to visit?After all, how much can you really enjoy something you have stashed away in an offsite storage unit? Take a photo of all the things you like so much. Often, it's the memory you're looking for.A photo will take care of that, allowing you to get rid of the items themselves.If you're ready to take control of your storage situation, I have two words for you: eliminate and organize, in that order.Make a decision for when you will go through all those boxes and bins. Tell a friend or relative of your decision, then ask that person to hold you accountable to keep it.Mary Hunt is the founder of EverydayCheapskate.com, a frugal living blog, and the author of the book "Debt-Proof Living."COPYRIGHT 2023 CREATORS.COM 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article analyzes the self-storage industry's business model, economic implications for consumers, and financial decisions related to storage costs. While it touches on personal finance and lifestyle, the core focus is on the economic aspects of a growing industry.

title: Caroline Commissioners proclaim Economic Development Week
author: Connle Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com
content:
Caroline Commissioners proclaim Economic Development Week

 October 25, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connle Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com | Page: A1 | Section: News 
 
 427
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - With only two more months in her tenure as director of Caroline County Economic Development ScTourism, Deborah Bowden is checking off her Iengthy to-do list.On item on that Iist included Stopping by the County Commission's 9 a.m. meeting Tuesday, Oct. 24, to hear a proclamation celebrating Caroline County Economic Development Week Oct. 23 to 27.Commissioner Frank Bartz read the proclamation that highlighted the department's "vision of lifelong citizens and newcomers, high school graduates and returning professionals growing and thriving in a steadfast business climate.""Fostering a diverse local economy leads to business retention, attraction, job creation, workforce development and a robust quality of life for the citizens of Caroline County," Bartz said.The proclamation recognized "a prevailing culture of customer service and community, and partnering with the state and local stakeholders (to bring) tremendous opportunities to Caroline County."Also celebrated were "a legacy of rural values with a vision for emerging capabilities in farming, food and agritech," as well as "a dynamic business community that works towards the betterment of businesses, workers and the county."During the week, selected businesses throughout the county have been and will be visited by a county commissioner, a CCEDT staff member and "perhaps a town representative.""We are also going to ask a representative from a business that we visit to attend the next business that we visit in a 'pay it forward' gesture of supporting the community," Bowden wrote in an email.Each visit will allow the county and town leaders to express their gratitude, accompanied by a token of appreciation, to the businesses for all they "bring to the local economy and community" and to pose for team photos for posting on social media platforms.During the week, 16 businesses located in or near six towns will be visited.On Monday, the team visited Arcadia Living in Denton, Lorry Industries in Denton, Choptank Supply in Denton and Lywood Electric in Federalsburg.On Tuesday, a team visited Awards Engraving Company, Caroline Review, Bob Breeding Contractors and On Your Mark Lighting Design and Equipment, all in Denton.Wednesday's schedule includes Benedictine near Ridgely, Tri Me Warehouse in Ridgely, Masten Pools in Greensboro and Ridgely Pharmacy in Ridgely.Thursday's visits will include Sisk Fulfillment in Federalsburg, The Sewing Outlet inFederalsburg, Smokey Cat Lavender Farm near Federalsburg and Outstanding Dreams Farm near Preston.

title: Smithsonian adds visionary leaders to 'American Enterprise' exhibition - Museums
content:
Smithsonian adds visionary leaders to 'American Enterprise' exhibition - Museums

 October 26, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 27 | Section: News 
 
 658
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Collections from groundbreaking entrepreneurs Byron Lewis and Lillian Vernon are now showcased in a new display within the landmark "American Enterprise" exhibition at the Smithsonian's National Museum of American History. The two stories, "Lillian Vernon, Kitchen Table Millionaire" and "Byron Lewis, Ad King Extraordinaire," will be featured in the exhibition's Consumer Era (1940s-1970s) section.The exhibit will feature selected objects from across both entrepreneurs' career trajectories, including Vernon's original yellow Formica kitchen table and Lewis' antique French provincial desk and chair. Her kitchen table served as a foundation for Vernon's home business-turned-major corporation, The Lillian Vernon Corp., and Lewis ran his pioneering ad agency, UniWorld Group, from behind this desk."Innovations in broadcasting, advertising, postwar consumerism and an increased number ofwomen and African Americans in the business world really begins between the 1960s and 1970s," said Anthea M. Hartig, the museum's Elizabeth MacMillan Director. "It is in this 'consumer era' that we see entrepreneurs such as Lewis' and Vernon use their persistence, creativity and drive to launch and see their enterprises thrive."As a young, married woman in 1951, Vernon began selling monogrammed accessories from her kitchen table to earn additional income for her family. Starting with a handbag that was manufactured by her father and advertised in Seventeen magazine, Vernon sold her products using niche marketing and direct-mail catalogs.These innovations helped her home business flourish, eventually expanding into a major corporation by the 1990s. Graphics of those early ad campaigns, along with an early example of the monogramed purse from 1951, will be on view. The Lillian Vernon Corp. became the first wom-en-founded business to be publicly traded on an American stock exchange.Lewis founded UniWorld group in 1969, inspired by his time working in the multicultural neighborhoods ofNew York City. As the CEO ofUniWorld, Lewis advanced the interests of Black consumers and promoted the work of Black artists, filmmakers, activists and politicians. Among his many projects, Lewis promoted the 1971 movie "Shaft," co-directed the National Black Political Convention and UniWorld was the first Black-owned agency to land a general consumer campaign with "3 Musketeers" candy.In recognition of author Alexandre Dumas' French and African ancestry, he cast a Black actor as one of the three musketeers. Three swords used in that campaign will be on view along with a number of awards, including one recognizing Lewis' induction into the Advertising Hall of Fame by the American Advertising Federation in 2013."American Enterprise" chronicles the tumultuous interaction of capitalism and democracy that resulted in the continuous remaking of American business-and American life. Visitors are immersed in the dramatic arc of labor, power, wealth, success and failure in an 8,000-square-foot gallery.To mark the opening of the exhibit on Oct. 17, the museum presented a panel discussion titled "Women's Business: From Kitchen Table to C-Suite," focusing on how women of color are changing the ways Americans do business, moderated by MSNBC news anchor Symone D. Sanders-Townsend.The exhibition was made possible by significant support from Mars Inc., the Wallace H. Coulter Foundation and SC Johnson. Generous support came from Intel, Monsanto Co., the United Soybean Board and History Channel, with additional support by Motorola Foundation, 3M, Pete and Linda Claussen, the William T. Kemper Foundation and John Deere.Through incomparable collections, rigorous research and dynamic public outreach, the National Museum of American History seeks to empower people to create a more just and compassionate future by examining, preserving and sharing the complexity of the past.The museum, located on Constitution Avenue N.W., between 12th and 14th streets, is open daily except Dec. 25, between 10 a.m. and 5:30 p.m. Admission is free. The doors of the museum are always open online and the virtual museum offers exhibitions, PK-12 educational materials and programs.For more information, go to https://americanhis-tory.si.edu. For Smithsonian information, call 202633-1000. 
 
 Caption: SMITHSONIAN PHOTOS
 
The Smithsonian's National Museum of American History has added collections from entrepreneurs Byron Lewis, pictured above left, and Lillian Vernon, shown in a portrait, for the new "American Enterprise" exhibition. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the Smithsonian's exhibition highlighting entrepreneurial achievements of Byron Lewis and Lillian Vernon, emphasizing their business innovations, impact on consumerism, and economic contributions. While the museum context ties to 'Arts & Culture,' the core subject is business history and economic development.

title: How much debt is OK?
author: Mary Hunt
content:
How much debt is OK?

 November 2, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mary Hunt | Page: 15 | Section: News 
 
 301
 Words 

 Read News Document

 These days, as my virtual mailbag fills with messages and pleas for help, I'm noticing a decided increase in those that are related to debt. I pulled out a couple to share with you today.Dear Mary: Is it ever OK to have debt? How much debt can I afford? - Deanna Dear Deanna: Sure, it is OK, under the right reasonable and safe conditions. After all, not many of us could be homeowners or purchase a car without a mortgage or financing of some kind. These days, it's difficult to finish a college education without incurring some amount of student debt. But there needs to be self-imposed limits and boundaries.Mortgage debt: Your monthly mortgage payment - including principal, interest, real estate taxes, and homeowners insurance - should not exceed 30% of your gross monthly income (before taxes).Student debt: A good rule to follow is that your total student debt should not exceed the first year's income in your chosen field of study.Auto debt: Your loan should be for no more than 36 months.With this kind of aggressive pay-back structure, you can be pretty sure your car won't go upside down where it's suddenly worth less than your outstanding debt.Credit card debt: It is never OK to have credit card debt.It's just too expensive. If you are charging more than you can reasonably repay in that same month, you are overspending.Your total monthly debt obligation should not be more than 36% of your gross income. This is known as your debt-to-income ratio.I hope this helps as you determine if debt has a place in your financial life, and if so, how to handle it responsibly so it makes your life better, not worse.Got a question for Mary?You can send it to Dear-Mary@everydaycheapskate.com. Selected questions will be answered in future columns.COPYRIGHT 2023 CREATORS.COM 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on personal debt management, financial guidelines, and economic decision-making, aligning most closely with 'Business/Economy.' While student debt and financial advice touch on 'Education,' the core content is about financial responsibility rather than educational institutions. 'Local Life' is a weaker fit as the article's advice is general rather than region-specific.

title: Breakfast event to connect businesses at Waterfowl Festival
author: Contributed
content:
Breakfast event to connect businesses at Waterfowl Festival

 November 3, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Contributed | Page: 6 | Section: News 
 
 259
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Talbot County Department of Economic Development and Tourism will again team up with the Waterfowl Festival to host Coffee and Conservation, a networking event, to celebrate the opening of the festival's 52nd year.Sponsored by The Arc Central Chesapeake Region, the breakfast event will be held in Art at the Pavilion, a tented venue across from the Waterfowl Building on South Harrison Street from 8:30 to 10 a.m. on Friday, Nov. 10.The event connects the business community with the Waterfowl Festival and celebrates the business of conserving the region's abundant environmental resources.For 52 years, the Waterfowl Festival has been a boon to the local economy, bringing thousands of visitors to Talbot County to local shops, restaurants and hotels.The festival attracts more than 15,000 attendees each year, and it generates an economic impact of $3.5 million. Excluding the cost of festival admissions, research shows that these visitors spend nearly $3 million on various goods and services within Talbot County's economy.The Talbot County Department of Economic Development and Tourism's mission is to enhance and promote a business-friendly environment for current and prospective enterprises and to advocate for policies that support and strengthen the economic vitality of Talbot County.The department's vision for Talbot County is built on the principles of strong communities, empowered businesses, and innovative solutions.Business owners and managers are encouraged to receive the department's Talbot Works newsletter and breaking business news by subscribing at talbotworks.org. The department can also be reached at 410-770-8058 or by visiting their office at 215 Bay Street, Suite 5, Easton.

title: Board of Realtors installs officers, presents awards
author: Mid Shore Board Of Realtors
content:
Board of Realtors installs officers, presents awards

 November 3, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mid Shore Board Of Realtors | Page: 11 | Section: News 
 
 603
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - The Mid-Shore Board of Realtors gave a heart-warming farewell to its outgoing president while recognizing new leadership and the achievements of its members this past year.Megan Rosendale ended her term as president of MSBR at the Oct. 26 ceremony held at Pintail Point in Queenstown, with Shelby Roney taking up the leadership role for 2024.Members who were honored at the event included Rookie Realtor of the Year Janet Powers and Shandell Green, who received the President's award for her contributions to the association.Chuck Mangold, Jr. was presented with the Community Service Award, and Kari Anderson with Oceans Lending was named the affiliate of the year.Both Annie Raymond and Shandell Green were recognized with the Diversity, Equity and Inclusion Award for their roles in overseeing the Understanding Through Diversity Summit.The Realtor of the Year award went to Laura Anderson of Coldwell Banker Realty, a past MSBR president.Anderson also received citations from Sen. Johnny Mautz and Gov. Wes Moore.Chris Hill, president of Maryland Realtors, installed the directors. Debbie Leber, association executive director, installed Shelby Roney as the newly elected Mid-Shore Board of Realtors president.Roney is with Benson and Mangold and has over 20 years of experience in real estate. She noted she feels a deep sense of purpose for the position of president and the real estate industry.Roney said changes, transitions and setbacks are all natural parts of any industry, and real estate is no different.She plans to focus on education and providing the members with quality programs that will enhance their skills to meet future challenges. Community service is also important, and Roney said Mid-Shore Board of Realtors will continue to support programs and causes in Caroline, Dorchester and Talbot counties.Outgoing president Megan Rosendale thanked those who helped her this past year and noted how this role helped her grow both personally and professionally.Rosendale said starting the Down Payment Grant was a highlight of her year. With 13 grants awarded already this year, she said she appreciated everyone who has helped with this program.The Mid-Shore Board of Realtors 2023-2024 executive committee is Shelby Roney, MSBR president with Benson and Mangold; Megan Rosendale, MSBR immediate past president with Rosendale Realty; Michelle Abplanalp, MSBR president-elect with Rosendale Realty; Shandell Green, MSBR secretary with Douglas Realty; and Trey Quinn, MSBR treasurer with Fidelity First Home Mortgage.The Mid-Shore Board of Realtors 2023-2024 directors include: Andy Beaven with Wright Real Estate; Kathleen Brenton with Brenton Realty Group; Jenn Dudley with Title Excellence; Samantha Grimes with Chesapeake Real Estate Associates; Mary Mabry with Keller Williams Select; Petra Quinn with Realty Navigator and Randy Staats with Benson and Mangold.The Mid-Shore Board of Realtors mission is to advocate for its members and the public to preserve the right to own, transfer and utilize real property.For more news and information on the grant program, visit midshoreboardofrealtors.com. 
 
 Caption: MID-SHORE BOARD OF REALTORS
 
The Realtor of the Year award went to Laura Anderson of Coldwell Banker Realty, a past MSBR president. Anderson also received citations from Sen. Johnny Mautz and Gov. Wes Moore.
 
PHOTOS COURTESY OF MID-SHORE BOARD OF REALTORS

title: Project to put homes on long-time vacant property
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Project to put homes on long-time vacant property

 November 3, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 568
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - For years, 807 N. Washington St. was a vacant property. Now, a local investor has plans to build 10 homes on the parcel.Beth Spurry, who works for the investor that has started the Sandy Lane project, said it all started about three years ago."We were looking for an in-town development opportunity to build houses for normal people, so to speak," Spurry said. "It's sort of a passion of my client." The 10 homes will be around 2,000 square feet each. They will all have garages as well as primary bedrooms on the first floor.Spurry said they will be energy-efficient homes."We're really hoping to create an economical, high-quality, custom-built product for that buyer," she said.The houses will be priced somewhere in the $400,000s, Spurry said. However, that number could fluctuate based on raw material costs.Before the project, Spurry said there was a unsalvageable vacant house on the property, as well as a garage that was falling down."I'm 52 years old," she said."I can't remember there ever being a person living in that house." One benefit of this being an infill development project is that it will bring up surrounding property values "because what was there before was a blight and wasn't even safe," she said.This is not the only infill development project in Easton right now. Joseph Mayer, the plan reviewer in the Town of Easton's Planning and Zoning Department, said there are a few smaller lots in town that developers are "trying to make meaningful" for the community.One infill project to build a duplex on North Street will compliment the community, he said."It's not too big," he said."It's on par for what's already out there." Mayer said he is looking forward to seeing the Sandy Lane project when it is complete."They really put a lot of effort into their architecture and how to make use of the land," he said.Spurry said she thinks everyone is excited for the project."It's really positive for the town," she said. "It's housing we need. It's good land use." Spurry added that the developers have "followed all the rules" and listened to the community. She said they have included green space and are protecting a small piece of wetlands at the back of the property.For more than a year, the developers have been doing all of the site work to prepare the land before the homes can be constructed. Now that they have put in a road, Spurry said it is possible to have the first building permit approved."We'll be waiting for that with bated breath for the first house to go in," she said. "Which will be the one that's closest to Washington Street." Spurry said the city has given the developers a "preliminary thumbs up" but couldn't give them a building permit until that blacktop went in."Now that that's done, we shouldn't have any hurdles to that first permit being released," she said.Even though no houses have been built yet, Spurry said they have already had lots of interest from prospective buyers."I think it's the kind of housing stock that is really missing in the town of Easton," she said about the project. 
 
 Caption: MAGGIE TROVA TO/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
A view of the Sandy Lane project from Washington Street in Easton on Nov. 1
 
MAGGIE TROVA TO/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Ten homes, around 2,000 square feet each, are planned to be built off Washington Street in Easton.

title: Hollywood distillery wins awards for bourbon
content:
Hollywood distillery wins awards for bourbon

 November 7, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 4 | Section: News 
 
 269
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Tobacco Barn Distillery of Hollywood in St. Mary's County was recently awarded the Top Farmer-Distiller award, best Maryland whiskey and gold medal for their Single Barrel Bourbon in the 2023 Heartland Whiskey Competition.For the fourth year, the competition was managed by the American Craft Spirits Association, which judged craft whiskeys from across the nation. State corn marketing associations, such as the Maryland Grain Producers Association, sponsored the event which took place in St. Louis, Mo.Tobacco Barn Distillery is a farm to bourbon business located in St. Mary's County providing bourbon and other products at their tasting room and select retail locations throughout Maryland.Three good friends - Dan, Sean, and Scott - started Tobacco Barn Distillery in December of 2015 and offer very limited quantities of their single-barrel bourbon.For the bourbon aficionados, they will soon be releasing a bourbon that is Bottled In Bond.Everything about their products is local. The Distillery grows their own corn and utilizes locally sourced rye.Scott Sanders, director of Bourbon Relationships for Tobacco Barn Distillery, is very proud to represent Maryland and honored to win a national award."This award is an acknowledgement that Craft Distilleries are producing some of the best bourbons and whiskies in America" Sanders said. "We have a lot of new and exciting products growing in popularity, and available in the coming months. Be sure to stop by our small town and check out the Nation's best Farmer-Distiller." Learn more about the distillery online at www.tobaccobarndistillery.com and learn more about the competition online at americancraftspirits.org. 
 
 Caption: TOBACCO BARN DISTILLERY PHOTO
 
The Tobacco Barn Distillery in Hollywood recently won several awards.

title: Trim both your hair, expenses
author: Mary Hunt
content:
Trim both your hair, expenses

 November 13, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mary Hunt | Page: 6 | Section: News 
 
 308
 Words 

 Read News Document

 If you or someone in your family could use a haircut but you're a little short on cash this month, don't let this challenging economy keep you from looking your best.Check out these tips and tricks for saving cash on family haircuts and other salon treatments.BRAVEGo online and search for beauty schools in your area. BeautySchoolsDirectory.com is one option that lists barber and cosmetology schools by state or "near me" for the entire country.If you are lucky enough to have one located nearby, you and your family can save as much as 50% to 75% off the cost of a haircut and other salon services.BRAVERKeep your hairstyle simple. Whether your hair is long or short, make it manageable and low maintenance. This goes for all family members.Cut back on the number of trips you make to the barber or hair salon. Many hairdressers will have you believe that you need a cut every six weeks, but this may be more to keep them in a job than anything else.Another option is to invest in a good pair of haircutting scissors. Trim your bangs yourself and give family trims, too. YouTube is loaded with step-by-step tutorials for how to trim your own bangs and others', too.BRAVESTBuy hair clippers. For approximately $25 or less at a store like Walmart or Amazon, you can eliminate your family's trips to the hair salon altogether. You will save hundreds of dollars a year, plus time and gas money.Choose basic hair styles that are easy to maintain. All clippers come with an instructional video, DVD and/or manual. And don't forget YouTube. You'll find tons of videos for how to give a professional-looking haircut. Follow directions carefully, and remember that practice makes perfect.Mary Hunt is the founder ofEverydayCheapskate.com, a frugal living blog, and the author of the book "Debt-Proof Living. " 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on cost-saving strategies for haircuts and salon services amid economic challenges, directly relating to personal finance and economic decision-making. While 'Local Life' is a secondary fit due to practical tips, the primary emphasis on economic factors aligns most strongly with 'Business/Economy'.

title: Thank You! Tour visits, honors county businesses
content:
Thank You! Tour visits, honors county businesses

 November 15, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 8A | Section: News 
 
 640
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Caroline County Economic Development & Tourism (CCEDT) celebrated businesses throughout the county with a "Thank You! Tour" Oct. 23-27 as part of Economic Development Week in Maryland.The week gives economic development professionals the opportunity to showcase businesses that contribute to their local economy through job retention, innovation, public service and improving the quality of life in local communities.CCEDT staff visited 16 businesses throughout the week in a variety of sectors."The value these businesses bring to our community is far reaching, from specialized care for the adult population and innovative family-run facilities to women-owned businesses and those that nurture the agriculture industry in our county," a press release stated. "There are plenty of reasons to celebrate the businesses that call Caroline County home." The Ridgely Pharmacy, for example, is a community staple that houses an ice cream parlor and cafe where locals meet and greet each other daily."The owner is a great contributor in the community, hosting and participating in numerous community events," the release stated."Choptank Supply takes pride being more than just a typical hardware store, offering many services and rental items. Their incredible service and extensive offerings bring customers from near and far. The Sewing Outlet is another example of a community staple, supplying fabric, upholstery, and decorating services right in the heart of Federalsburg, as is the Tri-Me Warehouse, a full-service grocery store in Ridgely." Other Caroline County businesses visited on the tour were Smokey Cat Lavender Farm, where visitors can pick their own lavender or shop in the artisan gift shop, and Outstanding Dreams Alpaca Farm, specializing in alpaca sales and breeding services.Shoppers can find artisan items crafted from alpaca fiber at their farm store."There are businesses who provide care and compassion, such as Arcadia Living, a premier assisted living facility that sets a new standard for elder care and those with unique needs. The Benedictine School in Ridgely is another example, supporting children and adults with developmental disabilities," according to the release."There are businesses we turn to for life's big moments, such as On Your Mark Lighting, offering specialized lighting for events of all sizes - from fundraisers and weddings to awards programs, and more," the release continued."Awards Engraving in Denton is there for you when you need a beautiful, custom award, trophy, memento or gift."And there are businesses that help other businesses, such as Lorry Industries, a forward-thinking fulfillment provider servicing innovative e-commerce brands and international partners in the design and furniture industries, and Sisk Fulfillment, who has been in business for more than 30 years and offers personalized customer service, and the attention to detail and flexibility of a small company combined with the efficiency, high volume capability and competitiveness of a very large company."Caroline is also home to the companies you count on for large projects, such as Bob Breeding General Contractors, a leader in construction and installation of metal buildings and foundations.There is Masten Pools, who have been performing high quality pool installations since 1982. And there is Lywood Electric, specializing in industrial and commercial instrumentation, automation and controls."Lastly, there are businesses that work tirelessly to keep us informed about the great things taking place in our community, such as the Caroline Review, Caroline County's information magazine since 1980."These companies are just a snapshot of Caroline's incredible businesses, and Caroline County Economic Development and Tourism is honored to be able to recognize all they do for our community and quality of life," the press release concluded.Caroline County Economic Development and Tourism is an office within Caroline County government. Its mission is to help businesses of all sizes thrive in the community. 
 
 Caption: CONNIE CONNOLLY/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
As part of a late October "Thank You Tour," local leaders visit the owner and staff of Ridgely Pharmacy.
 
CONNIE CONNOLLY/STAR DEMOCRAT
 
Ridgely Pharmacy contains a popular lunch counter, and sells gifts, Rise Up coffee and Smith Island cake.

title: Why gift cards are not gifts
author: Mary Hunt
content:
Why gift cards are not gifts

 November 16, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mary Hunt | Page: 15 | Section: News 
 
 362
 Words 

 Read News Document

 What to give for Christmas when you don't have time to shop, don't want to put much thought into it and just need to check someone off your list? A gift card, of course.At this point, I will resist the urge to list all the reasons that gift cards are not really gifts, why they are so problematic for both the giver and the recipient, or ask if you're going to give money, why not just give the money?The truth is, consumers racked up more than $162 billion in gift card sales in 2022. I can't stop the insanity, but I can shed a little light on how these things work and how to avoid the pitfalls.Understand that no gift card is the same as cash. It's not. It's the same as store credit. That's what you are giving as a gift. The store gets to write the rules for how it will handle your recipient and its store credit. And should that store fall into financial trouble, that gift card will become instantly worthless even if it has no expiration date.Unused gift cards represent free money for stores.Consumer Reports has estimated that a quarter of all gift cards go unredeemed for a year after purchase, and about 7% never get used at all. Bankrate reports 47% of U.S. adults have at least one unused gift card. It all adds up to an estimated $8 billion windfall annually for the retail industry.If you have a gift card you just know you aren't going to use, sites like Raise, Gift Card Granny and Card Cash may take it and give you cash back, credit your PayPal account or give you an Amazon gift card a percentage of the original gift card's value.I can no longer resist the urge to ask: If you're going to give money this holiday season, why not just give the money? Your recipient will get every single penny of that $20 bill to spend wherever he or she desires.Chances of that money getting lost or forgotten are slim-to-none, and you won't be feeding that completely out of control retail monster known as the Gift Card Retail Industry.COPYRIGHT 2023 CREATORS.COM 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article analyzes consumer behavior around gift cards, highlighting their economic impact on retailers and the broader retail industry. It discusses financial implications, unused gift card statistics, and the $8 billion annual windfall for retailers, aligning with Business/Economy topics. While it touches on general consumer trends, it lacks specific local or national news angles.

title: Credit cards are 2-faced
author: Mary Hunt
content:
Credit cards are 2-faced

 November 21, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mary Hunt | Page: 6A | Section: News 
 
 304
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Erma Bombeck, the late humorist, summed up family relationships when she spoke of "the ties that bind and gag!" That just makes me laugh because it is such a colorful word picture. Maybe you've thought this from time to time: "Family - can't live with 'em, and can't live without 'em!" The same thing could be said about credit cards in these very strange times in which we live. Many people can't live with them but can't live without them, either.The relationship I have with my credit card is appreciation on the one extreme and hatred on the other. I have an "appreci-hate" relationship with it.Yes, I said hate. It is a strong word.The credit card relationship is a funny thing.When you maintain a $0 balance at the end of every month so that you have no credit card debt, you have a very useful financial tool that you are free to appreciate.Your $0 balance credit card works hard to keep your credit score high. That financial tool makes it possible for you to purchase an airline ticket, rent a car, buy things you need online - all without paying a nickel's worth of interest. You get a 25-day grace period when you keep your balance at $0.You own it. You're the boss of it. It works for you, and you win.But if it's the other way around, and you've racked up revolving debt that rolls from month to month accruing more and more interest, sorry, my friend.That credit card owns you. You are its slave. Yes, another strong word. So be it. That's exactly the relationship.That credit card debt beats you up to keep you down. It is a master of torture, inflicting cruel treatment.Mary Hunt is the founder of EverydayCheapskate.com, a frugal living blog, and the author of the book "Debt-Proof Living." COPYRIGHT 2023 CREATORS.COM 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses credit card usage, financial responsibility, and personal debt management, which relate to economic behavior and financial literacy. While not explicitly about business operations, the themes align most closely with 'Business/Economy' due to focus on financial tools, debt, and consumer economics.

title: Going cardless in 2023
author: Mary Hunt
content:
Going cardless in 2023

 November 22, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mary Hunt | Page: 10A | Section: News 
 
 269
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Dear Cheapskate: I hardly ever carry cash and rarely use credit. I use only a debit card. But still, there are times I feel out of control.How can I get some control over my spending?- Rob K., Nebraska Dear Rob: Merchant research groups have proven it over and again: Customers who shop with plastic spend about 30% more than those paying with cash. I believe that's because credit and debit cards (even checks) are stand-ins for our money. They're not the real thing, but more like "play money." I know for myself that swiping a card or writing a check for, say, a $50 purchase doesn't require the same kind of mental consideration as paying with cash. It's painful to part with cash.I suggest you put yourself on a cash-only diet for the next 30 days. Don't even carry a checkbook or plastic - debit or credit.Except for payments you must send through the mail, force yourself to pay with cash. You bet it's inconvenient, and you must plan ahead for how much cash you'll need for the day. Keep a written record of how you spend every penny, too.While making the switch to cash will be quite an adjustment in the beginning, I predict your mindless spending will disappear.Mary invites you to visit her at EverydayCheapskate.com, where this column is archived complete with links and resources for all recommended products and services. Mary invites questions and comments at https://www.everydaycheapskate.com/contact/, "Ask Mary." This column will answer questions of general interest, but letters cannot be answered individually. Mary Hunt is the founder of Everyday-Cheapskate.com, a frugal living blog, and the author of the book "Debt-Proof Living." COPYR IGHT 2023 CREATORS.COM

While it's a advice column in a local newspaper, the core content about cash vs. card spending relates to economic behavior rather than local community life or other categories.

title: What's on the List? Games and Toys for 2023
author: Amy Pollick; Wealth Of Geeks
content:
What's on the List? Games and Toys for 2023

 November 23, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Amy Pollick; Wealth Of Geeks | Page: 5 | Section: News 
 
 927
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Sears & Roebuck Wish Book may have gone the way of the dodo bird, but children still make Christmas lists with games and toys at the top. According to a Research and Markets study, the worldwide games and toys market is worth $342 billion.The study reports the games and toys market is driven by an emerging middle class in populated areas and the continued growth of legacy brands, among other factors.TOP OF THE WISH LISTSIf kids still want toys, what items are most popular?Statista reports the U.S. toy market is seeing a resurgence in traditional toys, like dolls, board games, puzzles, and construction sets.The Barbie movie topped $1 billion at the box office, so it follows that Mattel's flagship toy is popular this year. Emma Stessman and Bella Druckman with The TODAY Show interviewed Laurie Schacht, Chief Toy Officer at The Toy Insider.She shared that Barbie: The Movie Collectible Doll, Barbie: The Movie Ken Doll, the Barbie Dreamhouse 2023, Barbie Fashionistas Doll, and the remote-control Hot Wheels Barbie Corvette are some of the most popular toys of 2023.Arts and crafts toys are making a comeback, too, according to Schacht. The Make it Real Mini Pottery Studio and Cra-Z-Art The Real Cotton Candy Maker are also a hit with youngsters this year.Other retailers have released their most popular toys for 2023. Kohl's department store list includes the L.O.L. Surprise Magic Flyers and the Melissa & Doug Stack, Sort & Pound Wooden Toy Collection.The list at Macy's includes a revamped Tamagotchi Uni.Sesame Street's Elmo is still popular and appears as the Elmo Slide Plush.Amazon reports the Clue Conspiracy Board Game is a popular choice, while Walmart offers the Nerf Elite Junior Flyer.STEM/STEAM toys are popular, too, including the Educational Insights Geo-Safari Jr. Kidnoculars and the Melissa & Doug Super Smile Dentist Kit.TOYS PARENTS LIKENo matter what toys the kiddos want, mom and dad have the final say on what goes under the tree or in a birthday gift.Monica Fish, founder of Planner At Heart, says, "Despite my kids' 5-year age difference, they both have LEGOs on their holiday wish list. It is a toy that encourages creative, imaginative play, problem solving, and introduces engineering concepts. But they just think it's an exciting gift from their favorite Disney or video game franchises. Even though LEGOs tend to be a high-priced item, it's one that always makes it under the tree." For youngsters whose preferences are a little harder to nail down, parents have to watch what the kids are playing with for a better idea of what to buy.Sarah Gilliand is a travel editor and mom of three kids who owns the On The Road With Sarah travel blog.She's on board with being an observant parent where holiday gifts are concerned."The 4-year-old always wants everything he sees: in stores, on TV, you name it," she says. "We usually can't ask him what he wants because it's always a huge list, but we know what he plays with the most. He loves building things, and he recently received a marble run set for his birthday, so we will probably get him more attachments for that. He also loves LEGO blocks and magnetic tiles for building." "Pretend play has also ramped up for him," she continues, "and he enjoys being a chef or a doctor, so we will mostly likely add to his accessories for those costumes. Dinosaurs and MatchBox cars are also always welcome. We love the brands Melissa & Doug, VTech, and LEGO." Sometimes, gifts for youngsters are an easy pick.Gilliland explains, "My tweens want gift cards, money, or accessories for their phones." Parents also have opinions on gifts they're not sure about.JayDee Vykoukal, owner of Mom Blog Life, expressed her concerns. "My 5-yearold has two consistent requests this year so far. A tablet, because her other friends have one, and a Llama squishmallow. The squishmallow is an easy win," she explains, "but I'm hesitant to get my child an electronic [device] at such a young age. I've been looking into kid-friendly tablets with educational apps, parental control, and time limits.We'll see as it gets closer to Christmas."WHAT THE EXPERTS LIKEChild development experts have their own thoughts about toys and games for children.The editors at New York Magazine's The Strategist spoke with Dr. Roberta Golinkoff, a professor of child psychology at the University of Delaware. She said, "The best toys allow growing kids to engage in imaginative play, practice communication, and develop fine motor skills." Experts on the Early Learning Centre website recommend toys that stimulate children's touch and motor skills, particularly for toddlers. Older children like toys that allow them to practice their communication skills, like toy phones that also encourage their auditory skills.Kids love physical activity toys, too, and child development experts recommend them to encourage children to move and exercise. Bubble machines and mini ball pits are popular toys to help get kids moving.Experts also recommend kids use crayons, finger paints, modeling clay, and other art supplies to express their creativity and to develop fine motor skills and color recognition.This article was produced by Media Decision and syndicated by Wealth of Geeks.

Dog-E, by Mastermind Toys, whose lighted wagging tail shows hearts, is displayed at the 2023 Toy Fair, in New York's Javits Center, Monday, Oct. 2, 2023.

title: Shop Local - Merchants Aim To Bring Great Experiences To Customers This Saturday And Every Day
author: Maggie Trovato; Mtrovato@Chespub. Com
content:
Shop Local - Merchants Aim To Bring Great Experiences To Customers This Saturday And Every Day

 November 24, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato; Mtrovato@Chespub. Com | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 1078
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - For some, shopping is all about the experience of walking into a store to sniff a candle, touch the sleeve of a soft, cashmere sweater or even sample an infused cocktail.On Small Business Saturday - and everyday - local businesses in Easton are making sure that each of their customers has the particular experience that makes getting out of the house to go shopping, rather than doing it from the convenience of your couch, worth it.Mark Greene, owner of the clothing store Sailor in Downtown Easton, describes why it's so great to shop local with a simple phrase: "It always fits better in a small box.""In other words, we're not a big box store," he said. "So there's always better product and better stuff and more one-on-one in a small box (store)."Not only do you get that one-on-one time with a store owner or employee, but you get the opportunity to do business with those that keep money in the community, Greene said.Joan Hoge-North owns The Mercantile, a boutique next door to Sailor that has been open for about 18 months.Hoge-North said she gives what she can when she is approached by different organizations for things like silent auctions.One thing she's been doing since she opened is putting a quarter aside every time someone declines a shopping bag for the items they have purchased."For every bag not used, I donate a quarter to conservation on the Shore," she said. "Last year it was the equivalent of about 560 bags, and I made a gift to Eastern Shore Land Conservancy."This year, Hoge-North said they are up to more than 600 bags not used.Those 600 plus quarters will be donated to ShoreRivers, she said.Saturday, Nov. 25, the Saturday after Black Friday, is Small Business Saturday - a day to celebrate and support small businesses during the busiest shopping season of the year.Small Business Saturday was founded by American Express in 2010 and has been officially cosponsored by the U.S. Small Business Administration since 2011. Reported projected spending among U.S. consumers who shopped at independent retailers and restaurants on Small Business Saturday reached an estimated $17.9 billion, according to the 2022 Small Business Saturday Consumer Insights Survey commissioned by American Express.Deena Kilmon, director of strategic initiatives at Easton Economic Development, said small shop owners are "the heartbeat of Easton.""They create its personality, they open their doors to our visitors and locals with a smile, they support our non-profits with their many donations and they are crucial players in all of the amazing events we have downtown that are free to the community," she said.Darcy Bernot, the owner of Lizzy Dee, which is also located in downtown Easton, said that buying local is worthwhile because the gifts are often more thoughtful and unique."We mostly buy from what are called made-to-order companies," Bernot said."That means that they only make what I and other store owners order. So you're not going to see these things coast to coast, all over the place."Kilmon said that three-quarters of every dollar spent locally stays in the local economy."Those dollars are crucial to maintaining a healthy downtown," she said.Until opening The Mercantile, Hoge-North spent her career in the nonprofit sector."This is something completely different," she said."But the nonprofit - giving back - is just a part of who I am, who the store is."Supporting other small makers, women-owned businesses and socially-and environmentally-conscious brands is something Hoge-North makes an effort to do in her store."A lot of things in here have a story that comes with them," she said. "People like giving that too, and knowing that through their purchase, they're giving back and helping someone else."Some of the best holiday gifts in The Mercantile, Hoge-North said, are dish towels that show off local pride and cocktail infusers - tall, glass jars of dried items like orange slices and rosemary that you can add the liquor of your choice to."Like, this one says tequila is best," Hoge-North says, pointing to a jar. "You let it sit for three days, you strain it out, you make an awesome margarita."This weekend, The Mercantile will be offering samples of the three different infusers in the shop.Along with the opportunity to take a sip of a cocktail (or three), Hoge-North said The Mercantile will be offering a few sales beginning Friday and ending Sunday. There will be discounts on all jackets and tops, a buy-oneget-one-half-off deal on jeans and select boots will be on sale.Starting next Tuesday, The Mercantile will be open seven days a week for the holiday season."To make it easier for everybody," Hoge-North said.Sailor has also extended its hours for the holiday season.Greene said it will be open from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. on Monday through Saturday and from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m. on Sundays.For those looking to gift their loved ones with name brand items like like Patagonia, Vineyard Vines and Lilly Pulitzer, Sailor is the place to go.Open from 10:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. on Saturday, Lizzy Dee will have gift guides posted around the boutique.The guides will have different groupings of merchandise on them based on personality and style to make gift giving a piece of cake this year.Hoge-North said shopping downtown keeps Easton thriving."It's one of the reasons people love living on the Shore is that we have a really vibrant downtown," she said. "People shop for an experience. They come downtown to hear the stories, to see the different things, to be a part of all that's going on, and there's a lot going on this weekend."Those interested in learning more about Small Business Saturday and the different merchants in Easton can visit DiscoverEaston.com.

title: The Narrows celebrates 40th anniversary
content:
The Narrows celebrates 40th anniversary

 December 1, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 9 | Section: News 
 
 402
 Words 

 Read News Document

 KENT NARROWS - Owners of The Narrows Restaurant, known for their elegant waterfront dining, the Hardesty family held a party at the end of October for longtime friends and patrons of the restaurant, celebrating their 40th year in business.Bo and Brenda Hardesty opened the restaurant the day after Thanksgiving in November 1983.Since then, they have experienced great success, according to Brenda, "due to the great support of our local community.""We've had some great chefs over the years," she added, "and I can't say enough about our wait staff. We like to take care of our staff because they are so good."Almost since the restaurant opened, Veteran's Day has been recognized by providing a free meal once a year to veterans, in thanks for their service to the nation. Honoring veterans began at The Narrows Restaurant as Bo wanted to honor the memory of his youngest brother, Michael Hardesty, who gave his life serving in the U.S. Army during the Vietnam War.The Hardestys are also loyal supporters of the local fire departments and have always been leaders in protecting public health."When our restaurant first opened, we didn't have cigarette vending machines, and we were the first restaurant to have a 'smoke free' dining area," Brenda said. "That was before it became law, as smoking has not been permitted in any restaurants for many years now."Bo and Brenda's daughters, Kelly and Kate, now manage the restaurant. Bo comes in frequently, but the daughters are in charge, they quipped.The Narrows Restaurant has become well known for overnight mailing of different dishes of their foods all over the nation."During the pandemic, those overnight orders for our crab cakes and crab soups helped us stay open," shared Brenda."[And] you should see all the boxes that go out of here in December! People wanting to overnight mail their family and friends foods they love."The restaurant is open daily at 11 a.m. and closes most evenings at 9 p.m., except Friday and Saturdays when it stays open a little longer. You can view their menu online at thenarrowsrestaurant.com. 
 
 Caption: Outside The Narrows Restaurant in Grasonville, members of the Hardesty family celebrate the 40th anniversary of the restaurant.
 
From left, restaurant founders Bo and Brenda Hardesty, with daughters Kelly Hardesty Phipps and Kate Hardesty Pizzo who manage the restaurant now. The restaurant continues to be family owned, well known for its elegant waterfront dining.

title: Tasty Toucan shines as national Paleta Champion
content:
Tasty Toucan shines as national Paleta Champion

 December 1, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 8 | Section: News 
 
 427
 Words 

 Read News Document

 STEVENSVILLE - Kent Island's Tasty Toucan emerged victorious at the North American Ice Cream Association 2023 Paleta Competition at their annual convention in Las Vegas.The North American Ice Cream Association, a dedicated trade organization committed to advancing the frozen dessert industry, annually recognizes outstanding contributions and innovation. Tasty Toucan seized the title of Paleta Champion, solidifying their place as an example of excellence in the frozen dessert industry.For those unfamiliar with the term, a Paleta is a Mexican-origin frozen treat, similar to a popsicle, that has gained popularity in the United States. Unlike traditional popsicles, paletas are crafted from fresh fruits, chocolate, or cream. The distinguishing factor lies in their use of natural ingredients and creative flavor combinations, offering a more authentic and artisanal experience.The six artisan Paleta competitors had two hours to make their best strawberry and chocolate popsicle/Paleta. Nikki Neboshynsky, owner and chief tasty officer of Tasty Toucan, Stevensville whirred and stirred her best recipes before the judges. Her final submissions were Summer Tango and 'Tis the Season.The judges analyzed every pop/paleta for taste, uniqueness, presentation and appeal to the market.The Summer Tango is a delightful blend of whole strawberries, fresh-squeezed lemon juice, twisted with layers of mango, dipped in Tajin. On the other hand, the 'Tis the Season features chocolate fudge infused with natural peppermint extract and adorned with shimmering candy cane pieces.Neboshynky's entries are a true standout, earning unanimous praise from the judges for its unique flavor profile, exceptional texture, and eye-catching presentation."We are thrilled to recognize Tasty Toucan and Nikki Neboshynsky as the Paleta Champion of 2023," stated Evan Waldt, Board member of NAICA. "Their Paleta not only demonstrated exceptional craftsmanship but also highlighted the innovative spirit that drives our industry. It's an honor to celebrate their talents and dedication to the craft."Neboshynsky shared her excitement about the win, saying, "Tasty Toucan's goal has always been to deliver sweet frozen treats with incredible flavor from natural ingredients, this competition was the perfect platform to showcase that.We are incredibly proud to have received this recognition and are excited to continue our journey of creating unique and delicious popsicles."To savor these award-winning paletas, head to Tasty Toucan at 400 Love Point Road in Stevensville.Additionally, you can find them at various concerts, festivals, and catering events. Don't miss the chance to indulge in the authentic and bold flavors that set Tasty Toucan's paletas apart. 
 
 Caption: Nikki Neboshynsky, owner of Stevensville's Tasty Toucan, prepares her winning treats for the judges of the North American Ice Cream Association's competition in Las Vegas. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Nominations opened for Talbot County's Community Impact Awards
content:
Nominations opened for Talbot County's Community Impact Awards

 December 7, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 6 | Section: News 
 
 382
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Talbot County Department of Economic Development and Tourism and the Economic Development Commission are now accepting online nominations for the 2023 Community Impact Awards.These awards are presented each year to recognize outstanding businesses, nonprofits, community projects and individuals who have made a significant impact in Talbot County. Winners will be announced at the annual Talbot County Business Appreciation Summit to be held on Thursday, May 2, at a.m. at the Tidewater Inn in Easton.The Summit is hosted each year by the Talbot County Department of Economic Development and Tourism in partnership with the Talbot County Economic Development Commission."Your nominations help us recognize those who are doing extraordinary things to make Talbot County a prosperous, forward-thinking place to live and work," said Cassandra Vanhooser, director of economic development and tourism for Talbot County. "Our businesses and the people who make them work are award-worthy, and we're grateful to recognize so many of them through this event and in the nomination process."Last year's winners included Channel Marker Inc. Residential Crisis Services, Chesapeake Landing Seafood Restaurant, Choptank Community Health System, Ferry Cove Oyster Hatchery, and McDaniel resident and volunteer Bill Shrieves."This is an exciting event for the business community," says Vanhooser. "We want to recognize the businesses and individuals in Talbot County who have made a significant impact on the community in 2023.I'm looking forward to seeing the impressive list of winners from this year's event."Nominations for the 2023 awards are being accepted until Monday, Jan. 15. The form can be found online at TalbotWorks.org.The Talbot County Department of Economic Development and Tourism's mission is to enhance and promote a business-friendly environment for current and prospective enterprises and to advocate for policies that support and strengthen the economic vitality of Talbot County. The department's vision for Talbot County is built on the principles of strong communities, empowered businesses and innovative solutions. 
 
 Caption: Last year's Talbot County Community Impact Award winners, from left: Chesapeake Landing Restaurant and Bay Hundred Seafood owner Joe Spurry Jr., Choptank Community Health System CEO Sara Rich, McDaniel resident and community volunteer Bill Shrieves, Ferry Cove Shellfish President Stephan Abel, Chesapeake Landing Restaurant owner Erin Spurry and Channel Marker Inc. CEO Cathy Cassell with Talbot County Department of Economic Development and Tourism Director Cassandra Vanhooser

title: Economic Humbug - One-Third Of Americans Are Skipping Christmas Gifts Thanks To Inflation
author: Jon Dulin; Wealth Of Geeks Undefined
content:
Economic Humbug - One-Third Of Americans Are Skipping Christmas Gifts Thanks To Inflation

 December 11, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jon Dulin; Wealth Of Geeks Undefined | Page: 1 | Section: News 
 
 888
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Inflation seems to have found its way into Santa's workshop - and the elves aren't happy. A recent survey found that more than one in three Americans are skipping gift-giving this year thanks to inflation, while 50% say Santa will be less generous than in previous years.Even though it appears that consumers are handling a slowing economy, some cracks are forming. Credit card debt is rising.
Almost half of Americans say they won't pay off their holiday purchases by the due date.
Additionally, over half of people surveyed report feelings of anxiety.
Luckily, there are steps one can take to limit the damage to their finances and the stress they experience during this time of year.
A SNAPSHOT OF CHRISTMAS 2023 According to a Wallethub study, Christmas 2023 will see a thriftier Santa. Over one in three Americans say they will not give gifts due to inflation, and 28% say they plan to spend less on holiday shopping. Almost half say that inflation has affected their charitable giving.
Forty-eight percent of Americans said they planned to start their holiday shopping earlier in hopes of smaller monthly bills as opposed to one large one. It could also help them take advantage of earlier sales many retailers offer to get consumers in the door.
Dana M. Peterson, chief economist at The Conference Board, says, "October's Consumer Confidence Index suggests Americans are entering the holiday season in a somewhat cautious mood, with the overall, present situation, and expectations indexes all seeing dips." She continues, "The softening in confidence may have affected overall holiday spending plans.
Planned spending on non-gift items fell materially this year." CHRISTMAS PRESENT VS CHRISTMAS PAST Christmas spending has fluctuated in recent years. The overall amount people planned to spend on holiday gifts plummeted during the pandemic, from $942 in 2019 to $805 in 2020. Last year, people spent an average of $932.
The $923 estimated spending this year is a slight decrease from last year. But with conflicting consumer data, retailers are stuck. Still reeling from excess inventory after the pandemic and its negative impact on their bottom lines, they're nervous about stocking up because of softer consumer demand. As the season progresses, this could lead to many out-of-stock items or even fewer discounts if demand is higher than forecasts.
DEBT IN THE NAME OF CHRISTMAS CHEER Instead of cash stuffing throughout the year in preparation for the upcoming holiday season, many people rely on credit for Christmas shopping.
While budgeting is not a magic bullet, it can help an individual maintain perspective and plan more efficiently for increased spending at the end of the year.
Sadly, credit card debt is almost synonymous with the holidays.
People start racking up debt around October and continue through mid-to-late December.
Then, they spend at least a portion of the following year paying off that debt.
This year, though, consumer credit behavior is a little more telling, hinting at a financial struggle amid growing inflation in a sinking economy. Almost one out of five Americans plan to apply for a new credit card to help with their holiday expenses.
Nearly one in four Americans say they are still paying off last holiday season's credit card debt, and roughly half say they won't pay off their purchases in full by the due date.
STRESS AND THE HOLIDAYS: IT'S NOTHING NEW Stress is also synonymous with the holiday season, and spas offer special packages ingeniously targeted at those who may feel the pressure of the holidays.
Physician referral site Sesame polled 500 respondents about their mental health and stress levels as they approach the holidays. Two-thirds said they were experiencing moderate to extreme holiday stress levels, including increases in: · Anxiety (52%) · Depression (41%) · Financial stress (66%).
Some of the most stressful parts of the holiday shopping season include: · Coming up with gift ideas (35%) · Holiday weight gain (33%) · Crowds (28%) · Finding the best deals (20%) · Cost of gifts (17%).
Only about 34% of Americans polled said that they would consider seeking counseling to help them deal with the stress. About 14% said that they are interested in seeking professional help from a mental health counselor but feel that they are not able to afford it now.
CHRISTMAS SURVIVAL TIPS FOR LESS FINANCIAL STRESS The good news is there are solutions to lessen or avoid much of the stress surrounding the holidays.
The simplest for most is to plan ahead by knowing how much money can go towards gifts. Then, keep a list of receipts to avoid overspending.
Some people should pick up a side hustle if money is tight, like becoming a rideshare driver or helping others wrap gifts. There are many ways to double your money so that the cost of gifts is not as stressful.
Many people (35%) feel stressed about coming up with gift ideas. To limit this stress, contact the person and ask what they need. Alternatively, ask their friends or family for ideas.
Finally, it's critical to take some personal time to limit stress and enjoy the true meaning of the holiday season. By being proactive and intentional this year, it's possible to make this season the most enjoyable one yet.
This article was produced by Media Decision and syndicated by Wealth of Geeks. 
 
 Caption: ASSOCIATED PRESS

 A man dressed as Santa Claus waves as a train arrives carrying passengers for a Christmas tree lighting ceremony and parade Saturday, Nov. 25, 2023, in Plains, Ga.

title: Realty Navigator Celebrates Grand Re-Opening Of Kent Island Offices
author: Eric Sylvia; Special To The Star Democrat
content:
Realty Navigator Celebrates Grand Re-Opening Of Kent Island Offices

 December 15, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Eric Sylvia; Special To The Star Democrat | Page: 15 | Section: News 
 
 414
 Words

 CHESTER - On a cool, but festive December afternoon, the team at Realty Navigator in Chester, invited family, friends and business colleagues to come and celebrate the grand re-opening of their offices at 110 South Piney Road, Suite 110. Members of the Queen Anne's County Chamber of Commerce, Mid-Shore Board of Realtors and Queen Anne's County Commissioners were on hand to join the celebration.Realty Navigator is comprised of a group of hand-selected realtors who have been very successful in both listing and selling homes, land, and light commercial properties, and conducting rental transactions and property management.
They have worked with buyers and sellers to achieve their personal and investment needs for both short-and long-term goals. Individually they have all worked with developers and builders, business owners, and charitable groups and have created a broad database of clients and business associates that help to sell or acquire what their clients request, by direct word-of-mouth referral.
With the corporate drive of demanding high agent counts within larger franchises, which isn't necessarily reflective of a quality sales team, Realty Navigator focuses more on relationship building and disseminating information through their database, digital and print marketing and internet/social media to meet or exceed their client's individual needs.
Realty Navigator has 60+ years of combined sales experience within their select group of realtors.
This affords Realty Navigator the opportunity to provide topshelf Real Estate Services while catering to their client's unique needs. Their preferred service area expands from Annapolis and Anne Arundel County to Prince George's, Charles, Calvert, and St. Mary's County in the south, in the West and North we cover Montgomery, Frederick, and Howard counties, and East.
Realty Navigator has experts in Chester in Queen Anne's, Caroline, Talbot, Kent, and Dorchester Counties, and a broad network of strong referral partners across the entire state of Maryland, the country and even Europe.
If you decide not to renew your current listing agreement, if you are ready to put your house up for sale for the first time, move up, or size it down a notch, let Realty Navigator conduct a market analysis and marketing plan organized to meet your goals, or, if you are ready to buy your first, second, vacation home or investment property Realty Navigator has an agent for you.

title: Double payments to slash mortgage principal - how does that work?
content:
Double payments to slash mortgage principal - how does that work?

 December 22, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 13 | Section: News 
 
 149
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Dear Cheapskate: Would you please explain how making double mortgage payments works to reduce the principal? - Stephanie Dear Stephanie: Sure!Let's say you have these loan terms: $150,000 principal at 6% interest for 15 years.
Your monthly payments are $1,265.78.
You are about to make your first monthly payment.
If you asked for an amortization schedule, you know that payment will be allocated $750 to interest, and $515.78 to the principal.
After you make your first double payment, your new principal balance is $149,484.21, because the entire $1,265.78 of your second payment went toward reducing the principal balance or for "principal prepayment." Typically, the terms of a home mortgage allow you to make any amount of additional principal payment during the month once you have paid the payment and interest due. It doesn't have to be a full payment. (Don't assume anything, though.
Check the terms of your mortgage.)
