title: Tinned Fish Market on the Rise as 'Affordable Luxury'
author: Cara Campbell; Wealth Of Geeks
content:
Tinned Fish Market on the Rise as 'Affordable Luxury'

 January 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Cara Campbell; Wealth Of Geeks | Page: 7A | Section: News 
 
 802
 Words 

 Read News Document

 According to a report by Persistence Market Research, the tinned fish market in the United States is predicted to reach $17.2 billion by the end of 2033.That's a jump from $9.5 billion in 2022.
Part of the demand is driven by consumers becoming more health-conscious.
Tinned fish contains omega-3 fatty acids, which are known to help with heart and brain health, and they help protect against the negative impacts of mercury, which some other fresh fish are known for.
Health coach Karen Kelly from Seasonal Cravings says tinned fish is excellent for several reasons. "I often recommend canned fish to my clients who need more nutrient-dense foods in their diet and are looking for convenience.
It is readily available, easy to prepare, and affordable," she says. "It tastes great in grain bowls, with leftover roasted vegetables and a drizzle of your favorite salad dressing." WHAT IS TINNED FISH?
Tinned fish, or canned fish, are fish that have been processed, sealed, and sterilized.
Some popular examples include tuna, sardines, salmon mackerel, anchovies, and herring. And while many are probably familiar with a classic tuna sandwich, tinned fish has gone way beyond that, finding its way onto everything from charcuterie boards to upscale restaurant menus.
TIKTOK REVIVAL
Part of the recent increase in sales is attributed to the "rediscovery" of tinned fish on social media. Anna Hezel is an Epicurious senior editor and the author of Tin to Table: Fancy, Snacky Recipes for Tin-thusiasts and A-fish-ionados. She says, "Getting into tinned fish is a little intimidating if you've never bought a particular product, and you have no idea what it's going to look like when the lid is peeled back.
TikTok has really helped demystify this category of seafood for so many people and celebrated the social and visual aspects of collecting and eating tinned fish." The hashtag #tinnedfish has 116.4 million views on TikTok as of this writing, and it's also cultivated a community called #tinnedfishtok, which has nearly 68 million views.
ORIGINS
Although a younger North American audience may be discovering tinned fish for the first time, it's a food with a long history. It originated in the 1700s in France, when preserved foods were in great demand. Their long shelf life and accessibility were precious for the French military.
Hezel says COVID-19 played a part in opening up American markets to the industry more recently. "I think there was a big cultural shift during the onset of COVID-19 when people started seeking out shelf-stable foods way more and also started to do their grocery shopping online a lot more," she says. "This coincided with the launch of a bunch of new tinned fish brands with availability in the U.S., and from there, the trend hasn't really slowed down." AFFORDABLE LUXURY
The booming trend on TikTok is revamping the image of tinned fish for many young people. Either they didn't know what to do with it or were scared by it.
Now, says Hezel, canned fish has become an approachable form of luxury, mainly at a significant cost reduction from fresh seafood, like ahi tuna.
"I think of certain hobbies, like collecting wines, which require hundreds of dollars just to get started," says Hezel. "By comparison, you can buy a really beautifully crafted, hand-packed tin of sardines in amazing olive oil from Portugal for $6." Much like appreciating the craftsmanship that goes into a chef-made lobster ravioli dish or a perfectly selected bottle of wine, "you get to taste all of this skill and tradition that's gone into preparing the fish without buying a plane ticket or paying for a restaurant meal," says Hezel.
HOW TO USE TINNED FISH AT HOME
Tinned fish is a versatile ingredient. A quick search online will reveal a wide array of pasta, salads, charcuterie boards, toasts, and more creative ways for tinned fish lovers to consume this product.
Lavender & Macarons food blogger Iryna Bychkiv says she eats tinned sardines at least once a week. "They make an excellent 'emergency' food when you're too tired or busy to cook a complicated meal," she says.
On the flip side, if she has time, she'll make a sardine salad with boiled potatoes, eggs, chopped cucumber, and green onion. "It's very filling and satisfying, plus sardines are packed with proteinso it's a win-win." Hezel loves to make tinned fish the star of the show when she's having a fancy dinner or a date night.
"I love to make a big, elaborate salad, buy a nice loaf of sourdough, and open two or three tins to try," she says.
HERE TO STAY
With the market set to grow over the next 10 years, the popularity, availability and choice for tinned fish isn't going anywhere.
It's affordable, nutritious, convenient, and versatile.
It may appear on pantry shelves, restaurant menus, and date nights for years.
This article was produced by the Gourmet Bon Vivant and syndicated by Wealth of Geeks. 
 
 Caption: WEALTH OF GEEKS

 BURKHARD MÜCKE/WIKIMEDIA COMMONS

 Anchovy Pizza

title: Comptroller highlights changes during tour of Queen Anne's County
author: DOUG BISHOP dbishop@chespub.com
content:
Comptroller highlights changes during tour of Queen Anne's County

 January 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DOUG BISHOP dbishop@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 607
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Maryland Comptroller Brooke Lierman visited four establishments in Queen Anne's County on Dec. 20: the newly opened YMCA in Centreville, Everside Health Center also in Centreville, and two local businesses on Kent Island, both located in the Chesapeake Bay Business Park — Italberco, a growing sweet-tooth business working with the food industry providing dessert ingredients and Queen Anne's County's largest employer, Paul Reed Smith Guitars.Her visit began at the YMCA, where she met with YMCA Mid-Shore Region Executive Director Robbie Gill; two Queen Anne's County commissioners, Chris Corchiarino and Jack Wilson; Queen Anne's County Administrator Todd Mohn; county Economic Development and Tourism Director Heather Tinelli; and Queen Anne's Community Services Director Cathy Willis. The meeting was "a working lunch" served at the Y.
During the lunch, Lierman spoke about the changes made within the comptroller's office in the past year. Several new positions have been created, including a chief information officer. She said that the Comptroller's Office is striving for "more transparency."
Beginning in February, for the first time ever, businesses will be able to pay their taxes online.
"We are also preparing, in the Comptroller's Office, a designed plan for future prosperity for the state," Lierman said, "not a plan for just the next four years, but far beyond that."
Lierman has been visiting each of Maryland's 23 counties over the past year, sharing a similar message.
She expressed concern in an interview with the Bay Times and Record Observer that the state deficit is mounting, beginning with the 2024 state budget. Former Maryland Gov. Larry Hogan left the state with a surplus. However, that surplus has since disappeared.
Before the Hogan administration left office, the General Assembly passed massive legislation for new state funding for public schools, which will kick-in in 2024.
She said, "The governor and I will need to speak about what we're going to do. It will be either to cut state services, or find new sources of revenue."
She didn't mention anything about raising taxes when mentioning "new sources of revenue."
Wilson spoke about efforts in Queen Anne's County to help restore the Chesapeake Bay and suggested Lierman come back to go out with some watermen to witness oyster seeding that is helping cleanse the bay waters. He also spoke about concerns with local farmers on the issue of solar panels being erected near preservation farmlands within the county.
Wilson praised the newly established Everside Health program, which is now covering all county government and public school employees. Queen Anne's is the first county in Maryland to become part of the Everside Health benefits. It was mentioned that Everside is about to cover six other Maryland counties.
Wilson spoke about the Queen Anne's Chamber of Commerce looking into Everside covering local small businesses within the county to help with health care benefits for their employees.
Corchiarino spoke briefly about the issues concerning the Chesapeake Bay Bridge. He said, "The effects of bridge traffic are crippling to Queen Anne's County."
Lierman said, "As of Jan. 3, there will be a published 'State of the Economy' report presented to the public, providing residents with both good and bad outlooks for the state going forward."
She mentioned that there are 12 comptroller offices within the state. The Eastern Shore office is located in Salisbury. The closest office to Queen Anne's County is in Annapolis.
Lierman was elected the state's first female comptroller in November 2022. She was a state delegate previously for eight years, representing part of Baltimore City. She is the mother of two children, a boy, 11, and girl, 6. Lierman grew-up in Montgomery County.
After the meeting at the Y, Lierman visited and toured the other three facilities, gathering information about their business successes. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Gas prices fall almost 3 cents in week
author: Staff Writer
content:
Gas prices fall almost 3 cents in week

 January 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Local News 
 
 435
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Average gasoline prices in Maryland have fallen 2.9 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.05 per gallon Monday, according to GasBuddy's survey of 2,167 stations in Maryland. Prices in Maryland are 4.8 cents per gallon lower than a month ago and stand 22.6 cents per gallon lower than a year ago.The national average price of diesel has fallen 2.0 cents in the last week and stands at $3.89 per gallon.
According to GasBuddy price reports, the cheapest station in Maryland was priced at $2.74 per gallon yesterday while the most expensive was $4.79 per gallon, a difference of $2.05.
The national average price of gasoline has risen 0.6 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.04 per gallon Monday. The national average is down 1.4 cents per gallon from a month ago and stands 23.9 cents per gallon lower than a year ago, according to GasBuddy data compiled from more than 11 million weekly price reports covering over 150,000 gas stations across the country.
Historical gasoline prices in Maryland and the national average going back 10 years:
January 15, 2023: $3.28/g (U.S. Average: $3.28 per gallon).
January 15, 2022: $3.25/g (U.S. Average: $3.30 per gallon).
January 15, 2021: $2.46/g (U.S. Average: $2.39 per gallon).
January 15, 2020: $2.51/g (U.S. Average: $2.56 per gallon).
January 15, 2019: $2.24/g (U.S. Average: $2.24 per gallon).
January 15, 2018: $2.55/g (U.S. Average: $2.53 per gallon).
January 15, 2017: $2.37/g (U.S. Average: $2.34 per gallon).
January 15, 2016: $1.92/g (U.S. Average: $1.92 per gallon).
January 15, 2015: $2.24/g (U.S. Average: $2.07 per gallon).
January 15, 2014: $3.40/g (U.S. Average: $3.30 per gallon).
Neighboring areas and their current gas prices:
Baltimore: $3.01/g, down 3.0 cents per gallon from last week's $3.04 per gallon.
Washington D.C.: $3.13 per gallon, down 3.6 cents per gallon from last week's $3.16 per gallon.
Hagerstown: $3.06 per gallon, down 3.2 cents per gallon from last week's $3.09 per gallon.
"Last week was a bit of a mixed bag for gasoline prices, with prices increasing early on but falling again in recent days as the situation in the Red Sea continues to drive market volatility," said Patrick De Haan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy. "While last week saw the U.S. attacking Houthi militants engaged in attacks on vessels in the Red Sea, oil prices jumped, but then promptly fell as economic concerns with weak demand sapped the upward move after the U.S. and allies attacked Houthi rebels. Gasoline inventories also saw another large rise, putting some downward pressure on gas prices, and leaving an opportunity for the national average to potentially briefly fall below $3 per gallon. We'll have to see if the stars finally align for such a move." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: 2023 year-end housing statistics for the Eastern Shore
author: MID-SHORE BOARD OF REALTORS
content:
2023 year-end housing statistics for the Eastern Shore

 January 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MID-SHORE BOARD OF REALTORS | Section: Real Estate 
 
 715
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Home sellers were happy in 2023, as the median and average home prices increased across our five-county Mid-Shore region.The flip side is that many homebuyers continue to be priced out of the market, said Shelby Roney, Mid-Shore Board of Realtors president.
But that may change in 2024, as the federal reserve has indicated they may lower interest rates.
For the five counties of Caroline, Dorchester, Kent, Queen Anne's and Talbot, 2,466 homes were sold in 2023, and these homes sold in 44 days or less.
The average sold price went up in four of the five counties, and those homes sold within 95% of their original list price. This is all good news, Roney noted.
A positive indicator for sellers is the list price compared to the sold price. This means that homes are selling for 95% or better than the asking price on average, which is great news for those looking to maximize their profits.
Combine that with the average days on market still being a little over a month, and it shows pricing your property competitively from the start leads to a quick and rewarding home selling experience.
For our five counties 2023 home prices averaged:
Caroline County's average home price was $314,874, a 7.13% increase compared to 2022.Dorchester County's average home price was $304,646, a 2.07% increase compared to 2022.Kent County average home price for 2023 was $402,413, down 1.82% compared to 2022.Queen Anne's County average home price in 2023 was $561,349, a 1.86% increase from 2022.Talbot County's 2023 average home price was $789,471, a 13.77% increase compared to 2022.
Continuing with the low inventory of recent years and adding in the rising interest rates, it is no surprise that the overall number of homes sold in all the five counties declined in 2023.
The 2,466 homes sold in 2023 represented a decrease of 8.6% from the year prior.
In Caroline County, 308 homes sold in 2023, 117 fewer than in to 2022.
Dorchester County had 539 homes sold in 2023, 56 fewer than in 2022.
Kent County sold 308 homes, 10 fewer than in 2022.
Queen Anne's County had 805 homes sold in 2023, 70 fewer than in 2022.
In Talbot County, 506 homes were sold in 2023,140 fewer than in 2022.
There is only a week difference in the number of days it took to sell a home in 2023 compared to 2022.
Homes in 2023 in Caroline County sold on average in 51 days, only seven days longer than in 2022.
Dorchester County homes took eight days longer to sell, or 51 days, compared to 2022.
Kent County took 41 days on average to sell, four days longer than in 2022.
Queen Anne's County homes sold in 35 days, six days longer than in 2022.
Talbot County homes sold on average in 41 days, one day less than in 2022.
The year-end statistics continue to show a strong demand for homes on the Eastern Shore, said Roney.
The trend continues with families moving from Baltimore County and Washington, where the home prices are higher, to the rural sections of the state such as the Eastern Shore, southern Maryland and western Maryland, where the home prices and property taxes are generally lower.
A small ray of hope for both buyers and sellers was at the end of 2023, where the falling mortgage rates helped more buyers purchase homes in December. But they still face the same issues that we have seen for the past years, the severe lack of homes, Roney said.
Looking forward, reduced interest rates will allow for more buyers to enter the market, but it will also create a more competitive environment as home buyers compete for the few listed properties.
"I am encouraged to see that 2023 ended with an 11% increase in active listings compared to the year's end in 2022," Roney said.
For buyers, you still need to act quickly, and your Mid-Shore Realtor can help you make a strong offer.
It is important to remember, Roney said, that once mortgage rates start to decline, there will be more competition for the already limited number of available homes for sale. Right now, buyers should expect a very competitive market in 2024, with prices continuing to rise.
The Mid-Shore Board of Realtors' mission is to advocate for its members and the public to preserve the right to own, transfer and utilize real property. For more news and information, visit midshoreboardofrealtors.com. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on housing market statistics, including home prices, sales trends, and interest rate impacts, which directly relate to economic data and real estate markets. While 'Local Government' is tangentially connected to regional data, the core content aligns most strongly with Business/Economy.

title: A taste of the Shore: Eat Sprout cafe opens in Statehouse
author: Natalie Jones
content:
A taste of the Shore: Eat Sprout cafe opens in Statehouse

 January 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones | Section: General Assembly 
 
 635
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Maryland lawmakers and legislative staffers returning to the Statehouse this year are welcoming a delicious upgrade to the building's canteen: an Eat Sprout cafe.The new cafe, jokingly called the "Sprout Canteen" by owners Ryan and Emily Groll, is serving up a full spread of locally-sourced and organic grab-and-go food options in the heart of the state capitol.
The cozy cafe is Easton-based Sprout's fourth location and its second in Annapolis.
The opportunity to open a cafe in the Statehouse came "relatively fast," according to Ryan Groll.
Sprout was already known to some year-round Statehouse staff, who've shopped at Sprout's Annapolis location or popped by to the St. Michaels cafe while on vacation, he said.
Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Talbot, Caroline, Dorchester, Wicomico), a St. Michaels resident, also advocated for a Sprout cafe opening in the Statehouse when he found out about the search for a new vendor, joining a number of other legislators and government officials impressed with Sprout.
When Groll was at the existing Annapolis cafe late last year, he began talking with one staffer, who mentioned the canteen's previous offerings were lacking during the legislative sessions.
Armed with that knowledge, Groll voiced an idea.
"(I) said, 'Hey, what if Sprout came in and provided all kinds of foods, bread, snacks and espressos to all the senators and congressmen and legislators and governor,'" he said. "They said, 'Oh my gosh, that would be amazing if you can do that.'"
From there, it was "kind of like wildfire," Groll said.
The Sprout team had about a month to make everything work, including securing vendors, equipment and staffing, along with tackling other logistical challenges of opening up shop in the Statehouse.
"I'm not sure who did what or who connected us to the right person, but it was almost like every day somebody from the Statehouse was calling me to just check in on us to see how the progress was going," Groll said.
"Getting phone calls from senators and phone calls from chiefs of staff was really neat, to see how much they truly cared and wanted to make sure that we were there and open and ready for them when they were in session," he added.
Several other small businesses on the Shore helped support Sprout's newest cafe, too.
Shawn Bell of Cambridge-based Kommercial Kitchens Inc. supplied refrigerators, with a team helping to unpack and unload the equipment early one morning. John Callahan of Callahan Signs printed marketing materials the same day Groll called him and installed them the next day.
Chesapeake Coffee Roasters, a Crofton-based business, also lent a hand with setting up espresso machines.
All of the logistical work was done remotely, unfolding during the holidays, but it finished just in time.
"We had equipment delivered on a Monday, cooked food on Tuesday and opened for session on Wednesday," Groll said.
Though the session is only a week in, the newest Sprout cafe already has some regulars, said Emily Groll, nodding toward a familiar legislative staffer who'd popped in for a quick bite on a chilly Tuesday morning.
Lawmakers, staffers and law enforcement alike are still scoping out the cafe, milling in and out between sessions, meetings and calls of duty.
"This is nice," a first-time customer said as he perused the refrigerated display case's offerings.
Mautz praised Sprout's innovative business model, acknowledging the cafe's fresh, originally made food being available in a convenient grab-and-go style seems to fit well with the busy and sometimes inconsistent schedules in the legislative world.
Sprout's menu, though different from the previous canteen staples, is a refreshing change, he said — and the business being Eastern-Shore-based is another plus.
"(It's) a variety, and a lot of healthy options — not everybody's looking for 100% healthy food, but they want to know what they're eating is good quality. I view quality over the health factor," Mautz said. "They know it's a good quality product that they're getting." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the opening of a new business (Eat Sprout cafe) in the Statehouse, highlighting entrepreneurial efforts, local partnerships, and economic activity. While there is mention of the Statehouse (local government), the core subject is the business venture and its economic implications.

title: Humble Hearts feeds body and soul
author: ANNIE HASSELGREN Special to the Star Democrat
content:
Humble Hearts feeds body and soul

 January 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANNIE HASSELGREN Special to the Star Democrat | Section: Business 
 
 405
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Chef Alicia Boyd's Humble Hearts catering business came alive on a napkin in 2014.Following an event she and a friend had done together, they knew they had something special. In the 10 years since, Boyd has found that the act of coming together around food represents much more than just breaking bread.
Born into a family of women who prioritized family meals, Boyd learned from her grandmother, aunt and mother how to prepare "soul-warming feasts."
"I knew I wanted to be a chef … (which) came from being able to cook with my grandmother, aunt and mother," she said. "My grandmother's home was open to everyone: different backgrounds, ethnicities — you were going to feel loved, and you were going to feel taken care of. That's how my family has always celebrated … That was ingrained in me."
A graduate of Baltimore International College's culinary program, Boyd shared her gifts cooking in restaurants from 2014 to 2018, waiting for the right time to establish the Humble Hearts concept. After a setback from breast cancer, from which she has recovered, doing events with her then-business partner became full-time in 2018.
The catch? Both had other full-time jobs.
"In 2020, we decided, 'Let's do this full time,'" she said. "We left our jobs one month before the pandemic started. It was a huge leap of faith, but we had no choice but to move forward. We quickly pivoted the business [from events and catering] to meal deliveries for five Upper Shore counties and Annapolis. People got to know us and our brand and spread the word."
Humble Hearts was a thriving operation, which Boyd still finds to be rewarding but challenging. Her business partner took a different path at the end of 2022 and Boyd became the sole owner.
She credits the success of her business with implementing sustainable policies and procedures, staying true to the company's values and not jumping on the bandwagon of every food trend that comes along.
"I've been trying to learn how to fail and know that it's OK," she said. "How you get back up after failing really determines the success of your business. There are so many things I don't know and have to learn … You may know how to make great jam, but do you know how to run a jam business?"
Thankfully, she has a stellar support system within the family-owned business. Her sister, "mother-in-love" (law), "sister-in-love" (law) and daughter are all employees. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Chef Alicia Boyd's catering business, highlighting entrepreneurial challenges, business strategies, and career transitions. While mentions of health (cancer recovery) and local community impact exist, the core narrative centers on business operations, sustainability, and economic resilience.

title: Salt truck crews work to keep ice at bay and local businesses open
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
Salt truck crews work to keep ice at bay and local businesses open

 January 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Local News 
 
 517
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Up before dawn, the team came with pallets of salt, ready to get their jobs done and help local businesses stay open, despite icy weather.Darrell Doupnik, the owner of Greenshore, an Easton-based landscaping company, has been providing salt and snow plow services in the winter for 40 years.
He met with his crew Friday morning to discuss their strategy for keeping walkways and parking lots ice-free for the company's roster of commercial clients.
Some members of the team, like foreman Jerry Widener, have years of experience with winter weather.
"I have been doing this for 15 years," Widener said. "I got up at 5 this morning. It's no big deal. I am used to it."
"In the winter we are clearing snow. When it snows, we are out here pushing snow. I am a pushing guy today, but I will do whatever it takes," he said.
According to Widener, Friday's temperatures, though frigid, were high enough to keep the workload manageable for the team.
"If it gets too cold, the salt doesn't work," Widener said. "I am the foreman today. I have five guys working for me. But for this, today, it is not too cold, and the salt works well."
Rock salt, lots of it, gets put in a spreader, which is attached to the back of a pickup truck for crews to drive around clients' roads and parking lots.
Doupnik said the team used over 100 40-pound bags of salt to handle Friday's workload, purchased from Site One landscaping supply.
"It is not cheap. Salt costs $450 a ton," he said. "We get them in 40-pound bags. You can put six bags at a time in the tailgate salt spreader."
Friday's storm brought upwards of three inches of snow to Easton and upwards of four inches to the town's north and east, according to the National Weather Service.
In more intense winter weather, Doupnik said, the team requires even larger quantities of salt, and staying ahead of the icy roads can be a strain on their bodies.
"This (storm) is a piece of cake. It is not really blowing. The six- to 10-inchers, you are out for two days. It sucks. You go home and try to get some rest, and then you are back out fixing it up. You just go back out there," he said.
In his 40 years of plowing snow, Doupnik has learned the value his team's hard work provides to not only his customers, but to the community as a whole.
"For commercial clients, you kind of have to provide it. They like an all-inclusive package," he said. "We do a lot of banks, we do these private schools and the churches. People still go to church. People still bank, and they have got to go to school. These places have to be open — especially the banks. We were out early this morning getting the banks opened up. Since schools are out, we do them last."
Doupnik said the community often shows appreciation for what his crew does.
"My guys get treated very well. My customers give them stuff a lot — especially at Christmas time," he said. "These are good guys, hard workers." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a landscaping business providing snow removal and salting services, highlighting operational challenges, customer relationships, and economic aspects of winter maintenance. While local life and public safety are tangentially related, the core subject is the business's role in supporting community operations.

title: What are the benefits of Roth IRA accounts?
author: KEVIN CALDWELL
content:
What are the benefits of Roth IRA accounts?

 January 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KEVIN CALDWELL | Section: News 
 
 700
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Roth IRA accounts are one of the best retirement vehicles available to most people. These accounts are excellent avenues to lower your income taxes in retirement.Below we will discuss the advantages and disadvantages of these accounts. Please keep in mind that these are generalities, and the nuances of everyone's situation can change the strategies discussed below so it is important that you consult with your financial advisor to discuss your particular situation.
ADVANTAGES OF ROTH IRA
The advantages of Roth IRAs are significant and each one has some subtleties included in it. Some advantages are similar to other IRA accounts; however, the unique advantages of Roth IRAs bring substantial value over time.
1) Tax-Free Growth — As with all other IRA accounts, the earnings while in the account are tax-free. However, unlike some other IRA accounts, the contributions to a Roth IRA have already been taxed, meaning you will not receive tax deductions at the time of funding the account like you do in a 401(k) account.
2) Withdrawals are tax-free and include more flexibility — Since the contributions have already been taxed you can withdraw those at any time, penalty-free and tax-free. The earnings cannot be withdrawn until you reach 59 and a half-years-old and the account has been open for five years. But once you meet those criteria, all withdrawals are tax-free.
The only exceptions to the age and time requirements are due to disability, a first-time home purchase, or death.
3) No Required Minimum Distributions — There are no Requirement Minimum Distributions on Roth IRA accounts. Most other IRA accounts force you to start taking withdrawals at the age of 73, at an increasingly higher rate each year. Those withdrawals are taxable, and you can get hit with severe penalties if you do not meet the RMDs. This also means Roth accounts can be left to heirs tax-free.
4) No age limits — There is no age limit for contributing to a Roth IRA. As long as you have earned income from a job or receive 1099 income, then you can contribute to a Roth IRA.
5) No effect on Social Security benefit taxes — One of the most overlooked advantages of a Roth IRA is the positive effect on the taxes of Social Security distributions, potential Medicare Surtax and Medicare premiums. When you take social security distributions in retirement, you may get taxed on those distributions. If your combined income is between $25,000 and $34,000 (if filing as an individual) or between $32,000 and $44,000 (if filing as married filing jointly), then up to 50% of your social security distributions could be taxed. If you are above those thresholds, then up to 85% of your social security distributions could be taxed.
The key here is the term "combined income", which includes your adjusted gross income plus nontaxable interest and one-half of your Social Security benefits. That means that non-taxable income like interest from Municipal Bonds and Capital Gains (assuming you are in the 0% Capital Gains tax bracket) can still increase your taxes by the effect that income has on your Social Security benefits tax.
DISADVANTAGES OF ROTH IRA
There are really only two disadvantages. First, you are funding the account with after tax dollars versus other IRA savings where contributions can reduce your current income (such as 401k contributions), and thereby your current tax liability.
So if you are in a high income tax bracket while working and expect to be in a lower tax bracket in retirement, then taking advantage of 401(k) contributions can be more beneficial.
The second disadvantage is the income limitation.
For 2024, if you are a single filer and your Modified Adjustment Gross Income is more than $146,000, your contributions are reduced. Contributions are completely eliminated at $161,000. For married couples filing jointly, those figures are $230,000 and $240,000 respectively.
As you can see the advantages of owning a Roth IRA while in retirement are enormous. That does not mean they are better for everybody throughout a lifetime of savings, but if you are able to take advantage of these accounts, they will help you stretch your retirement income by reducing your taxes.
Kevin Caldwell is found and advisor at Islands East Advisors in Stevensville. Contact him at 833-303-3278 or visit his website at www.islandseast.com. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

This falls under Business/Economy as it relates to personal finance, investment vehicles, and economic decision-making. While there is a slight educational aspect, the core content is financial/economic.

title: Talbot County Economic Development and Tourism welcomes new tourism manager
author: Staff Writer
content:
Talbot County Economic Development and Tourism welcomes new tourism manager

 January 31, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Local News 
 
 365
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Talbot County Department of Economic Development and Tourism recently appointed Kristen Goller as tourism manager.In this role, Goller will play a pivotal part in advancing the county's tourism initiatives and fostering economic growth through strategic marketing and development efforts.
Talbot County Department of Economic Development and Tourism Director Cassandra Vanhooser said, "We are delighted to welcome Kristen to the Talbot County team. Her extensive experience and proven track record make her a valuable asset to our efforts in promoting tourism and driving economic development. Kristen's dedication to fostering partnerships at the local and state levels aligns perfectly with our vision for the future."
With a career dedicated to the tourism and hospitality industry, Goller brings a wealth of experience to her new role.
Before joining Talbot County, she served as the tourism manager for Wicomico County, Maryland, where she successfully led initiatives to market the county, boost visitation and generate a positive economic impact. Goller's 16-year tenure with Wicomico County included her role as the director of marketing and public relations for the Wicomico County Department of Recreation, Parks & Tourism.
Goller is well-versed in collaboration, having worked closely with city, county and regional elected leaders, advisory boards, economic development directors, hotel partners, and businesses within the tourism industry. At the state level, she forged strong partnerships with Maryland's Department of Commerce, particularly with the Office of Tourism Development and with Maryland Sports.
In addition to her professional accomplishments, Goller holds a master's in history and museum studies from the University of North Carolina at Greensboro and a bachelor's in history and English, with a concentration in professional writing.
A resident of the Eastern Shore for 30 years, she looks forward to becoming an integral part of the Talbot County community.
"Talbot County is an incredibly vibrant area to both live and visit," Goller said. "I look forward to working with Talbot County's tourism partners to help promote all the great ways to experience Talbot County."
Goller has also been actively involved in the tourism community, serving as a board member for the Maryland Tourism Council, President of the Beach to Bay Heritage Area, and holding various roles within the Maryland Association of Destination Marketing Organizations, including secretary, treasurer and chairman. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Talbot County's economic development and tourism initiatives, highlighting the appointment of a tourism manager to drive economic growth through strategic marketing and partnerships. While local government is involved, the core emphasis is on economic development and business-oriented tourism strategies.

title: Remote Realities: Office vacancies rise as work from home fully takes root
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG National Enterprise Editor
content:
Remote Realities: Office vacancies rise as work from home fully takes root

 February 1, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG National Enterprise Editor | Section: Business 
 
 1553
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Office vacancies are at record highs in the U.S.A year-end report from Moody's Analytics found the national office vacancy rate ended 2023 at a "record-breaking 19.6%."
What's the culprit?"
Remote work born from the coronavirus pandemic is fully rooted for many workplaces and expected by many workers for certain occupations.
There are also significant declines in job postings for office jobs as automation, artificial intelligence and corporate restructurings change the economic landscape and reduce workforces.
According to Moody's, the previous record high for empty office was 19.3% set in 1986 and 1991 during the savings and loan crisis. Moody's also found new office construction in 2023 (24.5 million square feet) is the lowest since 2012.
Remote work is here to stay for many workers — with many permanently at home offices or working hybrid models of two to four days at home and limited office time.
"The permanence of dynamic hybrid models has effectively muted office demand, making the year of 2023 the most downbeat since the Great Financial Crisis," Moody's economists Thomas LaSalvia, Lu Chen and Nick Luettke write in their year-end analysis, referring to the Wall Street and global financial upheavals of 2007 and 2008 and resulting recession and real estate crash.
Other commercial real estate firms also see record-high vacancy levels.
According to real estate firm Avison Young Inc, 23.4% of U.S. office space was available for lease in the fourth quarter of 2023. That includes 27.4% of Class A space.
Vacancy and availability rates are north of 30% in Atlanta, Dallas and Austin and ended last year at 36.2% in San Francisco, according to Avison Young's Q4 numbers.
Among other large markets, vacancy rates end the year at 26.4% in Chicago, 19.2% in Manhattan, 23% in Los Angeles, 29.6% in Houston, 21.9% in Minneapolis-St. Paul, 29.8% in Denver and 19.1% in Miami.
The commercial real estate firm said office space needs could continue to be downwardly impacted by significant drops in job postings for office jobs infields such as finance, media, public relations and insurance as well as decrease in job openings in markets such as San Francisco, Charlotte, New York, Tampa and Atlanta.
IMPACTFUL ACTIONS
Many employers across the U.S. have set their post-pandemic paths on remote work and whether and how to require workers to be at the office, according to Alicia Scott-Wears, content director for World at Work, a Scottsdale, Arizona-based human resources association.
While some bosses yearn to require workers to be physically present, contemporary realities, including labor preferences and employee retention — are often resulting in hybrid work models where employees can work at home but are required to show up at offices an expected number of days each week or month.
That is becoming accompanied by some tracking of employees' attendance and productivity via wi-fi usage and badge swipes.
Scott-Wears said employers and managers need to tread carefully on these fronts otherwise they run the risk of losing existing employees and could find themselves struggling to hire new ones.
"The manner in which employers approach the implementation of their preferred strategy will be an impactful aspect. An organization's culture not only influences the decision for the chosen path of workplace flexibility but how the organization rolls that out will in turn impact the culture and perception of the organization," she said. "Organizations will want to take care not to erode trust and positive culture they have worked long and hard to build which could easily occur if adequate consideration and thoughtful practice in implementation are not taken with return to office efforts."
Scott-Wears said many job applicants prefer work from home jobs but that she's seen a drop in those types of jobs listed by employers. The result is high numbers of applicants for jobs with remote options.
"However, even though there are fewer remote jobs, those are the positions receiving the high interest and application submittals. So even though it may not be the expectation, there is certainly a desire and preferential availability to the talent with remote work," Scott-Wears said.
Working from home has made suburban office locations more popular for employers with hybrid models, according to Moody's.
BEST PLACES FOR REMOTE WORK
An analysis of U.S. Census Bureau occupation data by SelectSoftware Reviews (SSR) found the District of Columbia (54%), Colorado (37.3%), Maryland (37%), Massachusetts (36.4%), Utah (36%), Washington (34.8%) and Minnesota (33.7%) have the highest percentage of remote workers.
Telework has also allowed some workers to relocate to smaller towns and rural areas since they are no longer tethered to metropolitan commutes.
Real estate agents and brokers from Montana, Wyoming, Idaho and Florida say they have seen remote workers relocating from more urban and many times more expensive coastal areas. Some are taking advantage of states with no or lower income taxes while others are looking for less expensive real estate and more hospitable places for their small businesses or freelance work.
"We are seeing a lot of small business owners and workers relocating here. I think the main driver is the healthy economy, good schools, low crime and abundant choices of recreation,' said Mike DeVries, a broker with McCaw, Devries, Steinhauer and Company Real Estate in Bozeman, Montana.
Technology sectors are also growing in the Mountain West.
"I think there is more tech coming here and not just computers and software stuff. There is a surprising amount of smaller high tech manufacturing businesses that just do their thing and stay under the radar,' DeVries said.
According to Massachusetts-based SSR. Mississippi (11.9%) and Louisiana (13.7%) had the lowest percentages of teleworkers. Among other states, 29.9% of California workers report doing at least part of their jobs remotely. That figures stands at 31% in Oregon, 23.6% in Idaho, 25.4% in Wisconsin, 25.2% in Florida, 27% in North Carolina and 24.2% in Ohio.
BY THE NUMBERS
According to year-end 2023 figures from the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics, 21.9% of American workers report teleworking some hours on the job with 10.5% working totally at home.
Overall, 21% of private sector workers, 33.5% of federal workers, 22.6% of state government workers and 9.8% of local public sector workers (which include police officers, firefighters and public works employees) have telework options, according to BLS.
For some professions, remote work (including totally working from home) is increasingly the norm.
Two-thirds (66%) of workers in computer and mathematical related jobs work remotely with 38.3% of tech workers completely out of the office.
Among other professions, 43.2% of employees in media, design, arts and sports-related office jobs work remotely at least some of the time with 22.7% completely working from home, according to BLS.
More than half (52.6%) of lawyers and other legal workers work remotely some of the time but only 18.2% are completely remote.
Demographically, Asian men are the most likely to be able to work remotely — with 33.4% reporting they work remotely some of the time. Just over 30%of Asian women, 24.4% of White women and 21.3% of Black women are able to work remotely for some of their occupation, according to December figures from BLS.
That compares to 20% of White Men, 12.3% of Black Men and 8.5% of Hispanic Men working remotely for some of their jobs.
A lot of that has to do with the types and level of employment. Some jobs — ranging from graphic designers and news editors to software engineers and programmers — can work from home.
Women, especially those with college degrees, are more likely to work in office settings that now afford telework options, Employees with more education and higher pay levels are more likely to be given remote work options than lower-paid, frontline, blue-collar and part-time workers.
"The type of work to be performed also plays a large role; if the nature of the work is not conducive to a remote environment then there is unlikely to be as much demand or push for it with those roles. On the other hand, there are many professional positions that are readily feasible to be performed from anywhere and highly conducive to remote work which then also opens up talent pool options for the employer," Scott-Wears said.
IS AI COMING FOR YOUR JOB?But those same employee groups who are able to work from home are also more likely to have jobs that could be impacted by artificial intelligence and automation.
An analysis by the Pew Research Center, 19% of U.S. workers have jobs that could be impacted by AI. That includes potentially being replaced. Women are more likely than men to be jobs impacted by AI. Asians are the potentially most impacted racial group and higher educated workers have more automation exposure professionally, according to Pew.
Some of the jobs likely to be most impacted — and potentially most at risk from AI — include budget analysts, tax preparers, data entry workers, technical writers and web developers, according to Pew. Frontline workers and service providers such as barbers and hair stylists, construction workers, child care workers and those working at restaurants and hotels are the least likely to feel the employment affects of artificial intelligence.
Scott-Wears said larger employers are more equipped for telework options and it allows them to take advantage of larger labor pools less dependent on geography and commute times. That might give them some competitive advantages in attracting and retaining workers. "The size of the business is also a factor as larger multinational organizations have a higher likelihood to be better prepared for a more flexible or remote-first approach as they often have fewer obstacles through culture, connection, or technology platforms etc." she said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on office vacancy rates, remote work trends, and their economic impacts on commercial real estate and employment. Key themes include business sector shifts, labor market changes, and economic data analysis, aligning most directly with Business/Economy. Local Government and National News are weaker candidates as the content emphasizes economic trends over specific policy or general news coverage.

title: KustomScapes acquires Clearwater Pool and Spa
author: EMILY DOBSON Special To The Star Democrat
content:
KustomScapes acquires Clearwater Pool and Spa

 February 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: EMILY DOBSON Special To The Star Democrat | Section: Business 
 
 253
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — KustomScapes and Pools, a leading provider of outdoor living solutions on Maryland's Mid-Shore, acquired Clearwater Pool and Spa, effective Jan. 2.This development expands service offerings for KustomScapes and strengthens its commitment to serving the Eastern Shore and surrounding areas.
"Despite the transition, our goal remains the same — to provide exceptional customer service and offer high-quality products and materials," said KustomScapes Founder and Owner Jon Glass Sr. in a recent letter to current Clearwater customers. "We're thrilled to expand our business and remain actively engaged in our hometown community."
The acquisition brings together Clearwater's established reputation for pool maintenance and service with KustomScapes' extensive portfolio of outdoor services, including construction, renovation, hardscaping, masonry, outdoor living, landscape lighting, excavation and landscaping. This comprehensive range makes KustomScapes a one-stop shop for all outdoor needs.
KustomScapes is dedicated to ensuring a smooth transition for Clearwater customers. They will continue to offer ProTeams Chemicals and sell Aspen Spas, in addition to their existing services.
"While we transition to our name and brand, you may see a Clearwater vehicle at your home for service," said Glass. "We appreciate your patience during this time of change and would be happy to assist you with any questions or concerns."
Glass and his wife Karen, a former educator, are committed to upholding the high standards established by Clearwater and are already actively involved in the community in Easton and greater Talbot County. Glass serves as an engineer for the Easton Volunteer Fire Department and Karen Glass actively participates in the Cordova Ladies Auxiliary.

title: Chestertown council discusses potential new hotel and restaurant
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Chestertown council discusses potential new hotel and restaurant

 February 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Business 
 
 764
 Words 

 Read News Document

 At a council meeting earlier this month, Chestertown Mayor David Foster expressed optimism at the prospect of filling the space at 98 Cannon Street with a restaurant once again.Following a utility report, hotel entrepreneur, Donald J. Urgo approached the podium and announced his intentions of building a hotel and restaurant on that parcel of property.
He owns 60 hotels in North America, 17 of them in Quebec alone, and has a residence across the Sassafras River.
"It took me actually 50 years after coming to Maryland in 1972 to discover the majesty of the northeast Chesapeake Bay. After we purchased a home here, it took me five days to discover Chestertown."
Urgo informed the council that he and his wife were in town and had looked for a place to eat on the water. To his surprise, he couldn't find one.
So after walking past 98 Cannon Street many times over the next few years, he was compelled to action.
He intends to close the deal on the property there, and after looking at the building, would prefer to demolish it and rebuild.
Upon conferring with his team of architects and experts, Urgo is confident they can fit a restaurant and about a forty-room inn on that plot of land. The restaurant, he said, would be mid-priced, without too many fancy things involved. They would provide "good seafood and steaks at a moderate price; a Chesapeake Bay-to-table and farm-to-table situation.
He presented a few examples of his other hotels in some exotic locations as far as the Village Mont Blanc, a ski resort in the Canadian mountains.
He designed his hotel to fit with the french-speaking culture there and said it was an award-winning project.
Urgo presented another one of his projects, nestled in the Adirondack Mountains in New York.
He showed the council yet another, built in Quebec City, and said it was "suitable for the old town." They had remodeled a building at the gateway of the town, and was proud of how Ait fit with the culture there.
He talked to the packed crowd as much as the council.
"We're here to get a feeling from the council and the folks here if something like that would be attractive to the town," Urgo asked.
His team from Phillips & Donovan Architects presented their plan to the council. The group consisted of Joe Philips and Anna-Kate Payha.
Together they reviewed the potential area looking down Cannon Street and across Water Street.
Though it was a rudimentary plan, he gave the council a rundown of where the guest houses would face out, the parking lot space as well as calling attention to the fact the building would not obstruct the view of the water. They are also looking to incorporate the old wharf building to include it near the water.
The next step, Philips said would be to develop a more detailed site and floor plan.
Town Attorney Christopher Drummond indicated Urgo would be going through the Historic District Commission and the Planning Commission.
The approving authorities are there, Drummond added.
Regardless of that, Foster and the council expressed positivity toward the possibility of Urgo's project.
"I want to express my appreciation to you for showing interest in Chestertown and for recognizing that all of us, I think, without exception, really miss having a waterfront restaurant."
Foster said he cannot say if there's enough space for 40 rooms, or if the historic district or planning committee will approve of their plans.
However, offering his opinion he said, "I'd love to have a restaurant there and tell people, yes, there's a room for you right down the street."
Council member Tim O' Brien backed up Foster.
"I find this very exciting. Quebec is one of the oldest cities in North America. Talk about historic rules on steroids. If you can get permission there, there's hope here."
O' Brien said Urgo's sensitivity to local design means he's already headed in the right direction.
Urgo said that very same sensitivity is being implemented in their projects in Frederick, Maryland right now. And hearing that, Foster said he could compare notes as he's meeting with their mayor shortly.
Council member Meghan Efland, said, "Thank you for making the presentation. There have been so many questions about what is going on with 98 Cannon? We really haven't been able to talk about it so at least making this public, it can start a dialogue and people can start giving feedback."
Council member Jose Medrano said for two years they've been without a restaurant on the water.
"I'm happy to hear that and that you'll respect the historical context you're in," he said.
Urgo's properties consist of hotels operating under flags such as Hilton, Marriott and Hotel Indigo. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a hotel and restaurant development proposal by a business entrepreneur, involving local government discussions and economic implications for Chestertown. While local government is involved, the core subject is a business venture with economic impact.
