title: Maryland Democrats try to cap live-event ticket prices
author: ANGELIQUE GINGRAS Capital News Service
content:
Maryland Democrats try to cap live-event ticket prices

 February 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANGELIQUE GINGRAS Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 806
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — State lawmakers are proposing legislation that cracks down on ticket scalping in Maryland, hoping to stop unfair ticket prices and bad actors in the resale market.Sen. Dawn Gile (D-Anne Arundel) and fellow Democrats in both chambers are pushing this ticketing reform bill, inspired by the overwhelming demand for artists like Taylor Swift and Beyoncé and by the scalpers who in recent months have preyed on their fans.
"We really believe that, you know, entertainment tickets are not real estate, stocks, other commodities," said Gile. "They should be for fans to see the show, and so this bill would get to the heart of the scalping issue by eliminating the incentive to scalp in the first place."
But critics are concerned about some parts of the bill they say won't protect consumers — and may even encourage monopoly. The proposed changes might limit a consumer's choice on where to purchase tickets, they say, and threaten healthy competition in the market.
The debate comes amid a rise in online ticket scalping. Swift fans came to know the problem all too well in 2022 when an unprecedented number of buyers tried to score tickets to her "Eras Tour" on Ticketmaster. Also flooded with resellers and ticket scalpers, the site crashed, leaving fans with less than a love story.
That fiasco triggered interest in Congress, still considering legislation aimed at rebuilding trust in the ticket industry. Lawmakers are trying to increase transparency in ticket sales and protect consumers from overpriced tickets with harsher penalties on scalpers. According to Live Nation Entertainment, Ticketmaster's parent company, Maryland is one of 12 states that have passed laws or are considering legislation to protect resale.
The fiasco also inspired Gile's bill in the Maryland General Assembly last year, which focused on restricting resale, but Gile withdrew the bill after small concert venues complained that it didn't do enough to address the scalping issue.
Now, Gile and Del. C.T. Wilson (D-Charles), chair of the Economic Matters Committee, are taking another stab at the problem.
They will focus on three things: requiring the full ticket price to be disclosed at every step of the transaction; banning so-called "speculative ticket" sales, so third-party vendors can't sell tickets they don't have in hand yet; and capping the secondary market, so that a ticket can't be resold for an amount more than its face value.
This new approach has the backing of at least one major venue in the state.
"This bill would make Maryland the premier state for protecting consumers and the ticket buying experience," said Tom Coale, a lobbyist for It's My Amphitheater, which operates on behalf of Merriweather Post Pavilion in Columbia.
He added: "It takes on all of the worst practices, ticket scalpers, it addresses speculative tickets, it addresses the upselling of these tickets, and that shows just the level of deliberation and research that Senator Gile and Chair Wilson put into this bill."
While there is general support for increasing transparency in ticket sales, critics are concerned with other parts of the bill.
Dana McLean, executive director of the Coalition for Ticket Fairness, said her organization represents small business in the ticket resale industry as well as fans and season ticket holders. She told Capital News Service that "spec ticketing" has a negative connotation in the industry, but that responsible resellers are actually good for the fans.
"The term spec ticketing now is synonymous with people not actually getting the tickets that they paid for because somebody can't come through and actually deliver that," said McLean. "When it's done the right way and done by the people who should be doing it … It's actually really beneficial to the customer. It gives them more options."
While Gile's proposed legislation doesn't define speculative ticketing either way, it does say that any tickets sold in the secondary market should be capped at their initial price. CTF calls this an anti-consumer practice.
"When you have a closed market, when you restrict resale, it restricts competition and consumer choice from entering into a market and it gives more power to monopoly," said McLean.
Closer to home, the House Republican Caucus has similar concerns about consumers not being able to freely sell tickets they purchased.
House Minority Leader Jason Buckel (R-Allegany) said if "regular people resell tickets to sporting events or concerts that they've purchased fairly and honestly they can't attend, and now they want to sell their tickets and there's a hot commodity for it, I don't want to in any way prohibit them from being able to engage in those transactions."
Still, Buckel said, if "there's a very organized, technological effort to basically control the ticket site, and groups come in and purchase almost all of the tickets within minutes, and then create a secondary market where they gouge folks for what the face value of the tickets are … that's a different set of facts. I'm certainly open to applying limitations." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on legislative efforts to regulate ticket pricing and scalping, which involves market practices, consumer protection, and economic policies. While entertainment events are mentioned, the core issue is economic regulation rather than cultural or governmental operations.

title: Maryland charter boat and commercial fishermen air grievances about rockfish limits
author: Connie Connolly
content:
Maryland charter boat and commercial fishermen air grievances about rockfish limits

 February 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly | Section: Local News 
 
 1538
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Charter boat operators were joined by commercial fishermen Saturday, Feb. 17, to air grievances about proposed restrictions on catching Atlantic striped bass in the Chesapeake Bay.About 75 people, including Mid-Shore political leaders and 1st District congressional candidate Chris Bruneau, attended the afternoon forum hosted by Delmarva Fisheries Association and the Maryland Charter Boat Association at the Talbot County Community Center.
Attending the 1 p.m. forum, were Maryland Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico); Del. Tom Hutchinson (R-Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico); Kent County Commission President Ron Fithian and Kent County Economic and Tourism Development Director Jamie Williams.
At issue is the economic impact the restrictions will have on the charter boat industry and the ripple effect among related businesses if the Maryland Department of Natural Resources and the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission get their way, panelists said.
"We've got to put a stop to this," said Fisheries Association Chairman Robert Newberry.
Newberry was part the panel explaining the issue and proposing solutions, along with Capt. Brian Hardman, president of the Maryland Charter Boat Association; Capt. Ken Jeffries, vice president of the Upper Bay Charter Captains Association; commercial waterman Brian Nesspor of Rock Hall; attorney James Butera of Meeks, Butera & Israel in Washington, D.C.; and David Reel of Quantum Communications.
An emergency action enacted in 2023 by the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission restricting the size and number of rockfish — as striped bass are known locally — that can be caught by recreational anglers. That emergency action was extended in January 2024 for implementation May 1.
Although charter boats operate for profit, they fall under the recreational fishing designation.
The commission's action "was approved to reduce fishing mortality in 2024 and support stock rebuilding," according to its website.
ASMFC "has served as a deliberative body of the Atlantic coastal states, coordinating the conservation and management of 27 nearshore fish species," according to Asmfc.org, Three commissioners from each state serve on the commission, along with other representatives. Each of the 15 states from Maine to Florida has one vote.
Maryland commissioners are Lynn Waller Fegley, DNR director of fishing and boating services, whose ongoing proxy is Michael Luisi, DNR director of the monitoring and assessment division; Russell Dize of Tilghman, vice president of the Maryland Watermen's Association, whose proxy is Robert Brown, president of the Maryland Watermen's Association; and Del. Dana Stein (D-11B), whose proxy is David Sikorski, executive director of Coastal Conservation Association Maryland.
"I can't believe that ... other states can dictate how a business is run in the state of Maryland, and how they can create financial havoc on a business in the state of Maryland," Hardman said.
"They're Godzilla," Newberry said.
States must submit implementation plans by March 1 for Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission board review and approval.
The commission's 19-inch to 24-inch slot limit, one-fish bag limit, is too restrictive, and the economic impact will have far-reaching effects, forum participants said.
PUSHING BACK
"The bottom line is they want to address the overfishing in the Chesapeake Bay and the coasts of striped bass by … recreational fishermen," Newberry said. "They said commercial (fishing) is not the problem."
However, along with maintaining the 2022 striped bass season dates, Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission measures toward "stock rebuilding" will reduce commercial quotas by 7% in both the ocean and the Chesapeake Bay.
On Feb. 9, DNR announced striped bass emergency regulations "to bolster the species" spawning population were "effective immediately." The regulations were approved by the Maryland General Assembly's Joint Committee on Administrative, Executive, and Legislative Review. The regulation aligns with the commission's plan.
"Maryland is considering establishing these new rules permanently," the DNR press release stated. The department encourages anglers to instead pursue invasive species, such as blue catfish and snakeheads to contribute to "a healthier ecosystem in the Bay."
Charter boat operations are still recovering from pandemic-related restrictions, as well as marinas, bait and tackle shops, restaurants and hotels, which would be "decimated" by the restriction, Hardman said.
"These businesses are saying, 'If you guys are gonna have a 30, 40, 50% decrease, so are we because we depend on that summer business' — kind of like Ocean City," Hardman said. "So, it's gonna have a huge impact far beyond the charter boats."
He said charter boats were "hammered" during COVID-19, but inflation also is taking its toll.
"People can't afford to go fishing, so we take a hit on that. Maybe they've got to make a choice between going fishing for two fish or groceries. If it's one fish, that (choice) has already been made for them. So we're getting hit on a lot of fronts."
"I explained (to DNR) it's not because there's not any fish out there," Hardman said. "Sometimes it's an environmental thing, but mostly it's what's going on in economy."
APPEAL FOR SUPPORT
Hardman said 377 charter boats are registered with the Chesapeake Bay FACT electronic reporting system.
Charter boats are often booked the year before with clients' paying deposits, Hardman said. Restricting the limit from two to one fish with size restrictions for each client gives clients second thoughts about chartering a fishing expedition.
It also creates a conundrum for charter boat captains.
"You can catch (one rockfish) in half an hour," Jeffries said. At that point, the captains move on to catch perch, catfish or other species. If a rockfish gets on the line, it's thrown back. Captains are required to report statistics electronically through the whole fishing cycle. Charter boat catches are measured in number of fish, but commercial fishermen's catches are measured in pounds.
Both Bay charter boat operators and commercial fishermen say they are disproportionately blamed for "dead discharges" resulting from catching and releasing striped bass.
"ASMFC has this big saying: A dead fish is a dead fish," Newberry said.
Nesspor said he's argued with DNR officials "till I'm blue in the face."
"A dead fish is not a dead fish," he said. "A dead fish comes up on my beach for the buzzards and an occasional eagle. Mine gets a tag in his mouth and eight people make money off of it after it leaves my hands."
"This is DNR and ASMFC's great idea of how to save these fish, putting a burden on the charter boats. They caught 100,000 fish last year; they're saving 50,000 fish — that's it," Newberry said. "All this and your financial difficulties is for 50,000 fish. You probably find that, when boat traffic's busy on the Fourth of July, about 100,000 are killed a day with all the boats going up and down the Bay."
Forum speakers thanked local legislators for pushing back against DNR, but consistently pointed fingers at environmental groups, DNR, ASMFC and Gov. Moore for their predicament. "They ganged up on us," Jeffries said.
"Give us our own quota like the commercial guys," Hardman said. "We are a commercial entity; give us our own quota and then leave us alone. If we fish it out, that's our problem."
Commercial fishermen must also take a hit, adding a cumulative financial burden that has affected their businesses for the last eight years, Newberry said.
ECONOMIC BOONS
Both commercial and recreational industries are economic boons for states.
According to ASMFC, "In 2016, marine commercial and recreational fisheries generated approximately 1.7 million jobs in the U.S. economy. In addition, commercial and recreational fishing combined generated $212.2 billion in sales impacts, $64.2 billion in income impacts, and $99.5 billion in value-added impacts throughout the economy. Further, more than 90 percent of the Atlantic coast recreational catch is taken in state waters, with many of the most prominent species, such as Atlantic striped bass, summer flounder and red drum, moving through multiple jurisdictions."
Newberry has another concern. "Out of the 34 species that ASMFC manages, there is only one species that does not have what they call conservation equivalency. Whales even have conservation equivalences, (but) not the striped bass, so they can overregulate it," Newberry said.
"This has got to stop and … we've got to explore all avenues," including protesting in Annapolis and "telling the governor, 'Do the right thing, be a man of your word … don't leave us behind.' He's not leaving just the charter boats and the commercial guys in the dirt, he's leaving restaurant owners, marina owners, tackle shops …"
"When you look at the voting record on the ASMFC, every single state from Maine to Florida … goes to bat for their fishermen except one state — Maryland," Newberry said. "Our state does not, our legislators do not support the fishermen."
ASMFC oversees compliance with the Atlantic Striped Bass Conservation Act of 1984. "(A)ll Atlantic coast states that are included in a commission fishery management plan must implement required conservation provisions of the plan or the secretary of Commerce (and the Interior in the case of striped bass) may impose a moratorium for fishing in the noncompliant state's waters," according to the organization's website.
Newberry suggested organizing a protest in Annapolis, strategically "going out of compliance" as other states have done and possibly taking legal action in federal court.
"I'm tired of people telling us how we have to work, when we have to work," Newberry said. "The bottom line is no one holds a gun to our head to go to work. We go to work because we love the Bay, and we love what the Bay gives us, and that is a living for our families. So, this has got to stop." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the economic impact of fishing regulations on charter boat operators and commercial fishermen, highlighting business concerns, industry ripple effects, and political lobbying. While environmental aspects are mentioned, the core issue is economic viability and regulatory burdens on the fishing industry.

title: Income tax hike unlikely in Maryland, this year
author: LYDIA HURLEY Capital News Service
content:
Income tax hike unlikely in Maryland, this year

 February 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LYDIA HURLEY Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 1015
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Some Democratic lawmakers in Maryland are proposing a set of income tax hikes this year, but even bill sponsors have admitted that getting their colleagues on board will likely be a long-haul effort.The lawmakers aim to address a looming state budget deficit with a bill that would raise an estimated $1.6 billion per year for the state's general fund once it's fully phased in, supporters say.
Supporting lawmakers want to start to build the case for a restructuring of the tax system, even if the initiative doesn't seem likely to pass this session, Sen. Shelly Hettleman (D-Baltimore), the sponsor of the Senate bill, said.
"I'm under no illusion that the bill is going to pass this year," Hettleman said, laughing. "However, there are important policy issues that as a legislature we need to be considering as we're trying to figure out how we're going to pay for the services Marylanders value and need."
The sponsoring lawmakers hope to shift more of the tax burden from working families onto high-income earners and corporations, while relying on tax credits to assist in closing the income gap. Other states are making similar moves. Massachusetts passed a law in 2022 that requires a 4 percent income tax on those who earn more than $1 million annually.
Advocates for businesses are worried that the bill would threaten corporations and small businesses and might even deter them from operating in Maryland.
Aside from the bill sponsors, though, most Maryland officials are not jumping at the chance to raise taxes this election year. Democratic Gov. Wes Moore introduced a 2025 fiscal year budget that is balanced without any tax increases. This is despite the fact that the state is projected to face a deficit of $1.8 billion in 2028 if it doesn't dramatically change its spending and revenue habits.
The deficit might threaten Maryland's ability to keep some of its most important state programs adequately funded, advocates say.
"We see looming holes in the budget that need to be dealt with. Otherwise, we're going to have to start cutting things," Del. Julie Palakovich Carr (D-Montgomery), the sponsor of the House bill, said.
Health care, education and transportation all depend on state funding, said Kali Schumitz of the Maryland Center on Economic Policy. The budget deficit might inhibit the state's ability to keep money flowing toward these initiatives, Schumitz said.
The revenue raised by the bill, known as the Fair Share Maryland for Act of 2024, aims to address these concerns. A major goal of the bill is to increase income taxes for Marylanders who earn more than $250,000 a year.
The bill would also reduce taxes for lower-income earners by expanding Maryland's Child Tax Credit, Schumitz added. The additional funds would make more people eligible for the tax credit by increasing the maximum earning level allowed.
"This would increase the number of kids benefitting from the credit, which is a really powerful anti-poverty tool," Schumitz said.
Child tax credits would assist working families, bringing economic relief to those who need it most, said Terry Cavanagh from SEIU 500, a public sector workers union, told lawmakers in the Senate bill hearing on Wednesday.
The increased income taxes would go toward the state's general fund, and lawmakers can use their discretion to decide where the funding should go, said Palakovich Carr.
Economic justice advocates are urging lawmakers to consider using the revenue on education. If not, schools could be left severely underfunded, said Shamoyia Gardiner, Executive Director of Strong Schools Maryland, a grassroots educational organization. A similar fate is possible for the Blueprint for Maryland's Future, an initiative that is fully funded only for the next couple of years, Gardiner added.
Other advocates think lawmakers should use it to support housing affordability and assistance, as these initiatives go hand-in-hand with education, Schumitz said. "There's an increasing recognition that all these things are interconnected," Schumitz added.
The bottom line for some lawmakers is that, regardless of where funds may be used, the tax system is in need of a restructuring.
"Our tax system is upside down. The wealthiest 1 percent of Marylanders, people making over $700,300 a year, pay a smaller share of their income in state and local taxes than people in any other income group," Schumitz said.
The bill is a way to "check and rebalance the fairness" of Maryland's tax system and re-evaluate funding state programs, Hettleman said.
Unlike in some other states, this initiative has not been labeled a millionaires tax because the tax increase would impact some high earners who make less than $1 million.
The impact on tax rates wouldn't be as drastic as it seems, some advocates say. "More people are actually getting a tax cut than a tax increase under this bill," Christopher Meyer, a research analyst at the Maryland Center on Economic Policy, said.
The bill also aims to close corporate tax loopholes that allow big corporations to file taxes in places that don't charge a corporate income tax, avoiding paying the income taxes they owe in Maryland, Schumitz said.
The legislation would address this by requiring parent corporations to file a combined tax return, reflecting the income of all its subsidiaries as one entity for tax purposes.
However, opponents of this bill raised concerns about the use of this so-called "combined reporting."
"There is no guarantee that mandatory worldwide combined reporting would actually increase state revenues, and certainly would not create a stable revenue stream," Leonore Heavey, a senior tax counsel with the Council On State Taxation, told lawmakers in the Senate bill hearing.
Other opponents were concerned that enforcing combined reporting would discourage small businesses from continuing to operate in Maryland.
"You're looking at tax policy that discourages entrepreneurship and the expansion and even creation of small businesses here in Maryland," said Mike O'Halloran, the Maryland State Director of the National Federation of Independent Business.
"The state is facing a lot of fiscal issues," O'Halloran said. "There are a lot of priorities that this administration and the prior administration laid out, that you all are now having to deal with how we pay for it. So it might be better for the body to pursue this than a roughly $1 billion tax hike over the next few years." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Maryland's proposed income tax hikes, budget deficit solutions, and economic policy debates. While education and local government are mentioned as affected areas, the core subject is tax policy and economic restructuring, aligning most closely with Business/Economy.

title: Sell beer, wine in groceries
author: Staff Writer
content:
Sell beer, wine in groceries

 February 25, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 395
 Words 

 Read News Document

 As the former chief of staff to the Comptroller of Maryland, and as the first chairman of the Alcohol and Tobacco Commission, I was pleased to testify in Annapolis recently on behalf of House Bill 847. This important legislation, sponsored by Del. Marlon Amprey, would permit beer and wine to be sold in Maryland grocery stores.Based on my own experience as a 20-year resident of Talbot County — the one jurisdiction where this is actually legal — we can safety conclude there are two things this bill would do and three things it would not.
It will provide immeasurable convenience for consumers who lead increasingly hectic lives, which is why more than 80 percent of Marylanders support it.It will provide much-needed economic sustenance for grocery stores that provide good-paying jobs, reinvest in our state's economy and are now fighting to stave off the threat posed by online retailers.It will not put the local, independent retailers — colloquially known as the "mom and pops" — out of business. Experience here and elsewhere has confirmed that the big box retailers tend to stock the most popular, mass-produced products and leave it to the local package stores to sell craft beer, boutique wines and locally sourced products. Furthermore, our package stores will still have exclusive domain over the sale of distilled spirits. Finally, the "mom and pops" offer a level of customer service and subject matter expertise that the grocery stores just cannot match.It would not increase underage consumption of alcohol. In more than two decades of shopping in Talbot County grocery stores, not once have I witnessed an adolescent or teen try to sneak out of Aisle 9 with ill-gained IPAs or Merlots. In fact, one can argue that grocery stores — equipped as they are with multiple cameras, secured storefront doors and other theft prevention devices — are better suited to prevent unauthorized access and theft than the independent stores.Finally, this will not lead to alcoholism, substance abuse, vehicle fatalities and other dire outcomes cited by the Annapolis lobbyists who are hired to kill this bill every year. Their hypothetical scenarios and apocryphal anecdotes are simply not reflected in the data.
Forty-seven other states already have this measure in place. It's time that Maryland join the 21st century and pass this bill into law. Consumers win and our state's economy will be stronger as a result.
LEN FOXWELL
Baltimore 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on legislative efforts to allow grocery stores to sell alcohol, emphasizing economic benefits for businesses, consumer convenience, and counterarguments against opposition. While there is a governmental aspect, the core discussion revolves around economic impact and business operations.

title: Local cowrites business book based on Ted Lasso
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
Local cowrites business book based on Ted Lasso

 February 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Local News 
 
 579
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GREENSBORO — A local author has co-written an uplifting and humorous business leadership book based on the wisdom of a favorite TV show."Ted Lasso," a hit AppleTV+ series that ran from 2020 to 2023, caught the attention of two successful software developers, Marnie Stockman, an Greensboro resident, and Nick Coniglio, who lives in Georgia. They loved the show, so they said, "Let's write a book."
Stockman and Coniglio recommend seeing the show before delving into their book, "Lead It Like Lasso," which you can get on Amazon.
In the show, a successful American college football coach gets recruited to coach a Premier League soccer team in England. He knows nothing of English culture or the game, but he knows people and how to get the best out of his different players. He knows how to build a cohesive team.
"It is a feel good, fish out of water story where you are rooting for kind of everybody," she said.
The book focuses on five characters from the show as archetypes of leadership. Sam is the "optimistic achiever." Roy is a "tough love mentor." Keeley is "the supportive collaborator." Rebecca is "the visionary transformer."
People have read the book and were surprised to find themselves a "Roy/Keeley" or another mixture, the authors said.
"We don't need a whole Earth of Teds. It takes everybody including the Diamond Dogs," Stockman said.
Diamond Dogs, who play a comic role in the show, are depicted in the book as friends who both support you and tell you the truth. They hold you accountable.
Both Stockman and Coniglio have had experience leading and being lead in corporate settings, and one of the points they emphasize in their book is that anyone can be an effective leader. Mothers, small business owners, college kids and nonprofits can all learn from the different leadership styles portrayed by characters in Ted Lasso.
"Leadership is life. We believe everyone is a leader," Stockman said.
Stockman and Coniglio's company got acquired three times, and each time they were given more responsibility and less resources to succeed, they said. This frustrated them. They wanted to think of building something they believed in.
Ted Lasso came out as they began building their company, Lifecyle Insights.
"We built a platform on that right as Ted Lasso started," Coniglio said.
He told Stockman, "You are Ted Lasso, and you need to watch this show. I saw her positivity, optimism and kindness. It is really tied to his belief in people and inspiring people. And his relentless commitment to insure that people work to achieve the best versions of themselves," he said.
She liked it and agreed to work on the book.
"If we hooked it to what folks love about Ted Lasso and paralleled his leadership principles with our leadership framework and told stories about both, that might just do it. So that is the book we wrote," Stockman said.
A lot of leadership books emphasize vision. This book is more about core values.
"Two of our core values — one was raving fans and one was transparency. Focusing on doing the right thing for our customers created raving fans," she said. "So they ended up doing the sales for us. And the transparency piece is when the site went down once, I immediately sent out a note saying, 'The site is down. I will be back in an hour, and we are working to resolve it.' They were super appreciative that we were open with them."
Since the book first published in November, Stockman and Coniglio have sold 4,000 copies. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on two authors creating a business leadership book inspired by the TV show Ted Lasso, emphasizing leadership principles, corporate values, and entrepreneurial experiences. While the local author angle and TV show reference add context, the core subject is business leadership and corporate culture.

title: Best places in America for remote workers: Colorado, Florida, Oregon, North Carolina do well
author: Mike Sunnucks APG Newspapers
content:
Best places in America for remote workers: Colorado, Florida, Oregon, North Carolina do well

 February 29, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks APG Newspapers | Section: National 
 
 529
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Colorado, Florida, North Carolina and Oregon — and a number of college towns — are the best places in the U.S. for remote workers.That is according to a new analysis.
DesignRush — a Miami-based B2B consulting firm — looked at factors such as housing costs, broadband connections, costs for internet and phone services, commute times. and current numbers of remote workers.
The group used U.S. Census Bureau and Federal Communications Commission numbers for come up with the rankings.
Boulder, Colorado tops the list.
"Boulder's high suitability comes from a high percentage of workers working from home at 20.8%, 114% above the national average of 9.7%, high percentage of households with a broadband subscription at 93.3%, 6.3 percentage points above the national average of 87%, and cheap access to fiber internet," the according to the study.
Colorado and the Mountain West are well represented in the list of top remote working locations with Fort Collins, Colorado 7th, Denver 11th and Boise, Idaho 21st.
Raleigh-Cary, North Carolina is second with 16.3% of local worker doing their jobs from home and 91.6% with broadband internet connections. Durham-Chapel Hill ranks 9th and Charlotte 15th on the list.
Austin, Texas is third. Bend, Oregon is fourth accompanied by three other Oregon cities including Corvalis 6th, Portland 8th and Eugene 26th.
Punta Gorda, Florida is fifth on the remote working list.
According to the study, 12% of workers in Punta Gorda (in Southwest Florida) are employed from home and the area has lower average monthly housing costs ($908.50) compared to the national average ($1,203.50).
Four other Florida cities make the top 30 for remote working:
Tampa-St. Petersburg 12th
Homosassa Springs, Florida 17th
North Port-Sarasota-Bradenton 24th
Pensacola 29th.
Florida's warm weather, population centers and lack of a state income tax make it attractive to remote workers especially from more expensive norhthern and eastern states.
The rest of the top 30 includes a number of college towns. Those include Ithaca, New York (10th); Ann Arbor, Michigan (13th), Charlottesville, Virginia (19th) and Bloomington, Indiana (25th).
"Remote working has become increasingly viable in recent years due to a combination of faster and more reliable internet connections, changing societal priorities, the changing nature of work, and in some cases necessity, such as during the pandemic," said Gianluca Ferruggia, general manager at DesignRush.
Remote work was prevalent during the coronavirus pandemic and its shutdowns. It has become the norm and expected from workers in fields such as media and communications, professional services, finance as well as law firms and among graphic designers and other creatives.
"Many workers now prefer to work from home due to the better work-life balance it can provide, plus it can allow workers to take advantage of higher average salaries that might be paid in other areas than the areas in which they live," Ferruggia said.
"Businesses also benefit from the increased desirability of remote working, as it allows them the widest talent pool to choose the best candidates for a job. This could be done by hiring workers for remote roles or by outsourcing projects to digital contractors when a full hire might not make financial sense."
Other cities making the list including Atlanta, Pittsburgh, Lawton, Oklahoma; Santa Fe, Mexico; Kingston, New York; Portland, Maine and Minneapolis-St. Paul. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article analyzes economic factors (housing costs, broadband access, remote work trends) affecting workforce locations, conducted by a business consulting firm. While it has national scope, the core focus is on economic and business implications of remote work infrastructure.

title: Haven Harbour marina manager talks shop and sails
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Haven Harbour marina manager talks shop and sails

 March 1, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 874
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Erik Lostrom, manager of Haven Harbour Marina Resorts in Rock Hall, is trying to keep an important industry afloat here.Boat building, boat repair and marina management.
The recreational marine industry.
He's hoping his new position on the board of directors of the Marine Trade Association of Maryland can help him support the industry that has been in his family for generations.
To do this there has to be new blood.
"We need to develop the younger generation to get them interested in the business," he said.
He acknowledged it's an aging trade and noted that schools should do a better job encouraging the industry. Trades, in his opinion, offer better pay starting out and does not come with enormous debt.
To get younger people enthused, he spends his time talking to the high schools.
He's doing his part to educate at the college level too, teaching a course on Marine Systems two nights a week, where students learn to install, troubleshoot, diagnose and repair marine equipment and systems.
The class consists of some late teens but also boat owners who wish to gain knowledge about the hobby they enjoy.
In the classroom, his students have the benefit of learning from a man coming from a long line of shipbuilders. His grandfather on his mother's side, Elmer Rosenblad was a master shipbuilder during World War II.
His father, Robert F. Lostrom built wooden boats as well.
He carries on that tradition, working in naval architecture and boat building before settling into boat repair.
"It's in my blood I guess. I've built 15 types of wooden boats."
Being born on the Jersey shore was an ideal place to learn those skills. After high school, Lostrom pursued his passion in Kennebunkport, Maine, the location of the infamous Bush compound. In Kennebunkport, at the Landing School Lostrom spent two years of intensive study being instructed on wooden boat building and yacht design.
Graduating in 1989, he found a way to ply his trade, in Philadelphia at the Independence Seaport Museum.
His marine versatility grabbed the attention of Kent County residents, the Johnson family in Quaker Neck. They owned a log canoe that was built in 1890, they wanted restored. After several months, working with a crew, Lostrom completed the job.
He remarked it was so efficient it started winning races.
Over a summer watching the log canoe compete, soaking in the sights and sounds on the Chesapeake Bay, Lostrom said he fell in love with Kent County. He found a job at Higgins Yacht Yard in Saint Michaels around 1995 and has lived on the Eastern Shore ever since.
With forty years experience he's a good candidate to keep our elected officials informed about the issues of the business.
He was nominated to the board the Marine Trade Association of Maryland board in December.
A group that consists of marina owners, boat builders and boat suppliers, they lobby with the state on regulations to support the marinas. Lostrom will be helping in the area of workplace development.
They'll be addressing all the changes in the industry. An industry, he said which is a luxury business.
Lostrom further described it as a "sunset dream industry."
"The people who sail, have a dream view in mind, of having a cocktail and cruising on their boat," he added.
The business may be luxury, but it is also vital to the economy on the Bay.
According to John Stefancik, executive director of Marine Trades Association of Maryland, a nonprofit dedicated to promoting the recreational marine industry, the annual economic impact to Maryland is $4.2 billion. He estimated that in Kent County that could be tens of millions.
With approximately 350 marinas in the state and only 1100 workers, Lostrom sees the challenges ahead.
There is lack of experienced skilled trade labor to service customer vessels in a timely manner.
He said, "The customer base has become more 'turnkey' type users putting more demand on skilled labor to keep vessels operating."
For instance, vacationers might have two weeks to get their yacht in the water. If it's still in the shop for repairs, and the boats are backed up, they might decide to sell it and stop living that specific dream.
A dream doesn't have to be limited to the boat owners either.
It could also be a dream for a lot of young men and women on the Shore, who hunt, fish, boat and love the outdoors.
A career outside of a cubicle.
There is a need for workers, Lostrom said. All marine trades are needed, from mechanics, marine plumbing to administrative work.
With a salary range starting at $40,000 that can go upward to $200,000, it could be a good option.
Lostrom pointed to one local success story, a life long employee of his. Under Lostrom, the employee learned about working with wood, received tips on proper use of tools and was instructed on fiberglass repair, engine mechanics and proper maintenance.
And he's doing it where he loves, working outside around the boating environment. And at Haven Harbour, a business that Stefancik indicated is one of the largest marinas in the state.
Between balancing the responsibilities of his marina, Lostrom will be lobbying across the state, passionate over his newfound responsibilities.
"I want people who read this to know that this is a professional career. A trade that should be treated as such."
In April, Lostrom will be conducting a career fair; the exact date to be determined later. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the marine industry's economic impact, workforce challenges, and business advocacy through the Marine Trade Association. While education is mentioned (teaching a course), the primary emphasis is on industry economics, trade dynamics, and professional career opportunities within the sector.

title: Talbot Chamber hosts Best in Business Awards Dinner
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
Talbot Chamber hosts Best in Business Awards Dinner

 March 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Business 
 
 559
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ROYAL OAK — Around 140 members of the Talbot Chamber of Commerce met on Thursday at the Oaks Waterfront Hotel for an awards dinner.The circular tables were filled, chicken was served and Amy Kreiner, president of the chamber, made the celebratory evening flow briskly and kept it fun, even referencing Taylor Swift in her opening remarks.
Kind of like the Oscars, some people kept track of the winners by writing on their program that listed all the awards. There were milestone awards, business awards and other recognitions.
Photographers popped flashes as each winner finished their speech and brought their team up to stand in front of room. The crowd cheered for each award acceptance.
"We have 23 awards to be presented. This whole evening is just about celebration. It is a fun evening," Kreiner said. "Celebrating and recognizing our businesses is at the very core of what the chamber does."
According to Kreiner, the chamber has added 76 new members this year.
"We have 626 total members. Fifty percent of them have fewer than 10 employees. Last year we had 17 ribbon-cuttings, 15 mixers, 10 lunch and learns, a fishing tournament, a golf tournament, an economic symposium and the legislative luncheon. This totals 1,351 event attendees," Kreiner said.
The next speaker joked that he had a 25-page Powerpoint to present. People groaned.
"Talbot County is the place to live, do business and work," said Reza Jafari, the outgoing chair of the chamber, who now serves on the Maryland Economic Council. "This is a special gathering of all the community leaders, all the influencers, all those who make a difference each and every day. We all know that economic development, business development and community development is a team sport."
Jafari introduced Dr. Arvin Singh, the incoming chair of the chamber, who works for The University of Maryland Shore Regional Health as vice president of strategic planning. Singh spoke about the new hospital planned on U.S. Route 50, which should be finished by 2028.
"We have an outstanding board of directors who are committed to our mission and elevating our business community," Singh said. "Thank you all to our entire business community and our winners tonight and we appreciate your continued support."
Joe Riley, director of operations at the Oaks Waterfront Hotel, said, "It is a pleasure to have everyone here to show them the new renovations that we have done."
Milestone recognitions were given for the length a business had worked in the community and business awards were given in seven categories. Bay Vanguard Bank was recognized for 150 years in business.Awards presented at the Chamber Dinner

title: Down payment grants awarded by Mid-Shore Board of Realtors
author: Mid-Shore Board of Realtors
content:
Down payment grants awarded by Mid-Shore Board of Realtors

 March 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mid-Shore Board of Realtors | Section: Real Estate 
 
 460
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — In less than one-year, the Mid-Shore Board of Realtors Love Down Payment Grant program has distributed 15 $1,000 grants to new homeowners in the five-county area the board serves."The first down payment grant was awarded in May 2023, and we have had a grant distribution almost every month since then," said Shelby Roney, president of Mid-Shore Board of Realtors. "It is such a needed program. With home prices being high and interest rates around 7%, these $1,000 grants really help."
The 15th grant went to Madison Loker, the emergency management coordinator with Talbot County, who is a first-time homeowner.
Loker combined the Mid-Shore Board of Realtors grant with another grant from the county. This is another advantage of the MSBR program, noted Roney. It can be combined with other grants and programs.
Tom Draper, branch manager with First Home Mortgage, said, "When I met with Madison and reviewed her application, I recommended she apply for the MSBR Love Down Payment Grant. The application process is very simple and streamlined. Once the application was complete it was submitted to the grant committee who expeditiously reviewed the application and awarded her the grant. It took less than a week to be approved for the funds."
The first recipients of the Mid-Shore LOVE Down Payment Grant were Melissa Crews and Liam Mayo, who purchased a house in Hurlock, and they said having the extra funds helped them make repairs and paint.
The $1,000 grant does not have to be repaid and gives homeowners extra cash to fix the house up and make it their own. Crews and Mayo were grateful to Mid-Shore Board of Realtors, saying every dollar saved really helps.
The grants have benefited a police officer, a school bus driver, and administrative and trades employees. Of the 15 grants, five have gone to new homeowners in Dorchester County, four in Caroline County, and three to both Queen Anne's and Talbot Counties.
Mid-Shore LOVE Down Payment grant is for those working and also buying a primary residence in Caroline, Dorchester, Kent, Queen Anne's or Talbot counties. The income limit is based on the USDA amounts. The applicant's buyer's agent or the seller's agent must be a Realtor with MSBR. Additional information can be found on the Mid-Shore Board website at midshoreboardofrealtors.com.
To continue providing grants, Mid-Shore Board of Realtors is holding a golf tournament fundraiser on Tuesday, May 14, at Hog Neck Golf Course in Easton.
Registration is at 8 a.m. and tee off time is 9 a.m. Diemon's BBQ will be providing lunch, and participants can enter to win raffle prizes or the 50/50.
"We are excited to hold this spring fundraiser and are actively seeking golfers and sponsors so MSBR can provide additional grants to even more homeowners," Roney said.
To sponsor or register to play, visit midshoreboardofrealtors.com. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: A business built on kindness
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
A business built on kindness

 March 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Business 
 
 662
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Araceli Castillo, owner of Castillo's Cleaning, has built a business based on the kindness she receives from her clients. Castillo said that the community of Oxford motivated her to begin her own business and build a better future for her daughters.Originally from Puebla, Mexico, Castillo said the poverty of her hometown made it difficult for her family to sustain themselves. She came to the Eastern Shore with her husband and three daughters 15 years ago. Everything about the experience was challenging, Castillo said.
She didn't know the language, didn't know how to drive and had difficulties getting accustomed to the culture of her area.
"It wasn't easy to start new," Castillo said. "If you don't have family in the area, it's hard to find a place to live, and it's hard to find work."
Yet, she said, the kindness she experienced living in Oxford pushed her to where she is now. Castillo is a business owner who provides for her family and is a gracious member of the Eastern Shore community.
The first act of kindness she received was when she was hired to clean a woman's house, and she gifted Castillo a vacuum cleaner. Owning her own equipment gave her independence and the possibility of doing better work and earning more money.
Castillo laughs when she remembers how she would carry that vacuum from job to job because she couldn't drive.
Many clients would pick her up from her home and drop her off. Those were kindnesses she appreciated daily. When there wasn't a client to do so, Castillo would walk home or wait until evening for her husband to finish work to come pick her up.
She said she remembers one client fondly. After finishing cleaning a woman's house, the client was so impressed that she made a deal with Castillo: "Get a business license, and I will give you a car."
"That was the best experience for me," Castillo said. "There are good people, there are people who notice when you work hard and appreciate seeing your efforts and your potential."
That same client gave Castillo advice: "Clean my house the same way you would clean your own. Clean it the way you want someone to care for your home."
Castillo said she carries that advice with her in every home she cleans.
"I clean with love and care," Castillo said. "I think that you need to love your job to have results that you would be proud of because if you don't have love in your work, it shows. When I leave a home, I leave with the satisfaction that I left the place the best way I possibly could and leave it in the most impeccable shape possible, so my client could feel it too."
The kindness continued to pour in for Castillo and her family.
Clients would refer their friends and family to her business, and at one point, a client rented out an apartment to her family so they could live more comfortably.
At the time, Castillo and her family lived in one room of a home they shared with many other people. Their new home allowed each of their daughters to have their own room, and they stayed there until they could buy a home of their own.
Castillo's daughter, Leslie Rodriguez Castillo, works managing the business. She said she has been helping her mother with her business since she was a child. Rodriguez Castillo handles communication between clients, works as a dispatcher, creates schedules and handles billing and invoices.
"Seeing where she is right now, I always look back, and I'm so grateful for how motivated she's been throughout the years," Leslie Rodriguez Castillo said. "She has learned a lot, and I have learned a lot through her clients and through her."
Castillo continues to work hard every day and is grateful for the blessings in her life.
"My life changed when I moved to the United States," Castillo said. "If you have drive and work hard to move forward, then it's possible to accomplish anything. It's the American dream." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Chesapeake Bloom: Healing and building through flowers
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Chesapeake Bloom: Healing and building through flowers

 March 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Local News 
 
 575
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — On Friday evening, Dede Hoopes, owner of Chesapeake Bloom, a full-service floral design studio in historic downtown Easton, hosted a flower bar.The shop welcomed residents to come by and learn how to build bouquets to celebrate International Women's Day.
Women poured in with friends, mothers and sisters. Each had a vase in hand and carefully reviewed the bundles of flowers they had to create their bouquets.
Hoopes said gardening and flowers have healed and changed her life. She seeks to bring that same joy to the people of the Eastern Shore.
This was not where she thought her life was heading. In 2015, Hoopes had a career in human resources. Due to health challenges, she turned to gardening and flowers to help her heal.
She decided that she wanted to be a flower farmer, and she shared her dream with her family.
"It seemed far-fetched at the time, but it was my husband who said I should follow my dreams — he was all in," Hoopes said. "We moved and built our flower farm in Oxford. My daughters asked me why I didn't do this when they were younger. They were so excited."
She left her career in human resources. The Hoopes built a house on a quarter acre dedicated to her flower farm, which she named Oopsy Daisy Farm.
Through her interest in flowers, she met Samantha McCall, a fellow garden enthusiast, floral designer and her soon-to-be business partner and dear friend. They began sharing their dreams of opening their shop and made moves to make it happen. Hoopes said it happened quickly. It was an idea in December, and by March, they were in business.
Together, they shared their love for fresh, local and specialty flowers with the Eastern Shore. Their business grew, and even through the pandemic, they adapted by delivering hand-tied bouquets curbside to customers and avoided supply chain issues by growing local flowers.
Due to health issues, McCall had to step away from the business in 2021. McCall and Hoopes remain best friends and are a support system for each other.
Today, Chesapeake Bloom is in its fifth year of thriving. Hoopes said Chesapeake Bloom is an all-women business operated by five flower enthusiasts.
"I feel lucky to work with such motivated, smart and hardworking ladies here," said Madeline Poe, floral designer for Chesapeake Bloom. "We have a great team. … This job really has been a blessing because this is where I feel at home."
During the flower bar on Friday, Poe guided attendees to create unique and beautiful bouquets. Working alongside Pam Keeton, co-worker and master gardener, they trimmed and cut fresh flowers for attendees.
"It's a cheerful place," Keeton said. "It's a great way to meet like-minded people. We all like to garden. Most of us are into conservation and horticulture."
Hoopes said she is proud of her team and business and believes that if women want to open their own businesses, they should do so with faith in themselves. Hoopes said that women tend to be hesitant to take on challenges or changes, but if they don't try, they will never succeed.
"This is a second act for me, and I absolutely love it," Hoopes said. "I have two daughters, and if I could tell them to do it, I would say to do it. I would say go have your own business because I love it. It challenges you every day, every aspect of it at the same time. I don't think I would do anything different." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the establishment, growth, and community impact of Chesapeake Bloom, a local floral business. It highlights entrepreneurial efforts, business challenges, and the owner's transition from a corporate career to running a flower farm, aligning most directly with 'Business/Economy.' The local community angle and artistic aspects of floral design also connect to 'Local Life' and 'Arts & Culture,' but the core narrative centers on business operations and economic activity.

title: Inflation: Higher prices for car insurance, beer, housing, fabric, baby formula
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Newspapers
content:
Inflation: Higher prices for car insurance, beer, housing, fabric, baby formula

 March 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Newspapers | Section: Business 
 
 442
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Inflation was up 3.2% in February compared to a year ago with higher prices for housing, car insurance, dining and items such as beer, baby formula, sew machines and fabric.Prices for consumer goods, items such as insurance and staples including food and housing are up 20% from before the COVID pandemic and its shutdowns and massive spending and monetary measures.
U.S. prices are up 18.6% since January 2021 when President Joe Biden took office.
The Consumer Price Index for February shows higher prices across the U.S. as voters continue to have consternation over their personal finances and the economy.
Housing helped drive the overall 3.2% CPI inflation rate with a 5.7% increase in costs from Feb. 2023.
Rents are up 5.8% as affordable housing continues to be a problem for many households across the country.
Higher prices are also showing up in spending areas across the economy creating reelection challenges for Biden in his rematch with former president Donald Trump.
Car insurance rates are up a whopping 20.6% compared a year ago, according to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics.
Prices for food at restaurants are up 4.5% with the industry facing continued labor shortages, higher prices for food, alcoholic beverages and equipment and increased financing costs and debt loads stemming from Federal Reserve interest rate hikes to tackle inflation.
Baby formula and baby food have jumped 8.8%.
Tuition for day care and preschools are 5.5% more expansive than 12 months ago.
Sewing machines are fabric prices have increased 11% since last February. Those increase have been seen with patterns, equipment and fabric and comes as JoAnn's Fabric, a major retailer in the space, has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.
Tax service providers have hiked their prices by 9.8% over the past year.
Cameras and photo equipment are 9% more expensive
Beer prices are up 4.1%.The beer market has seen some upheavals with the higher prices impacting consumer decisions and the growth in popularity of brands such as Yuengling and Modelo.
Bud Light is still the top U.S. beer brand but was its popularity negatively impacted after a social media ad featuring transgender influencer Dylan Mulvaney and an Anheuser-Busch marketing executive deriding the brand's customer base as 'too fratty.'
Higher grocery prices have eased some from their inflation wave highs but are still up 2.2% from a year ago. Smartphone prices are down 10.5% from a year ago, according to BLS.
Public opinion polls show voters rank inflation and the economy among their top concerns. That comes despite Biden, Democrats and media acolytes touting some strong macro-economic figures.
U.S. prices rose 7.7% during Trump's term in office (2017-2021), according to BLS. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on inflation trends, rising prices for consumer goods, and economic indicators like the Consumer Price Index, all central to Business/Economy. While it touches on national implications, the core content is economic data rather than news events or public announcements.

title: New owner hopes to be a 'steward' of Robert Morris Inn's history
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
New owner hopes to be a 'steward' of Robert Morris Inn's history

 March 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Business 
 
 577
 Words 

 Read News Document

 OXFORD — The owner of the historic Robert Morris Inn, which overlooks the Tred Avon River, has big dreams for this Oxford landmark.Part of creating owner David Snyder's dream is picking a great team. He chose veterans Gretchen Gordon and chef Sean Raspberry to help him implement a new menu and oversee renovations in the 16-room inn.
"Instead of watching all the cars go across to St. Michaels, we want to watch them coming across to come here, and this will be great for the town," Gordon said. "We will be open seven days a week."
By early April, the plan is to offer three meals a day.
The restaurant is called Financier. The offerings — like crispy ginger fried oysters, lamb sliders and tandoori chicken skewers — let you know this isn't some backwater joint. They want this to be a destination.
Snyder, who was a history major, read a lot about Robert Morris.
"The history of this property is unbelievable," Snyder said. "I still can't believe that I am associated with it."
The name of the restaurant comes from Morris' role as a financier during the American Revolution. He lived at the inn for three years and was a confidante of George Washington.
To capitalize on that notoriaty, Snyder wants to create Robert Morris beer along with bourbon and wine. He is balancing between celebrating what is historic and expanding and reenvisioning what is possible for future growth.
Some of the entrees speak to the wide-ranging palate of Chef Raspberry, who has cooked at The Inn at Perry Cabin, Out of the Fire and General Tanuki's. Asian-style crispy duck, cornmeal dusted crispy fried whole snapper and chimichurri marinated braised short rib enchalladas all make the choice difficult.
"I have been cooking for 40 years," Raspberry said. "(My food says) 'I am here. Come see me.' Me and general manager Gretchen, we were bound to meet, bottom line. It is a match made in heaven. I want to do 150 plates a day."
"I am excited about the whole menu," he said.
They have a plan to get into catering. Snyder said he would love to do weddings on site too.
The menu at the Inn is "Southwest meets the Chesapeake Bay," Gordon, who used to run Latitude 38 in Oxford and sold it, said. "This chef's flavors are right up there at the top."
Once they get that established, they will open for lunch and eventually create a breakfast and coffee bar.
Their goal is to convert an outdoor space behind the inn into a beer garden with views of the Strand and the Oxford Ferry. Snyder wants to get permission from the Historic District Commission to make these changes.
He employs around 20 people already. He has worked back of the house and front of the house, but his focus will be on building the brand and finding new opportunities for this property.
Snyder wants to convert the parking lot in the back of the Inn into permeable space like grass for people to play lawn games. Eventually, permits allowing, he wants to put a pool and putting green in the back and have yoga classes up on the roof.
"We can turn this back into the 'River View House,' and it will have views again," he said.
With all these plans, he remains aware that he has invested in something built in the 1700s.
"I want to bring it up and improve it in ways that future generations can use it," he said. "Just being a steward of that is incredible." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the business transformation of a historic inn, including menu development, renovations, expansion plans, and branding efforts. While historical aspects are mentioned, the primary context is entrepreneurial activity and economic development.

title: Price of gas in state jumps 16 cents in week
author: Staff Writer
content:
Price of gas in state jumps 16 cents in week

 March 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: State News 
 
 504
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Average gasoline prices in Maryland have risen 16.6 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.50 per gallon on Monday, according to GasBuddy's survey of 2,167 stations in Maryland. Prices in Maryland are 12.5 cents per gallon higher than a month ago and stand 21.9 cents per gallon higher than a year ago. The national average price of diesel has declined 2.2 cents in the last week and stands at $4 per gallon.According to GasBuddy price reports, the cheapest station in Maryland was priced at $2.49 per gallon on Sunday while the most expensive was $4.58 per gallon, a difference of $2.09 per gallon.The national average price of gasoline has risen 4.4 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.44 per gallon on Monday. The national average is up 18.7 cents per gallon from a month ago and stands 1.6 cents per gallon higher than a year ago, according to GasBuddy data compiled from more than 11 million weekly price reports covering over 150,000 gas stations across the country.
Historical gasoline prices in Maryland and the national average going back 10 years:
March 18, 2023: $3.28 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.43 per gallon)
March 18, 2022: $4.13 per gallon (U.S. Average: $4.27 per gallon)
March 18, 2021: $2.84 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.87per gallon)
March 18, 2020: $2.21 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.16 per gallon)
March 18, 2019: $2.57 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.56 per gallon)
March 18, 2018: $2.55 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.54/g)
March 18, 2017: $2.30 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.29 per gallon)
March 18, 2016: $1.98 per gallon (U.S. Average: $1.98 per gallon)
March 18, 2015: $2.42 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.42 per gallon)
March 18, 2014: $3.52 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.52 per gallon)
Neighboring areas and their current gas prices:
Baltimore- $3.50 per gallon, up 19.3 cents per gallon from last week's $3.30 per gallon.
Washington DC- $3.57 per gallon, up 8.9 cents per gallon from last week's $3.48 per gallon.
Hagerstown- $3.47 per gallon, up 11.3 cents per gallon from last week's $3.36 per gallon.
"Most Americans continued to see average gasoline prices march higher last week. The reason is the season: gasoline demand is rising as more Americans are getting out, combined with the summer gasoline switchover, which is well underway, and continued refinery maintenance," said Patrick De Haan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy.
He added: "The madness should slow down in the next few weeks as we've seen positive data that refinery output is starting to increase, a sign that the peak of maintenance season could be behind us."
In some positive news for Midwest motorists, the BP refinery in Whiting, Indiana, that can process 440,000 barrels of oil per day, is finally back to normal operations for the first time since an electrical failure happened in early February. For now, gas prices will likely continue to trend higher, but the fever may break soon. When it comes to diesel, the news has been good — above average temperatures have lowered heating oil demand, and average diesel prices are on the cusp of falling back below $4 per gallon." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Kent County raises economic concerns over one-fish limit on charter boats
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Kent County raises economic concerns over one-fish limit on charter boats

 March 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 642
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — Owners of charter boats in Kent County all seem to agree — a single-limit fish-per-person rule is going to hurt their business, especially when striped bass, rockfish, season begins May 16.During summer season, the rockfish size and limit will be 19 inches to 24 inches, and each person can keep one rockfish, new regulations state.
That might discourage clients from booking trips on charter boats, especially for a trip that costs almost $600 for a half day, say opponents of the limit.
The Kent County Commissioners recently sent a letter siding with the charter boat captains to Josh Kurtz, secretary of Natural Resources.
The letter expressed the county is opposed to the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission Addendum II to Amendment 7 of the Interstate Fishery Management Plan for striped bass.
"We are frustrated with the one-fish bag limit, the increased slot limit and all the restricted season dates which will negatively affect the Charter Boat industry," the letter states.
Commission President Ron Fithian composed the letter after attending a Feb. 17 meeting in Easton, alongside Kent County Director of Economic and Tourism Development Jamie Williams.
There, charter boat operators were joined by commercial fishermen to air grievances about proposed restrictions on catching striped bass in the Chesapeake Bay.
Rob Newberry, Delmarva Fisheries Association chairman, said at that meeting, "We've got to put a stop to this," referencing the overregulation commercial watermen are experiencing.
Fithian too expressed his concern over the matter on Tuesday, March 5, at the commission's weekly meeting, informing the public about the letter.
He restated how much the fishing industry means to the area.
"In 2022, we had $72 million dollars in visitor spending, so this is very detrimental to Kent County. This is going to affect the lodging, restaurants...any and all of them."
He added with a population of 13,000 full-time residents, they have about 1,500 boat slips, which turn into second homes for lodging.
Quite frankly, he said, it's going to be a "gut punch" to the county.
Already he knows of one group who schedules ten trips a year who have cancelled after learning of the policy in effect.
Williams, also at the meeting, has become more educated in the manner, since it will affect what she sees as well. She talked about how a one-limit catch rule will result in more catch-and-release, which will create more dead fish on the shores.
"It doesn't make common sense when you follow it down the line," Williams said.
At the public portion of the meeting, Newberry provided his statements. And like Fithian, gave an example of paying clients disenchanted with the idea of the one-catch policy.
He said a party from Talbot County normally rents a room 12 times a year to fish. They stay from Thursday until Saturday night and head home the next day. They cancelled all trips this year. That, he pointed out, is about $3,000 a night lost.
Newberry is not optimistic about the Department of Natural Resources' help either.
"The Department has showed no willing move to put forward to the charter boat industry to right this wrong."
He added when they reached out to Kurtz, they only received an effort on his part to ensure the captain and his mate each get a fish for themselves.
Unfortunately, with the regulations becoming more strict, Newberry told to the commissioners some people won't cooperate with the DNR any longer.
They might decide to not electronically report any fish caught.
The commissioners had no comment about that.
Fithian just wanted it to be made public their stance on this policy.
"We're speaking out against it and hoping something will get done down the road."
The position of DNR and ASMFC is that these emergency actions are needed, and the tighter striped bass fishing regulations are in response to ongoing population decline and rock-bottom reproduction.
In October 2023, according to the DNR, the results of the annual juvenile striped bass survey found the worst recruitment in Maryland since 1957. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on economic impacts of fishing regulations on charter boat businesses, local tourism, and related industries. While local government actions are mentioned, the core issue is the business/economic disruption caused by the one-fish limit policy.
