title: Cambridge is 1 of 6 picked for NPS Chesapeake Gateways pilot
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Cambridge is 1 of 6 picked for NPS Chesapeake Gateways pilot

 March 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 550
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Cambridge is one of six communities along the Chesapeake Bay that is taking part in the National Park Service Chesapeake Gateways Communities Initiative pilot.During the 78th Annual Dorchester Chamber of Commerce Business Meeting and Dinner Thursday night at the Hyatt Regency Chesapeake Bay, NPS Chesapeake Gateways Superintendent Wendy O'Sullivan spoke about the initiative and what it could bring to Cambridge and Dorchester County.
The initiative is intended to bring leaders of gateway communities — or small towns and cities outside of significant nature areas — together to connect nature-based and cultural tourism to economic initiatives, according to NPS.
O'Sullivan, the keynote speaker of the event, said that in May, NPS Chesapeake Gateways will host the first Chesapeake Gateways Communities Initiative pilot workshop with those six communities from around the Bay.
"There is no question in my mind and in my heart that Cambridge would be part of our first cohort of towns," she said.
O'Sullivan made it clear throughout her speech that Cambridge has a special place in her heart.
During a conference in Cambridge 16 years ago, her and her NPS mentor, Brian O'Neill, snuck out to explore the county, she told the audience. That experience, she said, changed the arc of her career.
"Over crabs at the Odyssey, a spark of an idea came forward," O'Sullivan said, remembering a trip to Ocean Odyssey Crab House and Seafood Restaurant.
That idea: For NPS to partner with business leaders and community members to "bring the principals of well-known, successful gateway communities from around the country here to the Chesapeake region," O'Sullivan said.
With this pilot, that idea is becoming a reality.
"I am thrilled to share that NPS Chesapeake Gateways is poised to take the next step in our 25-year journey of partnerships to begin to work at a whole-community scale," O'Sullivan said.
NPS Chesapeake Gateways has rebuilt its team so that it can lean into its ability to work with the private sector. That authority, O'Sullivan said, hasn't been utilized in 25 years.
Along with tapping into its authority to work with the private sector, NPS Chesapeake Gateways has revived its grants and technical assistance, and it has reactivated the Chesapeake Gateways Visitor Experience Network. The network offers opportunities and benefits to sites and places that join.
Dorchester Chamber of Commerce member Joel Bunde will lead Cambridge's team for the Chesapeake Gateways Communities Initiative pilot. The Cambridge team will be part of a cohort that tests and refines the gateways community training and helps build this initiative, O'Sullivan said.
During her speech, O'Sullivan said gateway communities "embrace and leverage" the outdoor economy.
"Capitalizing on their natural assets to stimulate new businesses (and) economic growth," she said. "Which, in turn, enhances the overall well-being of their communities."
After O'Sullivan's speech, Dorchester Chamber of Commerce President Bill Christopher called the initiative a "game changer."
"We think it's going to be a great program for us and potential for the community to make a huge difference," he said to the audience.
In an interview, Cambridge Waterfront Development Inc. Executive Director Matt Leonard said the initiative will "absolutely" complement the Cambridge Harbor project, CWDI's project to develop the space along the Choptank River.
Leonard said CWDI will be part of the Cambridge team for the pilot.
"We just think it's a tremendous opportunity for the local community and we're really proud to be a part of it," he said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the National Park Service's Chesapeake Gateways initiative, which aims to connect nature-based tourism with economic development through community partnerships. Key themes include economic growth, business collaboration, and leveraging natural assets for local economic opportunities, aligning most directly with 'Business/Economy.' The 'Environment' topic is also relevant due to the Chesapeake Bay context, but the primary emphasis is on economic initiatives.

title: Bee-ing grateful: Store owner embraces gratitude at Bee Crafty Collectibles
author: LISA J. GOTTO Special to the Star Democrat
content:
Bee-ing grateful: Store owner embraces gratitude at Bee Crafty Collectibles

 March 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LISA J. GOTTO Special to the Star Democrat | Section: Business 
 
 635
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — Kent County is the home of many well-established, women-owned businesses, all bringing unique offerings and services to the community at-large through their specific enterprises.One woman in particular is approaching her eighth year in business as the owner of a gift and upcycled furnishings store at 335 High Street.
Along with her talents for merchandise mixing and furniture rehabilitation, Helen Cowley brought a fierce sense of resolve to her store, Bee Crafty Collectibles, after a chronic arthritic illness nearly sidelined her working life.
The experience would be transformative for Cowley, who worked in office management prior to opening her own business.
After 15 years of battling debilitating pain in her feet and ankles that began in her 50s, Cowley came up with the concept for her store between the two surgeries that would ultimately address the underlying arthritic condition in her feet.
A long, painful road was walked prior to that, however, as years of doctors' visits and various medications did little to address life with her debilitating condition.
"It was stopping me from doing a lot of things because I couldn't walk for long periods. I just sat around, and I was in pain constantly," she said.
It was around this time when, Cowley said, her daughter, who is a researcher, told her about an unconventional pain treatment called apitherapy.
"At this point, I felt I had nothing to lose," she said, of the treatment that uses live bee venom as an anti-inflammatory agent. Cowley said she found she could purchase bees for this purpose, and she began the process of "stinging with bees."
Fortunately, it wasn't long before Cowley began to experience results.
"After getting the bees and using them for just a few days, I had relief," she said.
The break in the pain allowed Cowley's creativity to flourish and enhanced her ability to focus. She began the process of educating herself on the art of furniture restoration and began working out of her house to find new homes for old, but reimagined furnishings between the two years where she would have the surgeries to address her pain in both feet.
Cowley thrived. However, she couldn't help but develop a sense of profound gratitude for the bees that helped her to do so.
It was a bittersweet thing, she said, knowing what would happen to the bee once it treated her, as a bee does die after it stings.
She knew she wanted to do something that would pay homage to her friends, the bees. And so, when she was able to get her upcycled furniture business going, she did just that.
"They gave up their lives for me, so I named my store after them."
Today, Bee Crafty Collectibles is command central for all the upcycled projects she creates and a plethora of other home goods and gifts. Cowley said her regular customers know that 335 High Street is where they can go to purchase signature items like humorous message signs, Fisher's Popcorn, Foozie socks and Route 1-brand merchandise.
"Everyone loves Maryland and the flag," she said, of her popular Maryland-centric merchandise.
While Cowley is currently getting ready for Easter with a 15 percent-off sale on all Easter basket stuffers this weekend, she admits her biggest vertical is all the bee-related items in the store, including bee-themed jewelry, plushies, kitchen wares and, of course, local sweet honey.
This was all part of her plan to create not just a store, but something experiential. And she does a great job at that, too.
"I like to be involved with things that are going on in town," she said. People shouldn't be surprised to see her in a bee get-up or any number of the fun costumes she dons to help promote the town's famous festivals and events.
"One of my customers once said, 'This is a shopping experience in here," she said.
To readers, Cowley said, "Come experience it for yourself!" 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Helen Cowley's entrepreneurial journey as the owner of Bee Crafty Collectibles, detailing her business model, product offerings, and community engagement. While health aspects (apitherapy) are mentioned, they serve as background to her business story. The primary emphasis is on her commercial enterprise and economic activities.

title: DoCo Axe Co. aims to support community
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
DoCo Axe Co. aims to support community

 March 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Business 
 
 711
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — For DoCo Axe Co. co-owner Sabrina Franciotti, the business is about more than having fun.Although DoCo Axe Co. offers fun in multiple forms — from virtual reality escape room adventures to a virtual golf simulator to virtually-projected axe throwing games — Franciotti said the local business is also a great place to practice healthy coping mechanisms.
"Coming to a place like us is actually super beneficial to your mental wellness," Franciotti said. "Being around other people doing this activity that we coach you through, we can help you with. ... It's cathartic to sink the axe in the wood."
Franciotti, along with Rob Chase and her husband Carmen Franciotti, took over the business in December 2022.
Along with offering a place for people to practice healthy coping, DoCo Axe Co. wants to help the community in other ways.
This year, the local business started naming a DoCo Axe DoGooder of the Month. Every month, people can nominate someone who is doing good in the community. Whoever wins the title that month receives $50 from DoCo Axe Co.
Franciotti herself is also working to do good in the Cambridge community and beyond. In 2022, she started a nonprofit called Homeless & Human, which works to advocate and resource share for people who are experiencing homelessness or on the verge of homelessness.
Franciotti understand that the resources available to those experiencing homelessness "far under-weigh the overwhelming needs." For years, she experienced homelessness as a single mother with two kids and a full-time job.
Technically, Franciotti said, she is still homeless, living with her sister.
"Most people are struggling to find housing," she said. "Even well-employed people."
Owning DoCo Axe Co. has given Franciotti the opportunity to make more connections in the community and get the word out about her nonprofit.
"We have a donation box," she said about DoCo Axe Co. "We tell every single person who comes through the door what they're supporting is this."
Franciotti said that conversation is important because a lot of the business' clientele don't know about the needs of the homeless population.
"So we can have this opportunity to chat with people about how it's teachers and nurses and the person who's working at the grocery store ... (who) are struggling to find housing and just survive day to day."
Although DoCo Axe Co. has made itself a part of the community, it is facing multiple challenges as a local small business. Franciotti said the business is not currently making a profit.
The main challenges come from difficulties with staffing, a decrease in consumer spending and rising costs, from operating expenses to card processing fees, she said.
Franciotti said the problems DoCo Axe Co. is facing aren't unique in Cambridge. She said other local business owners she has spoken with are facing similar challenges.
Dorchester Chamber of Commerce President Bill Christopher said finding staffing is one of the biggest challenges local businesses are currently facing.
The reason for this challenge includes a decrease in the workforce during the COVID-19 pandemic, an increase in people retiring early and even a lack of childcare options.
Christopher said that even if a person can find childcare, the cost can be so expensive that it doesn't make sense to work and pay for childcare.
Christopher also said the expectations for people who are graduating school and entering the workforce aren't "level-set with what the economy needs."
"So we've got to attack all three of these things to get the (staffing) problem solved," he said.
Promoting a business and the cost of running a business are two other major challenges local businesses face.
"The dollars and cents," Christopher said. "Because if you find the staff, can you afford them?"
There are multiple ways that people can support DoCo Axe Co. — and not just with a wallet.
Franciotti said learning about the business, having conversations about it, sharing and interacting with social media posts and even clicking on the website to boost its search engine optimization can all benefit DoCo Axe Co.
And for those that have the means to support businesses with their wallet, Christopher said a dollar spent locally goes far in the community.
"You go to DoCo Axe and you spend that dollar, they're going to then use that dollar to pay for other things in the community, so it stays here," he said. "That's the key. Rising tides raise all boats." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on DoCo Axe Co., a local business discussing its community initiatives, challenges like staffing and costs, and economic impact. While it mentions mental wellness and community support, the core subject is business operations and local economic challenges.

title: Talbot County Council approves Hog Neck Golf Course renovation
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Talbot County Council approves Hog Neck Golf Course renovation

 March 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Local News 
 
 454
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Talbot County Council's Thursday evening to discussion of the county's enterprise funds budgets for the upcoming fiscal year included a lengthy talk about the renovations of the Hog Neck Golf Course.Richard Settler, general manager at Hog Neck Golf Course, came to the council with a plan for the future of this golf course.
The plan includes improvements such as driving range enhancements, venue operations and a new kitchen so the golf course can generate significantly higher revenues in the future.
Settler focused on the need for funds for kitchen improvements. This project would require $405,000, including items like a flat-top grill, oven, fryer and hood unit.
Settler provided financial projections to the council, showing that with the new projects, revenues could increase to around $3 million annually once the new facilities are open and fully operational.
The goal, Settler said, would be for the golf course, which is owned and operated by the county, to become more financially self-sufficient over time and generate enough revenue to pay for its capital projects and operations without needing as much subsidy from the Talbot County general fund.
"We're basically creating a whole new business," said Settler of the golf course's renovations, many of which are already underway.
Including Settler's $405,000 ask, the project will cost about $2.3 million.
Council members Lynn Mielke and Dave Stepp supported the changes to the golf course.
"I'm the only one that has seen one of these driving ranges and how popular and successful it is," Mielke said. "That makes an impact on me in terms of my view on proceeding on this and making an investment."
Council members Chuck Callahan, Keasha Haythe and Pete Lesher were more hesitant about investing further into the project.
Haythe said it was essential to treat this as a new business and take a more conservative approach to the revenue produced during its first fiscal year. Funds have already been provided for other capital projects, like the driving range enhancements.
Callahan suggested that they wait a bit longer before approving the decision. Haythe and Lesher agreed with this statement.
"It's a business decision that we have to make with the taxpayers' money," Callahan said. "I would feel a bit more comfortable waiting to see."
Stepp and Mielke protested.
"My theory on this is if we're going to do it, let's do it right," Stepp said. "Let's get everything in place because we're going to have an opportunity here for a lot of first impressions."
Settler stressed that revenue would drastically decrease if the business were unable to sell hot food, which ultimately changed the minds of Callahan, Haythe and Lesher. The council approved fully funding the kitchen improvements at the golf course.
Settler said they hope to complete kitchen renovations before the "true grand opening" in May 2024. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on financial projections, revenue generation, and business planning for the Hog Neck Golf Course renovation, which aligns with Business/Economy. While the Talbot County Council's involvement relates to Local Government, the core content centers on economic development and operational business strategies.

title: Best of Caroline County business awarded at annual celebration
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
Best of Caroline County business awarded at annual celebration

 March 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Local News 
 
 575
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Danielle Forrest, who is assistant branch manager at Shore United Bank, was named the Caroline County Chamber of Commerce's Citizen of the Year before a crowd of about 160 Wednesday night."I think I was nominated because of my financial literacy classes that I go out and teach. I take any opportunity to go out in the community and share," Forrest said.
She highlighted the connections she has made through the chamber with church members, nonprofits and businesses to help her to get out and teach her classes.
But Forrest was not the only member of her family who was recognized at the Caroline County Best in Business Awards.
In perhaps a first, Forrest's sister also won an award that night — the Rising Star award.
"I wish everyone could have won an award. Everyone deserved it — they all work so hard," said Michelle Dahlman, Forrest's sister and owner of Shore Love Cleaning Service. "(Chamber Executive Director) Tracey (Snyder) does so much hard work for all the members. The moment I joined, I felt like family. I always have someone cheering me on. It has opened up so many possibilities."
The sisters were among nine representatives from the local business community who received awards and citations from Sen. Chris Van Hollen at the annual celebration, which was held amid the Celtic splendor of the Market Street Public House in Denton.
It was a packed house of community leaders who had a buffet dinner provided by the pub. There was a wine raffle that benefited the Caroline County Chamber of Commerce's Scholarship Fund.
"We share what great things our businesses are doing in our chamber and our community," Snyder said. "What makes this county great is what all these businesses do to cheer each other on."
Chamber Vice President David Harper came up to the podium.
"Entrepreneurs are the backbone of our community. Somebody with a good idea and a strong work ethic changes the lives in the community and maybe even the world a little bit," he said.
There was anticipation in the room, as there were several businesses nominated in each category. Ultimately when a winner was announced the whole room gave them recognition with applause.
Best nonprofit went to CASA of Caroline, and Amy Horne, executive director, received the award.
"We represent one of the most vulnerable populations in our county. These are young children who don't have resources. The chamber has really allowed us to grow and expand," said Horne.
The Excellence in Agriculture Award went to Clayton Farms. Eileen Simmons spoke for co-owners Sean Rizer and her husband Kenny Simmons.
"We are a small community and we are all winners. If we don't have it, we will send them your way. We are third generation and have three daughters next," Simmons said.
Business leader of the year award went to Realtor Kathleen Brenton.
"I want to say thank you, thank you, thank you. I look around this room and see a whole bunch of people that deserve this award just as much, if not more than me. I am in shock. I am a strong believer in this community," Brenton said.
Tenchi Spanish American Kitchen won business of the year.
Recognizing these businesses' work is part of the Chamber of Commerce's bread and butter, said new Chamber President Laura Reeder.
"Helping our businesses grow and thrive is what our chamber is all about," Reeder said. "Our goal this year is to increase the number of member to member connections. We have some wonderful people in this county." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on local business awards, community business recognition, and chamber of commerce activities, directly aligning with 'Business/Economy.' While 'Local Government' and 'Local Life' are tangentially related, the primary emphasis is on business achievements and economic community efforts.

title: Flying Decoy in Rock Hall rises from ashes of January fire
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Flying Decoy in Rock Hall rises from ashes of January fire

 March 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Business 
 
 564
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ROCK HALL — With a limited handful of dining options in Kent County, the Flying Decoy Bar and Grill is open for business on Main Street in the former Bay Wharf building.Since its opening at the beginning of March, chef and owner Chris Golder said they served about 400 people.
And it's been receiving good reviews, employee Dayna Price said.
Golder described the cuisine as "elevated casual," meaning some familiar favorites from the Eastern Shore, served with a twist.
For example, a few weeks back they ran a rock fish special, a favorite, but with a tantalizing orange-basil butter sauce included.
In Rock Hall, there are some great dining options already. But what sets the Flying Decoy Bar and Grill apart is it is chef-driven, Golder said. Along with a small, reliable staff, Golder said he's thankful for, he'll be cooking most of the time.
And he's happy to be running it, focusing on cleanliness, service and fresh food from local sources when available.
As the former chef at the 98 Cannon Riverfront Grille in Chestertown, which shuttered its doors due to a fire, he's had to face uncertainty and setbacks to get back to what he enjoys.
That fire changed things for Golder.
It occurred Jan. 12, caused by an electrical or mechanical failure within the ice maker or the electrical system energizing the component.
About 60 firefighters from Chestertown and surrounding areas responded and brought the flames under control in two hours.
But the smoke hovering above the waterfront signaled the beginning of the end for the popular restaurant.
There were some efforts to keep it going. The summer after the fire, Golder was running a food truck from the patio, hoping to reopen.
That fell through, and with very few restaurants hiring, what was a chef with over 40 years experience to do?
The location in Rock Hall was a fortunate find.
Not only did The Flying Decoy allow Golder to stay at his residence in Chestertown, but they offer great dishes, benefitting folks on the Eastern Shore.
With a focus on resourcing from local farmers, producers and watermen, he calls for only the freshest ingredients to put on the plate.
Blue catfish served creole style is on the menu.
Burgers and ribeye are Rosetta beef, a consistent brand of beef, known for quality. Shrimp with grits and jalapeno corn fritters and many other tantalizing dishes.
With plenty of space to accommodate 80-100 people a night and a nice selection of wine and craft beers to choose from, Golder invites the public to drop in.
As a low-key person, not one to wear his name badge on his jacket, his affection comes through in the food he prepares.
Golder has a willingness to teach as well. He's looking for staff, anyone who feels as he does, who gets a thrill of seeing people enjoy the food, who is willing to work hard.
The benefits: you learn from a certified chef who traveled the states, managing crews on yachts and restaurants and who understands the business side of the food industry.
The cons: you may have to clean out the grease trap every once in a while, Golder said.
Being a chef is not as glamorous as they make it look on reality television, he added.
But it's worth the effort to see his customers leave happy.
The Flying Decoy's located at 21270 Rock Hall Ave. Their hours are Monday through Saturday, 4 p.m. to 9 p.m. with plans to open up for lunch this month. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the reopening of a restaurant business after a fire, detailing operational aspects, local sourcing, and entrepreneurial challenges. While mentions of local community and agriculture are present, the core subject is the business venture and its economic implications.

title: Gluten-Free Bakery Girl rises to the challenge
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Gluten-Free Bakery Girl rises to the challenge

 March 31, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Business 
 
 628
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — It began as a challenge for an already established cook.Tricia King, owner of Gluten-Free Bakery Girl, said that during her time as a personal chef, she had a client with rheumatoid arthritis who needed to avoid gluten in her diet. King undertook the task of creating tasty gluten-free recipes.
Now, about 20 years later, she is the owner of Gluten-Free Bakery Girl, an entirely gluten-free bakery on the Eastern Shore.
King centers the health and well-being of her customers in everything she does, and that includes making sure all her baked goods are not only safe but also a delight to eat.
The passion for tasty food has been a long love of King's. She has been cooking almost all her life, and even when she wasn't cooking, she was studying and watching other cooks like Julia Child and her mother. She said that cooking just came naturally to her.
"When you have a passion for it, it's easy to do it," King said. "I've loved food my whole life."
After studying interior design, she decided to open a personal chef business in Salt Lake City, Utah, called Purple Pomegranate. For two years, she traveled from house to house every day, doing the shopping and cooking for two weeks and then repeating the same cycle with different clients.
Then, she had the opportunity to be a sous chef in a hotel in Scotland.
It was there that she dove into baking. When she came back to the States, she trained under pastry chef Matt Ratliff in the Perry Cabin.
The work was intense, King said. Daily, the kitchen would produce 40 souffles, bake bread and cookies, and make wedding cakes.
In the back of her mind, she still yearned to open her dream bakery. So, she began using the back kitchen to try different gluten-free desserts.
Before she made the leap to establish her bakery, she shared her dream with one of her friends, and he said, "Oh, it's never going to work. A gluten-free bakery?" She smiles, recollecting the memory and how he has since taken back his words.
Gluten-Free Bakery Girl has been in business in St. Michaels for 12 years and will be opening in a bigger location in Easton. Its products can be found throughout Maryland, Delaware, D.C., Massachusetts, New York and other states nationwide.
King said the vast majority of her customers have celiac disease, an immune reaction to eating gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley and rye. Due to this, it is of the utmost importance that there is no cross-contamination in her kitchen.
She operates in a 100% certified gluten-free facility and kitchen.
All products are individually wrapped to prevent any potential cross-contamination from other foods during shipping and sale, and all employees are only allowed to bring gluten-free food to work.
"People don't understand that you can't just bake in a kitchen and then wipe it down and then bake gluten-free," King said. "Twenty parts per million, which is a crumb of bread, is enough to make someone who has celiac disease sick."
More than anything, King wants to help people with celiac disease lead a more accessible and safer day-to-day life. King said her customers with celiac disease often feel that they need to miss out on treats for their health, but having the opportunity to provide people the chance to indulge in a baked good makes all the effort she puts in her bakery worth it.
King urges young girls thinking of starting a bakery or any business to have faith in themselves and allow themselves to grow outside their comfort zones.
"We women are the hardest on ourselves," King said. "We beat ourselves up the most. It puts blocks in front of us, but we have to know we can make it through. So, keep going. You have to keep going." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Tricia King's journey as a business owner establishing a gluten-free bakery, detailing her entrepreneurial efforts, business expansion, and operational strategies. While health (celiac disease) is a contextual factor, the primary narrative centers on her business venture, making 'Business/Economy' the best fit.

title: Tradepoint Atlantic will be essential to Key Bridge cleanup
author: Connor Bolinder connor.bolinder@chespub.com
content:
Tradepoint Atlantic will be essential to Key Bridge cleanup

 April 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connor Bolinder connor.bolinder@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 498
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Last weekend, demolition crews began to carefully remove the first pieces of the collapsed Francis Scott Key Bridge from the Patapsco River.A 200-ton portion of the bridge was cut away by demolition experts, hoisted out of the water with massive cranes, and floated away on a barge.
According to Gov. Wes Moore, this 200-ton segment was only a small, "bite-sized" piece of the wreckage. Thousands of tons of steel and concrete need to be removed from the Patapsco River after the devastating collapse of the Key Bridge last week when it was hit by a cargo ship. Estimates to clear the debris and reopen the shipping channel range from months to over a year, with a heavy emphasis on safety.
"I cannot stress enough how important today and the first movement of this bridge and of the wreckage is. This is going to be a remarkably complicated process," Moore said.
Central to the cleanup efforts is Tradepoint Atlantic, the Sparrows Point-based logistics center on the site of the old Bethlehem Steel mill. Located off Interstate 695, businesses at Tradepoint Atlantic depend almost entirely on the Key Bridge and the Port of Baltimore to move goods.
"I want to thank Tradepoint Atlantic," Moore said. "This human tragedy is also an economic catastrophe. In the early hours, it was Tradepoint who said 'Let us help.'"
Although the facility won't be able to take in most of the shipping traffic bound for the Port of Baltimore, it will act as a staging area for Unified Command to bring in heavy equipment like the Chesaepeake 1000, a crane capable of lifting 1000 tons. After a piece of the collapsed bridge is lifted and carried away, barges take it to Tradepoint for disposal.
"Generally when the debris is taken to the laydown yard at Tradepoint Atlantic at Sparrows Point, it will be inspected and secured until they find the final disposition for disposal in a safe manner," Army Corps of Engineers Col. Estee Pinchasin said.
With deep-water docks, railroad connections and plenty of heavy equipment, Tradepoint is in an ideal position to take away the debris. In fact, it has the only deep-water berths in the Chesapeake Bay that are still accessible.
"We will continue working with their team, and we are grateful for their support and grateful for their leadership," Moore said from a shipyard at Tradepoint.
Along with clearing the shipping channel to reopen the port, officials are trying to figure out how to rebuild the major bridge, which was completed in 1977.
"I know, right now everybody wants to see things moving," Pinchasin said. "You need to know and you need to trust that behind the scenes, it's moving."
Even as the demolition crews shift their focus to removing the debris, officials extended their sympathy and prayers to the families of the six victims.
"As our engineers are assessing and surveying and figuring out how they're going to lift those loads, they know in the back of their minds that they're also looking for any traces of the fallen." Pinchasin said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the economic impact of the bridge collapse, the role of Tradepoint Atlantic as a logistics hub, and the efforts to restore shipping operations. While public safety and infrastructure are mentioned, the primary emphasis is on the economic implications, business coordination, and trade logistics.

title: Fishery Association takes limit to court
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Fishery Association takes limit to court

 April 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 866
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GRASONVILLE — Chairman of Delmarva Fisheries Association Rob Newberry is opposing a single-limit fish-per-person rule set by the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission, or ASMFA, slated to take effect May 1. In an effort to protect the interests of those watermen he represents, he's taking the issue to court.Instead of allowing two rockfish per person as in times past, regulations state only one can be caught this year.
The new rules reduce the recreational catch limit on striped bass from two bass at 19 to 31 inches per person to one fish at 19 to 24 inches per person.
The position of DNR and ASMFC is that these emergency actions are needed, and the tighter striped bass fishing regulations are in response to ongoing population decline and rock-bottom reproduction.
In October 2023, according to the DNR, the results of the annual juvenile striped bass survey found the worst recruitment in Maryland since 1957.
The ASMFA argues the regulations will help reduce fishing-related mortality.
Newberry, a captain himself, said the measures will just hurt the fishing industry. And he's certainly not alone in this stance.
The Kent County Commission President Ron Fithian expressed his disapproval of the regulations during the commission's session on March 5.
"In 2022, we had $72 million in visitor spending, so this is very detrimental to Kent County. This is going to affect the lodging, restaurants...any and all of them," he said.
"Quite frankly, it's going to be a gut punch to the county. We're speaking out against it," Fithian said.
In an interview, Newberry, building on the commissioner's statements, said the regulations won't just affect the charter boat industry, but commercial and recreational fishermen throughout the entire state.
It prompted him, as well as commercial waterman Brian Nesspor; Brian Hardman, the president of the Maryland Charter Boat Association; and Kenneth Jeffries, vice president of the Upper Bay Charter Captains Association, to file a formal lawsuit challenging the ASMFC's mandate.
At Newberry's latest meeting Saturday, March 30, at the Grasonville VFW, he updated the roughly 100 in attendance on what happens next.
Hardman also spoke, as well as their attorney James Butera of Meeks, Butera and Israel.
Newberry lamented that he sent out invitations to all 146 legislators, as well as the governor and secretary of agriculture, inviting them to the meeting, but none showed up.
He also sent invitations out to all the Eastern Shore Delegates. Delegate Jay Jacobs and Maryland State Senator Stephen Hershey were in attendance.
However, there is statewide support for their case, Newberry noted, coming from The Maryland Rural County Coalition, who claims the one-fish policy will have an adverse affect on Maryland's economy.
The memorandum supporting Newberry's claims indicate they filed their complaint regarding "ASMFC's promulgation on January 24, 2024 of drastic and unwarranted limitations on commercial and recreational fishing for Atlantic Striped Bass in the coastal Atlantic Ocean and, in particular, the Chesapeake Bay and its tributaries."
Cutting through some of the legal terminology, Newberry summed it up as the ASMFC acted outside the bounds of the U.S. and the Maryland Constitution.
"They (ASMFC) promulgated regulations directly in violation of that," Newberry said.
He said he's hopeful to have the new rules overturned, based on the crowd at meetings and the overwhelming support he said his efforts have received from the counties.
Newberry has faced what he described as a naysayer, Russell Dize, the vice president of Maryland Watermen's Association. Newberry said Dize claimed this lawsuit was a "waste of time and resources."
There's more opposition as well, including that of the Bay Foundation and the Coastal Conservation Association.
Newberry was adamant when he said he "doesn't care" what they think.
And even more so, Newberry said, the optics are not in the favor of the ASMFC when describing the process in which the regulations were first enacted.
He explained. The ASMFC is composed of three deciding bodies: representatives of the governor's office, representatives from the Department of Natural Resources and representatives for the legislative body headed by Speaker Pro Tempore Delegate Dana Stein, his proxy being David Sikorski, executive director of the Coastal Conservation Association.
The only one initially voting for the stricter regulations was within Stein's body, Newberry said. Nobody from the Department of Natural Resources nor the governors office was for the new mandate.
According to Newberry, Sikorski lobbied for the one-fish rule to the ASMFC commission, influencing them.
This doesn't sit right with Newberry, who is calling for the Eastern Shore delegation and the entire legislative body to clarify its position.
He wants them to be clear so Marylanders will understand who they elected into office.
"Right now, the whole thing looks like the legislative body is responsible for putting Marylanders out of work," Newberry said.
He and others filed the lawsuit in federal court on March 8. On March 22, they signed a memorandum of understanding.
The hearing will be held on April 12, 11 a.m. at the federal court building in Baltimore concerning the complaint. Moving forward, a trial date will be set for April 26.
ASMFC is required to have their answer to the complaint by April 5 and the plaintiffs response to that by April 9.
In his years of defending watermen's issues Newberry said this effort is one of the larger ones he has taken on.
"This is rather important," Newberry noted. "It's our economy we're taking about. Our livelihood." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the economic impact of fishing regulations on the industry, including legal challenges, visitor spending, and livelihood concerns. While environmental aspects are mentioned, the core conflict revolves around economic interests and regulatory impacts on businesses.

title: Mid-Shore Realtors golf tournament to be held May 14
author: MID-SHORE BOARD OF REALTORS
content:
Mid-Shore Realtors golf tournament to be held May 14

 April 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MID-SHORE BOARD OF REALTORS | Section: Events 
 
 310
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Mid-Shore Board of Realtors is holding a charity golf tournament on Tuesday, May 14, at Hog Neck Golf Course in Easton with all proceeds going to their Love Down Payment Grant program.This program has distributed 16 $1,000 grants to new homeowners in the five-county Mid-Shore area, with two additional grants closing in April.
Maintaining funding for this program is essential, said Shelby Roney, president of Mid-Shore Board of Realtors, and the spring golf fundraiser will ensure the program continues.
Registration is at 8 a.m. and tee-off time is 9 a.m. The cost is $125 per golfer, or $500.00 for a group of four, and includes the round of golf, cart, coffee and donuts, and an amazing lunch catered by Diemon's BBQ.
Golfers will have an opportunity to purchase 50/50 and raffle tickets and mulligans.
The first down payment grant was awarded in May 2023, and Mid-Shore Board of Realtors has had a grant distribution almost every month since then, Roney said.
"When you attend a closing and see the smiles and hear how this money made a difference, it makes it all worthwhile. Buying a home is not an easy process, this grant program makes the experience less financially stressful," she said.
The grants have benefited a police officer, a school bus driver, and administrative and trades employees. Of the 16 grants, five have gone to new homeowners in Dorchester and Talbot Counties, three in Caroline County and three in Queen Anne's County.
Mid-Shore Love Down Payment grant is for those working and buying a primary residence in Caroline, Dorchester, Kent, Queen Anne's or Talbot counties.
The income limit is based on the USDA amounts. The applicant's buyer's agent or the seller's agent must be a Realtor with Mid-Shore Board of Realtors.
To sponsor or register to play in the golf tournament, or for more information about the Love Down Payment Grant program, visit midshoreboardofrealtors.com. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: A forgotten promise and a pillowcase filled with cash fuel local business owner's dream
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
A forgotten promise and a pillowcase filled with cash fuel local business owner's dream

 April 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Local News 
 
 593
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — It began with an unshakable passion, a forgotten promise and a pillowcase filled with cash.Those three things brought Jessica Tanglao, owner of Tanglao Carriage Driving, to her passion today, providing horse-drawn carriage rides to the Eastern Shore.
Tanglao said she had no idea where her love for horses originated, but it was her first defining feature as a child. When she was about 5 years old, after continuously begging for a horse, her mother made her a promise. If she could raise $2,500, then she could have a horse.
Tanglao went door-to-door in her neighborhood for over four years and took any job she could. From shoveling snow to raking leaves, she was determined to have her horse. Then, at the age of 9, she brought a pillowcase filled with cash to her mother, who had completely forgotten the promise, and finally got her horse.
Ebony, Tanglao's first horse, was mean and a biter. He was forced out of horse school for bad behavior. Yet, she loved this ill-mannered horse and found joy in caring for him every day.
From there on, her love for horses grew. She got another horse and another.
"I think they're just like my will to live," Tanglao said. "There's something about them that's just part of my soul. I love them."
Originally from Lexington, Virginia, she learned of horse-drawn carriage tours in the area and begged the local business for a job over the course of years. Finally, they gave her a job that she loved. There, she decided to one day have her own horse-drawn carriage business.
Today, Tanglao has 11 carriages, ten horses and acres to help teach people how to lead a horse-drawn carriage.
Jessie Willey, owner of Alternative Therapy, said that Tanglao's love for horses is striking to anyone who meets her, and her work ethic knows no bounds.
"Jessica's passion is evident through the happiness of her horses," Wiley said. "I've never met a group of horses more excited to work. Jess puts her heart and soul into her horses and her business. Rain or shine … or snow, she'll be out at the barn taking care of her best friends. Her knowledge about the horse and carriage is a gift to the rapidly growing community."
Tanglao says doing carriage rides allows her to entertain and bring joy to all her customers. Putting on a show and making her customers laugh is what makes this job worth it.
Her two children, both under the age of 6, share the same passion for horses. Tanglao said her children saw her around horses, and soon, their love for them became infectious.
Now, her daughter Millie Tanglao is interested in driving horses and being around her pony, JamJam.
While leading her pony to enjoy some grass, Millie shared what she loved most about horses, which included being around them, especially when they were sniffing her.
Tanglao says it's important to encourage young people's interest in animals, especially regarding activities with animals. She shared that it is uncanny how much her daughter reminds her of herself as a child. They both share the same determined love for horses.
Tanglao hopes to share her love for horses with everyone and show young girls that being driven and believing in themselves can result in achieving their dreams.
"I tell my daughter all the time that the words 'I can't' don't exist," Tanglao said. "If you want something and you want to do something, figure it out. You can figure it out. Look at all the women who have figured it out before us. Just keep going and keep the dream alive." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Jessica Tanglao's entrepreneurial journey in establishing a horse-drawn carriage business, highlighting her business model, challenges, and community impact. While it includes personal and local elements, the core subject is her business venture, making 'Business/Economy' the most precise category.

title: County Council sends letter of support for H-2B visa cap exemption
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
County Council sends letter of support for H-2B visa cap exemption

 April 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 250
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — The Dorchester County Council is sending a letter of support for a United States Senate bill that would exempt seafood processors from the numerical limit on H-2B nonimmigrant visas.At a regular meeting April 2, the County Council voted unanimously to send the letter of support.
According to the U.S. Department of Labor, the H-2B program allows employers in the United States to temporarily hire nonimmigrants for nonagricultural labor or services.
Currently, there is a cap on how many H-2B visas can be issued every year. According to the U.S. Department of Homeland Security Citizenship and Immigration Services, the cap is currently 66,000 H-2B visas per fiscal year.
If Senate Bill 3013 is passed, seafood processors would be exempt from this cap.
County Council Vice President Mike Detmer said at the meeting that it is important to emphasize in the letter the "huge impact" that the limit on H-2B visas issued has on crab picking houses in the county every year.
"Especially in the southern part of our county where everybody is working on the water or adjacent to them," he said.
Detmer said the letter should include the number of workers needed in the county to open all the local picking houses, "and maintain our heritage and our economic development." He said this number is a small one "compared to a larger pool."
Council President Lenny Pfeffer agreed and said that county staff could contact the Dorchester Seafood Heritage Association for those numbers.
"We can have good factual information put in our letter," he said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the Dorchester County Council's support for a federal bill to exempt seafood processors from H-2B visa caps, highlighting economic impacts on local businesses. While local government action is involved, the core issue revolves around labor policies affecting the seafood industry's economic operations.

title: Maryland gas prices up 4.6 cents this week
author: Staff Writer
content:
Maryland gas prices up 4.6 cents this week

 April 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: State News 
 
 433
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Average gasoline prices in Maryland have risen 4.6 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.60 per gallon Monday, according to GasBuddy's survey of 2,167 stations in Maryland. Prices in Maryland are 26.3 cents per gallon higher than a month ago and stand 9.9 cents per gallon higher than a year ago. The national average price of diesel has increased 3.1 cents in the last week and stands at $4.02 per gallon.According to GasBuddy price reports, the cheapest station in Maryland was priced at $3.25 per gallon yesterday while the most expensive was $4.79 per gallon, a difference of $1.54per gallon.
The national average price of gasoline has risen 6.5 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.57 per gallon today. The national average is up 17.1 cents per gallon from a month ago and stands 0.8 cents per gallon lower than a year ago, according to GasBuddy data compiled from more than 11 million weekly price reports covering over 150,000 gas stations across the country.
Historical gasoline prices in Maryland and the national average going back 10 years:
April 8, 2023: $3.51per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.58 per gallon)April 8, 2022: $3.74per gallon (U.S. Average: $4.12 per gallon)April 8, 2021: $2.78per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.86 per gallon)April 8, 2020: $1.98per gallon (U.S. Average: $1.88 per gallon)April 8, 2019: $2.68per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.75 per gallon)April 8, 2018: $2.67per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.65 per gallon)April 8, 2017: $2.36per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.39 per gallon)April 8, 2016: $2.05per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.04 per gallon)April 8, 2015: $2.35per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.39 per gallon)April 8, 2014: $3.59per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.58 per gallon)

"After a brief break, gas prices have leapt back up, driven by extensive refinery maintenance on the West Coast, where prices have increased notably; only a handful of states have seen prices decline over the last week," said Patrick De Haan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy. "With oil prices rising to nearly $87 per barrel last week, their highest since October, we are not only facing the seasonal factors that push prices up — refinery maintenance, the switch to summer gasoline and rising demand — but also escalating crude oil prices as OPEC's production cuts continue to cause declining global oil inventories, with escalations between Iran and Israel adding to concerns of further destabilization."

title: Easton Utilities picks John Horner as president
author: Staff Writer
content:
Easton Utilities picks John Horner as president

 April 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Business 
 
 426
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Easton Utilities has named John J. Horner Jr. as the next president and chief executive officer, succeeding Hugh Grunden who retires July 1."John's extensive knowledge in the energy/utility sector, strong business acumen and exceptional leadership skills made him the ideal choice to lead Easton Utilities into the next chapter," said W.W. "Buck" Duncan, chairman of the Easton Utilities Commission.
In this role, Horner will provide strategic leadership for the seven diverse businesses to assure operational excellence and the safe delivery of reliable services with exceptional customer service.
"I am grateful for the confidence placed in me by the commission and the entire team at Easton Utilities and look forward to navigating the bright future together," Horner said.
Horner understands the importance of Easton Utilities' mission "to enhance the quality of life in our community" and plans to carry out the direction and vision already in place. Easton Utilities has an impeccable reputation based on exceptional customer satisfaction, high reliability and competitive prices. With a constant focus on safety and environmental stewardship, the 175 employees serve more than 11,000 customers in the Town of Easton and portions of Talbot County.
Horner currently serves as executive vice president and chief operating officer for Easton Utilities. His focus has been on the oversight of daily operational activities, project management and providing leadership to the multi-disciplinary teams in the organization. He was instrumental in securing the substantial grant funding of approximately $30 million needed for the Connect Talbot project to extend broadband to all unserved residents in Talbot County.
"We were committed to being a solution, and I am proud of the Easton Velocity team as they continue making significant progress to ensure everyone has access to broadband, which is needed now more than ever," Horner said.
Horner has more than 30 years of industry experience. Prior to joining Easton Utilities in 2016, he was the director of northeast regional electric operations and director of distribution system operations (gas and electric) for BGE. Horner graduated from The Johns Hopkins University with a Bachelor of Science in electrical and computer engineering and holds a Master of Business Administration from Loyola College.
He is a graduate of Leadership Maryland, Class of 2020, and a Shore Leadership alumnus. He has a philanthropic spirit and is active in the community volunteering for numerous organizations over the years including the Talbot County Chamber of Commerce, Talbot Hospice, Friends of Hospice, Tidewater Rotary and the MD/DC Utilities Association. Horner lives in Easton with his wife. He has two children and enjoys all the benefits the Eastern Shore has to offer. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

'Local Government' is a secondary consideration due to the utility's community role, but the core subject is corporate leadership.

title: Actor Jim Belushi launches his cannabis brands in Cecil County
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Actor Jim Belushi launches his cannabis brands in Cecil County

 April 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: State News 
 
 1054
 Words 

 Read News Document

 PERRYVILLE — Larry Villani and his wife, Yvonne, were beaming on Wednesday as they walked off the concert hall stage in the back of Grounded Coffee near Perryville after meeting actor Jim Belushi, who has appeared in more than 90 movies and 60 television shows since the late 1970s."I told him that my family has been watching your family for almost 50 years," Larry said, referring mainly to Belushi's work as an actor, comedian and musician in the entertainment industry and that of his late brother, John Belushi, who was one of the original seven "Saturday Night Live" cast members before starring in "Animal House," "The Blue Brothers" and other movies.
As for the North East couple's brief interaction with Belushi, Yvonne summarized, "He''s a very laid-back, nice person."
Belushi starred in "According to Jim" from 2001 to 2009 and was a "Saturday Night Live" cast member from 1983 to 1985, to list a couple of the dozens of TV shows on his resume. His long list of movie credits includes "Red Heat" with Arnold Schwarzenegger; "Trading Places" with Eddie Murphy, Dan Aykroyd and Jamie Lee Curtis; "The Principal" with the late Louis Gossett Jr.; and "Curly Sue" with Steve Carell and Alisan Porter.
But Belushi wasn't in Cecil County on Wednesday to look back on his acting career thus far. Nor was he here to promote any existing or upcoming film or TV projects. Belushi, instead, was in Cecil County to launch his own cannabis brands — Belushi's Farm and Blue Brothers — in Maryland through a partnership with Warwick-based SunMed Growers, which he visited on Wednesday as part of his whirlwind promotional tour.
Belushi spent about five hours at SunMed Growers, a licensed grower and processor that employees about 200 people. SunMed grows, processes and distributes various types and brands of cannabis to approximately 90 state-regulated marijuana dispensaries throughout Maryland, including Nature's Care and Wellness on Route 40 near Perryville, which now is selling Belushi's products and was one of Belushi's stops on Wednesday.
"He was down to earth. He talked to every employee and thanked them for their hard work. He shook hands. He signed autographs," outlined Paul Quill, director of sales and security at SunMed, noting that Belushi talked shop at length with SunMed President, Jacob Van Wingerden. "Mr. Belushi is very knowledgeable. He talked plants and genetics and processing with Jake."
Belushi then visited Nature's Care and Wellness, founded and owned by Bobby Windsor. While touring that dispensary, Belushi chatted with employees and customers, graciously signing autographs and posing for photos. At one point, after Belushi was introduced to an employee whose name is Mary Jane, he joked with her because "Mary Jane" is slang for marijuana.
From there, he made the short walk eastward to Grounded Coffee, also owned by Windsor. Belushi then spent approximately the next two hours interacting individually with the dozens of people who waited in line to meet him. Attendees were gifted different strains of one of his brands — Blues Brothers — in flower and pre-rolled form along with other swag, including a Belushi's Farm poster. Belushi autographed the posters, the plastic tubs containing the Blues Brothers flower and other items presented to him by the meet-and-greet attendees.
"I am a Jim Belushi groupie," gushed Abingdon resident Laura Martin, moments after meeting him on the stage.
Martin was sporting a shirt covered with images of Jim Belushi's face. She turned sideways to reveal a fresh scribble near the bottom of her Jim Belushi print top and then remarked happily, "He autographed my shirt for me."
She is more than a fan of Belushi — the entertainer.
"I love his product, too," Martin said, holding up a couple of containers of Belushi's cannabis.
Located on 93 acres along the Rogue River in Oregon, Belush started Belushi's Farm Cannabis with 48 plants in 2015 during that state's medical marijuana program. A long-time proponent of adult-use legalization who has advocated for patients rights across the United States, Belushi operates a farm that now grows a wide range of legal cannabis offerings that include Captain Jack's Gulzar Afghanica and Good Ugly Weed. Belushi's brands of cannabis are now sold in 13 states.
Chronicling his work in the legal cannabis industry is a television show on The Discovery Network called "Belushi's Farm," and Season 3 premieres at 9 p.m. on Friday (April 5). The show provides the audience with an insider perspective on the people, operations and mission behind Belushi's Farm cannabis.
(Belushi is an ambassador for Last Prisoner Project — a coalition of cannabis industry leaders, executives and artists dedicated to bringing restorative justice to the cannabis industry. He is working with the Oregon Liquor and Cannabis Commission and the Portland City Council to create an opioid trade program in which "veterans, the infirmed, downtrodden and addicted" can have a place for healing for low to no cost, according to a press release regarding Belushi's product launch.)
The partnership between Belushi and SunMed started last year, according to Quill, who explained that Belushi's celebrity and his high-profile involvement in and advocacy for cannabis, including his popular "Belushi's Farm" television show, were attractive to SunMed.
SunMed replicated the different marijuana plants that yield the various brands and types of cannabis that Belushi's Farms grows, a process that began with taking cuttings of those plants and then essentially cloning them, in the broadest of terms. The repeated process involved about 16 weeks to grow the desired plants, followed by drying and curing. The cannabis produced then was sent to a state-certified lab, where tests were performed to measure the various levels of properties, including the percentages of THC, which is the psychoactive ingredient in marijuana, and to determine if the cannabis is "clean and safe," according to Quill.
Consistency is paramount at SunMed, as with any reputable grow center.
Belushi's Farm offers two brands. Belushi's Farm has a THC level from 25 to 30 percent and is considered to be a premium brand while the other, Blue Brothers, has a THC level of 20 to 25 percent and has been dubbed by Belushi as "the working man's cannabis."
Regarding the partnership between SunMed and Belushi, Van Wingerden commented, "Our collaboration with Belushi's Farm symbolizes more than just the strength and maturation of Maryland's market. For me and Jim, it is a testament to our shared commitment to innovation, quality, social responsibility and the healing power of cannabis." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Jim Belushi's launch of cannabis brands through a business partnership, emphasizing commercial operations, branding, and market expansion. While his entertainment background is mentioned, the core subject is his entrepreneurial venture in the cannabis industry, aligning with Business/Economy. Entertainment is a secondary consideration due to his celebrity status but is not the primary focus.

title: Mother-daughter duo treats texture with style
author: NIAMBI DAVIS Special to the Star Democrat
content:
Mother-daughter duo treats texture with style

 April 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: NIAMBI DAVIS Special to the Star Democrat | Section: Business 
 
 625
 Words 

 Read News Document

 QUEENSTOWN — In October 2022 Onyx Beauty Supply, Salon, and Barbershop opened in Queenstown Premium Outlets to fill a particular need."Growing up here, raising two daughters, we always had to go outside of the area, often 35-40 minutes away, and even to other states to get hair and skin products compatible with our texture and skin tone," said Deayna Ewell, co-owner of Onyx with her daughter Kay Bowser.
Before owning Onyx, the pair had already forged a business relationship with the Outlets. When Deayna's mother, Pastor Annie Ewell, passed away, Kay returned from Atlanta where she trained as a phone repair technician. At the time, Ewell had over 30 years of corporate retail experience at the Outlets with The Loft, Express, Old Navy, and Brooks Brothers.
When the mother-daughter team put their heads together, utilizing Kay's training as a phone repair technician, the women opened and operated a phone repair store in Queenstown for three years. "But Kay was forward-thinking," recalled her mother. "She saw that the industry was changing and would not be a good fit in the long run."
In its place, their skills, experience, and drive produced a business that provided a much-needed service to the community and honored Annie Ewell's community outreach legacy.
"We do all hair," the shop's motto proclaims.
"When people come into our shop and ask 'do you do the texture of my hair' it sparks an instant conversation that shows that hair is not a race, it's a texture," Ewell said. And the barbers, braiders and stylists at Onyx know how to service all of them.
"We need to try to understand each other; we don't need to be afraid of each other," Ewell said.
At Onyx it's a common sight to see a white man getting his hair cut next to a black woman having her hair braided.
In the culture of community barbershops, Onyx upholds its role as a source of information, fellowship and aid.
"Everything goes back into how we can help our community. We do a lot of outreach here," Ewell said.
As part of its community outreach activities, Onyx has sponsored three "Free cut/Quick style" charity events in support of back-to-school activities, families in need, and shelters for men and women. They've put on events to introduce the staff and business to the community, which resulted in Onyx receiving Business With The Biggest Heart and Favorite New Business Owner in community-voted awards.
At Onyx, care extends into the place where beauty and emotional well-being meet. Motivated by the experience that left a friend and cancer patient weeping and distraught from her treatment at a wig shop, Onyx carries a selection of wigs that Ewell cuts and styles to suit each woman. "I want to make the experience personal and private. We offer encouragement to people going through cancer treatment, and losing their hair to alopecia. We've done more of that than we've made money. But I say if that's why I'm here we'll keep going."
As part of its goals, Onyx hopes to raise capital for expansion into alopecia/COVID/cancer hair loss solutions, apprenticeships for local cosmetology/barber school students and additional salon/barber equipment.
"Our name is spreading and we need our business to catch up with our name," Ewell said.
Onyx Beauty Supply celebrated its first year this past November. "There were times when I felt like giving up. But then someone would come in and say "I'm so glad you're here. We believe in our hearts that our communities, more than ever, need every opportunity to be united and come together for strength and encouragement in these tough and uncertain times. At Onyx we value creating a diverse and inclusive environment to support unity within our community, one customer at a time."
Onyx Beauty Supply and Barber is located at 439 Outlet Center Drive in Queenstown. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the establishment and operations of Onyx Beauty Supply, a business addressing community needs. It details entrepreneurial efforts, community outreach, and economic impact. While diversity and local life aspects are mentioned, the core theme revolves around business development and community economic engagement.
