title: Delmarva Balloon Rides: providing fun throughout the Eastern Shore
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Delmarva Balloon Rides: providing fun throughout the Eastern Shore

 July 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 594
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Todd Davis is in the business of amazing people.Whether it be providing people with hot air balloon rides across the Eastern Shore or entertaining people as a magician, Davis has made a life bringing unique experiences to people.
For over 20 years, Davis, owner of Delmarva Balloon Rides, has been providing countless people of all ages with not only the chance of flight, but a unique view of the Eastern Shore landscape.
Davis believes the hard work he has put into his business have been more than worth it.
"I have the biggest balloon in Maryland," Davis said. "I've already fulfilled my dream."
For Davis, his journey began when he was in his early 20s and a friend invited Davis to accompany him on a hot air balloon ride. He was hooked.
Davis would spend the next decade working toward making that one experience with his friend his everyday life.
But the journey to piloting hot air balloons is no easy feat, Davis said. To pilot a hot air balloon, a person needs to get instruction from a commercial pilot, as hot air balloons are considered an aircraft that needs to be licensed and registered with the Federal Aviation Administration.
Additionally, a potential pilot is required to have a minimum of 10 hours in "free balloons," which must include six flights under the supervision of an instructor. Potential pilots must also take various tests and obtain a license, similar to getting a license for an airplane.
It took about 10 years for Davis to fulfill all the requirements as well as earn enough money to buy the needed equipment. During those years, Davis said he was earning money by being a magician and providing people with a different kind of unique experience.
Today, Davis says he knows his flying area like "the back of my hand." He said he is confident of his piloting skills, ensuring even the most height-fearing flier an enjoyable experience.
During flights, he provides experiences such as a 360-degree view of the Eastern Shore and picking leaves off the tops of trees.
"It makes you feel like a bird," Davis said. "The whole process from set up to the end, and the landing is something that people don't realize what they've signed up for. They're always happy.
"... All those fears and worries of heights, all those worries go away after we take off," he said.
Tom McKnight, a chaser at Delmarva Balloon Rides, said in his role he handles the equipment, assists the pilot with flight preparation and follows the balloon during flight and packs up.
For McKnight, the opportunity to experience the world from an Eagle's point of view is one of the best parts of this line of work. Alongside the view, McKnight says he enjoys being a part of the hot air balloon community and working with Davis.
"There are no strangers," McKnight said. "You are a part of the crew pilot, or have anything to do with the balloons, there are no strangers. I could go to any balloon company and start helping them, and it's just like we've known each other for years. It's just a good bunch of people."
For Davis, he hopes to continue his flights for years to come. He said if he one day retires from his career, he would look back at his years of work and feel satisfied bringing people joy and making them "a part of nature."
"If I stop doing everything I've done to make people happy, I will have completed my mission on this planet," Davis said. "(Because) at this point, I made thousands and thousands of people happy." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Todd Davis's hot air balloon business, detailing his entrepreneurial journey, operational challenges, and business model. While it mentions entertainment aspects, the core narrative revolves around business operations, licensing, and economic activities, making 'Business/Economy' the primary topic.

title: 2nd quarter housing statistics for the Eastern Shore
author: MID-SHORE BOARD OF REALTORS
content:
2nd quarter housing statistics for the Eastern Shore

 July 25, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MID-SHORE BOARD OF REALTORS | Section: Business 
 
 624
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Low inventory continues to be the theme for the second quarter of 2024, according to Mid-Shore Board of Realtors President Shelby Roney.For Caroline, Dorchester, Kent, Queen Anne's and Talbot counties, 736 homes were sold during the second quarter of 2024, and these homes sold in two months or less.
Another positive indicator for sellers is the list price compared to the sold price. Homes are selling for 95% or better than the current asking price on average, which is great news for those looking to maximize their profits.
For the five Mid-Shore counties the second quarter of 2024 home prices averaged:
Caroline County's average home price was $295,845, a 3.75% decline compared to second quarter of 2023.Dorchester County's average home price was $295,600, a 1.7 decrease compared to the second quarter of 2023.Kent County average home price for this quarter was $523,250, up 30.29% compared to the second quarter of 2023.Queen Anne's County average home price in the second quarter 2024 was $589,539, a 5.23% increase from 2023.Talbot County's second quarter 2024 average home price was $900,800, showing a 27.22% increase compared to the second quarter of 2023.
With interest rates still higher than many buyers are willing to pay, plus the lack of homes available for sale, it's not surprising that the number of homes sold in all but one county declined in the second quarter of 2024.
In Caroline County, 89 homes sold this quarter. This is 18 fewer homes than this time in 2023.
Dorchester County had 155 homes sold. This is six fewer homes than this time in 2023.
Kent County sold 97 homes. This is 17 more than in this time 2023.
Queen Anne's County had 234 homes sold, 23 fewer than this time in 2023.
In Talbot County, 161 homes were sold. This is 23 fewer homes than in the second quarter of 2023.
Sellers usually ask how long it will take to sell their home, Roney said. In a balanced market, a five- to six-month supply of homes is typical.
Currently, the single-family home inventory has a four-month supply. However, some buyers are not waiting for interest rates to drop. Sellers can expect their home to sell in one to two months in our area.
Homes for the second quarter of 2024 in Caroline County sold on average in 45 days, which is 20 days faster than in the second quarter of 2023.
Dorchester County homes took seven days longer to sell, or 56 days, compared to this time in 2023.
Kent County homes took 43 days on average to sell, nine days longer than the second quarter of 2023.
Queen Anne's County homes sold in 35 days, seven days longer than this time last year.
Talbot County homes sold on average in 30 days, seven less days than in the second quarter of 2023.
Beginning Wednesday, Aug. 14, buyers will be required to sign a Buyers Representative Agreement with the realtor of their choosing before being shown property. This is a nationwide ruling from the Department of Justice and applies to all agents.
In this agreement, it will state the services the agent will provide to the buyer and the compensation due to the buyer's agent at settlement.
For Maryland, this is not new. Maryland has had buyers representation since 1999 and formal written agreements for the past 16 years that are continuously updated to comply with Maryland Code. What might be new to some is having this agreement signed before a home is shown, Roney said.
This agreement provides additional transparency and will help buyers understand who pays the buyer's agent and how much they are being paid. Just like it has always been, the commission is negotiable.
When you are thinking of buying a home, it's important to speak with several Mid-Shore realtors before you decide which realtor is best for you. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Power hungry: AI is putting data centers on steroids, accelerating energy use, cooling needs
author: Mike Sunnucks APG National Enterprise Editor
content:
Power hungry: AI is putting data centers on steroids, accelerating energy use, cooling needs

 July 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks APG National Enterprise Editor | Section: Business 
 
 1089
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The warp speed developments of artificial intelligence are propelling exponential growth — but also ravenous power and cooling appetites — for data centers, which are driving the technology backbones behind the machine learning upheavals across the world.The AI-powered data storage market is projected to grow from $28.7 billion this year to as much as $217.3 billion by 2033, according to a market analysis by Precedence Research.
That's just one of scores of bullish and ambitious growth expectations for AI's impacts on server farms and other technology infrastructure.
Dell Computer founder CEO Michael Dell said at this year's South by Southwest (SXSW) conference that AI could drive 100 times more demand for data centers and their computing capacity over the next 10 years.
Dan Watts, CEO of US Signal (which operates data centers in Wisconsin, Michigan, Illinois and Indiana, and is adding others in Oregon, Colorado and Arizona via its recent acquisition of OneNeck) agrees.
"It's going to be a massive growth driver for data centers," said Watts.
He sees AI hyperscalers — big technology companies such as Microsoft, Google/Alphabet, Amazon, Oracle and IBM that provide cloud computing service and operate big data centers — driving approximately 60% of that growth in the short-term.
NUCLEAR OPTIONS
Those same big tech firms, along with private equity technology investors and data center developers, are also confronted with AI's voracious energy and cooling needs, potential strains on power grids and water supplies and their climate-change inspired promises to curtail carbon emissions.
"AI and machine learning are very power intensive," Watts said.
An analysis by Goldman Sachs projects AI driving a 160% increase in power demand from data centers by 2030.
"On average, a ChatGPT query needs nearly 10 times as much electricity to process as a Google search. In that difference lies a coming sea change in how the U.S., Europe and the world at large will consume power — and how much that will cost," reads the Goldman Sachs analysis released in May.
All that worries environmental groups concerned about climate change, droughts and rising temperatures already straining power and water systems.
"American energy consumption is going up for the first time in 20 years. Data centers are a huge part of what's driving that," said Michael Khoo, a program director with Friends of the Earth.
Khoo foresees potential battles over power supplies and water allocations between high-intensity data centers and other users. Data centers require cooling — often in the form of water-based systems — to keep servers and processors from overheating.
"I see very real fights for power access for local communities versus data centers," he said.
For utilities to keep up with data center needs, U.S. power grids could need a $2 trillion overhaul, according to commercial real estate firm JLL.
Private power grids — including some that could be powered by small-scale and micro nuclear reactors — could be developed to keep up with the capacity demands of AI data centers processing oceans of data and electronic transmissions.
"We're just using so much technology. That is not going to change," said Pat Lynch, executive managing director and global head of data center solutions for CBRE, a national commercial real estate firm.
Lynch said small modular nuclear reactors are being seriously explored by large data center operators with concerns about whether renewable sources and traditional grids can keep up with demand while also avoiding increased carbon emissions.
"The demand is migrating to the places where they can now find power," he said, noting potential natural gas and hydroelectric paths to powering and cooling high-volume data centers.
Small nuclear reactors to power and cool data center still have to gain regulatory approvals and could face community concerns. But there is interest in their development from big money players, including Microsoft, as well as its founder, Bill Gates — who is developing a new sodium-cooled nuclear power plant in Wyoming.
The nuclear energy segment for data centers could ramp up to a $38.3 million marketplace globally by 2028, and hit as much as $278.4 million by 2033, according to BIS Research Inc.
SPACE INVADERS
There are more than 5,380 data centers currently in the U.S. and close to 11,000 worldwide, according to technology firms Cloudscene and Brightlio.
Data centers are currently located across the country. That includes near major internet and telecommunications hubs in Silicon Valley and Northern Virginia outside Washington, D.C., as well as other big cities and regions including the Pacific Northwest, Midwest and Mountain West (including Idaho and Wyoming).
Watts said three components to data centers are being monumentally impacted by the AI revolution.
"You've got floor space. You've got power, and you've got cooling," said Watts, referring to space and power needs, as well as ways to keep servers and IT infrastructure from overheating.
POWER PLAYS
Data centers currently consume 3% of power nationally — a figure that could rise to 8% by the end of the decade.
That could be accompanied by a doubling or more of carbon dioxide emissions from data centers by 2030, according to the Goldman Sachs analysis.
Utilities (large and small) are trying to navigate the new AI universe.
"In some areas of the country, the demand for electricity is growing faster than the available capacity," said Ben Fowke, CEO and president of American Electric Power, during a congressional hearing in May. AEP operates in 11 states, including Ohio, West Virginia, Tennessee, Texas and Louisiana.
"Just a few years ago, a large-scale industrial manufacturing facility might require 100 megawatts (MW) of electricity – enough to power about 100,000 homes. A facility that size would typically be one-of-a-kind in a region and would be a major source of economic activity for the area.
Now, it is common for a single data center to require three times to up to 15 times this amount of power for a single site," Fowke said.
Lynch said AI-driven demand is driving limited supply for exponentially larger data center capacity, but sees technology infrastructure developments in Atlanta and Dallas. He also sees more projects landing in Ohio, Indiana, Nebraska and Nevada, as well as areas of Virginia and Maryland with ample power grids. Data centers avoid places with potential weather and other power disruptions.
"What we're seeing today is growing demand and very little supply — mostly limited by utility capacity," he said.
Lynch said some existing data center space could be retrofitted to accommodate AI needs, but said that can be challenged by the need to maintain existing operations, and some might eventually become obsolete.
The commercial real estate broker sees rural areas landing more data centers related to cryptocurrency (which have less intensive power needs than their AI counterparts).
"It seems like crypto is a more viable option for those communities," Lynch said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on AI's impact on data centers, discussing market growth projections, corporate strategies, energy demands, and infrastructure challenges. While environmental concerns are mentioned, the primary context is economic and business-related, covering industry trends, investment, and market analysis.

title: BeeGeorge Honey: 'Every day keeping bees is a great day'
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
BeeGeorge Honey: 'Every day keeping bees is a great day'

 July 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Business 
 
 679
 Words 

 Read News Document

 OXFORD — According to his mother, when George Meyer was a baby, a swarm of bees flew in an open window and landed on his cradle."I was ordained since then," Meyer, now the owner of BeeGeorge Honey, said as four hives of bees buzzed a few feet away.
About 12 years ago, Meyer made a career change. He left his job as a program manager at a computer company to spend his time caring for 150 hives and bringing joy to people throughout Maryland with his locally sourced honey.
Though it was a big decision at the time, it was not a surprising one. Meyer said he had been preparing his whole life to make this popular hobby a full time job.
As a child he would find creative ways to obtain and care for hives, and as a young adult he spent a year and a half keeping Africanized bees and doing pollination work in Nicaragua.
Over the years, Meyer has taught classes on beekeeping, given small tours of the hives and provided mentorship to bee enthusiasts of all ages.
During a tour of his Oxford site, Meyer sought through the hives with his bare hands, thousands of bees swarming around him. In swift and quick motions he used a beekeeping smoker, a device designed to emit cool smoke when working with honeybee colonies, to help inspect the hive. Meyer said the device calms bees as the smoke interferes with the bees' primary form of communication, which is smell.
Throughout the tour, Meyer made sure to explain the high functioning environment of a hive from the worker bees, brood (baby bees) in the pupa (cocoon) stage and closely pointing out the queen bee herself, who only mates once in her lifetime.
At some point, Meyer looked through the hive and excitedly pointed out glossy combs in the hive which he explained was honey. According to Meyer, nectar, honey, comes from flowers and nectar can be a high percentage of water but honey is 16% to 18% water, so the bees evaporate off the extra water by fanning away moisture with their wings before it is officially honey.
"Fortunately for us, honeybees aren't very good at figuring out how much nectar they need, and they way over produce," Meyer said. "As a beekeeper, I've got enough experience to know how much they're going to need in the wintertime, and so I just take the rest."
And that is where his profits come in. Meyer bottles up the extra honey and sells it to local businesses throughout the Eastern Shore.
Ricky Travers, owner of Simmons Center Market, said he has been selling BeeGeorge Honey for about five years now and says he is happy to work with local businesses.
"It's great having a local supplier, and just being able to pick up the phone and give him a call and the next day he drops him in here to us, takes good care of us, and his products are just really, really good," Travers said.
Keith MacPherson, owner of Captain's Ketch Seafood, said BeeGeorge's local honey is not only popular along the Eastern Shore but provides many people with health benefits.
"It (BeeGeorge Honey) is very popular," MacPherson said. "It has a very good following in the area with customers and very good customer service … A lot of our customers say they like it because it's local honey and it's good for their allergies."
Meyer said he is proud with the work he does throughout the Eastern Shore and hopes to maintain a functioning small business so he can continue to have hands-on time with his hives. When asked about his future aspirations he told a story about a museum in Key West.
"There's a museum down there about a guy who spent his whole life trying to find the wreck from a Spanish galleon that was loaded with gold," Meyer said. "And so every day he said, 'This is going to be the day,' And okay, that's cool I appreciate that. (But) this is the day for me. Every day is a great day. Every day keeping bees is a great day." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on George Meyer's transition to running a honey business, his interactions with local enterprises, and the economic aspects of selling locally sourced honey. While agriculture and environmental themes are mentioned (e.g., beekeeping, pollination), the primary emphasis is on the business operations, entrepreneurial journey, and economic impact of BeeGeorge Honey.

title: 'Massive potential': Easton Utilities embraces AI technology
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS msunnucks@chespub.com
content:
'Massive potential': Easton Utilities embraces AI technology

 August 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS msunnucks@chespub.com | Section: Business 
 
 338
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The artificial intelligence wave is creating opportunities and challenges across industries.That includes utilities.
AI is poised to make big energy demands on data centers and power grids.
A ChatGPT artificial intelligence request requires 10 times more electricity than a Google search, according to the Electric Power Research Institute (EPRI).
The California-based group said AI-drive power consumption from data centers could potentially double by 2030 — going from 4% in 2023 to as much as 9.1% of total U.S. energy consumption.
That could require some big upgrades to power grids nationally.
But utilities and energy companies are also leveraging AI's innovative tools.
On the Eastern Shore, Fred Christie and Kelly Simonson with Easton Utilities — which provides electricity, internet, water and other services in Talbot County — see multiple opportunities for how the municipal utility can leverage AI.
"The Easton Utilities IT department has turned to predictive AI algorithms to strengthen our cyber defenses and enhance threat hunting. We have systems in place that are monitoring our network traffic in real-time looking for anomalies that may identify malicious actors' presence within our computing domain," said Christie, who is CIO for the local utility.
He said Easton Utilities' technology team is using generative AI tools to create source code for new applications reducing development times and getting products to market faster
Simonson, who serves as director of corporation communications, said her department is using ChatGPT for internal communications as well as for video content going forward.
Like many other businesses and organizations, Easton Utilities offers a customer service chatbot on its website.
The Eastern Shore is not currently a prime market for data centers — many of which are found in Northern Virginia. But the pair said while a data center would require local power grid changes Easton Utilities would be able to accommodate such a project.
They both see "massive potential" for AI helping with responding to demand trends and helping with energy conservation.
"We are always looking to provide information and tools for our customers so that they can better manage their usage and reduce their energy consumption," Simonson said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Easton Utilities' adoption of AI technologies for operational improvements, energy management, and business efficiency. While it touches on energy consumption (Environment), the primary context is the utility company's strategic use of AI in its business operations, aligning most directly with Business/Economy.

title: Average gas prices continue to drop in Maryland
author: Staff Writer
content:
Average gas prices continue to drop in Maryland

 August 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: State News 
 
 482
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Average gasoline prices in Maryland have fallen 8.0 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.38 per gallon today, according to GasBuddy's survey of 2,167 stations in Maryland. Prices in Maryland are 18.4 cents per gallon lower than a month ago and stand 39.4 cents per gallon lower than a year ago. The national average price of diesel has fallen 2.3 cents in the last week and stands at $3.76 per gallon.According to GasBuddy price reports, the cheapest station in Maryland was priced at $3.11 per gallon yesterday while the most expensive was $4.29 per gallon, a difference of $1.18 per gallon.
The national average price of gasoline has fallen 3.5 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.44 per gallon today. The national average is down 5.6 cents per gallon from a month ago and stands 37.2 cents per gallon lower than a year ago, according to GasBuddy data compiled from more than 11 million weekly price reports covering over 150,000 gas stations across the country.
Historical gasoline prices in Maryland and the national average going back 10 years:
August 5, 2023: $3.78 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.81 per gallon)
August 5, 2022: $4.05 per gallon (U.S. Average: $4.06 per gallon)
August 5, 2021: $3.07 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.19 per gallon)
August 5, 2020: $2.27 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.17 per gallon)
August 5, 2019: $2.64 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.70 per gallon)
August 5, 2018: $2.84 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.86 per gallon)
August 5, 2017: $2.35 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.34 per gallon)
August 5, 2016: $2.07 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.12 per gallon)
August 5, 2015: $2.62 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.63 per gallon)
August 5, 2014: $3.50 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.48 per gallon)
Neighboring areas and their current gas prices:
Baltimore: $3.35 per gallon, down 9.1 cents per gallon from last week's $3.44 per gallon.
Washington, D.C.: $3.58 per gallon, down 5.4 cents per gallon from last week's $3.64 per gallon.
Hagerstown: $3.38 per gallon, down 5.2 cents per gallon from last week's $3.43 per gallon.
"With oil prices plummeting due to new concerns over the U.S. economy after a poor jobs report, gasoline prices have seen downside in many states, with potential for more to join that trend this week as previous refinery disruptions in the Great Lakes region fade away and the restart process begins," said Patrick De Haan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy. "Diesel prices have also continued to drop, and while Tropical Storm Debby drops buckets of rain on Florida and the Southeast, it poses low risk to refineries or refined product pipelines, so the storm is not a major concern. With the Middle East on alert after Israel's attacks on Hamas and Hezbollah, there could be an impact on oil prices; however, with an inability to predict the outcome, I for now expect gasoline prices in most states to gently decline in the week ahead, with the Middle East situation being a wildcard." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on declining gasoline prices in Maryland, analyzing economic factors like oil prices, job reports, and refinery operations. This directly relates to economic trends and market dynamics under 'Business/Economy.' While it mentions regional data, the core subject is economic rather than local government or national news.

title: Local businesses closing, some citing economic downturn
author: Jane Bellmyer jbellmyer@cecilwhig.com
content:
Local businesses closing, some citing economic downturn

 August 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jane Bellmyer jbellmyer@cecilwhig.com | Section: News 
 
 253
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CECIL COUNTY — Elkton brewery Maryland Beer Company closed its doors Aug. 3 and Sonny Bea's Florist will close both of its Oxford, Pa. locations by the end of October.Through their social media, Maryland Beer announced its closure starting with merchandise and beer sales. There were also posts from fans thanking Jessica Alexander and Scott McCardall for their seven years in business and their commitment to the community.
"Your presence will be greatly missed and never duplicated. I wish you guys the best in your future endeavors," said Robert Rutkowski.
The organizers of the MS is BS fundraiser vowed to find a new location for the popular event and asked followers of the Maryland Beer Company Facebook page to offer suggestions. MS is BS Maryland & Beyond is dedicated to eradicating multiple sclerosis.
A restaurant is reported to be the next tenant of the 601 North Bridge St. location.
Natalie Weaver, co-owner of Sonny Bea's at 353 North Third St. and 1 South Third St., said original plans were to just close the Floral Design Studio in downtown Oxford.
" ...but with the current economic state, we've decided to close both brick and mortars. Michelle will continue to freelance design," Weaver said via email. "We are moving all sellable items to the Oxford Square Mall location for a business closing sale, which will take place evenings and weekends during September. I will post on social media once dates and times are confirmed."
Weaver opened the first store in November 2019 with the design studio following in March 2021. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on local businesses closing due to economic downturns, directly relating to business and economic conditions. While 'Local Life' is nearby, the primary emphasis is on economic factors affecting businesses.

title: Entrepreneur tries to 'Make Trappe Great Again'
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Entrepreneur tries to 'Make Trappe Great Again'

 August 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 660
 Words 

 Read News Document

 TRAPPE — Adorned in a red hat that read "Make Trappe Great Again" and carrying a book titled "Trappe: The Story of an Old Fashioned Town," Tom Mitchell, president of Delmarva Management Group and a Trappe business owner, said he has put his faith in the growth of Trappe.Over the last five years, the town undergone significant development.
Mitchell's newest business venture, Cork & Bottle Trappe Liquor Store and the construction of Trappe's new Dollar General are testaments to the effort and strategic planning behind the town's growth.
Mitchell says it is easy for him to believe in the potential of Trappe because it has already been done. In the book on historic Trappe, there passages that describe Trappe as a once vibrant and busy community, one that outshone the majority of towns in Talbot County.
"What we're trying to do is we're trying to save the town, bring it back to life and keep it from being dominated by Lakeside across the road," Mitchell said. "We want to maintain the identity of the town itself, because these old towns are very, very special."
In 2019, Lakeside at Trappe, a residential development began looking to build in the town. Across all six phases of the development's construction, 2,874 equivalent dwelling units are planned.
According to Mitchell, the Lakeside development will draw the people needed to support new businesses in town. He knew that before Lakeside developed further, alongside town leaders and community members, he could help decide what direction the town's future took.
The first business he chose to establish was the Coffee Trappe in an old brick bank building on Main Street. To preserve the character of the town, Mitchell said he tries to maintain the historic look of the buildings he purchases even if it would be more cost effective to tear it down and begin new again.
The cafe became popular, and soon after came Momma Maria's Mediterranean Bistro across the street, then the Old Trappe Tavern and now Cork & Bottle Trappe.
Cork & Bottle Trappe, the town's first liquor store, was opened following changes in county zoning laws earlier this year that allowed for a liquor store to be opened in the area.
Curtis Snyder, son-in-law of Tom Mitchell and general counsel for Delmarva Real Estate, said the support he received from local leaders, including the Talbot County Council, and residents when trying to establish The Cork & Bottle Trappe was wonderful.
"(The Talbot County Council) were awesome," Synder said. "They supported trying to help all the local towns. There was no reason that Trappe should be denied a Class E license like every other town in Talbot County, and they all were extremely helpful, welcoming and supported every step of the way."
Now, following the development of the Cork & Bottle Trappe, a Dollar General is being built in town.
The public relations team for Dollar General said every new store provides economic benefits, including additional access to affordable products for customers, the creation of new jobs, additional tax revenue for the town, and the ability for local organizations to apply for literacy and education grants through the Dollar General Literacy Foundation.
"Dollar General understands the unique needs of customers in rural areas and provides great values on products customers use and rely on every day in compact retail locations … we look forward to serving the Trappe community as a positive business partner and good community neighbor," an email from Dollar General said.
Dorian Mitchell, Tom Mitchell's son at the marketing director for Delmarva Management Group, said he is proud of the work his family has done to help Trappe, but particularly of the faith his father has in invested.
"It's been fabulous respecting townspeople's remarks, being the Town Council, being the County Council as well," Dorian Mitchell said. "And that comes from dad's belief in the power of synergy. And that's something to admire about him. I noticed that he believes in potential. He believes in the power of synergy coming together to achieve greater good." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on entrepreneurial efforts to revitalize Trappe through business development, including new ventures like a liquor store and Dollar General, economic impacts, and interactions with local government. While local government involvement is mentioned, the core theme centers on business growth and economic development.

title: Inflation stress: Higher car and homeowners insurance premiums add to Americans' economic angst
author: Mike Sunnucks APG National Enterprise Editor
content:
Inflation stress: Higher car and homeowners insurance premiums add to Americans' economic angst

 August 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks APG National Enterprise Editor | Section: Business 
 
 1319
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Insurance costs — for both car and homeowners coverage — are up significantly across the country adding to Americans' financial stresses since the pandemic and ensuing inflation wave.New inflation numbers released Wednesday by the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics showed the price of car insurance is up 18.5% compared to a year ago and 75% since the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020. That compares to overall U.S. prices being up 23% since the pandemic, according to BLS.
Homeowners insurance premiums have also increased.
In 2019 (before the pandemic and its economic upheavals and resets), the average homeowners insurance premium in the U.S. was $1,272 — now it is $2,511, according to consulting firm CAPCO.com and Marketwatch.com
That's a 97% increase.
Homeowners insurance prices are even higher in some states. Some are eye popping.
The average homeowners insurance premium with $300,000 in dwelling coverages averages $5,531 annually in Florida — 144% higher than the national average for the same coverage ($2,270), according to financial firm Bankrate LLC.
In Nebraska, which has seen premiums rise amid increased claims from hail and wind storms as well as inflationary price pressures, the average premium is $5,655, according to Bankrate. That is 149% higher than the U.S. average.
Also driving up premiums were significant damages from hurricanes and tropical storms — which have grown stronger and more destructive in recent years with warmer water temperatures in the Gulf of Mexico and Atlantic Ocean. A number of private insurers have pulled out of the Florida market or gone out of business after big storms, which has increased the public's reliance on the state-run Citizens Property Insurance Corp.
A growing number of residential property owners are bypassing homeowners insurance with that number increasing from 5% in 2019 to currently 12% nationally, according to Mark Friedlander, director of corporate communications with the Insurance Information Institute, an industry group.
Friedlander said 15% of homeowners in Florida, which has a significant number of cash buyers — have eschewed insurance.
"Florida has always run higher," he said.
Homeowners insurance premiums have also increased in other hurricane- and tornado-prone states such as Texas, Louisiana, Oklahoma and Kansas with warmer gulf waters helping spark more and bigger storms. Areas prone to wildfires have also seen some insurance hikes.
Earlier this year, Insurance firm Insurify projected homeowners insurance premiums to go up by 10% in Montana, 23% in Louisiana, 10% in North Carolina and 13% in Utah his year after previous national post-pandemic price hikes.
HI
GHER PREMIUMS, RECORD PROFITS
Auto insurance premiums are also up across the country since the post-pandemic spike in prices.
In 2019, annual car insurance premiums averaged $1,470, according to a market analysis by insurance portal TheZebra.com. Now, they average $2,329 nationally — a 58% increase.
Some states have seen even bigger increases and higher prices.
Average car insurance premiums average more than $3,000 per month in New York, Florida, Louisiana, Nevada and Michigan, according to Bankrate.
Premiums for automobile insurance are up 29% in Wisconsin, 42% in Maryland, 54% in Washington state, 33% in Tennessee, 44% in Delaware and 31% in Montana, according to TheZebra.com.
Premium increases come as the insurance industry reaps some big profits.
The American Association for Justice — which represents trial attorneys — points to data from the National Association of Insurance Commissioners showing property and casualty insurance companies made a record $87.6 billion in profits in 2023 — up 126% from 2022.
In the first quarter of 2024, underwriting improvements helped the U.S. insurance industry earn $39.9 billion in profits up from $7.9 billion in the first quarter of 2023 — a 408% increase, according to the Insurance Journal and an AM Best Special Report.
INFLATION AND CLIMATESo, what is driving the rise in insurance premiums?
R.E. Hawley, a writer with Bankrate's research team, said wider inflationary trends and higher costs to repair homes and cars are helping drive premiums higher.
The average price of a new car is $48,644 — up 32% since 2019, according to Cox Automotive and TheZebra.com insurance information group.
Used car prices are up 27% since 2019, according to the two groups, with the average price of a used vehicle sitting at more than $25,200.
More expensive cars have more expensive parts and higher costs related to repairs and mechanic labor, which affects both consumers and insurance companies paying accident and other damage claims.
"Rates are going up in every state. It's been going up for a few years," Hawley said.
Hawley also pointed to more extreme weather events that cause more financial and property damage — which increase insurance claims and costs and, in turn, premiums.
"We're seeing increased wildfires in certain areas. We're seeing a lot of severe weather in areas that are not traditionally high risk," said Hawley, who also pointed to more severe hurricanes and tropical storms.
Since 2019, the U.S. has seen 121 natural and weather disaster with a damages price tag of $1 billion or more. These disasters cost an estimated $667 billion, according to the U.S. National Centers for Environmental Information.
The warmer waters in the Gulf of Mexico are not only percolating bigger and badder hurricanes, they are also part of the climate dynamics fostering more tornados and other storms in the Midwestern and Plains states.
Hawley said some states have seen increases in insurance fraud and there have been contemporary and post-pandemic increases in distracted and dangerous driving contributing to higher insurance premiums.
"There's been an increase in risky driving," she said.
HIGHER REPLACEMENT, REPAIR COSTS
Friedlander said higher costs of natural disasters have conspired with inflation — including higher repair and replacement costs — to drive up costs for insurers, and in turn, premiums.
He said worker shortages in construction and repair businesses have resulted in higher labor costs, which also put upward pressures on insurers. "Legal system abuse" also contributes to higher insurance costs via lawsuits and litigation, he added.
Friedlander said replacement costs — such as materials and parts — shot up 55% during the post-COVID inflation wave — four times the inflation rate.
He also said more people are living in the paths of potential extreme weather events and natural disasters, pointing to population growth in hurricane-prone Florida, Texas and the Carolinas as well as weather factors that have resulted in more tornadoes and wind storms in the Midwest.
There's also more people living near wildfire-prone areas of the Mountain West, Pacific Northwest and area of California.
"We are seeing more storms that are major loss events," said Friedlander, pointing to the high costs of hurricanes and tropical storms and the increasing financial price tags of tornados and hail storms.
An increase in the number of uninsured drivers on U.S. roads can also translate into higher premiums.
According to the most recent numbers from Insurance Research Council, 14% of U.S. drivers are uninsured, up from 11.1% in 2019.
Car thefts and insurance fraud also contribute to how auto insurance premiums are priced.
There were more than 1 million car thefts nationally in 2023, according to the National Insurance Crime Bureau. That is up from 794,000 in 2019 — a 29% jump. Auto thefts jumped 63% in Maryland and 64% in Washington D.C. between 2022 and 2023, according to NICB.
The insurance industry also blames a familiar foe for some of the rise in premiums — plaintiff attorneys who specialize in accident claims and lawsuits. In Florida Where are the blue ribs and other states, the insurance industry has pressed for legal reforms to reduce high tides of litigation.
TOUGH TIMES
High insurance costs continue to add to Americans' economic stress and pessimism headed into the November election.
New Consumer Price Index numbers released Wednesday showed overall year-over-year inflation at 2.9% — the first time the CPI has been below 3% since 2021.
While Wall Street and big corporations have done very well since the pandemic, consumers and everyday households are still stressed and strained despite the macroeconomic reports and positive drumbeats.
A poll released Wednesday by The Economist and YouGov shows 51% of Americans believe the economy is getting worse versus 20% who say it is getting better. Only 12% of those surveyed said their personal financial situation has gotten better, according the national poll. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on rising insurance premiums (car and homeowners) driven by inflation, economic factors, and climate-related costs, directly relating to economic trends and business impacts. While environmental factors are mentioned, the core theme is economic stress and market dynamics.

title: Marriott awards top honor to Easton Fairfield Inn
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Marriott awards top honor to Easton Fairfield Inn

 August 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Business 
 
 435
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Easton Fairfield Inn & Suites has been recognized as the 2023 Hotel of the Year by Marriott out of more than 1,000 Fairfield hotels worldwide.Tucked next to Chipotle off of U.S. Route 50 and Chapel Road, the hotel is managed by Hill Hospitality, a hotel development and management company. Chad Hill, the company's vice president, said the 82-room hotel stands out in more ways than one.
"This is not a prototypical Fairfield hotel," Hill said. He emphasized its cleanliness, customer service and customized designs that give the hotel a small-town, Eastern Shore feel.
Every year, Hill said Marriott checks into each hotel for a random inspection. Marriott assesses each hotel based on a set of standards, while separately soliciting feedback from recent guests. Based on these evaluations and guest review scores, a small percentage of hotels receive the Diamond Award, a recognition from Marriott of the highest performing tier of Fairfield hotels.
Of the 1,118 hotels evaluated, the Easton Fairfield Inn & Suites was rated fourth in intent to recommend, fifth in staff service and seventh in cleanliness.
The Easton Fairfield was recognized with the 2023 Diamond Award, marking its second consecutive year and third since opening in 2015. However, this year, the hotel went a step further when Marriott recognized it as Hotel of the Year within the Fairfield brand.
According to Cristina Shockley, Hill Hospitality's director of operations, the Easton hotel is a popular destination for corporate stays and those in town for weddings.
Shockley added that many of the employees are familiar with the Eastern Shore and its history and charm, a benefit for guests that are visiting for the first time. Some team members have been at the hotel since it opened, she said.
"We're so fortunate to have an incredible team," Hill said of the team that hovers around 23 employees.
Since the hospitality group is based in Easton, Hill said it's special to have the hometown property recognized at such a high level. Hill Hospitality manages six hotels, two each in Maryland and South Carolina, and one each in Maine and New York. Two additional hotels are in the works, including one in Fruitland that will open in June 2025.
"Every guest is given the opportunity to enjoy the charming small-town atmosphere that the Easton team provides when staying at our hotel," Shockley said in a written statement. "The Hotel of the Year award is a testament to the team's unwavering commitment to give the ultimate in guest service. When walking through the front door, the hotel has a feeling of timelessness and added pride that distinguishes it from other Fairfields in the brand." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a hotel's business achievement, specifically its recognition as Hotel of the Year by Marriott. It details operational metrics, management practices, and industry rankings, aligning with Business/Economy. While Local Life could be a secondary consideration due to the local hotel's community role, the primary context is business performance.

title: Kitchen store opening in Easton
author: Staff Writer
content:
Kitchen store opening in Easton

 August 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Business 
 
 345
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A new location for culinary tools, fine tableware, high quality linens and luxurious bath products is coming to Easton. The kitchen store Welcome Home, 29 E. Dover St., had its grand opening on Friday at 4:30 p.m."We're a lifestyle store. We help you cook, dine, entertain and relax at home. We believe that everything we touch should be beautiful, serve a function and make everyday life better," said shop owner Jennifer Baker.
This commitment to quality can be found in the products that line the store's shelves. From Nordic Ware pans, Casafina tableware and Garnier-Thiebaut table linens, there is a legacy product for every lifestyle. From sheet pans, to plates, to napkins and butter dishes, one never knows what they will discover when they walk through the door.
Every season the owners edit the cooking tools to reflect the foods and cooking style of the season.
"Our displays bring together elements of our two businesses. You'll often find an amazing French jam next to a fabulous sweater, next to delightful measuring cups," Baker said. "We love bringing the process of living together, to showcase beauty and function together."
This is the third location for the specialty home store; Chestertown and Annapolis each claim a Welcome Home of their own. Chestertown is also home to Chester River Wine and Cheese Company, which Baker runs with her husband and business partner, John Laucik.
"We've long loved the vibrancy of downtown Easton and St. Michael's. Earlier this year the 'right' building opportunity popped up, and the time was right to expand our business," Baker said.
In honor of the newest location of Welcome Home, there will be a trunk show featuring 190-year-old French textile maker Garnier-Thiebaut with samples of fall patterns and 20% off their kitchen and bath linens. All guests may enter to win a $100 gift card and gift basket filled with bath and body products.
Welcome Home's Easton location is open seven days a week: Sunday-Monday, 11 a.m. to 4 p.m.; and Wednesday-Saturday 10 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. For more information visit the website WelcomeHomeMarkets.com or find them on Instagram @welcomehomemarkets. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: 6 potential Chesapeake Bay ferry routes recommended in study
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
6 potential Chesapeake Bay ferry routes recommended in study

 August 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 465
 Words 

 Read News Document

 OCEAN CITY — A five-county Chesapeake Bay Passenger Ferry Consortium released a Passenger Ferry Feasibility study identifying promising opportunities to enhance transportation and economic growth across coastal communities in Maryland.The year-long study was released at this year's Maryland Association of Counties Conference, held in Ocean City last week. According to the study, the baseline system for the passenger ferry plan is estimated to handle approximately 50,000 riders per season. There are six potential passenger ferry routes, all branching out to different communities in the Chesapeake Bay including Baltimore, Annapolis, Easton and St. Michaels.
Despite an estimated $2.5 million in revenue, the study states that without adjustments or additional funding the ferry system will operate with an anticipated loss of $2.5 million during its first year. But the study shows that the ferry system could stimulate economic growth in the region.
Heather Tinelli, director of economic and tourism development for Queen Anne's County, said the study was brought together through a grant awarded to the Chesapeake Bay Passenger Ferry Consortium from the Economic Development Administration.
According to Tinelli, if the study is implemented, it has the potential to have a more than $14 million annual economic impact and create over 140 jobs.
"It's certainly not something that's going to happen overnight, but it is feasible, and if it's phased in I think there'll be a lot of visitors and residents that would look forward to the opportunity of getting out in the water," Tinelli said.
The study found significant support from community partners and stakeholders for a regional ferry system, with 67% of survey respondents expressing interest in the ferry service and 62% of community partners interested in engaging activities for visitors as well as residents.
Kristen Pironis, executive director of Visit Annapolis & Anne Arundel County, said in a press release that the study and the consortium showcases the transformative potential of the Chesapeake Bay.
"Five counties across the state joined forces to work on this effort," Pironis said. "As we explore next steps, this opportunity can expand to include partners across the Bay. We are optimistic about the study results and the path forward, which could better connect our Chesapeake Bay destinations and create economic impact across the entire state."
The five-counties consortium consisted of representatives from Anne Arundel, Calvert, Queen Anne's, Somerset and St. Mary's counties.
Tinelli noted the consortium worked hard to provide this information to the public and hopefully, if properly implemented, the results will benefit communities throughout the Shore.
"Tourism is a major economic development driver in the state of Maryland, and we feel that working in a regional approach as a consortium, and a Chesapeake Bay region is helpful, even if the ferry doesn't move forward," she said. "To work together to boost the whole region as a whole is a way to move the state's economy forward." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a feasibility study for ferry routes emphasizing economic impact, job creation, and regional tourism development. While there are elements of local collaboration, the core discussion revolves around economic viability, revenue projections, and business implications rather than governance or environmental issues.

title: State gas prices drop to lowest level in 3 years
author: Staff Writer
content:
State gas prices drop to lowest level in 3 years

 August 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: State News 
 
 465
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Average gasoline prices in Maryland have fallen 10.7 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.35 per gallon today, according to GasBuddy's survey of 2,167 stations in Maryland. Prices in Maryland are 15.4 cents per gallon lower than a month ago and stand 43.9 cents per gallon lower than a year ago. The national average price of diesel has declined 2.6 cents in the last week and stands at $3.69 per gallon — the lowest level in 940 days.According to GasBuddy price reports, the cheapest station in Maryland was priced at $2.99 per gallon yesterday while the most expensive was $3.99 per gallon, a difference of $1 per gallon.
The national average price of gasoline has fallen 4.2 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.37 per gallon today. The national average is down 11.4 cents per gallon from a month ago and stands 47.8 cents per gallon lower than a year ago, according to GasBuddy data compiled from more than 11 million weekly price reports covering over 150,000 gas stations across the country.
Historical gasoline prices in Maryland and the national average going back 10 years:
August 19, 2023: $3.79 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.84 per gallon)August 19, 2022: $3.89 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.89 per gallon)August 19, 2021: $3.04 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.16 per gallon)August 19, 2020: $2.25 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.17 per gallon)August 19, 2019: $2.55 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.60 per gallon)August 19, 2018: $2.79 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.82 per gallon)August 19, 2017: $2.30 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.32 per gallon)August 19, 2016: $2.11 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.15 per gallon)August 19, 2015: $2.52 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.66 per gallon)August 19, 2014: $3.42 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.44 per gallon)
Neighboring areas and their current gas prices:
Baltimore: $3.31 per gallon, down 13.3 cents per gallon from last week's $3.44 per gallon.
Washington, D.C.: DC- $3.59 per gallon, down 8.2 cents per gallon from last week's $3.67 per gallon.
Hagerstown: $3.32 per gallon, down 6.8 cents per gallon from last week's $3.39 per gallon.
"Gasoline and diesel prices continue to trail off across much of the country as summer demand fades away. Lower demand in other oil-consuming nations is also helping to lead the downward pressure on pump prices as we approach Labor Day," said Patrick De Haan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy. "With little new action in the Middle East to rile up prices and Hurricane Ernesto remaining far out at sea, it looks like the downward trend could continue into the week ahead. As more schools begin to resume, gasoline demand will likely continue to ease. With the transition to winter gasoline less than a month away for the majority of the nation, gas prices will soon begin their seasonal cooling off— just as temperatures soon will as well." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Pinnacle Hospitality Group hopes to build hotel on Cambridge Harbor
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Pinnacle Hospitality Group hopes to build hotel on Cambridge Harbor

 August 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 600
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Less than a week after the city and Cambridge Waterfront Development Inc. settled a lawsuit regarding the ability to transfer certain land, members of the CWDI Board of Directors sat in the front row of an Aug. 26 Cambridge City Council meeting.With them: a hotel developer interested in building a hotel on Cambridge Harbor, the project led by CWDI to develop Cambridge's waterfront.
The first half of the meeting, the developer, Tauhid Islam, spoke about why he would like to build a hotel on Cambridge Harbor and what he would like that hotel to look like.
No deal has yet been made with Islam to develop on Cambridge Harbor. On Aug. 23, CWDI Board President Angie Hengst told the Star Democrat that CWDI will be working with the city and county to identify the appropriate time to sign a deal after "various details" have been worked through.
Islam, the founder of Eastern-Shore-based Pinnacle Hospitality Group who started his own venture in 2016 after spending two decades with Choice Hotels, has been in talks with CWDI for the past year. Islam said that in the past eight years, his group has built seven hotels, including a Cambria Hotel and a Hampton Inn & Suites, both in Ocean City.
Islam said in an oceanfront hotel room, when you turn off the lights, all you can see from the balcony at night is darkness. By contrast, in a hotel room "on the tip of the bridge," it's not just darkness, he said.
"The rumbling of the bridge, the beauty of the dolphins swimming by and the moon actually glistening on the water," he said. "That's what attracted me to Cambridge."
Islam sees this venture as an opportunity to embrace a working waterfront. He said it's an opportunity for the younger generations to learn about a "forgotten art."
"Things that our children and their children may not have the opportunity to see first hand," he said, mentioning boat repair. "I think Cambridge does bring that and it will resonate with people who are just trying to get away from the city. ... I want to create something that will make them stop."
Islam said his plans include a rooftop restaurant and a conference center. He said he wants to bring in a franchise that doesn't exist in Cambridge.
During the meeting, Islam and his team unveiled an initial rendering that shows the project concept. The rendering included balconies that overlook the Choptank River and a pool steps away from the river.
Maryland Del. Tom Hutchinson (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico), who sat in the front row of the meeting along with two CWDI board members, acknowledged that this hotel would take a few years to build and open if a deal is made.
"But boy, we have a great vision, and I think this is a great restart of Cambridge Harbor," he said.
Over the past year, tensions between the city and CWDI over the Cambridge Harbor project have received significant attention. With the lawsuit settlement — which includes both parties entering into a memorandum of understanding to address certain issues — representatives from both the city and CWDI Board have expressed hope about their relationship moving forward.
At the meeting, multiple City Council members thanked Islam for the presentation and shared their excitement for his approach to the project.
"There's an old adage that says a home without a heart is nothing but walls, roof and floor," Commissioner Laurel Atkiss said. "And its nice to hear you speak of the buildings, that they have heart in them as well. I think that's something we definitely want to have moving forward in our projects in Cambridge." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a hotel development project by Pinnacle Hospitality Group, involving business planning, partnerships with local entities, and economic development discussions. While local government interactions are mentioned, the core subject is the business venture and its economic implications.

title: Retailing is twice as nice for this Kent County business owner
author: LISA J. GOTTO Special to the Star Democrat
content:
Retailing is twice as nice for this Kent County business owner

 August 29, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LISA J. GOTTO Special to the Star Democrat | Section: Business 
 
 586
 Words 

 Read News Document

 QUEENSTOWN — Building on her more than eight years of experience as owner of the unique gift and upcycled vintage furniture store Bee Crafty Collectibles on High Street in Chestertown, Helen Cowley has expanded her enterprise to include a second location on the high-profile Outlet Center Drive of Queenstown Premium Outlets.The well-crafted Bee Crafty Collectibles sign created by her husband's enterprise, Bee Crafty Metals, was affixed atop Cowley's suite number 17 in early August in anticipation of the soft opening, which occurred on Aug. 8.
Cowley said she had been thinking of opening a second location for a relatively short time before choosing to move forward.
"Well, I thought about it last year and (then) dismissed it. And then, I thought about it again, just this past May and poof, here I am," she said.
For the last two months, Cowley has been a merchandising, machine ordering and working to fit out the 3,000-square-foot retail space, which she feels will give her core customers more opportunities to find more of the goods and products they already love from her Chestertown location.
"When I looked at the space, I thought, well, this is really big, but then it just kind of clicked. I wanted it to be 'bridge to beach,'" she said, in reference to the distance visitors often travel between the Chesapeake Bay Bridge and the Maryland and Delaware beaches.
"So, in the middle of the bridge and the beach is Bee Crafty Collectibles, and I'm going to provide whatever the clientele needs, like kitchen wares, clothes, gifts, purses and socks, and many of the same things I have in Chestertown," Cowley said. "I just try to provide my customers with what I think they'll need so they don't have to go to a big box store."
Her signature product line from Maryland-centric Route One Apparel has been wildly popular in Chestertown, so she is expanding that at the Outlet to be able to fulfill the demand of the growing, tourist-based customer profile in Queenstown.
Some new merchandise she is stocking is the Happy Crates line of apparel and festive crates. Filling crates with fun activities for kids with cancer has been the mission of another local business — Happy Crates — since its inception in 2009. Ten percent of the sale of every Happy Crates item returns to the organization to help support the mission.
And in the fall, Cowley said, customers will discover that Bee Crafty Collectibles is the place to be for Baltimore Ravens sweatshirts and gear. Right now, the store is stocked with back-to-school essential backpacks, Foozy socks and Cowley's other new line of "Swifty" merchandise for Taylor Swift fans.
Thoughts of the grand opening a few weeks ago brought a tear of gratitude to Cowley's eye for all of her Chestertown customers who took the time to support her over those first few days.
"I am really trying to make it into an extraordinary gift store just like Chestertown is," she said. "I mean, it is extraordinary, and this is going to make me cry. In fact, the first weekend I had more Chestertown people in here than anyone else."
Cowley sees both her enterprises as an extension of her own family, and that's how she wants customers to feel.
And for anyone who may be wondering about the future of her store in Kent County, Cowley simply replied, "I am not leaving Chestertown in any way."
Store hours for the Queenstown location follow regular outlet mall hours; Monday through Saturday, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m., and Sunday, 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.
