title: Urban design consultant presents analysis of Easton's economic potency
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Urban design consultant presents analysis of Easton's economic potency

 August 30, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 564
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Town employees and representatives gathered at the Easton Town Office on Aug. 22 for a presentation of Easton's economic potency for land use planning.Joe Minicozzi, the principal and founder of Urban3, an urban finance consulting group, spoke during the presentation regarding Easton's potential to up its economic potency. He compared the growth of the town to the trajectory of one's DNA.
"Cities all have those moments," Minicozzi said. "They all have a DNA baked into them through their infrastructure, their growth patterns, that will have effects into the future."
Miguel Salinas, the town's director of planning and zoning, helped organize the partnership with Urban3 and last week's presentation.
"We hired Urban3 to model the potential revenue implications of various development scenarios based on different types of land use, … how we build out, … and at what densities," Salinas said.
Minicozzi pointed out the success of Easton's core downtown area. His presentation provided hypothetical examples of how much certain residential developments, businesses and homes could deliver in property taxes per acre.
"As Talbot County taxpayers, you take up 3% of the county's footprint, you're producing 26% of the county's property taxes," Minicozzi said of the town. He encouraged the town to find "opportunities for infill" and "neighborhood growth areas."
Urban3's analysis noted there was a potential $637,000 in property tax revenue from a Poplar Hill housing proposal that never came to fruition.
In August 2023, an application from a developer to build 456 residential units between Easton Bypass and Oxford Road was rescinded. A 119-unit plan was approved by the Easton Planning Commission in September 2023, but this February, Talbot County bought the 120-acre Poplar Hill Farm property.
"That was an opportunity lost," Minicozzi said. "Make sure that you account for that or find a way to learn from this and do it in another place. Maybe that's not the right place, that's cool, your decision. But don't just avoid that."
Ward 3 Councilmember David Montgomery, who attended the meeting, said he felt it was "inappropriate" for the presentation to mention the canceled Poplar Hill proposal given that it was a "democratically led and made decision."
"The data are perfectly useful in their own way," Montgomery said of the presentation as a whole, "but I was disturbed by the way the presentation made it seem like the only objective we should have … is how we can maximize the amount of tax revenue we can take in. And that's just wrong. There are so many other things that matter, starting with how we preserve the character of the town and maintain our rural character, maintain our open spaces."
During the presentation, Minicozzi raised the topic of sea level rise. He noted Maryland Department of Planning projections that predict Talbot County will lose $817 million in property value due to sea level rise by the year 2100, with $8.1 million of that coming in Easton.
Minicozzi also encouraged the town to ensure underrepresented groups of people — such as those under 45 and the town's non-white population — should be heard in conversations of economic potency.
"Those folks get pushed out of the community and take on more burden in transportation to get here," Minicozzi said, "which is even more painful financially."
Salinas said the analysis and presentation brought information that can serve the town's planning and zoning department moving forward.
"This information can be important for us to add another tool to the toolbox," Salinas said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on urban planning analysis of Easton's economic potential, land use scenarios, property tax revenue implications, and development strategies. While local government and environmental factors are mentioned, the core subject is economic analysis and land use planning for financial outcomes.

title: Let us celebrate the mighty American worker
author: GLENN MOLLETTE
content:
Let us celebrate the mighty American worker

 August 31, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: GLENN MOLLETTE | Section: News 
 
 590
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Labor Day weekend is upon us. Let's celebrate the laborers.The willing workers of America have been the backbone to making our country the greatest nation in the world. People from all over the world have come here in search of a better life by having the opportunity and the freedom to work hard in order to make their dreams come true. The will and the joy of working has made life better for millions who have realized their dreams in America.
An acquaintance of mine who has done very well throughout his life has always been a hard worker. He has said, "The harder I work, the luckier I get." Good fortune has never just fallen on him accidentally but he has always worked hard and good things have come his way.
There is no way that Americans can stop working. Our government and all that we have and know flourishes or dries up based upon our work. Our work produces products, delivers goods, raises crops, provides fuel and feeds our families.
A country cannot sit down and expect that all the people will be clothed, fed and medically cared for without a large group of working people. The nation who does not work will soon fold. Our government cares for a lot of people now. Millions of Americans receive Social Security checks and other types of government monetary support. This money does not grow on trees but is reproduced daily by America's laborers who have their nose to the grindstone.
If you have a job and are earning a paycheck, then rejoice for your good fortune. There are many less fortunate who would love to be working who no longer have the physical or mental ability to do so.
Work is a good way to spend your time. Good honest work will keep you out of trouble and is helpful in keeping you out of a state of depression. In most situations, work is physically, mentally and emotionally healthy for people. There are always those dead-end jobs that may be very tough physically and mentally.
Sometimes you may have to change jobs. In America, you can change jobs or start your own business, but you have the option of making a new plan.
My dad was a hard-working coal miner. We would have starved if he hadn't been willing to work in underground coal mines for almost 37 years. My mother was a hard worker. Thus, we always had food to eat. Work has a payoff; you can go to the grocery store. Of course, in this economy, we haven't been able to buy as much.
A dear friend manages a restaurant with 85 employees. Most of them are immigrants who have come into the country in the last three or four years. He said, "Without them I couldn't operate the restaurant. They are faithful, work hard and do a good job. They also have a network of friends who want to work so I don't have trouble filling jobs. If I had to depend on the local American people in our community, then our restaurant would never survive. The locals don't want to work."
Sadly, I've heard farmers in Ohio and Indiana talk the same way. Their farming labor is dependent on the immigrants.
America will continue to be a strong and great nation if all Americans will keep working. When we hand all our labor over to others and quit working, we will lose our country.
Glenn Mollette's appear in all 50 states. Learn more about his books, columns and music at GlennMollette.com. Email him at gmollette@aol.com. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the role of workers in sustaining the economy, discusses labor's contribution to national prosperity, and touches on economic dependencies like Social Security and immigrant labor. While it has elements of national commentary and local workforce issues, the central theme aligns most strongly with Business/Economy.

title: Business owners weigh in on proposal to remove bag fee
author: Tom McCall
content:
Business owners weigh in on proposal to remove bag fee

 September 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 598
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — As the Easton Town Council is divided over a proposal to eliminate the town's 10 cent fee for paper bags, some local business owners are voicing that requiring the fee limits their ability to make decisions for their businesses.The law establishing the fee, which was put in place after Easton banned the use of plastic bags, requires that businesses charge customers 10 cents for every paper bag used. The idea was to encourage the use of reusable bags.
Some members of the Town Council presented an ordinance to remove the fee at the council's Sept. 3 meeting.
Business owners are divided in their stances on the fee. Some like it, as in reality a paper bag costs them more than 10 cents, and the law helps them to recuperate some of those costs. Others think charging a customer at the end of their purchase is bad for business. Several have said they feel they should be able to choose whether or not to impose the fee.
Joe Petro owns Hair of the Dog Liquors on Marlboro Avenue.
"I don't think the 10 cents is a necessary cost to the consumer, especially in this day and age," Petro said. "From a retail perspective, we already factor the cost of the bag into doing business. To pass that on to the customer — everyone is getting hit over their head with price increases everywhere they go. I think it is ridiculous."
As a businessman, he finds the rule invasive.
"If I want to give someone a paper bag as a retailer, why can't I just give them a bag? Why do I have to charge them 10 cents?" he asked. "If I give them a bag, it is my understanding of the law that I could be charged or fined for not charging 10 cents."
But Petro said he can see both sides of the issue.
"One thing good about it is it has made a lot of customers say 'I will just take it and walk out with it.' But say someone comes in and spends $500 on a bunch of really expensive wine or booze, and then I am going to charge them 10 cents on top of that. It is kind of ridiculous," he said.
There is another business owner who has given up on paper altogether.
"I don't think the environmental impact providing paper or plastic isn't going to do justice. It is either all or none. What we are doing with reusable bags is essentially passing on the cost to our consumer," said Eat Sprout owner Ryan Groll.
He also noted the economics of scale, with large business often getting a better deal on purchasing these bags because of the number they purchase at a time. Profitability is further from reach for small business, he said.
"We want to continue to do the right thing, so we buy the reusable bags. We buy 3,000 to 4,000 at time, sometimes 6,000 to 10,000 at a time. In order for us to get these bags at the price we are selling, for $1.50, do the math. As a small business, we have to fork out $12,000 to $15,000 of upfront expense," Groll said.
As far as the 10 cent ban on paper bags, he is thoughtful about the goals of that policy.
"What are we trying to incentivize? Are we trying to eliminate it? Or are we trying to punish people for taking a single use bag. You should, I think, give the business the chance to choose whether or not they want to charge for a bag. I don't charge people to use my WiFi," Groll said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on business owners' reactions to a local government policy (bag fee) and its economic implications. While the policy has environmental motivations, the core discussion revolves around business costs, regulations, and economic decisions.

title: Easton council supportive of potential spike in hotel tax rate
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Easton council supportive of potential spike in hotel tax rate

 September 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 415
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A plan to increase the accommodation tax rate in Talbot County was presented to the Easton Town Council at Tuesday night's meeting.Cassandra Vanhooser, the county's director of economic development and tourism, recommended the increase to the council. It would raise the accommodation tax, or hotel tax, from 4% to 6% in the county.
"Anybody who's renting a room to someone for less than four months who's considered a 'transient' would be required to collect accommodations tax," Vanhooser said.
Vanhooser pointed out that Talbot County's rate is the lowest in the state. Around $2 million was collected throughout the county in accommodation taxes in fiscal year 2024. If the rate had been 6%, that total would have increased to just above the $3 million mark.
She noted the success of the county in the tourism industry. Despite the rate remaining stagnant since 2004, Talbot County has more than doubled its accommodation tax revenue.
"We consider this as an indicator of our success as a tourism destination," Vanhooser said. "We know people are coming here. We know we're commanding a premium price, and people are willing to pay that."
In order to raise the rate, the county needs to ask state delegates this October to bring the proposed change to the General Assembly next year. The county is looking for support from three towns, including Easton, in order to move forward.
The towns of Easton, St. Michaels and Oxford collect revenues from the 4% tax on all hotels and short-term rentals within respective town limits or within a mile of those limits. The county collects the tax from lodgings that don't fall in or within a mile of town limits.
"The county would like to hear a vote from you on whether you would support this or not, because obviously, we don't want to go to the state legislature and ask for something that you do not support," Vanhooser said.
Ward 2 Councilmember Don Abbatiello asked if the county reached out to hotels in the area for feedback on the spike. Vanhooser said the county's tourism board has hotel representation, adding that the county is aiming to reach out to all hotels as a courtesy.
After a short discussion, the council voiced support for the proposed increase, unanimously voting in favor. No formal resolution was required for the agenda item.
"Talbot County obviously is not unique," Ward 3 Councilmember David Montgomery said. "But we have attractions that are not matched by our neighbors, and for that reason, I fully support raising this to 6%." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a proposed hotel tax rate increase to boost tourism revenue, emphasizing economic development and fiscal policy. While local government procedures are mentioned, the core discussion revolves around economic implications for tourism and taxation.

title: A better option for promoting Chesapeake Bay tourism
author: DAVID REEL
content:
A better option for promoting Chesapeake Bay tourism

 September 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 827
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A consortium of five Maryland counties — Anne Arundel, Calvert, Queen Anne's, St. Mary's and Somerset, recently released results of a $250,000 feasibility study on a new Chesapeake Bay passenger ferry system.The study concludes that passenger-only ferries — not vehicle-carrying ferries — serving Annapolis, Baltimore and the Eastern Shore destinations of Easton, Cambridge, Rock Hall, Kent Narrows, St. Michaels, Oxford, Chestertown and Crisfield are feasible.
Members of the consortium and other supporters of this new ferry system are well intentioned. The ferry feasibility study looks good on paper.
Upon closer scrutiny of the Aug. 24 executive summary of the consortium's feasibility study, there are a number of unanswered questions. There is also one alternative that should be thoroughly evaluated before proceeding further. The questions and alternative include:
Why does the consortium only have two Eastern Shore counties — Queen Anne's and Somerset?
Who will pay for projected start-up costs for a base line system requiring at least $8 million in ferry boat acquisitions and up to $5 million in necessary infrastructure improvements such as docks, passenger shelters, restrooms and attraction shuttle services at system destinations before ferry operations can begin?
Who will pay for projected $5 million in annual operating costs for a baseline system that will be only partially offset by the feasibility studies "suggestion" that 50,000 ferry passenger riders will generate $2.5 million in revenue in the first season of operation?
What is this suggestion of 50,000 riders based on?
Who will cover this deficit if passenger revenue is below projections?
What assurances are there this new venture will not replicate the historical record of cost overruns during start up and post start overruns on new transportation projects?
Where do the 67% of individuals live, who responded to a consortium-sponsored survey who expressed interest in the ferry service?
Where do the 62% of community partners live and/or operate, who have expressed interest in engaging activities for visitors to and residents of proposed ferry destinations?
Were survey respondents made fully aware that a new ferry system would not carry vehicles and would thus likely have a minimal impact at best on enormous amounts of vehicular traffic going to and from Ocean City every year?
Are consortium partners and supporters planning on state or local or government funding, for start-up and post start-up operating expenses? If so, how much?
Are they acknowledging the following current and projected fiscal realities in Maryland? The state and local governments in Maryland are facing significant challenges in funding current programs including the Blueprint for Maryland's Future (Kirwan Plan). Current projections are the state deficit will be $1 billion in 2026 and 2027, $3.5 billion in 2028, and $4 billion in 2029. Maryland also has a deficit in the state six-year transportation plan deficit that does not yet reflect the loss in toll revenue after the Key Bridge collapse and the yet to be finalized amount of state funding needed to rebuild that bridge. Earlier this week, the state proposed new cuts of cutting $1.3 billion from the six-year transportation plan after previous cuts of $ 3.3 billion to the plan a year ago, cuts that were partially restored by tapping the state's "rainy day" fund and increasing vehicle registration fees. Gov. Moore recently told Maryland Association of Counties Summer Conference attendees, all new state spending will be facing "extreme scrutiny."
Is it realistic to assume state and local funding for the launch and operation of a new Bay ferry service will be a priority or even considered in Annapolis or with local governments in the near future, if ever?
Has the consortium and supporters of more ferry service on the Chesapeake Bay given serious evaluation of an alternative to meet the goal of a new ferry service to promote tourism that could also help an endangered Chesapeake Bay way of life to survive and hopefully thrive?
There are over 400 charter boats registered in Maryland.
Operators of these charter boats have been and are dealing with extraordinary hardships due to new state regulations limiting the size and number of rockfish that can be caught by recreational fishing enthusiasts who historically come from within Maryland and beyond.
Charter boats could be more heavily promoted by destination marketing organization in the Chesapeake Bay region for Bay pleasure cruises. Charter boats can take clients anywhere they want to go, whenever they want to go, and for as long or as short a time as they want to go.
Charter boat operators also can provide data on the actual demand for Bay cruises that may or may not match data from the consortium's surveys on the demand for passenger ferry boats.
The next best step for the consortium is to meet with a representative group of charter boat captains to discuss their interest in, capacity for, and feasibility of providing more pleasure cruises on the bay. Charter boats could be a cost-effective alternative to a new, costly and unproven Chesapeake Bay passenger ferry system as the way to generate more tourism and economic benefits for the Eastern Shore and the entire Chesapeake Bay region. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a feasibility study for a Chesapeake Bay passenger ferry system, emphasizing economic viability, funding challenges, and comparisons to alternative tourism strategies like charter boats. While local government collaboration is mentioned, the core discussion revolves around economic feasibility, fiscal constraints, and business model alternatives.

title: CWDI plans to sell land to Yacht Maintenance on Monday
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
CWDI plans to sell land to Yacht Maintenance on Monday

 September 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Business 
 
 427
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — After the settlement of a months-long lawsuit between the City of Cambridge, Cambridge Waterfront Development Inc. and Yacht Maintenance Company over a land transfer agreement, CWDI is scheduled to sell property to Yacht Maintenance on Monday.The lawsuit, filed in May, alleged CWDI, the group spearheading the Cambridge Harbor project, was in violation of a transfer agreement it entered into with the city in June 2021. The transfer agreement gave CWDI roughly 22 acres of land — including about 2.6 acres of land subject to a lease agreement between the city and Yacht Maintenance — for $5.
CWDI has hoped to sell part of those 22 acres to Yacht Maintenance, but with the lawsuit that requested temporary, preliminary and permanent injunctions stopping defendants from transferring any portion of that property, CWDI had been unable to sell the land.
With the lawsuit settlement, the city and CWDI have entered into an agreement that allows CWDI to transfer property from the 2021 transfer agreement to Yacht Maintenance.
At the CWDI Board of Directors meeting on Sept. 11, Board President Angie Hengst said the sale of that property to Yacht Maintenance is scheduled for Monday, Sept. 16.
During the meeting, the board unanimously voted to allow Hengst or board Secretary-Treasurer Frank Narr to execute any documents necessary for the property transfer.
Narr said as part of the lawsuit settlement, CWDI has opened a separate bank account for the net proceeds from the upcoming property sale. He said CWDI will report how those dollars are being spent to the city and county once they receive that money.
"That was the spirit of the agreement so that the city and county are just aware of where those dollars are being spent," he said.
Narr said it was agreed with the city that none of the money from the property sale will be used for expenses incurred from litigation.
At the CWDI Board meeting on July 31, Narr brought up the need for CWDI to sell property so that it can use that money to pay for other expenses. During the Sept. 11 meeting, Narr said that CWDI's finances will look "a lot more favorable" once the sale is made.
At the end of the meeting, Hengst and Board Vice President Shay Lewis-Sisco expressed excitement and gratitude for the dismissal of the lawsuit with the city. Hengst said the board is looking forward to having a better working relationship with Cambridge and Dorchester County.
Cambridge Mayor Stephen Rideout, who attended the meeting, agreed with Hengst.
"So hopefully that'll continue and we can see really good things happening in the future," Hengst said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a business transaction involving land sale, legal settlements, and financial agreements between CWDI and Yacht Maintenance. While local government entities are mentioned, the core subject is a commercial real estate deal with economic implications, making 'Business/Economy' the primary topic.

title: Gas prices drop another 10 cents in past week
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
Gas prices drop another 10 cents in past week

 September 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: State News 
 
 482
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Average gasoline prices in Maryland have fallen 10.2 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.07 per gallon today, according to GasBuddy's survey of 2,167 stations in Maryland. Prices in Maryland are 31.0 cents per gallon lower than a month ago and stand 61.2 cents per gallon lower than a year ago. The national average price of diesel has declined 3.4 cents in the last week and stands at $3.57 per gallon — the lowest level since January 2022, more than 900 days ago.According to GasBuddy price reports, the cheapest station in Maryland was priced at $2.69 per gallon yesterday while the most expensive was $3.89 per gallon, a difference of $1.20 per gallon.
The national average price of gasoline has fallen 6.9 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.15 per gallon today. The national average is down 26.2 cents per gallon from a month ago and stands 70.5 cents per gallon lower than a year ago, according to GasBuddy data compiled from more than 11 million weekly price reports covering over 150,000 gas stations across the country.
Historical gasoline prices in Maryland and the national average going back ten years:
September 16, 2023: $3.68 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.85 per gallon)September 16, 2022: $3.44 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.67 per gallon)September 16, 2021: $3.04 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.18 per gallon)September 16, 2020: $2.24 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.17 per gallon)September 16, 2019: $2.46 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.58 per gallon)September 16, 2018: $2.83 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.84 per gallon)September 16, 2017: $2.64 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.61 per gallon)September 16, 2016: $2.19 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.19 per gallon)September 16, 2015: $2.30 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.30 per gallon)September 16, 2014: $3.34 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.37 per gallon)
Neighboring areas and their current gas prices:
Baltimore: $3.01 per gallon, down 10.2 cents per gallon from last week's $3.12 per gallon.
Washington, D.C.: $3.34 per gallon, down 15.1 cents per gallon from last week's $3.49 per gallon.
Hagerstown: $3.03 per gallon, down 15.3 cents per gallon from last week's $3.18 per gallon.
"Gasoline prices continue to crumble across nearly the entire nation, with average prices below $3 per gallon in 18 states, with some 65,000 stations selling below that psychological mark. Diesel prices are also falling and are at their lowest level in nearly 1,000 days," said Patrick De Haan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy. "With the change to winter gasoline happening today at most stations across the country, the outlook is bright for the national average to continue to make a run at falling to $2.99 per gallon for the first time since 2021. But while nearly all states are seeing prices drop, refinery maintenance and some outages at California refineries have led to tight supply and rising prices — a situation I hope can be remedied by the end of the month and help California join in on the decline."

title: Four Eleven Kitchen opens at Packing House
author: Tom McCall
content:
Four Eleven Kitchen opens at Packing House

 September 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 363
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — On Sept. 12, about 100 people came to the Packing House to celebrate the opening of a community kitchen that hopes to incubate culinary talent with space and equipment.Four Eleven Kitchen, a shared-use commercial kitchen which will serve as a space for community collaboration, has Amanda Kidd as the driving force.
"About seven years have gone into this," Kidd said."With the support of our community, we have established relationships throughout the years. We were able to take on some partnerships and get some grants. We started out with a partnership with the state and partnership with University of Maryland Shore Regional Health, many partners including DHCD (Department of Housing a Community Development)."
Kidd is not so much a chef as a community connector. Many of the speeches given at the ribbon-cutting event spoke of her tenacity, vision and grit.
In front of the crowd, Kidd said, "I want you to know Four Eleven Kitchen is not just about me. It is about every food entrepreneur, every food business, restaurant owner. We want to be a support system for them. We want to connect not only the dots for the entrepreneur but also connect the community to the food."
She also said she wants to create a safe place for "foodpreneurs" to grow and scale their businesses so that the community can thrive.
"Food is one of the things that drops all barriers," she said.
The facility was equipped with gleaming stainless kitchen machinery. There is a professional-level bakery with mixers and convection ovens. The equipment will be available for community members to book in advance.
"There will be a booking portal that will allow them to go in and select their time, their day, what pieces they want to use so there isn't much overlap. We look for a lot of collaborations and synergy to start to happen," Kidd said.
Alyssa Boyd, owner of Humble Hearts Catering and Events, is catering about 80 events a year. She said she will be using this industrial kitchen in the future.
"We are going to be catering out of here and do some classes and being able to do some social events," Boyd said.
For more information about Four Eleven Kitchen, visit https://411.kitchen/. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the opening of a community kitchen designed to support food entrepreneurs and local businesses, emphasizing business incubation, partnerships, and economic development. While there are local community elements, the primary emphasis is on business and economic opportunities.

title: AnywhereVet Mobile Clinic: a business of friendship
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
AnywhereVet Mobile Clinic: a business of friendship

 September 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Business 
 
 554
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — From building a lifelong friendship to establishing a veterinary clinic together, Paige Roberts and Holly Conroy, owners of the AnywhereVet mobile clinic, are an animal loving duo who have committed their lives to providing care to furry friends across the Eastern Shore.Together, Roberts and Conroy are changing the traditional approach to animal care through client education, individualized care and maintaining a human touch with every one of their patients.
According to Conroy, animal owners on the Shore can face many delays and difficulties when trying to get care. Conroy said she had the realization after her sister's dog got sick, and they had to travel over 2½ hours to get care.
"We need better vet care on the Shore," Conroy said. "The vet care is just so few and far between on the Shore. So we finally, kind of decided to lock down servicing this whole Shore area."
Roberts said they were both working at an emergency room in Laurel, Maryland, prior to owning the clinic together. They became friends while working overnight shifts. Conroy worked as a technician, and Roberts worked as a veterinarian.
Conroy said they worked really well together and became best friends due to their similar levels of commitment to their work and expectations of themselves.
Conroy said that though they were passionate about their work, it is a "thankless job," and working in emergency room services can make workers lose their love for their work due to being "beaten down all the time."
The idea of a mobile clinic restarted a passion for Roberts and Conroy.
Now, their clinic provides a variety of services to people throughout the Eastern Shore, including urgent care services, hospital transport, wellness services and emergency care.
For Roberts, it's important that they treat the whole patient. With their personalized care, they can provide services to cater to the individual needs of the animal and to the needs, wants and limitations of the owner.
"This is a way that we could really control all the components (from) the standard of care, the prices, and when you need to mark things up, and when you don't," Roberts said. "There's a time and a place to mark things up more significantly than other things. And we really think it's important that we're not profiting significantly off of the essential vital services like euthanasia."
Jamie Romph, client of AnywhereVet, said when her yellow lab Dixie got sick she turned to the AnywhereVet to provide Dixie with the most comfortable care she could. Even going as far as providing Dixie with pain medicine at 10 p.m.
"Those girls will be there for you, whether it's on video, answering a text message or (saying) 'hey, you're right. This is a real we'll be right out and we'll come help you through it,'" Romph said. "All the vets are great, but they work business hours. These girls have upped it a notch."
Roberts said they look forward to continuing to work across the Eastern Shore and hope to one day establish a brick and mortar clinic to better serve all their patients' needs.
"Every pet deserves care," Roberts said. "Every pet deserves that no matter what, even if they are fear aggressive and they want to bite my hand off, they still deserve care, and I will find a way. Holly and I are really good, and we still love them." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the entrepreneurial venture of a mobile veterinary clinic, highlighting business operations, market gaps, and service models. While health care is involved, the primary emphasis is on the business aspect, including client education, pricing strategies, and service delivery. 'Business/Economy' is the best fit, with 'Health' as a secondary consideration.

title: QA celebrates minority-owned business program initiative
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
QA celebrates minority-owned business program initiative

 September 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Business 
 
 549
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — A collaborative initiative to strengthen minority owned business presented its first inaugural class to the Queen Anne's County Commissioners Sept. 10.Funded through the Rural Maryland Economic Development Fund, which is supported by the Maryland Department of Commerce and Upper Shore Regional Council and administered through Queen Anne's County Economic and Tourism Development, the Minority Entrepreneurship Training Accelerator (META) pilot program provided tailored mentoring, networking opportunities, and strategic resources to help small minority-business owners overcome challenges and achieve sustainable growth.
Presenting certificates of achievements to participants, Rebecca Murphy, founding consultant of Upper Shore Community Development Founder and Chief Strategist noted META was created with the belief that diversity and entrepreneurship strengthens communities and economy.
"It is with great pride and joy that we congratulate the graduates of the inaugural class of the Minority Entrepreneurship Training Accelerator program today at this commissioners meeting. We celebrate not only their accomplishments but also the bright futures that each of them is carving out in our community," she said.
"META is a six month intensive business development and coaching program aimed at providing a cohort of small minority businesses with the resources they need to scale," said Sam Shoge, cofounder and partner of Rivers and Roads Consulting, who served as program facilitator and coach.
The program intends to close the knowledge resource and funding gap between minority-owned and non-minority owned businesses, he said.
Data is applied across all minority businesses including women-owned and veteran-owned, he said, and the importance of the program is noted in the disparities between minority and non-minority owned businesses, he said.
The average revenue of black sole proprietorships versus non-minority sole proprietorships is $22,000 versus $50,000 respectively, according to Shoge.
On average non-minority owned businesses are six times larger than black-owned businesses, he said.
A total of 15 applications from women and minority owned businesses were received in 2023 and five Queen Anne's County businesses were selected to participate in the inaugural program, he said.
Participants included Moniesha Baynard, owner of Three Guys and a Girl Personal Chef and Catering; Diane Moorman-White, owner of DMW Soul Fitness; Timeka Wheeler, owner of Long Live Assisted Living; Deayna Ewell, owner of Onyx Beauty Supply Salon Barbershop; and Ebony Johnson, owner of Tips and Toes Nail Studio.
The six-month program at the Kent Island Library began its first seminar in February 2024 and concluded in August.
META entailed monthly business development seminars including a variety of topics such as market strategy, business planning, sales and customer service, bookkeeping best practices, licensing and regulation as well as personal coaching, Shoge said.
A key aspect of the program was how entrepreneurs can partner and collaborate and support fellow community small businesses, he said.
"Our secretary of commerce Secretary (Micheal) Gill always said that economic development is a team sport and that is very much reflected in this program here," Shoge said.
Officials were very happy with the outcome and success of the program, with many participants reporting increased revenues, Shoge said.
Transitioning from a 36-year veterinary career, participant Moorman-White, credited the program with giving her the push and the confidence to prove to herself she could turn her "side-gig" into a full time career.
"Probably the biggest thing the META program has done for me was it changed my mindset. I am now recognizing the power I possess to achieve my goals both big and small," she said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a business development program for minority-owned enterprises, highlighting economic disparities, funding gaps, and entrepreneurial support. While race and diversity are mentioned, the core subject is economic development and business initiatives.

title: Maryland small businesses get $10 million grant
author: STEVEN JACOBS JR. Capital News Service
content:
Maryland small businesses get $10 million grant

 September 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STEVEN JACOBS JR. Capital News Service | Section: Business 
 
 226
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Maryland small business owners will get help with legal, accounting and financial services under a new $10 million grant from the federal government, officials announced last week.The Treasury Department is awarding the money this fall as part of the American Small Business Opportunity Program.
The award came as good news to Maryland Gov. Wes Moore, who used to run his own small business helping underserved students navigate college.
"When people would tell me it's really hard to build a business in Maryland, my response to them was always the same: I know, I had to do it myself," Moore said in a Monday press call announcing the grant.
"This is going to help more Marylanders turn ideas into jobs and businesses," Moore said, "and turn individuals into job creators."
The money is meant to fuel local growth and provide innovative resources to disadvantaged start up businesses in the state, according to a Treasury press release.
This federal funding will go to the Maryland Technology Development Corporation, an independent instrument of the state that provides funding, insight, resources and connections to early stage companies.
"There are three 'T's' that every entrepreneur faces: they face a challenge of time, a challenge of talent, and a challenge of treasure," said Troy A. LeMaile-Stovall, CEO of TEDCO.
The program, he said, will "give them access to talent that they need to grow and scale their enterprises." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: ‘Ahead of the curve’: Maryland realtors not as affected by NAR settlement
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
‘Ahead of the curve’: Maryland realtors not as affected by NAR settlement

 September 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 632
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A $418 million settlement by the National Association of Realtors has brought forth changes to traditional practices of how broker commissions are paid. Maryland realtors, however, aren't having to adjust as much as their counterparts.The settlement was reached in May after class-action lawsuits by home sellers alleged antitrust violations stemming from requirements placed on listing brokers. The NAR denied any wrongdoing in connection to those claims.
In the wake of the settlement, two key changes from the NAR went into effect in August. First, homebuyers must sign a written agreement with an agent before that agent provides any services to the buyer. Second, offers of compensation from a seller to a buyer's agent may no longer be shared on multiple listing services, which are marketplaces for realtors.
The Mid-Shore Board of Realtors' stance on the changes is that there is now an increased sense of transparency for homebuyers and sellers.
"The lawsuit was really about transparency and how (buyer's agents are) getting paid," Shelby Roney, board president, said. "And it kind of makes you reiterate why you should be paid."
Roney, a realtor for Benson & Mangold Real Estate, said Maryland won't be feeling that first change as much as other states. She pointed out that Maryland has had buyer's agency since 1999, noting a law enacted in 2016 that required written buyer agency agreements.
Maryland realtors representing potential buyers are used to signing those written agreements, detailing to the buyer what services the agent will provide and at what cost. The national rule will reinforce that routine and force buyers and agents to sign agreements that are even clearer in outlining how much commission will cost for the agent.
"We've always been very proactive and ahead of the game, ahead of the curve," Roney said of Maryland.
Meanwhile, other states that did not have clear buyer's agency law had to quickly adjust to the new requirements.
"They were already freaking out before March," Roney said of other states. "When I was in California, there were agents from all over the country, and most of them did not have anything resembling buyer's agency. And it was very concerning for them, that they were nowhere prepared. How to explain it, how to even enforce it, how to word it, their state laws were going to have to change."
The increased focus on explicit buyer's agency agreements only furthers the advantages of a buyer paying their own agent rather than relying on a sub-agent during the buying process, Roney said.
Sub-agents are agents unaffiliated from the listing real estate broker but paid by the seller or seller's agent to assist prospective buyers. They do not work for the same company as the seller's agent.
Sub-agency is still alive in the state, according to Roney. However, sub-agents are only able to provide so much help to buyers since their loyalties are only to the seller. For prospective buyers, having a dedicated buyer's agent is beneficial.
"It's the biggest investment that you're going to make in your lifetime," she said of buying a home. Roney did note that many first-time homebuyers have benefitted from the seller paying the commission for an agent.
The option for a seller to offer compensation to a buyer's agent is still available, Roney said, though not through multiple listing service databases. Now, it'll be clear to buyers before any agreement is signed.
The benefits of having a buyer's agent are significant for buyers, especially when housing prices rise, the Mid-Shore Board of Realtors says. It'll also help realtors understand their value and be upfront about what "tier" of services they will offer depending on the compensation rate.
"You have to know your value and you have to explain your value, and you also have to decide what your tiers (of service) are," Roney said. " … Where do you want me to work for you?" 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the impact of a $418 million NAR settlement on real estate business practices, including commission structures and buyer-agent agreements. While it mentions Maryland-specific adjustments, the core subject is economic regulation affecting real estate professionals, making Business/Economy the primary topic.

title: More questions on the Chesapeake Bay ferry service
author: DAVID REEL
content:
More questions on the Chesapeake Bay ferry service

 September 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 839
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Recently, numerous media outlets provided updates on a proposal for a new Chesapeake Bay ferry service.The proposal suggests a fleet of passenger-only ferries connecting Annapolis, Baltimore, Kent Island, Easton, Cambridge, Rock Hall, St. Michaels, Oxford, Chestertown, Tilghman Island, Betterton, Havre de Grace, Solomons Island, Chesapeake Beach, North East, Leonardtown, Salisbury, Galesville and Crisfield.
The proposal suggests this new ferry service would help boost tourism and economic development in the Chesapeake Bay region of Maryland.
Previous media updates reported consultants for five Maryland counties that comprise the Chesapeake Bay Passenger Ferry Consortium — Anne Arundel, Calvert, St. Mary's, Somerset and Queen Anne's concluded a new passenger ferry system was feasible and cost effective.
The most recent media updates on this project report that Anne Arundel County alone has received a $3.9 million federal grant, a grant amount far less than a requested $7.2 million.
According to their grant application, Anne Arundel County plans to use the available federal grant money for new ferry service between Baltimore, Annapolis and Kent Island.
Later this month, a 17-person delegation will be traveling to Sweden. Their itinerary includes a tour of an electric passenger ferry factory and learning more about ferry planning.
The delegation includes representatives from the Maryland Departments of Commerce and Natural Resources, the Anne Arundel County Executive, Anne Arundel County senior staff members, Anne Arundel County Council members, Annapolis Mayor, Annapolis City Council members, Annapolis City senior staff, executive director of Visit Annapolis and Anne Arundel County, CEO of the Anne Arundel County Economic Development Corporation and executive director of the Resilience Authority of Annapolis and Anne Arundel County.
Funding for attendee costs on this trip includes donations of $25,000 from the Denker Foundation and an unspecified donation from the MHE Foundation.
While this most recent update is somewhat informative, it does not provide answers to a wide range of critical questions about this project, some of which were included in my recent commentary on this proposal.
In this commentary there are new unanswered questions.
Why are all the individuals going to Sweden from state government or Anne Arundel County?Why are there no attendees on the trip from Calvert, St Mary's, Queen Anne's and Somerset counties, all of which are members of the Chesapeake Bay Passenger Ferry Consortium?Do the donations from the two foundations cover all the attendee costs for the trip to Sweden? If not, where will the balance of funding come from?Why was one of their first priorities in the Anne Arundel County grant application ordering two electric ferry boats for service between Baltimore, Annapolis and Kent Island?Why is another first priority the placement of an order for boats before the end of 2024 when no ferry service is expected to start until 2027?How do these priorities impact the feasibility of and timeline for previously announced consortium plans to launch new passenger-only ferries serving all the locations listed above in the Chesapeake Bay Passenger Ferry Consortium proposal?What is the status on efforts securing a public/private partnership to operate the proposed new ferry system?
To date, money spent or approved on this new ferry proposal include a $250,000 federal grant for a feasibility study, another federal grant commitment of $3.9 million, another possible federal grant commitment for the balance of the original $7.2 million grant request that was recently denied.
While all of the above questions merit answers, I suggest there are two questions that merit immediate answers before any more money is spent or requested for this new ferry proposal.
Have members of the Chesapeake Bay Passenger Ferry Consortium spoken to, or will they speak to owners and operators of Chesapeake Bay tour boats to discuss the impact on their business of a new ferry system operated by a public and private partnership?
A number of these charter tour boat operators already offer regularly scheduled Bay tours. They regularly go to and from Baltimore, Annapolis, St. Michaels, Crisfield, and Cambridge among other Bay locations. Some tour operators also offer customized tours to anywhere clients want to go on the Bay, whenever they want to go, and for as long a time or as short a time they want to go. Recently, a local small business in Easton recently chartered a tour boat for a customized roundtrip between Kent Island and Baltimore for an Orioles game. By all accounts, this trip was a great success.
Have members of the Chesapeake Bay Passenger Ferry Consortium spoken to, or will they speak to owners and operators of recreational fishing charter boats to discuss on if and how they can expand their services to meet the increased public demand for Bay tours as projected in the consortium's feasibility study on a new ferry? These charter fishing boat operators especially need help as their livelihood and way of life is currently seriously threatened by new state regulations on rockfish fish harvesting limits.
Answers to these questions could accomplish two things.
They can avoid reinventing the wheel. They could also allow for a more fully informed decision on whether or not this proposed new ferry system is the best and cost-effective program to help increase tourism and economic development in Maryland. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a proposed ferry service's economic impact, funding mechanisms, public-private partnerships, and its role in tourism and regional development. While local government and environmental aspects are mentioned, the core discussion revolves around economic feasibility, business implications, and financial planning.

title: Gas prices bounce back up 18 cents in Maryland
author: Staff Writer
content:
Gas prices bounce back up 18 cents in Maryland

 October 1, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: State News 
 
 471
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Average gasoline prices in Maryland have risen 17.7 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.23 per gallon Monday, according to GasBuddy's survey of 2,167 stations in Maryland. Prices in Maryland are 3.7 cents per gallon lower than a month ago and stand 28.9 cents per gallon lower than a year ago. The national average price of diesel has declined 1.2 cents in the last week and stands at $3.54 per gallon.According to GasBuddy price reports, the cheapest station in Maryland was priced at $2.75 per gallon Sunday while the most expensive was $3.89 per gallon, a difference of $1.14per gallon.
The national average price of gasoline has risen 1.4 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.17 per gallon today. The national average is down 15.4 cents per gallon from a month ago and stands 63.8 cents per gallon lower than a year ago, according to GasBuddy data compiled from more than 11 million weekly price reports covering over 150,000 gas stations across the country.
Historical gasoline prices in Maryland and the national average going back 10 years:
September 30, 2023: $3.52 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.81 per gallon)September 30, 2022: $3.43 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.75 per gallon)September 30, 2021: $3.08 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.18 per gallon)September 30, 2020: $2.22 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.18 per gallon)September 30, 2019: $2.54 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.65 per gallon)September 30, 2018: $2.79 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.87 per gallon)September 30, 2017: $2.49 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.54 per gallon)September 30, 2016: $2.24 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.22 per gallon)September 30, 2015: $2.23 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.28 per gallon)September 30, 2014: $3.31 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.33 per gallon)
Neighboring areas and their current gas prices:
Baltimore: $3.24 per gallon, up 23.4 cents per gallon from last week's $3.01 per gallon.Washington, D.C.: $3.25 per gallon, up 3.7 cents per gallon from last week's $3.21 per gallon.Hagerstown: $3.11 per gallon, up 8.4 cents per gallon from last week's $3.02 per gallon.
"Another week brings a mixed bag at the gas pump, with gas prices declining in slightly more than half of U.S. states while others have seen increases due to some refinery snags and maintenance that have emerged, temporarily delaying declines in some areas. Meanwhile, GasBuddy data shows 18 states with sub-$3 per gallon average gas prices, a count that should certainly rise over the next few weeks," said Patrick De Haan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy. "While Hurricane Helene left feet of rain behind and some states are seeing challenges in getting gasoline to stations, the storm did not broadly impact fuel production. For now, with oil prices falling back below $70 per barrel, the national average may be a bit stuck in the low $3s until fall maintenance wraps up, which could help bring a sub-$3 national average later this fall."

title: APG Chesapeake hires new regional president
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
APG Chesapeake hires new regional president

 October 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 519
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Orestes Baez, Adams Publishing Group's new Chesapeake regional president, is no stranger to APG nor the Chesapeake region.Baez started the new job Monday, Sept. 30, meeting employees at the Star Democrat in Easton. He will be traveling to APG Chesapeake offices in Chestertown, Chester, La Plata, California, Prince Frederick, Dundalk and Elkton for the rest of the week.
Baez was APG's Southern Wisconsin regional president from August 2020 through 2022. A decade before that, he lived on the western shore of Maryland as the CEO of the Maryland Pennysaver.
In 2010, Baez entered the news industry when he took a job with Tribune Publishing Company in Newport News, Virginia.
"I joined newspapers in 2010 and have been with them ever since," he said.
As regional president, Baez will oversee the Chesapeake market.
"I'm excited," he said about his new role. "Adams is a great company. They've been really good to me."
Baez — who won the first ever APG Regional President of the Year award in 2021 — said one of his favorite company memories is when the company asked him for his opinion and they supported him.
"And they let me go do that," he said. "That speaks volumes for the kind of culture that the company has."
Before taking on the new role with APG, Baez was the CEO of TravelHost, a publication connecting businesses with travelers. He said that during his time in the news industry, he's enjoyed getting to connect businesses with audiences that desire the products and services of those businesses.
"That's the creative part," he said. "That's the energizing part."
Baez, whose family immigrated to the United States as political exiles from Cuba, said he is a big fan of free speech.
"From that standpoint I think journalism plays a great part," he said. "I think journalism has evolved a lot, and we continue to evolve it along with what people want. I think we have to get smarter about how we write (and) what we write about because it is something that we have to eventually monetize to sustain."
APG CEO and President Mark Adams said in a news release that Baez brings "familiarity and experience" to this position.
"It's always rewarding when we can have an executive like Orestes return to our organization," he said.
When he's not working, Baez can often be found on the pickleball courts. The three-time national champ is currently playing on the pickleball Senior Pro Tour.
His love for pickleball blossomed after decades of playing tennis. Since picking up a tennis racket at the age of 9, he has won over 300 tennis doubles titles. While in college, Baez played tennis for Clemson University. He also coached the Clemson team while in graduate school there.
It wasn't until he was in his 50s that Baez's friend convinced him to give pickleball a try. Since then, Baez has gone from playing the sport recreationally to playing in tournaments.
As he settles into his new role on the Chesapeake, Baez is looking for houses in Annapolis with his wife, Donna. He said he is excited to contribute to the Chesapeake team.
"It's about removing obstacles and helping guide," he said about his role. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a corporate leadership change within a publishing company, detailing professional background, roles, and business operations. While it mentions local locations, the core content pertains to business management rather than local government, community life, or official notices.

title: Cannabis tax receipts reach new heights in Maryland
author: STEVEN JACOBS JR. Capital News Service
content:
Cannabis tax receipts reach new heights in Maryland

 October 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STEVEN JACOBS JR. Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 243
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — A new report shows the state of Maryland collected more than $22.3 million in cannabis sales tax revenue between April and June – a 52 percent increase over receipts of the prior three months.As Marylanders take advantage of legalized personal use of cannabis over the age of 21, the recent spike shows the industry's potential impact on the economy, Comptroller Brooke Lierman said in a press release announcing the report.
"The market for cannabis continues to grow in Maryland and has shown capacity to create new jobs, new investment and new opportunities, particularly for areas that are marginalized and left behind by a changing economy," Lierman said.
Maryland voters approved a ballot referendum in 2022, supporting legal possession and use for people age 21 or older. Then the Maryland General Assembly passed the Cannabis Reform Act in 2023 and Gov. Wes Moore signed it into law that same year.
Now it's Lierman's job to collect the taxes and disperse them to different funds supporting public health, business assistance and other public purposes.
The new industry is growing, the report shows, and state officials see the potential for more public benefit.
For example, 5 percent of the quarterly sales tax revenues go to a fund helping small, minority-owned and women-owned businesses break into the industry.
"These revenue numbers are a clear indication of the potential for Maryland's cannabis industry to drive economic growth while prioritizing equity," said Audrey Johnson, executive director of the Office of Social Equity. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

While related to legalization policies, the primary emphasis is on financial and economic data rather than health, safety, or regulatory aspects.

title: Talbot County proposes hotel tax increase to local delegation
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Talbot County proposes hotel tax increase to local delegation

 October 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 589
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Talbot County leaders met with the local delegation Tuesday afternoon to discuss creating legislation during the upcoming General Assembly to raise the county's hotel taxes.Talbot County's current public accommodations tax rate, or hotel tax rate, is 4%, the lowest of any county in the state. The tax is levied on those staying in hotels or short-term rentals in the county, collected by the business and then paid to either the county or one of three towns.
Easton, Oxford and St. Michaels collect revenues from such properties within one mile outside town limits. The county collects revenue from all other properties not within those boundaries.
A potential increase to 6%, which would increase total revenue collected by around $1 million in fiscal year 2024, requires approval from lawmakers in Annapolis.
Cassandra Vanhooser, the county's director of tourism and economic development, along with Talbot County Council members briefed Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico), Del. Christopher T. Adams (R-Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) and Del. Tom Hutchinson (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) on the proposed increase.
"I'm anticipating that this is going to be our principal legislation request for the delegation this year," council Vice President Pete Lesher said.
Adams and Mautz explained that state lawmakers will be tasked with addressing significant budget problems in the upcoming session. Adams said it's likely lawmakers will try to pass the budget by voting for state tax increases that were not passed last year.
He said it's probably the first year he will vote against the budget. Any tax bill will require his careful consideration, Adams noted, saying he'd like to hear the council's opinions on potential hotel tax legislation.
Council Member Keasha Haythe said the spike would help "level the playing field" for the county, as well as increase funding for the tourism and economic development department. Revenue the county collects from the accommodations tax goes to that department.
"This particular tax I do believe is necessary for Talbot County and tourism and (the) hospitality industry," Haythe said.
Mautz agreed with Haythe's points but brought up the benefits of Talbot County's low accommodations tax rate.
"I also agree with the perspective that would say, if your accommodation tax is lower than the neighboring county, then you have an advantage as far as attracting (people)," Mautz said. He added that the council should take into consideration that it may make the area more attractive for investors.
Jessica Bellis, CFO at the Avalon Foundation and a member of the Talbot County Tourism Board, expressed her support for the increase. She said the taxes benefit her organization since they are cycled back into Talbot County's and Easton's respective economic development and tourism departments.
"We can't market in the big world, as tiny little Avalon Foundation or as a small Airbnb in Talbot County," Bellis said. "We really rely on that tourism office for its marketing power."
Hutchinson said the county should ensure business owners are on board and lay out to the delegation how the taxes collected cycle back into the local economy.
Council President Chuck Callahan said it's important for the county to do its "due diligence" and gather feedback from businesses before voting on the topic as a council. While the bill could be pre-filed by the local delegates in November, January was agreed upon as a deadline for the county to have a draft bill ready for the legislators.
"This is a really important issue," Mautz said. "We definitely don't want to be in a situation where we go up to Annapolis and are not prepared."
"It's a different discussion when you go across the bridge," he said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Talbot County's proposal to increase hotel taxes to boost revenue for tourism and economic development, directly relating to business and economic policies. While local government actions are involved, the core discussion centers on fiscal policy and economic impact.

title: Chestertown antique electrical appliance museum sparks interest
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Chestertown antique electrical appliance museum sparks interest

 October 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Business 
 
 654
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — Saturday, as residents and visitors to Kent County enjoyed the farmer's market on High Street, high school freshman Ryan Helgerman of Gaithersburg walked into Chestertown Electric, curious.The store's name might sound like a place to pay a utility bill, but what he found was something entirely different — a place where time, technology and culture merge.
In every corner there's something interesting to see, from Victorian-era clocks to a hand-crank vacuum cleaner.
Above Helgerman, spun a 105-year-old copper-plated ceiling fan, operating with fluid efficiently. A space heater from the early 1900's hummed in the corner, generating heat immediately.
Owner of the establishment, David Hoatson describes his shop as a museum where you can buy the items.
"It's like walking into the Smithsonian and being able to purchase a fossil," he said, grinning.
Helgerman pointed to what he thought, understandably, was a music box, which turned out to be a Little Edison high voltage coil from 1900.
Hoatson explained it was probably used as a generator for a spark plug in an old farm engine.
Beside that was a Carl Zeiss Carbon Arc lamp from the 1920s. That consists of two carbon rods of differing sizes that create a consistent flame when they touch.
The customer and shop owner had a great time deciphering its uses, browsing online for German words, trying to track the mechanism's origins. Hoatson is a knowledgeable guide to do so with.
As a mechanical engineer for 35 years, working at AAI corporation out of Cockeysville, throughout his career, he's conducted military simulations, working on computer graphics. He's worked on F-35 airplanes, spending much of his time on military bases.
For the past ten years he's been into sales, restoration and running his museum. After fixing up his first fan, an Emerson from 1918 he bought on eBay, he's had a steady stream of customers, learning as he goes.
He explained that when he disassembles an item he can see not only how it functions, but insights into the time and culture it was built in.
Case-in-point, Helgerman presented a light socket. There was nothing out-of-the-ordinary really, except it had a key hole on the side.
"So if somebody tries to unscrew it, they can't steal it," Hoatson remarked.
Light bulbs in the late 1800's were a day's wages for most people, and so like with anything valuable, protective measures were taken.
Another point of fascination was where old technology combined with new technology. For example Hoatson's Nixie tube clocks are all hooked to the internet.
"I'm using modern electronics using old tubes," Hoatson said.
The Nixie tubes were made in the '60s and '70s to put in computers and expensive electronics when they didn't have LEDs and LCDs. It was the only way people could do numbers, Hoatson explained.
These tiny clocks flashed the time of the day and date.
In the back room, a slot machine from the 1930s caught Helgerman's interest. While he tried his luck pulling the lever, Hoatson explained that inside the machine are separate shelves with varying thickness for the coins that drop down in mathematical sequence.
As the young man and store owner talked over inventions, Helgerman's father came in. He too was caught up in the intricate world of the museum. Not only are there inventions, but old maps of the region, Chestertown's history, documents from the 1800s and much more.
Helgerman told his father, "I'm fascinated by this stuff. What he's showing is some of the greatest minds of the 1800s. All of this is 130 to 150 years old, and it all works."
Hoatson shrugged.
"Alot of it just works without having to to fix it up. If I buy a 100-year old ceiling fan, there's probably a 95 percent chance it still runs," he said. He added he probably wouldn't have that luck with a 5-year-old one that has plastic parts and is imported.
Hoatson invited the father and son back, as well as the public, to see him at 324 Cannon St. every Saturday from 10 a.m. to 1 p.m. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a unique business venture (an antique electrical appliance museum) and its operations, including the owner's background and customer interactions. While it touches on historical/cultural elements, the primary context is the business itself, supported by the article's placement in the 'Business' section.

title: Maryland revenues see 'slight positive adjustment'
author: STEVEN JACOBS JR. Capital News Service
content:
Maryland revenues see 'slight positive adjustment'

 October 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STEVEN JACOBS JR. Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 236
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — State officials revised their estimate of general fund revenues upward this month, making what state Comptroller Brooke Lierman called a "slight positive adjustment."But the change is "not a dramatic revision," Lierman said. "Our economic performance has been really in line with our previous estimates."
Based on their analysis, the Board of Revenue Estimates submitted a revised estimate of general fund revenues for fiscal year 2025 of $25.1 billion and an estimate of $25.3 billion for fiscal year 2026 — a minor change, though a positive one.
"The Board and the Revenue Monitoring Committee will continue to meet and analyze revenue and economic trends in anticipation of December's estimates," the board said in its September letter to Gov. Wes Moore. The board updates its numbers three times a year.
"Today's presentation represents a moderate increase in our revenues, our economy remains stable, and we are not in a recession," said State Treasurer Dereck E. Davis, a member of the board. "And that's not a small thing to say. There have been predictions, and we've been able to largely avoid that, so to me that's good news."
Despite the positive news, though, the state continues to face massive budget challenges. The state's Department of Legislative Services fiscal said last January that Maryland will start running a structural deficit in fiscal year 2025 that will multiply nearly sixfold by fiscal year 2029, when it is projected to hit $2.93 billion. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Dip in gas prices may be short-lived, says analyst
author: Staff Writer
content:
Dip in gas prices may be short-lived, says analyst

 October 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: State News 
 
 471
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Average gasoline prices in Maryland have fallen 0.7 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.22 per gallon Monday, according to GasBuddy's survey of 2,167 stations in Maryland. Prices in Maryland are 3.5 cents per gallon higher than a month ago and stand 20.0 cents per gallon lower than a year ago. The national average price of diesel is unchanged from a week ago and stands at $3.54 per gallon."While the national average dipped slightly in the last week, Iran's attack on Israel has at least temporarily caused oil prices to surge to the highest level in months, which could cause the declines to cease for now and could lead to a rise in gas prices for many Americans," said Patrick De Haan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy.
According to GasBuddy price reports, the cheapest station in Maryland was priced at $2.75 per gallon Sunday while the most expensive was $3.99 per gallon, a difference of $1.24 per gallon.
The national average price of gasoline has fallen 4.6 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.13 per gallon today. The national average is down 11.6 cents per gallon from a month ago and stands 56.2 cents per gallon lower than a year ago, according to GasBuddy data compiled from more than 11 million weekly price reports covering over 150,000 gas stations across the country.
Historical gasoline prices in Maryland and the national average going back 10 years:
October 7, 2023: $3.42 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.69 per gallon)

October 7, 2018: $2.84 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.91 per gallon)
October 7, 2017: $2.43 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.48 per gallon)
October 7, 2016: $2.24 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.26 per gallon)

"In addition to the escalation in the Middle East, hurricane season remains active, with Hurricane Milton now heading toward a likely landfall in Florida," GasBuddy's De Haan said. "As a result of potential evacuations, GasBuddy's Fuel Availability tracker will remain online for areas likely to be affected by Milton. For now, motorists in most areas can expect to see more increases in gas prices primarily due to tensions in the Middle East, but I remain hopeful that a $2.99 national average remains possible this fall."

title: Caroline Economic Development Launches New Website
author: Tom McCall
content:
Caroline Economic Development Launches New Website

 October 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 395
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Caroline County Economic Development has created a new website.Director Rob Zimberhoff helped to bring it to life. It is designed to better support the local business community.
"We worked with contractor Maven and Smith, who really built this new website for us. We put lots and lots of hours into considering how it would look, the message we are trying to send," Zimberhoff said.
He tailored the site not only for function but also for the people who could use the site.
The new site includes sections like relocate and expand, business planning and startup, key industries, and life and leisure. There are aerial photographs of available commercial real estate.
"We wanted it to be more useful for anyone doing business in Caroline County — new businesses that would like to come into Caroline County or businesses that are already here," he said.
He noted farmers and agricultural sector as being a focus of the new design.
"We have a lot of folks who are innovating in the industry. Really paying mind to best practices and environmentalism. Another one is manufacturing, they are some of our biggest employers," Zimberhoff said.
He said there is opportunity to grow with unfinished properties in Denton and Federalsburg. There is warehouse space that is not being used. He wants the county to grow without creating sprawl. He also looked at the retail sector, and empty storefronts indicate that there is room to grow.
"We wanted to make sure it was an improvement over the old site. Kendall (Teague) and I put a lot of time into the actual writing, into finding the right pictures and into making sure the messages were clear," he said.
He said he was excited about the new resources that are on the site and that they are helpful to the business community. Like workforce development and training to how to start your business to working with a lender.
"Another tool I am excited about is Resimplifi. It is driven towards commercial and industrial real estate. And agricultural real estate. It is a tool that produces a map and other data of all the properties that are available in Caroline County. It lists them in a way that is easy to find," Zimberhoff said.
He said Teague has been a huge help and the Caroline County Chamber of Commerce has helped by spreading the word.
To check out the new site, go to carolinebusiness.com. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.
