title: Raging against the machine is a poor strategy
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Raging against the machine is a poor strategy

 October 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 835
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Starting in 1991 and still active today is an alternative rock band that named themselves Rage Against the Machine. That is not surprising since their musical messages consistently promote rage against the machine. For them, the machine is defined broadly as businesses and corporations.In the most recent strike by the International Longshoremen's Association, their public messaging strategy included rage against the machine. Longshoremen defined the machine much more narrowly as the United States Maritime Alliance, an industry trade association whose members are container cargo ship carriers, marine terminal operators and ports.
Among other member services, the alliance does labor contract negotiations with union leaders on a range of matters including wages and the use of artificial intelligence powered robots.
To generate support for their negotiations with the alliance on those two issues, the union leadership launched a rage against the machine messaging and negotiating strategy.
International Longshoremen's Association leaders regularly issued profanity-laced messages directed at container cargo ship carriers saying they are unappreciative of dock workers role in their success and are indifferent to the concerns of dock workers future in an ever-changing world.
The leadership also vowed their strike would continue until all their demands on wage increases and the future use of automation on the docks were met.
Despite that rage against the machine my way or the highway messaging, there were immediate and widespread concerns that a strike would cause enormous harm to America's economy, including more inflation and possibly an economic recession.
Even some union members in Baltimore expressed concern about a strike. They had just endured not working for two months after the Francis Scott Key Bridge collapse and closure of the Port of Baltimore.
Three days after the strike began the union president abruptly reversed course on his previous rage against the machine messaging and agreed to suspend the strike until Jan. 15, 2025.
He acknowledged a tentative agreement with United States Maritime Alliance on wage increases, which were only slightly more than originally proffered by the alliance, and a return to negotiate other outstanding issues.
The outstanding issue is a ban on artificial intelligence-powered robotic automation on the docks.
After pausing the strike, the union's leader issued the following statement: "The ILA is steadfastly against any form of automation — full or semi — that replaces jobs or historical work functions."
He also said in his statement that the preservation of historical work functions is "non-negotiable." Job security for members and resisting modern technology have been union priorities for decades. In 1977, the last time Baltimore dockworkers went on strike, they strongly opposed the introduction of another modern technology — large metal standardized shipping containers.
Despite their 1977 strike, the International Longshoremen's Association lost the battle against the use of containers. Containers are now standard operating procedure. Somewhat ironically, last year the Port of Baltimore set new records on handling multi-modal containers using longshoremen workers.
When a railroad tunnel expansion project is completed (scheduled for 2027), Baltimore will be well positioned to send even more containers by rail into the Ohio Valley and on to Chicago.
On the yet to be negotiated issue of a ban or limits on artificial intelligence-powered robotic automation on the docks, I predict the future will be a repeat of the 1977 outcome. More automation is imminent and inevitable for three reasons.
First, robots are more efficient and dependable for repetitive and routine jobs.
Second, there are decreasing numbers of individuals willing to work on the docks. Even with technological changes on the docks, dockworker jobs can still be dangerous, tedious, and dirty.
Third, the unions stance that "the preservation of historical work functions is non-negotiable" is a message that will not stand. Everything in life is negotiable. In a recent Baltimore Sun article, Will Brucher, a port labor expert at the Rutgers School of Management and Labor Relations, said "Protections are already in place. To keep labor relations smooth, the employers conceded that this was something that was negotiable. It's possible they [ILA] could put a stop on new automation, but what historically has happened is they have job protections around it."
For a view of the future of technology in supply chain management, look no farther than two massive Amazon warehouse fulfillment centers at Sparrows Point. They were built on the site of the former Bethlehem Steel plant, not far from where Baltimore dockworkers were striking and picketing. At one time, this plant was the largest steel plant in the world and was one of the largest employers in the Baltimore region.
Unable to compete efficiently it is now gone.
Today, at Sparrows Point, in indoor climate-controlled Amazon warehouses, robots are helping humans meet the order fulfillment demands of Amazon customers.
Going forward there are key lessons on messaging management that should be embraced by the International Longshoremen's Association leaders, other labor unions and many comparable organizations.
Raging against the machine has not been and will not be an effective messaging strategy in generating public support for your organization's goals whatever they may be.
Raging against the machine will likely diminish your value to and support from your constituents whoever they may be. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on labor union negotiations, corporate interests, and economic impacts of strikes, which directly relate to business and economic dynamics. While there are elements of public safety concerns (e.g., port closures), the core theme revolves around labor contracts, automation, and economic implications.

title: Electric vehicles not quite ready for mass markets
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Electric vehicles not quite ready for mass markets

 October 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 780
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Ford Motor Company, the second largest car maker in America recently announced it was making major changes in their production of electric vehicles, commonly referred to as EVs.Ford has put a hold on plans they announced last year to spend $1.8 billion to transform an assembly plant in Canada into a hub for electric vehicle manufacturing.
Now their plan is to shift production at that plant to Ford's gas-powered F-Series trucks which have been the best-selling truck lineup in America since 1977 and Ford's best-selling vehicle overall since 1981.
In its coverage of Ford's decision to pivot on EVs, the New York Times noted, "The move is the latest example of how automakers are pulling back on aggressive investment plans in response to the slowing growth of electric vehicle sales."
This decision by Ford comes with a measurable impact on its bottom line and on 2,700 auto worker jobs at their Canadian plant.
That plan alone will cost the company at least $400 million as they write down the costs for the manufacturing equipment they had put in place to build the EVs. Ford estimates the change in plans could ultimately cost them upward of $1.5 billion.
Those costs pale in comparison to Ford losing $4.7 billion on EV sales last year, which is approximately $40,525 per electric vehicle sold.
Ford's latest pullback from EVs is no surprise.
The economic reality is that Ford, other car makers and advocates for electric vehicles made unrealistic and unsustainable projections on consumer demand for EVs.
The two most likely factors for less than projected consumer demand are purchase price and reliability concerns.
The July 2024 edition of the Kelley Blue Book reports the average price for a new EV was $56,520, with some models costing more than $100,000.
Reliability is a concern due to a relatively limited number of EV charging stations.
Nationwide, there were 68,475 private and public charging stations at the beginning of this year, according to the U.S Department of Energy. While that's more than twice the number in 2020, it's still just a third of the number of gas stations and well below projections.
A 2023 survey by the Associated Press-NORC Center for Public Affairs Research and the Energy Policy Institute at the University of Chicago reported that 77% of those polled voiced concerns about how they would charge an EV if they bought one.
This concern is not limited to potential EV buyers. Some current EV owners share it.
Earlier this year, the New York Times profiled a purchaser of a Ford F-150 Lightning EV. The purchaser said it was the "coolest vehicle he'd ever owned" and "it is unbelievably fast and responsive." He also said, "the technology is amazing." High praise indeed.
The problem for this otherwise enthusiastic EV owner was the EVs range or, more importantly, lack of range.
When the weather grew colder, this owner found that the distance his vehicle could travel fell dramatically. His faith in the $79,000 truck diminished to a point where he found himself wondering if he should sell it.
"People say 'range anxiety' — it's like it's the driver's fault," he told the Times. "But it's not our fault. It's actually they're not telling us what the real range is. The truck says it's 300 miles. I don't think I've ever gotten that."
Such observations are not a positive branding moment for electric vehicles or for Ford.
So, does all this news mean electric vehicles will never be more widely accepted?
In a word … no.
History is full of stories where the acceptance of new technologies grew slowly but steadily over time following initial acceptance by early adopters.
Early adopters are individuals who buy and try a new product or technology soon after it is available. Early adopters eagerly embrace change, are often (but not always) young, often (but not always) highly educated, and often (but not always) having robust disposable income.
While early adopters are among the first to purchase and use new products and services, they often become public opinion leaders over time.
Widespread public acceptance of their opinions can be accelerated when producers and marketers of a new technology listen to, accept suggestions from, and address legitimate concerns brought to their attention by early adopters.
Ford appears to be on track to do that. Their president and CEO recently said, "As the No. 2 brand in the U.S. for the past two years, we are committed to scaling a profitable EV business, using capital wisely, and bringing to market the right gas, hybrid and fully electric vehicles at the right time.
Ford currently anticipates the right time will not occur until 2027 when they plan to resume EV production at their Canadian Assembly plant.
For now, it is clear that electric vehicles are an idea whose time has not yet come. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Ford Motor Company's strategic business decisions regarding electric vehicle production, financial implications, market challenges, and consumer demand factors. While EVs relate to environmental topics, the core discussion centers on corporate strategy, economic impacts, and market dynamics, making Business/Economy the most precise classification.

title: 'Team effort' is what it takes to build and retain businesses in Kent
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
'Team effort' is what it takes to build and retain businesses in Kent

 October 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 912
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — In a recent interview, Jamie Williams noted that in Kent County, businesses are coming and going regularly."It's a churning process," she acknowledged.
For instance, Rock City Cafe's last day was Oct 12. Then Oct. 15, at that same location, 21536 Rock Hall Ave., Little Lemon Leaf Diner is advertising a hiring event, for kitchen and dining room.
Some new businesses moved in recently as well. Starbucks is now open for business, and It's Masala Time, an Indian restaurant at 3 Washington Square, had its soft opening on Wednesday, Oct. 2.
As director of Kent County Department of Economic and Tourism Development for 11 years, Williams sees this turnaround daily, offering support and creating opportunities for businesses to thrive.
While working with the Economic Commission, business owners and leaders in the community appointed by the county commissioners provide guidance and insight.
Their goals line up with the county's comprehensive plan: to retain and expand businesses while supporting start-up businesses.
With a hefty schedule to close out the week, Williams, highlighted some projects her staff is working on.
Millington Senior Housing: The Millington Senior Village is a project that will provide 52 one-story apartments for people age 62 and up.
The project is located on land once part of the Millington Elementary School property.
The county is working with Millington during the grant search process. If successful, they hope to build a community resource center, food pantry, church and daycare center, centralizing services in one location.
With all that activity, Williams hopes to have Delmarva Community Transit services to accommodate residential needs.
"The more density we have the more services we can build there," Williams commented.
Railroad Upgrade: Williams pointed out the Worton railroad system, services five companies and was in a state of disrepair for quite a while. The county had received funding from the state to fix the tracks in May of 2020.
Williams was happy to announce that in September 2024 that project is finally completed.
The fact that from the time they had received the funding to the actual repair was four years, she said, should give an indication to the public of how slow-going these processes sometimes take.
Brownfield Properties: Williams and staff has identified 12 brownfield properties — places contaminated and needing remediation.
Most of these properties, the director said, were dry-cleaning establishments, dealing with chemicals. One of these is in Chestertown, Admiral Cleaners, located across from the 7-Eleven on 212 Maple Ave.; a building that sits dormant with graffiti on the walls.
Williams asked, is it worth the county adopting a brownfield credit, a state program. Is it worth going through that kind of process to redevelop the properties?
They are seeking answers to those pressing questions.
Recreational Cannabis: Beginning July 1, 2023, individuals in Maryland at least age 21 could legally use and possess the personal use amount of cannabis. Licensing is issued by the State for those who aim to start a dispensary.
Currently, Williams said the county issued only one micro-license, for a cannabis dispensary in Millington.
According to earlier reports, the establishment is under Rahul "Rocky" Dutta and if meeting all the requirements, will be located in the vacant Truist Bank building at 400 Cypress Street.
In talking with Dutta earlier in the week, Williams reported everything is moving forward.
Short-term rental tax:The county has been working with the municipalities to collect short-term rental tax from properties where AirBnb's or Vrbo properties or other rentals of that nature are located.
Williams acknowledged that is an extensive process involving lots of moving parts.
She had worked with her administrative specialist Rose Osborn to locate the properties throughout the county. They purchased software to track these properties more efficiently as well as send out notices.
Now it seems like they are seeing positive results.
According to the July report, Williams said "64 percent of properties are in compliance."
The director expects higher in the future.
"We feel we're going to see the biggest impact after the September numbers."
Other than using the tracking software, they worked closely with the municipalities to coordinate their memorandum of understandings for short-term rental tax, so they are all on the same page.
The county collects the taxes monthly and remit it to the towns. The towns receive 90 percent of the revenue with 10 percent going to the county for administrative costs.
Even before they purchased the software, Williams and Osborn have been working steadily on this issue since November 2022.
She was thankful for the cooperation that occurred since then.
"Getting all five towns together is an example of what we need to be doing for a lot of other projects," she said.
Business Retention and Expansion: Williams maintained they have always responded to the needs of business owners. However, now, that attention and focus is being formalized as they launch their Business and Retention Visit Program, starting last week.
The department has reached out to 10 or 11 businesses so far, refining their data-gathering process and consulting with business owners.
They've been all over the county, visiting KRM Development, Hickory Stick and Blue Heron Oyster House to name a few.
The qualitative information they gather will be assessed and used to help the community.
All of this would not be possible without Economic Development Manager Katie Abbott, the Kent County Chamber of Commerce and many others, Williams noted.
"It takes a collaborative effort from everyone; that's how economic development happens."
As a team, they are helping businesses find their niche area to succeed in a region specific to rural concerns.
"We're not an area to put up a big distribution center," Williams said."We're here to promote businesses focusing on what's unique and special in Kent County." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Kent County's economic development efforts, business retention programs, and collaborations between local government and businesses. Key themes include supporting startups, managing brownfield properties, short-term rental taxes, and infrastructure projects, all falling under Business/Economy. While local government initiatives are mentioned, the primary emphasis is on economic development and business operations.

title: Gas prices in Maryland continue rollercoaster ride
author: Staff Writer
content:
Gas prices in Maryland continue rollercoaster ride

 October 22, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: State News 
 
 502
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Average gasoline prices in Maryland have fallen 8.9 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.14 per gallon today, according to GasBuddy's survey of 2,167 stations in Maryland. Prices in Maryland are 7.5 cents per gallon higher than a month ago and stand 22.0 cents per gallon lower than a year ago. The national average price of diesel has declined 1.3 cents in the last week and stands at $3.56 per gallon.According to GasBuddy price reports, the cheapest station in Maryland was priced at $2.77 per gallon yesterday while the most expensive was $3.89 per gallon, a difference of $1.12 per gallon.
The national average price of gasoline has fallen 3.3 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.13 per gallon today. The national average is down 6.2 cents per gallon from a month ago and stands 39.7 cents per gallon lower than a year ago, according to GasBuddy data compiled from more than 11 million weekly price reports covering over 150,000 gas stations across the country.
Historical gasoline prices in Maryland and the national average going back 10 years:
October 21, 2023: $3.36 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.52 per gallon)October 21, 2022: $3.68 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.80 per gallon)October 21, 2021: $3.30 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.36 per gallon)October 21, 2020: $2.28 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.16 per gallon)October 21, 2019: $2.49 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.63 per gallon)October 21, 2018: $2.73 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.83 per gallon)October 21, 2017: $2.39 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.44 per gallon)October 21, 2016: $2.24 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.22 per gallon)October 21, 2015: $2.19 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.23 per gallon)October 21, 2014: $3.07 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.08 per gallon)
Neighboring areas and their current gas prices:
Baltimore: $3.10 per gallon, down 11.2 cents per gallon from last week's $3.22 per gallon.
Washington, D.C.: $3.23 per gallon, down 2.9 cents per gallon from last week's $3.26 per gallon.
Hagerstown: $3.23 per gallon, up 4.0 cents per gallon from last week's $3.19 per gallon.
"The median U.S. price for gasoline has just slipped below the $3 per gallon mark for the first time since early 2024, while the national average price of gasoline has returned to decline as oil prices have begun to cool off after Iran's attack on Israel, due in part to sources saying Israel has agreed not to attack Iran's oil infrastructure," said Patrick De Haan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy. "With the potential of an attack on Iran's oil infrastructure decreasing as a result, the risk calculus for oil is decreasing, and with continued economic weakness in China providing bearish sentiment, oil prices late last week slipped back below the $70 per barrel mark, opening the door for a longer decline to potentially return to the national average. I'm hopeful that the downward trend will continue again this week for a majority of Americans as we see the average price of gasoline start to make a targeted effort to fall below the $3 per gallon mark for the first time since 2021." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

While local data is mentioned, the core subject is economic pricing dynamics rather than local governance or news.

title: Bradford House Apartments under new management
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Bradford House Apartments under new management

 October 25, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Business 
 
 523
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — The Bradford House Apartments are under new management with a new principal owner.Nuveen — an asset manager and subsidiary of financial planning firm TIAA — has been made principal owner of the apartment complex on Race Street in Cambridge. Bradford House offers multifamily, subsidized housing for low-income individuals who are elderly or have special needs.
Paths Management Services, a subsidiary of Nuveen, will manage the property.
Over the past year and a half, residents have expressed concerns about the safety of the building, from bed bug infestations to call-for-aid systems not working to a lack of security.
In September 2023, the property — which was then managed by Cleveland-based company Millennia Housing Management — received a U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development inspection score of 30c. The score indicated health and safety deficiencies and other problems identified with building systems, the building's exterior and individual apartments.
In an email, Justin Henry with Paths Management said that since taking over, the company has begun making "significant repairs and improvements."
"Our top priority is residents' safety, so we currently are installing new security cameras, adding new indoor and exterior lighting, as well as updating the building's access system," Henry said. "We are working around the clock to ensure residents feel safe, secure and comfortable in their homes."
Bradford House resident and the complex's tenant association chairperson Linda Johnson said new management is friendly and putting in work to address problems on the property. Johnson, who has lived in the building since May 2000, said Paths Management Services has painted her apartment, put new lighting in the hallways and cleaned up the back stairwells.
"I can finally really smile," she said.
According to an Oct. 18 memo from Cambridge Assistant City Manager Brandon Hesson to the Cambridge City Council, Millennia is no longer responsible for the management of the apartment, but it will remain a "minority partner" on the property.
The memo says Millennia and its CEO Frank Sinito received a debarment order from HUD, which prevents the company from participating in any new business with HUD.
In an interview, Hesson said that while Millennia "grossly mismanaged" the property, the finger shouldn't be pointed at any one person. He said it's a partnership between ownership, management, the city and HUD.
"The way out of it is for us to get on the same page," he said. "That's all we're trying to do is remind each other that we all benefit, but the residents have to be able to live in a clean, safe environment."
In the memo, Hesson listed nine areas where progress is being made at Bradford House. Progress includes plans to be completed within 120 days, including completed repair of building's second elevator, commitment from management to do a complete repair of the roof, new contracts for security and security cameras, and advertisement of a service coordinator position.
Hesson said 13 of the building's units have been rehabbed and a plan is being made to address the building's remaining units.
"At this week's meeting, 48 open violations were reviewed, and half of those violations were closed and completed," Hesson said.
Weekly meetings between city code enforcement, HUD, management and ownership will continue, the memo stated. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the change of management and ownership of an apartment complex, involving financial entities (Nuveen/TIAA) and business operations. While public safety and local government aspects are mentioned, the core subject is the business transition and management restructuring.

title: Waterfowl Festival has economic impact of more than $3 million each year
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Waterfowl Festival has economic impact of more than $3 million each year

 November 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 503
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Talbot County Economic Development and Tourism Director Cassandra Vanhooser considers the Waterfowl Festival a crossroads between art, community and business."And some would argue —including I would argue — that those are the things that make Talbot County so strong and such a special place," she said.
During the festival's Impact Business Networking Breakfast Friday, the connection between art, community and business was in full force. Community members ambled the PNC Pavilion on Harrison Street, mingling with each other and gazing at art.
Waterfowl Festival Executive Director Deena Kilmon said the breakfast, hosted by The Arc Central Chesapeake Region and Talbot County Economic Development and Tourism, is a venue for the community and business leaders to meet and talk about the festival as well as what's going on in town.
"What economic development things are happening in the community, what's going to impact us coming up in the next few months," Kilmon said.
Kilmon called the relationship between the festival and local businesses "incredibly important."
"We're symbiotic," she said. "So if they succeed, we succeed and vice versa."
The three-day festival has an economic impact of more than $3 million each year, Kilmon said. It benefits hotels, restaurants, retailers and even local nonprofits.
"It's typically one of the biggest fundraising events of the year because a lot of the food vendors and people involved in the festival, they are nonprofits," Kilmon said. "And they're allowed to keep their proceeds, so it's extremely important to a lot of people."
Jonathon Rondeau, president and CEO of The Arc Central Chesapeake Region, said this is The Arc's fourth year sponsoring the breakfast event.
"As a provider that's focused on housing and services, we believe strongly in investing in the communities where we serve," he said. "And the Waterfowl being a signature event for the town that connects conservation and art and economic development, (it) aligns to the work that we do."
Addressing attendees of the breakfast Friday morning, Rondeau talked about the importance of that involvement in communities.
"And so we're incredibly proud to partner The Arc around this and to align the connection of art, conservation, economic development and, most importantly, community," he said. "In this day and age, that's what each of us are looking for."
The breakfast's keynote speaker, Carl Anderton, who is currently serving as the director of rural economic strategy in the Maryland Department of Commerce, talked about the importance of the business community. He called the opportunity to provide jobs a "generational blessing."
"When you employ someone, you're giving them an income, yes, but you're also letting that trickle down to the generations behind them," he said, "and it's just truly amazing."
Vanhooser thanked attendees for doing business in the county. She said it's the business community that makes the "wonderful things" that happen in the county possible.
"It's that private investment along with the public investment that builds the community," she said. "And it's the festivals like the Waterfowl Festival — the granddaddy of them all — that weaves that fabric of the quality of life that we all love so much." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the economic impact of the Waterfowl Festival, emphasizing its role in supporting local businesses, tourism, and community development. While arts and culture are mentioned, the primary theme revolves around economic development and business partnerships.

title: Dollar General opens in Trappe
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Dollar General opens in Trappe

 November 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 359
 Words 

 Read News Document

 TRAPPE — A Dollar General has opened in Trappe, bringing with it fresh produce, toys and essentials. The new store opened on Ocean Gateway near the U-Haul Moving & Storage earlier this month.The Dollar General is ready to serve new and established residents in Trappe who previously had to drive to Cambridge or Easton to secure groceries and other household goods.
The Dollar General's Public Relations team said the store believes in providing positive economic benefits including additional access to affordable products for customers; new job opportunities for local residents; generation of additional tax revenue for the town; and the ability to support local nonprofits, schools and libraries through the Dollar General Literacy Foundation.
"Dollar General is deeply involved in the communities it serves and is an ardent supporter of literacy and education through the Dollar General Literacy Foundation, which awards grants each year to nonprofit organizations, schools and libraries within a 15-mile radius of a Dollar General store or distribution center to support adult, family, summer and youth literacy programs," said an email from the Dollar General.
Though the Dollar General's Public Relations team stated that the store chain is not a grocer, there is a public investment in the health of "our hometown communities." Emphasizing the fresh produce stocked in more than 5,400 Dollar General stores.
The Dollar General was constructed by local entrepreneur Tom Mitchell, president of Delmarva Management Group and a Trappe business owner. Mitchell's previous business ventures include the Coffee Trappe, Cork & Bottle Trappe Liquor Store and Momma Maria's Mediterranean Bistro.
Mitchell said in a previous interview that he seeks to invest and add new businesses to the town in the upcoming years. Additionally, Mitchell said that the two lots next to the Dollar General are in discussion of new development, including a potential quick-service restaurant franchise.
The public relations team for the Dollar General said they are excited to invest in towns like Trappe and plan to employ approximately 10 to 15 employees in the upcoming months.
"As part of our mission of 'Serving Others,' we look forward to serving the Trappe community as a positive business partner and good community neighbor," the email from Dollar General said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Dollar General's new store opening, emphasizing economic impact, job creation, and community investment. While mentions of education and health are present, the primary theme aligns with business expansion and local economic development.

title: Alpacas, lunch and learn for Caroline Women in Business
author: Tom McCall
content:
Alpacas, lunch and learn for Caroline Women in Business

 November 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 374
 Words 

 Read News Document

 PRESTON — Zen, mindfulness and alpacas brought over 20 female leaders together on Tuesday.The super soft animals followed the women, who were all armed with green feed buckets, around in a pasture at Outstanding Dreams Alpaca Farm. This was the site of lunch and learn for the Caroline County Women in Business.
It was a fun moment of delight to see and touch these creatures from the Andes.
"Look at them following her. This is hilarious," Tracey Snyder, director of the Caroline County Chamber of Commerce, said.
"We love the alpaca farm. This is the second time the chamber has been here. Women in Business meets quarterly. We're going to eat a sack lunch from the Culinary Center. We are going to do a little sip and shop and we have Michelle Hammond as our guest speaker. She is going to show us how to be a little more zen in our hectic lives," Snyder said.
Owner of Outstanding Dreams Alpaca Farm Phil Liske gave a talk on the animal's behavior.
After the animal interaction, it was time to listen to the keynote speaker, healer Michelle Boulden Hammond.
"We are talking about mindfulness today. It is a peaceful forum and how to handle stress today. Some spiritual message like how to learn about frequencies. Learn about how to get yourself grounded. We will learn stress management techniques," Hammond said.
She said it is even beneficial for the animals and their frequencies. She specializes in sound healing.
"We are going to do a little breath work. I have got my sound bowls. I got my tuning forks and I have my ocean drum. So I will give a little demonstration. I have a brass and I have a crystal bowl," Hammond said.
She also had a comment on the current moment.
"In these times of high stress, there is a lot of hostility. You have got to learn to get grounded and centered. Always reflect the negativity with the goodness," Hammond said.
One participant was Nikendra Bordley, who runs the hair salon Scalp Reveals in Federalsburg. She specializes in dreadlocks.
"I love it. It is a new experience," she said about the event Tuesday. "I have never seen alpacas. I have only known of llamas. I like seeing everybody getting together and the other Chamber members." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a business networking event for women in Caroline County, featuring a keynote speaker on mindfulness and stress management. While there is a wellness component, the primary context is business-related activities and professional development.

title: Garden Girl coming to downtown Rising Sun
author: Jane Bellmyer jbellmyer@ceciwlhig.com
content:
Garden Girl coming to downtown Rising Sun

 November 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jane Bellmyer jbellmyer@ceciwlhig.com | Section: News 
 
 313
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Look for Garden Girl to bloom on East Main Street in Rising Sun next year, incorporating its salads, soups, sandwiches and acai bowls the food offerings of Rise N Grind Cafe."I always go out and look for healthy options," said Natalie Vanderhoef, owner of Garden Girl, now under construction at the corner of East Main and South Queen Street. "I couldn't think of a better place than Main Street."
In fact, Rise N Grind is converting its outdoor patio to indoor seating and the seating at Garden Girl will be made available to the coffee shop customers, and vice versa.
"We'll still have outdoor seating but now we're building a porch on the Main Street side," said Angie Vanderhoef, owner of Rise N Grind and Natalie's mother. "We're growing the indoor space and we'll have 50 more spaces when you include the enclosed patio."
Natalie has been working at Rise N Grind since it opened in 2018 but this is her first restaurant.
"I have really learned from my mom's dedication to growing her business," she said. "But it's always been my dream to open my own business."
Construction to turn the office building into a restaurant began three months ago.
"We want it to feel like you're in a farmhouse ... like your great grandmom's kitchen," Angie Vanderhoef said the goal for casual dining. "With an updated interior but in a cozy home."
Natalie is getting ready to start shopping for vendors including searching for locally sourced food to use for her menu.
"We are also going to be having vendors in the building," Natalie said. "We want to support more local entrepreneurs."
Natalie expressed her gratitude for the support she is receiving even though her grand opening won't happen until January.
"I am getting support like no other," she said. "I am unbelievably grateful to the people and the town. Without them I would not be able to do this." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the opening of a new restaurant (Garden Girl) emphasizing business expansion, local entrepreneurship, and community engagement. While health aspects are mentioned via healthy food options, the core theme revolves around business development and economic activity in the local area.

title: Talbot Works Business Academy graduates 8 small businesses
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Talbot Works Business Academy graduates 8 small businesses

 November 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 392
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A Talbot County initiative training small businesses and minority business leaders celebrated a graduation on Tuesday.The Talbot Works Business Academy, led by the county's economic development and tourism department, brought in eight small businesses for its second round of training in September. Following eight weeks of meetings and assistance, those businesses completed the academy.
Two business leaders spoke Tuesday at Talbot County Council, reflecting on how the academy helped them expand their ventures. Stefanie DiFiglia, founder of Two Tree Integrative Health, said "the program couldn't have come at a better time."
"I had grown pretty slowly, organically through word of mouth, and that only works until it doesn't," DiFiglia said. "I found myself in a situation where I had hired new staff and was really trying to figure out how to use them in the best way possible."
She said she feels she's in a "much better position now" than where she was before entering the program.
Anijah Wilson, owner of home health care service Libby's Loving Hands, also spoke to the council.
"We have had great benefit from this program," Wilson said. "I've learned a lot about numbers, marketing, laws, HR. And I'm so excited to see what comes from this, and grow my business and community."
The training program was created by Will Holmes Consulting, a Baltimore-based business management firm. Founder Will Holmes shared details of the program with the County Council.
"We focus heavily on cash flow projections as a foundation of the program to make sure that people understand their numbers so they can plan ahead when to hire people, when to expand and how much it will cost," Holmes said. "It helps them with their pricing. It helps them with understanding how to access capital."
Cassandra Vanhooser, Talbot County's director of economic development and tourism, said funding from the Maryland Rural Economic Development Fund helped launch the program, which graduated its first cohort of 15 businesses earlier in the year.
Vanhooser added that the Mid-Shore Regional Council is funding a third cohort this winter. She said the county contributed American Rescue Plan Act funds for cohorts in the future.
"I just want to say thank you again to the County Council, to all of you for your support," Vanhooser said. "(Council Member Keasha Haythe) especially, for your idea of bringing this to me. I think it's been five years but we got it done." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a business training program for small businesses and minority entrepreneurs, emphasizing economic development, funding sources, and business growth. While local government entities are involved, the core subject is economic development and business support.

title: 'A full circle moment': Maryland entrepreneur makes childhood dream a reality
author: Jane Bellmyer jbellmyer@cecilwhig.com
content:
'A full circle moment': Maryland entrepreneur makes childhood dream a reality

 November 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jane Bellmyer jbellmyer@cecilwhig.com | Section: News 
 
 375
 Words 

 Read News Document

 There's a new place to grab a cup of coffee and something gooey and sweet in the northernmost reaches of Maryland's Eastern Shore and it's called Izzy's Coffee House.'Izzy' is Izabelle Upp, and she opened Izzy's Coffee House earlier this month in the former Little Lamb Cafe at 2728 Augustine Herman Highway in Chesapeake City.
Upp saw herself owning a coffee shop in 7th grade. Born and raised in Cecilton, she graduated from Bohemia Manor High School in 2016 and now has a degree in veterinary medicine. However, her mother commented she should own a coffee shop and then she noticed Little Lamb was closing.
"It was a full circle moment and now here I am," Upp said. "It was just one of those things that kind of happened."
Upp had help from family and friends to give the shop a new coat of paint and new decor including pictures of her as she grew up, and furniture from the family home.
"I wanted people to get a grasp of who I am," she said, adding, "I wanted to communicate that you can come here and everyone can feel like family."
That family feel includes using products from nearby businesses and giving shelf space to local entrepreneurs.
"I use regional bakeries in Middletown, Delaware and the breakfast sandwiches made fresh come from 410-Seafood," Upp said, referring to the eatery a few doors down. Lockbriar in Chestertown is where she gets honey and ice cream for the menu, but also has their pasta sauce for sale on the shelf.
In the short time she's been open Upp said it's been fun to share her coffee knowledge with her customers. She offers hot and iced coffee, with or without espresso and already has customers returning to order a specific flavor called The Cortado.
"It's an espresso shot and steamed milk," she said, explaining the unique flavor blend. "Our coffee is traditional and authentic."
Izzy's Coffee House is open 6 a.m. until 2 p.m. Monday through Friday and from 7 a.m. until 2 p.m. Saturday and Sunday. Use the Clover app to order in advance.
Find the menu online at: https://www.izzyscoffeehouseccity.com
Call 410-885-7012 for more information.
Speaking of menu, feel free to bring your canine companion because there's a Pup Cup on the independent local coffee shop's menu too. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on an entrepreneur opening a coffee shop, highlighting business ownership, community engagement, and local economic activity. While 'Local Life' is relevant due to community emphasis, the primary focus on entrepreneurship and business operations aligns most directly with 'Business/Economy'.

title: Waterfowl Festival soaring to new heights
author: Staff Writer
content:
Waterfowl Festival soaring to new heights

 November 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editorials 
 
 579
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Congratulations to the many people who made this year's Waterfowl Festival a success.The annual celebration of wildlife, art, music and history brought between 25,000 and 30,000 people to Easton last weekend.
Congratulations, too, go to Deena Kilmon in her first year as executive director of the festival. She is definitely at the top of the list for a rookie of the year award.
If there was any fear of a drop-off with new leadership, Kilmon put those fears to rest and set a high bar for success in coming years.
"We know we broke every record we've ever broken," Kilmon said on Monday.
"We had the highest attendance ever," Kilmon said. "It's hard for us to gauge because not everyone buys a ticket. But we do know that every parking space was full and every bus had about 45 minutes to an hourlong wait, and we had to add three buses on Saturday to accommodate the people."
Kilmon got a helping hand from Mother Nature who blessed the weekend with lovely weather and temperatures approaching 80 degrees under sunny skies for several of the days.
The executive director said multiple vendors — many of whom are already asking about next year — sold out or had record days at the festival.
If you have a 2025 calendar already, mark the weekend of Nov. 14-16 for the 54th Waterfowl Festival. We have no doubt that Kilmon will improve upon the tremendous success of this year's festival.
The success of the Waterfowl Festival is a success for the town of Easton and Talbot County too.
Downtown Easton shops were packed all three days of the festival, and restaurants had waiting lists for tables.
Kilmon called the relationship between the festival and local businesses "incredibly important."
"We're symbiotic," she said. "So if they succeed, we succeed and vice versa."
The three-day festival has an economic impact of more than $3 million each year, Kilmon said. It benefits hotels, restaurants, retailers and even local nonprofits.
"It's typically one of the biggest fundraising events of the year because a lot of the food vendors and people involved in the festival, they are nonprofits," Kilmon said. "And they're allowed to keep their proceeds, so it's extremely important to a lot of people."
At a breakfast Friday morning, Talbot County Economic Development and Tourism Director Cassadra Vanhooser extolled the virtues of the business community that makes the "wonderful things" that happen in the county possible.
"It's that private investment along with the public investment that builds the community," she said. "And it's the festivals like the Waterfowl Festival — the granddaddy of them all — that weaves that fabric of the quality of life that we all love so much."
The festival may have just celebrated its 53rd anniversary, but it continues to grow and evolve.
Throughout the festival venues music filled the air and complemented the many duck and geese calls typical of the festival. Overall there were 38 musical acts on multiple stages.
"That made the festival have a different vibe this year, I think," Kilmon said, "just made it more of a friendly family party on every corner."
Feedback has been "incredibly positive," and Kilmon is excited to begin work on continuing Easton's Waterfowl tradition.
"Fifty-three years of our community coming together just gets better every year," Kilmon said. "And we're already working on next year, believe it or not."
It is good that Kilmon and her team are already working on the 2025 show. This year's show will be tough to top. We have no doubt they will rise to the challenge. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the economic impact of the Waterfowl Festival, including attendance figures, vendor success, local business benefits, and annual revenue. While it mentions cultural elements like art and music, the core emphasis is on the festival's role in driving economic activity for Easton and Talbot County.

title: Hundreds of laid-off miners mull their futures as winter begins
author: JACI WEBB Outlook Editor
content:
Hundreds of laid-off miners mull their futures as winter begins

 November 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: JACI WEBB Outlook Editor | Section: News 
 
 1206
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Eric Giesick thought he hit the jackpot when he landed a job at Sibanye-Stillwater mine in 2011. Growing up in Billings, he and his family often camped at Woodbine Campground near Nye, and Giesick would watch the big trucks go rumbling down the mountain loaded with ore from the mine. He told his folks he planned to work there one day.The last 13 years at the mine have had a permanent impact on Giesick, now 49 and living in Columbus. There were good times, challenges with historic flooding in 2022, new mine owners to adjust to, and now this — the layoff of as many as 700 miners, including Giesick. Giesick's last day at Sibanye-Stillwater was Nov. 8. He picked up his gear and walked away just after sunrise that morning.
It came as somewhat of a relief. The months of uncertainty were over.
"I'm kind of sad. I'm going to going to miss being underground. Mining gets in your blood."
'Looking for people to blame'
Giesick joins hundreds of others who worked at the mine, all trying to figure out what the next step is. The Montana Department of Labor & Industry organized a rapid response information event the week of Nov. 12, which was when the layoffs were finalized, and experts in employment, education, training and insurance helped miners consider their next move. Sibanye-Stillwater mine announced in September that it was laying off up to 700 miners from its workforce of 1,900 miners.
Elizabeth and Mitchell Ramba, of Red Lodge, started their career with Sibanye-Stillwater right out of college. The married couple graduated from the University of Colorado in Boulder with geology degrees, and were excited to begin their careers in hard-rock mining in 2020. Their first day on the job was Nov. 2, 2020, and on Sept. 12, they were notified that their jobs were being eliminated.
"There has been a lot of mistrust and hate. You want to look for people to blame, but it's the market shifts and other factors. I don't think it was any individual's fault," Elizabeth said.
They built a life in the mountain town of Red Lodge, fell in love with Montana, and got hooked on mining. They each worked with a team of miners and went in to inspect the operation between the drilling and the blasting.
After taking a break to go back home to Ohio and visit their families, the couple will begin the process of looking for work, most likely in the mining industry. But there is one thing that holds them back.
"A lot of places that have mines aren't as pretty as Montana," Mitchell said.
New job, new mine
Giesick starts his new job Dec. 12 at the Montana Resources open pit copper mine in Butte, but that's 185 miles away from his family back home in Columbus. He'll cross the Continental Divide on his commute to work, and start a new chapter in open pit mining.
There were many good years working at Sibanye-Stillwater mine. Giesick enjoyed the work and forged friendships with miners from all over the world. Miners are a tight brotherhood and sisterhood, connected now mostly through social media.
Giesick and some of his carpool buddies gathered for one last Taco Tuesday at the 5 Spot bar in Absarokee on Nov. 12. Like other businesses in the area, the 5 Spot will suffer with the loss of hundreds miners and their families.
Giesick counted all the ways he felt the company mismanaged funds, including buying equipment that wouldn't fit the tracks, and his favorite: putting in heated sidewalks at the mine.
Angry miners have been spray painting derogatory messages toward some of the management on the walls of the mine. Giesick said that is why some miners were invited to leave early. He heard about the offer, and asked if he could leave a few days early as well. His last day was originally scheduled for Nov. 12.
Another job, another layoff
Dustin Stanfield started his job with Sibanye-Stillwater in July, after a contractor he worked for, Moran Mining and Tunneling lost their contract with the mine. He feels like he was hired to be laid off to protect another miner's position.
"There were several of us hired on so the miners with seniority could stay. It's just part of it," Stanfield said.
Stanfield knows about layoffs. Originally from Oklahoma where he started working in the oil fields in Texas and Oklahoma, he was transferred to Douglas, Wyo., where he worked in the oil fields for 11 years before he got laid off. At Sibanye, he drove the muck truck. He missed his work with Moran on the raise crew where he helped with blasting for a little over a year, but he did like driving the truck through the slippery tunnels.
Now Stanfield is stuck. he doesn't have the 3-5 years of mining experience to transfer to another mine, and he doesn't want to battle the elements again in the oil fields of Wyoming. He hopes to get some training for a new career path.
'I needed two more years'
Annette McFarland, of Columbus, was the chief mining engineer until the November layoffs. She has spent 32 years working in mining, the last five at Sibanye-Stillwater. She was near the end of her career.
"I needed two more years," McFarland said.
Months before she was informed in September that her job was gone, McFarland got nervous.
"In April, I put my property on the market and sold it in May."
She bought property in Byron, Wyo., and is building a house there as she continues to look for work. McFarland worries about agism as she navigates the application process searching for another job in mining.
"There is a camaraderie, a fellowship in mining. People who mine are the hardest working, most dedicated people I know. It's a high-risk job, and you're doing everything you can to make sure everybody goes home safe," McFarland said.
'It's just sad'
Betty Kilburn, of Livingston, worked as an underground operator at the Sibanye-Stillwater East Boulder Mine for 22 years. She took a voluntary layoff to save someone else's job.
"It was so fast. You had a job one day, you didn't know if you had one the next," Kilburn said.
She talked the options over with her husband, Paul Rugh, who is a salaried supervisor at the mine. Rugh kept his job.
"It breaks my heart, it really does," Kilburn said. "There are a lot of people living paycheck to paycheck. My husband said, 'Babe, we're not hurting as much as other people are. If you take this layoff, you can give somebody else a job that probably really needs it."
So that's what she did.
"Everybody is sad," Kilburn said. "Everybody is just going to be uprooted. Now you're splitting up families. The husband is on the road, and the wife is home raising the kids."
Dan Beluscak, president of the United Steelworkers Local 11-0001, said there are many fathers and sons, and husbands and wives, who work at the mine. It's a proud legacy that miners passed on to the next generation.
"We were promised that our kids' kids could work at the mine," Beluscak said. "What happens when half of us have to leave? It's the schools and the businesses that are going to hurt the most. We built up these towns of Absarokee, Nye and Fishtail. We've raised our kids here." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the economic impact of mine layoffs, including market-driven decisions, workforce restructuring, and effects on local communities. While 'Local Life' is relevant due to community impact, the core theme revolves around business decisions and economic factors.

title: Thanksgiving meals are 29% more expensive from 2020
author: Mike Sunnucks
content:
Thanksgiving meals are 29% more expensive from 2020

 November 25, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks | Section: Food 
 
 278
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The cost of a Thanksgiving dinner is 29% more expensive from 2020, according to a new survey of holiday meal costs by the American Farm Bureau Federation.The Farm Bureau's annual Thanksgiving dinner price survey found holiday meal staples to serve 10 people total $58.08 nationally.
That is down from a record high meal cost of $64.06 in 2022 when the post-pandemic inflation wave was at its highest.
But holiday meal prices are still 24% higher than they were in 2020 in the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic's economic and social shutdowns.
Thanksgiving meals cost $46.90 in 2020.
Those prices are based on 10 Thanksgiving food items such as turkey, cranberries and pumpkin pie ingredients.
But if the food list expanded to include potatoes, green beans and ham the average cost in 2024 is $77.34, according to the Farm Bureau.
The same 13 items cost $60.11 in 2020, according to the agriculture group.
That's a 29% rise.
Turkey prices have come down compared to 2023.
Inflation was a top concern of voters in the 2024 presidential election with economically stressed voters preferring now President-elect Donald Trump over Vice President Kamala Harris.
Overall, U.S. prices are up 22% since before the pandemic in 2020, according to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics.
"While inflation has slowed down, it really hasn't slowed down enough to bring costs back down to these pre-pandemic levels. So it's really important to remember that our farmers and ranchers, like our consumers, are also dealing with inflation, so the cost of supplies to grow food has gone up, while USDA predicts that net farm income is going to be down nearly 25 percent compared to just two years ago," said Bernt Nelson, a Farm Bureau economist. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on inflation, rising food costs, and economic trends affecting Thanksgiving meals, directly relating to Business/Economy. While Agriculture is tangentially connected through farm bureau data, the primary context is economic inflation and consumer prices.

title: Heartfelt hospitality is 'baked in'
author: LISA J. GOTTO Special to the Star Democrat
content:
Heartfelt hospitality is 'baked in'

 November 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LISA J. GOTTO Special to the Star Democrat | Section: Business 
 
 1071
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Fall brings about the busiest time of year for Alicia Boyd, proprietor and head chef of Humble Hearts Catering & Events based in Queen Anne's County.With six years of experience as a small business owner, Boyd relishes this busiest of seasons catering weddings, baby showers and various autumnal celebrations.
Boyd is one of those people who goes about her business day with a genuine smile on her face and a sense of joy in her heart that resonates. She believes she's one of the lucky ones who gets to do what she loves for a living and happily shares that passion with others by sharing what she knows and continues to learn about food.
As she was preparing lunch in Queen Anne's at the Ruthsburg Community Hall — a chicken focaccia with her locally famous chimichurri sauce — she said the facility has been a godsend to her. It offers the key ingredient to the larger recipe for her small business, a licensed commercial kitchen, which she rents.
Boyd, 39, a wife and mother of two, has a culinary degree from Baltimore International College and some rich, Maryland-flavored roots.
"The reason why I'm here, the reason why Humble Hearts is a thing, is because our family grew up here. My family's originally from Virginia, and my grandmother moved down here with her children and she worked on the water," said Boyd. "My whole family worked in oyster houses and shucked clams … my grandmother, my aunt … they worked with the local watermen, and they would make the crab cakes and the oyster fritters and all those different things."
Hospitality, she said, was a way of life in her family, where everyone was welcome at her grandmother's table.
"Food has been my whole life being able to welcome people in, being able to connect with the community. That really has been my whole life," she said.
This extension of her formative years would eventually bring her to Chestertown, where she spent several years honing her skills in the catering departments of Washington College. She has also developed some solid working relationships through its vast network of professors, including Modern Stone Age Kitchen's Bill Schindler.
"While I was at the college, Bill was a professor there, and he was inviting me down to these intimate chef demonstrations," Boyd said. "He was having these different chefs come in from all over the world, and my heart was just jumping out of my chest."
Inspired by these experiences, Boyd felt strongly that after five years with the college, and a couple years of side catering hustles, she was ready to make the leap into catering full-time.
That was in 2020 and one month prior to the pandemic changing the way people would be living and eating. After making such a commitment, Boyd felt there were two possible responses: panic or pivot. Boyd and her team chose the latter.
"We started doing meal deliveries. We were doing deliveries from Cambridge and all the way to Annapolis. And that's what sustained us," said Boyd, who added they also saw this potential game-changer as an opportunity to make an impression and name for themselves in a business that was robust with established competition.
"So, we were coming in [to Ruthsburg Community Center] making meals and delivering everywhere. "For Mother's Day, we did brunch boxes that we were delivering to moms that had greeting cards in the boxes. They had a full-on brunch with a mocktail mixer. We did that for Father's Day, too. We did 'Sweet Success' graduation boxes with four different cupcakes for the kids that were graduating. We just were using ingenuity and grit to be able to say, 'we have to make it.'"
Boyd's approach and unique outreach was obviously successful, and she is happy that her team has been able to grow and build on that. And she is just as committed today to delivering those unique culinary experiences as she was back in 2020.
"I'm a creative and I like doing fun things with food. I like being able to see what's the farthest extent that I can go to with any food that I work with."
Case in point, her team regularly works with community-based organizations and resources to enhance her business's level of expertise and to check-in with the network of regional partners that the business has built. Last summer, Humble Hearts partnered with the Shore Rivers organization and Wildly Native Flower Farm in Chestertown to create a delicious sensory experience with edible flowers for the participants of a talk on the subject that the farm and Shore Rivers was sponsoring.
Boyd's out-side-of-the box, lunch box menu consisted of a focaccia with whipped basil ricotta and heirloom tomatoes accompanied by a fresh watermelon and aronia berry salad, showcased the topic in a deliciously creative way, much to the delight of the attendees.
Boyd said she spent hours with Wildly Native's owner, Liza Goetz, just walking through the vast plots of flowers to learn from Goetz which ones to work with and which to avoid. She revels in these learning experiences and seeks to take on others, so that she can also fulfill a role as a resource to the community that means so much to her.
"I am in this place where I want to learn more about what is out there in my field… so, I am at Cornell University right now working on a Food Product Development Certificate."
Once she acquires that knowledge, she said, she would like to be able to share what she knows with her network of businesses and farms who may be interested in bringing products to market.
In addition to continuing her education, raising her family, and managing a staff of nine on-call employees, Boyd also maintains key relationships with those in the community that have impacted her along the way. You can currently find Boyd already sharing what she knows as a guest chef back at Modern Stone Age Kitchen's Eastern Shore Food Lab where she teaches hands-on cooking classes.
Boyd said she has the utmost respect for the level of innovation and the business acumen she sees going on at Modern Stone Age Kitchen.
"I will call them with questions, or say, 'Can you please come look at this?' and when I have done that, they've been there," she said. And it's that sense of reciprocity that Boyd is ever grateful for and strives to emulate.
"I would not be able to do what I do every day without the community," she said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Alicia Boyd's catering business, her entrepreneurial journey, community partnerships, and business strategies. While education and local community aspects are mentioned, the core subject is her small business operations and economic activities.

title: Holiday shoppers take to Easton's small businesses to invest in community
author: BROOKE ENSMINGER Special to the Star Democrat
content:
Holiday shoppers take to Easton's small businesses to invest in community

 November 30, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: BROOKE ENSMINGER Special to the Star Democrat | Section: Business 
 
 449
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Locals and visitors supported small businesses by spending their Black Friday at local shops in downtown Easton.Caroline James from Washington, D.C., was visiting her parents in Easton and decided to check out the local shops Friday. She and her family wanted to try something different for holiday shopping this year.
"We were trying to do more thoughtful and more local stuff instead of just ordering online," James said. She said they wanted to spend their money in a way that would benefit the local community rather than filtering more money into corporations.
"If you want to live in a town that has so many thriving businesses, you have to put your money where your mouth is," James said.
Patricia Adkins, also from Washington, said she liked the unique selection from the shops in downtown Easton.
"We were here for Thanksgiving and decided after the dinner and enjoyment here to come and walk the streets of Easton," Adkins said. "We've heard good things about the shopping here in Easton. There are very unique pieces of furniture and clothing as well as handbags."
The local businesses in downtown Easton appreciate the customer support over the holidays and going into Small Business Saturday.
Barbara Ranson from Oxford owns Oxford Vintage & Trade, which recently opened its Easton location on Dover Street during the Waterfowl Festival.
"It benefits all of us to shop local," Ranson said. "We get to support local businesses and by doing that we ensure their sustainability and their longevity."
The local shops provide a unique variety of items that are unlikely to be found in brand-name and big-box stores.
"You can't find our things in the usual stores," said Diane Towers, co-owner of La De Da, a clothing shop in downtown Easton.
"All of the different stores bring a lot of different things into the town," Towers said. "We each have a different vibe so it makes it really nice as far as people shopping."
Local businesses depend on community support to keep them running. The holiday season is a great time to show support by purchasing gifts at local businesses, local business owners say. Many of the shops around town showcase beautiful festive decorations to get customers in the holiday season.
"We want to keep our small downtown alive and vibrant, and if you have individual owners of stores, they need the support of the community to survive," Kristen Dukes, owner of Cairn Antiques, said.
Shopping locally gives back to the community and helps the local economy flourish.
"We're the ones that are actually putting our money back in the community," Mark Greene, owner of Sailor, said. "Our money stays here, it doesn't go anywhere else."
Greene ended by sharing his traditional tagline: "Everything fits better in a small box."
