title: Trump’s businesses, product pushes in overdrive as White House return nears
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Newspapers
content:
Trump’s businesses, product pushes in overdrive as White House return nears

 December 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Newspapers | Section: National 
 
 1772
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Trump guitars ($1,500), autographed Trump Bibles ($1,000), Trump sneakers ($499), Trump watches ($899), Trump digital trading cards ($99), signed Trump books ($499), Trump two-dollar bills ($29.99).The marketing and merchandising of President-elect Donald Trump, along with desired profits, have been on hyperdrive during the 2024 campaign, since his election victory over Vice President Kamala Harris and as he prepares to take office again in January.
Trump and his aligned businesses recently promoted new $199 fragrances for men and women called "Fight, Fight, Fight" (referencing the July assassination attempt), new guitars "some of them personally signed," as well as a new book from a publisher founded by his eldest son, Donald Trump Jr.
Trump is no stranger to business and real estate ventures, merchandising and product licensing deals centered on his brand.
Those past deals have included less successful or unrealized ventures such as Trump University, Trump Vodka and Trump Steaks, a television drama called "Trump Tower," a potential Broadway show called "The Trump Follies," various beverages, casinos and a weekly radio show called "Trumped," according to U.S. Patent and Trademark Office filings by the president-elect and his companies, such as DTTM Enterprises. Trump has also previously had modeling and talent agencies, published magazines, owned the Miss Universe pageant and the United States Football League's New Jersey Generals.
Real estateThose products are on top of Trump's longtime business bread-and-butter real estate ventures, including hotels, golf courses and office buildings.
The main driver of that has been the Trump Organization, which is currently headed by the president-elect's sons Donald Trump Jr. and Eric Trump.
Eric Trump also runs Trump Winery (which includes a hotel, wedding venue and cidery) in Charlottesville, Virginia.
The Trump Organization and Trump Winery did not respond to requests for comments on their business approaches during a second Trump administration.
The Trump Organization has announced deals this year for real estate developments (including golf courses, residences and hotels) in Oman, Saudi Arabia, United Arab Emirates and Vietnam.
Developments in the three Persian Gulf states are part of a partnership with Dubai-based Dar Global PLC. (The development firm is an arm of Saudi-based Dar Al Arkan Real Estate Development Company, which recently hired Rothschild & Co. to help it explore more deals.)
"We are thrilled to expand our footprint in the Middle East and bring the Trump standard of luxury to the region through our longstanding relationship with Dar Global," Eric Trump said in a statement on the venture earlier this year.
The Oman development totals $4 billion, while the deal with Kinh Bac City Development Holding Corp. in Vietnam is worth $1.5 billion, according to reports.
Trump's flagship Mar-A-Lago resort in Palm Beach, Florida, generated $56 million for Trump, according to financial disclosures filed this summer. Trump's golf courses in Florida and New Jersey have also hosted tournaments from the Saudi-backed LIV Golf Tour.
Trump has promised to end the Middle East war that ignited after the Oct. 7, 2023 attacks inside Israel and broker an end to the war between Russia and Ukraine after the former's 2022 invasion.
Social mediaTrump owns 57% of the shares in Sarasota, Florida-based Trump Media & Technology Group (Nasdaq: DJT). The company operates the Truth Social media platform and is launching a streaming platform.
TMTG, which launched in 2022, lost $363.2 million through the first nine months of the year on revenue of $2.6 million.
Company executives have said TMTG's trajectory is tied to Trump's reputation and popularity. Trump said after the election that he has "no intention" of selling his $3.5 billion stake in TMTG.
Trump's business deals and real estate ventures — large and small — worry watchdog groups and progressives frequently critical of the populist president-elect.
"By maintaining his business life during his time in office, he's giving business associates, investors and others leverage over him and his personal financial health. The American people need to know if President Trump is looking out for them or for his own financial interests," said Tony Carrk, executive director of Accountable.US, a liberal watchdog group.
Carrk wants Trump to distance himself from some of his business and real estate holdings while serving as U.S. president.
"He needs to divest," Carrk said.
He's concerned about the Trump administration's future intersections with Truth Social, which is publicly traded.
"Those seeking influence over Trump could theoretically buy up Trump media shares to support the stock price, which is a major source of Trump's estimated $5.6 billion fortune," Carrk said.
Trump Media and Truth Social officials have not yet responded to requests for comment.
Licensing dealsTrump and his family's more contemporary business deals include a slew of merchandise licensing deals between vendors and Trump entities such as CIC Ventures LLC and CIC Digital LLC.
Trump is the president, secretary, treasurer and corporate manager of those two Palm Beach, Florida-based entities. Details of the licensing deals are not disclosed, but Trump licensing entities generated $12 million in annual income for Trump, according to financial disclosures.
Trump-endorsed and licensed "God Bless the USA Bibles," marketed via music singer Lee Greenwood, now include a $1,000 version signed by the president-elect and a special $69.99 Inauguration Day Bible.
"GodBlessTheUSABible.com is not political, and has nothing to do with any political campaign. GodBlessTheUSABible.com is not owned, managed or controlled by Donald J. Trump, The Trump Organization, CIC Ventures LLC or any of their respective principals or affiliates. GodBlessTheUSABible.com uses Donald J. Trump's name, likeness and image under paid license from CIC Ventures LLC," the website reads.
Freedom Park Design and 16 Creative, which are both based out of the same offices in Alabama, are part of the distribution and marketing of the Trump Bibles and the new Trump guitars, respectively.
GetTrumpGuitars.com is operated by 16 Creative and offers Trump-backed guitars for $1,500, as well as autographed models for $10,500.
"These are the only guitars endorsed by President Donald J. Trump!" the website reads.
Gibson Guitars has sent 16 Creative a cease-and-desist letter over the Trump guitar's design, according to reports. 16 Creative, which has a.product disclaimer distancing the Trump guitars from Gibson on its website, has not yet responded to a request for comment.
Two Sheridan, Wyoming-based limited liability corporations — 45Footwear LLC and TheBestWatchesonEarth LLC — (which share the same address) are the marketers and distributors of Trump Sneakers and Trump Watches.
The sneakers are priced at as much as $499, and the watches as much as $100,000.
"45Footwear is not owned, managed or controlled by Donald J. Trump, The Trump Organization, CIC Ventures LLC or any of their respective principals or affiliates. 45Footwear uses Donald J. Trump's name, likeness and image under paid license from CIC Ventures LLC," the company said on its website GetTrumpSneakers.com.
In a lawsuit filed in Arizona earlier this year aimed at alleged counterfeit sellers, 45Footwear said it also had a sneaker product license through DTTM Operations LLC, a New York-based Trump entity.
Wyoming-based 45Footwear also operates GetTrumpFragrances.com with a licensing disclaimer on the website. GetTrumpWatches.com also has similar licensing deal language on its website.
Another popular item, Trump digital trading cards, are marketed and distributed by Utah-based NFT Inc. LLC via CollectTrumpCards.com. The company has a licensing deal with Trump's CIC Digital.
Orlando-based Unicorn Wealth LLC operates the ProudPatriots.com, a site that sells a host of merchandise, including coins and $2 bill emblazoned with Trump's face, as well as bobbleheads, ball caps and Christmas ornaments. The company says on its website it is not directly affiliated with Trump or his presidential campaign, but does not reference a licensing deal.
Trump gear was popular at campaign rallies and is offered by various vendors online.
None of the companies have yet responded to requests for comment or details about their deals with Trump.
Public information on the shell companies partnering with Trump varies. The Montana LLCs, for example, share a Sheridan, Wyoming, address with other shell companies, with a law firm listed as the contact.
Trevor Potter, founder and president of the Campaign Legal Center, a progressive watchdog group, promised oversight and scrutiny of the incoming Trump administration in a post-election statement.
"One priority in this respect will be to combat the public perception that officials are not held accountable for their unethical behavior," he said.
Melania Trump, who is returning as first lady, published a memoir titled "Melania" in October. She is selling a $90 Christmas ornament and a $195 digital photography collection at MelaniaTrump.com. Trump is also promoting a new book, "Save America," priced at $99 and $499 for a signed copy. The new book is from Winning Team Publishing. Donald Trump Jr. is one of its co-founders.
There will be more focus on another Trump family member's business ventures.
Invest
Ment fund
Jared Kushner, who is married to Trump's daughter, Ivanka, and served as a top White House adviser during a first Trump term, operates a $3 billion investment fund, Affinity Partners.
A big chunk of Affinity's funding — $2 billion — comes from the Saudi sovereign wealth fund.
That has drawn attention from U.S. Sen. Ron Wyden of Oregon and other Democrats.
Wyden (who currently chairs the Senate Finance Committee) and U.S. Rep. Jamie Raskin, D-Maryland (a frequent Trump critic and ranking member of the House Oversight Committee) wrote U.S. Attorney General Merrick Garland in late October, asking that a special prosecutor be appointed to investigate Kushner's foreign business and investment dealings, including with the Saudis, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates, to see if they have violated laws governing those working on behalf of foreign governments and entities via the Foreign Agents Registration Act.
Wyden and Raskin said Kushner's investment firm has received $157 million in fees from foreign clients, including $87 million from Saudi Arabia.
"Mr. Kushner is simultaneously serving as a political consultant to former President Trump and acting as a shadow diplomat and political advisor to Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed Bin Salman and other foreign principals," Wyden and Raskin said, arguing Trump's son-in-law has not made needed FARA disclosures.
They argue Kushner still serves as a political advisor to Trump. The odds of a special counsel being appointed to on the matter are likely nil with Trump's election win.
Miami-based Affinity Partners has not yet responded to requests for comment. Earlier this year, Kushner defended his tenure in the White House and investment work after Trump's loss in the 2020 race.
Kushner and Ivanka Trump were not publicly involved with Trump's win over Harris. It is not clear what kind of roles, if any, they might have in Trump's new term.
But Kushner stirred some scrutiny earlier this year over the future of Gaza after the devastating Israel-Hamas war.
"Gaza's waterfront property could be very valuable if people would focus on building up livelihoods," Kushner said in March, according to the Associated Press.
Trump has named Charles Kushner (Jared Kushner's father) his pick for the U.S. ambassador to France.
Charles Kushner is the founder of the Kushner Cos. Trump pardoned Charles Kushner of tax evasion and witness tampering charges in 2020. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Trump's business ventures, product launches, real estate deals, and financial activities, which directly relate to Business/Economy. While it mentions his political role, the core content centers on commercial operations and economic interests rather than national news or public announcements.

title: Gas prices fall another 6.2 cents in Maryland
author: GAS BUDDY
content:
Gas prices fall another 6.2 cents in Maryland

 December 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: GAS BUDDY | Section: News 
 
 474
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Average gasoline prices in Maryland fell 6.2 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.04 per gallon Monday, according to GasBuddy's survey of 2,167 stations in Maryland. Prices in Maryland are 0.8 cents per gallon lower than a month ago and stand 16.8 cents per gallon lower than a year ago."Millions took to the road for Thanksgiving, and while some regions, like the Great Lakes, saw gas prices rise just in time for travel, most of the nation saw prices hold mostly stable or decline slightly as the national average remains near the lowest level we've seen since 2021," said Patrick De Haan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy.
The national average price of diesel has risen 1.1 cents in the last week and stands at $3.514 per gallon.
According to GasBuddy price reports, the cheapest station in Maryland was priced at $2.65 per gallon Sunday while the most expensive was $3.79 per gallon, a difference of $1.14 per gallon.
The national average price of gasoline has fallen 0.6 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.00 per gallon today. The national average is down 7.7 cents per gallon from a month ago and stands 23.2 cents per gallon lower than a year ago, according to GasBuddy data compiled from more than 11 million weekly price reports covering over 150,000 gas stations across the country.
Historical gasoline prices in Maryland and the national average going back 10 years:
December 2, 2023: $3.21 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.23 per gallon)December 2, 2022: $3.42 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.39 per gallon)December 2, 2021: $3.34 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.38 per gallon)December 2, 2020: $2.32 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.17 per gallon)December 2, 2019: $2.49 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.60 per gallon)December 2, 2018: $2.38 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.43 per gallon)December 2, 2017: $2.46 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.47 per gallon)December 2, 2016: $2.24 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.17 per gallon)December 2, 2015: $2.09 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.03 per gallon)December 2, 2014: $2.80 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.75 per gallon)
Neighboring areas and their current gas prices:
Baltimore: $3.00 per gallon, down 8.2 cents per gallon from last week's $3.08 per gallon.Washington, D.C.: $3.14 per gallon, down 5.5 cents per gallon from last week's $3.20 per gallon.Hagerstown: $3.04 per gallon, up 0.6 cents per gallon from last week's $3.03 per gallon.
"The weeks ahead should feature slight drops in gas prices in most areas, with over 100,000 stations now offering a gallon for $2.99 or less, which should stick around through the holiday shopping season," GasBuddy's De Haan said. "While the potential impacts from tariffs are something to watch, they would have no effect until late January, if implemented at all. For this week, all eyes will be on the previously delayed OPEC+ meeting on Thursday. If they begin to restore oil production, oil prices could soften to the mid-$60s."

title: Talbot County business owners push back against potential hotel tax spike
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Talbot County business owners push back against potential hotel tax spike

 December 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 784
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — During a public meeting at the Talbot County Free Library Tuesday, a number of business owners and managers pushed back on a proposed increase to the county's accommodations tax rate.Talbot County's current public accommodations tax rate, or hotel tax rate, is 4%, the lowest of any county in the state. The tax is levied on those staying in hotels or short-term rentals, collected by the business and then paid to either the county or one of three towns.
Easton, Oxford and St. Michaels collect revenues from such properties within one mile outside town limits. The county collects revenue from all other properties.
A potential increase to 6%, which would raise total revenue collected by around $1 million per fiscal year based on FY2024 numbers, requires approval from lawmakers in Annapolis.
Cassandra Vanhooser, director of economic development and tourism, and Judy Bixler, the Tourism Board chairman and Oxford-Bellevue Ferry captain, outlined the benefits of raising the rate to 6% for the county's marketing efforts, such as adding staff and being able to market more businesses individually.
However, local business owners had mixed reactions, with some "open-minded" but hesitant, and others in complete opposition.
Scott Wagner, owner of Oaks Waterfront Hotel in St. Michaels and a former Republican member of the Pennsylvania State Senate, said he wants to know where exactly the additional $1 million in revenue would be spent.
Wagner added that he doesn't "feel the love" from the county or its marketing efforts.
"Candidly, tonight, I can't support this tax, because I don't feel that Talbot County is supportive of our industry or at the Oaks," Wagner said. "You have not been supportive. Nobody's come out and visited us."
Vanhooser acknowledged Wagner's negative opinion of the tax as fair, but disputed his claim that the county doesn't support his hotel.
"We have sent you many travel writers. … We have sent international tour operators there," she said. "So it's not true that we haven't been to your property and we haven't supported you and marketed your property as one of our new assets. I will totally call you out on that one."
Easton, Oxford and St. Michaels have all voted in support of the tax increase, which Vanhooser and Bixler stressed is the first time in years has been the case.
Alfred Mercier, president of the Commissioners of St. Michaels, explained during the meeting why St. Michaels voted in favor of moving along with a hotel tax increase, noting its importance in funding services such as police and trash disposal.
"There's infrastructure that we have to support, and the accommodations tax is something that, it's a tax on transients that come from outside the town inside the town," Mercier stated. "I think that is the overwhelming reason why St. Michaels (and) the residents were in support of this."
Mercier added, "when it comes to an increase in a tax, if it's a destination location, people don't care. They really don't." Not all St. Michaels businesspeople and residents, though, agreed.
"I completely disagree with you Al," Travis Johnson, manager of the Old Brick Inn, responded. "My guests complain about rates. St. Michaels is very competitive."
Chad Hill, vice president of Hill Hospitality in Easton, was one of the "open-minded" representatives that spoke Tuesday. But Hill expressed that any increase in accommodations tax, which is passed onto the customers, will be substantial.
"Easton is a very low occupancy market, and it is a very, very … rate-sensitive hotel market," he said. "Two or three or four dollars is huge to slap on top of somebody's hotel bill. … Let's be careful not to be flippant that that doesn't make a difference. It makes a huge difference."
Hill, along with others, said they would like to see "transparency" and specifics of what the accommodations tax collected by the county funds more than just the marketing in general.
While no official decisions were made at Tuesday's public meeting, County Manager Clay Stamp told attendees that the County Council "is very interested" in what everyone has to say and is "all ears."
On Dec. 9, the Talbot County Council is expected to vote on whether it will send a letter to state delegates requesting they bring the tax legislation to the General Assembly this cycle.
At the end of the meeting Tuesday, Vanhooser said she thinks the county needs the increase "to stay competitive." The Talbot County Tourism Board had voted unanimously in favor of the increase.
"Regardless of what Mr. Wagner thinks, I'm appreciative of all of you who are my tourism partners," Vanhooser said, "and the work that you do, because it gives us a beautiful, wonderful, awesome destination to promote. I am proud of Talbot County, I think it is the premier destination in all of the state of Maryland and in the mid-Atlantic." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on business owners' reactions to a proposed hotel tax increase, emphasizing economic impacts, revenue allocation, and business community concerns. While local government entities are involved, the core issue revolves around business economics and tax policy.

title: Compare shipping costs
author: Staff Writer
content:
Compare shipping costs

 December 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 365
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I want to assure you that the U.S. Postal Service is primed and ready to deliver exceptional service during the 2024 holiday rush. Thanks to the substantial progress USPS has made under the Delivering for America plan our operational, transportation and delivery processes have never been more finely tuned and our ability to move packages and mail throughout our network has never been stronger.As you and your family prepare for the holidays, it's always a good idea to ship early. We encourage everyone to send their holiday mail and packages well in advance to ensure they reach their destinations on time, but we understand that sometimes cards or packages are sent last minute.
This year, our recommended send-by dates for expected holiday delivery within the continental U.S. before Dec. 25 are:
Dec. 18 — USPS Ground Advantage service; first class mail service.
Dec. 19 — Priority Mail service.
Dec. 21 — Priority Mail Express service.
USPS continues to offer the lowest postage rates and the most affordable and reliable way to ship packages and mail this holiday season.
How can you save money this holiday season?
Here are some important questions: what are you shipping, how much does it weigh, where is it going, how soon does it have to be there?
Here is one example. If you are sending a 10-pound package from Salisbury (or any post office in Maryland) to Santa Claus, Indiana, comparing our options, using Ground Advantage, the postage would be $20.15, Priority Mail Service by weight, $25.40, Priority Large Flat Rate Box, $26, and for the procrastinators, Priority Mail Express, $115.25. These prices have no "hidden fees" like surcharges for fuel, residential and Saturday/Sunday delivery.
What else sets us apart from our competitors?
We offer free boxes and tape for our Priority Mail and Priority Mail Express services. We include $100 insurance and free tracking on our Ground Advantage, Priority Mail and Priority Mail Express services and have free pick-up at home or your business. All these can be found on our website, usps.com.
Dare to compare with our competitors; however, I am confident you will prepare to compare USPS services before Dec. 18 to save money this holiday season and year-round.
MARK WAHL
Washington, D.C.

title: Maryland gas prices continue downward trend
author: GAS BUDDY
content:
Maryland gas prices continue downward trend

 December 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: GAS BUDDY | Section: State News 
 
 476
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Average gasoline prices in Maryland have fallen 8.8 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $2.95 per gallon Monday, according to GasBuddy's survey of 2,167 stations in Maryland. Prices in Maryland are 9.1 cents per gallon lower than a month ago and stand 20.3 cents per gallon lower than a year ago. The national average price of diesel has declined 2.3 cents in the last week and stands at $3.491 per gallon.According to GasBuddy price reports, the cheapest station in Maryland was priced at $2.60 per gallon Sunday while the most expensive was $3.79 per gallon, a difference of $1.19 per gallon.

"The good news is that we'll likely continue to see additional downward pressure on gas prices, with the national average potentially falling another 10 to 15 cents by Christmas," said Patrick De Haan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy.

"The national average has finally fallen below $3 per gallon, and it couldn't come at a better time for motorists with the holidays upon us. title: It's Masala Time opens in Chestertown
author: Elizabeth Alexander Special to the Star Democrat
content:
It's Masala Time opens in Chestertown

 December 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Elizabeth Alexander Special to the Star Democrat | Section: Business 
 
 300
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — When Prateek Mohar and his brother Ankit emigrated to the U.S., they aspired to pursue prosperity and the "American dream" while sharing the delectable tastes of India in their very own restaurant.Graduates of the Institute of Hotel Management Dehradun, they worked for many years as chefs in India and around the world on cruise ships, learning first-hand what it takes to run an efficient and successful kitchen.
After numerous years of hard work and savings, the two 30-somethings from New Delhi searched the northeast region for places without Indian restaurants and landed on Chestertown as a ripe location to open their new venture.
Their new restaurant, It's Masala Time, recently opened in the Washington Square shopping center, offering a vast array of delectable Indian favorites.
Their signature dishes are the butter chicken and the Tikka Masala chicken, as well as clay oven tandoori specialties along with many vegetarian offerings.
Other delightful favorites include Shahi Korma-a cashew and coconut-based curry, the very hot and spicy potato based Vindaloo dishes, a sweet, sour and spicy mango-based curry, and Biryani — a fragrant delicacy of rice and meat or vegetables with raisins, almonds, cashews, cilantro and aromatic spices. Diners may request spicy or mild when ordering their dishes.
The interior ambiance is chic and modern with saffron-colored walls bedecked with canvas photos of foods from across India. The building itself was previously a rough empty shell, which the Mohar brothers helped to renovate into its elegant atmosphere.
Prateek's wife Vedika Patel and the men's father R.N. Mohar also work there, making it a family affair.
The restaurant is open seven days a week, giving locals ample chance to "dive into a world of spice" as often as they like. In addition, catering for up to 50 people is available, as is online ordering for take-aways at itsmasalatime.com. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Average gas prices continue falling in Maryland
author: GAS BUDDY
content:
Average gas prices continue falling in Maryland

 December 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: GAS BUDDY | Section: State News 
 
 522
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Average gasoline prices in Maryland have fallen 3.7 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $2.91 per gallon on Monday, according to GasBuddy's survey of 2,167 stations in Maryland.Prices in Maryland are 26.5 cents per gallon lower than a month ago and stand 18.5 cents per gallon lower than a year ago. The national average price of diesel has declined 1.8 cents in the last week and stands at $3.472 per gallon.
According to GasBuddy price reports, the cheapest station in Maryland was priced at $2.63 per gallon Sunday while the most expensive was $3.79 per gallon, a difference of $1.16 per gallon.
The falling prices may be coming to an end.
"As we edge closer to the end of the year, we're seeing momentum for falling gas prices weaken, which is typical as the national average generally bottoms out between Thanksgiving and Christmas," said Patrick De Haan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy. "With oil prices rising back above $70 last week, gas prices may have less potential to drop much further, though there may be a second window of lower prices in January or February in some areas, but even that won't last long."
The national average price of gasoline has risen 0.8 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $2.98 per gallon today. The national average is down 7.5 cents per gallon from a month ago and stands 7.1 cents per gallon lower than a year ago, according to GasBuddy data compiled from more than 11 million weekly price reports covering over 150,000 gas stations across the country.
Historical gasoline prices in Maryland and the national average going back 10 years:

"While several states saw gas prices cycle last week, marked by a big jump in prices after a large decline, those that did see hefty jumps should see prices drift a bit lower, potentially making a second run at the season's lowest prices," De Haan said. GasBuddy's 2025 Fuel Outlook, among the nation's most accurate fuel price forecasts, will be released in the coming weeks, offering motorists a glimpse into gas prices for the coming year."

title: Board of Realtors installs officers for upcoming year
author: MID-SHORE BOARD OF REALTORS
content:
Board of Realtors installs officers for upcoming year

 December 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MID-SHORE BOARD OF REALTORS | Section: News 
 
 418
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Mid-Shore Board of Realtors gave a heart-warming farewell to its outgoing president while recognizing new leadership and the collective achievements of its members this past year.Shelby Roney, an associate broker with Benson and Mangold, ended her term as president of MSBR at the Oct. 22 ceremony held at Temple B'nai Israel in Easton, passing the gavel to Michelle Abplanalp of Rosendale Realty, who is taking up the leadership role for 2025.
Members who were honored at the event included Peter Stark with Benson and Mangold for Rookie Realtor of the Year. Gwen Eskridge, MSBR past president with Coldwell Banker Chesapeake, received the President's Award for her continuous contributions to the association.
Shontel Wilmer with Rosendale Realty was presented the Community Service Award, and Tom Draper with First Home Mortgage was named the Affiliate of the Year.
Ron Molock of Long and Foster was recognized with the Diversity, Equity, and Inclusive Award.
The Realtor of the Year award went to Megan Rosendale of Rosendale Realty, a past MSBR president and founder of Mid Shore Love's Down Payment Assistance Grant program. Rosendale also received citations from Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico).
Hugh Smith, broker of Coldwell Banker Chesapeake, was presented with the Life Achievement Award. This is the highest award the association gives and recognizes Smith's years of service to the community and to the real estate industry.
Cheryl Abrams Davis, 2025 president of Maryland Realtors, installed the directors, while Michael Rosendale, associate broker with Rosendale Realty, installed Abplanalp as the newly elected Mid-Shore Board of Realtors president.
Abplanalp has over 28 years of experience in real estate. Supporting programs and causes in Caroline, Dorchester and Talbot counties to increase education and professionalism is her focus.
Out-going president Shelby Roney received a citation from Easton Mayor Megan Cook, thanked those who helped her this past year and noted how this role helped her grow both personally and professionally. It was a year of industry changes and Mid-Shore Board of Realtors agents managed them well.
The Mid-Shore Board of Realtors 2024-2025 executive committee is Abplanalp; Roney; Shandell Green, MSBR president-elect with Douglas Realty; Petra Quinn, MSBR secretary with Realty Navigator; and Trey Quinn, MSBR treasurer with Fidelity First Home Mortgage.
The Mid-Shore Board of Realtors 2024-2025 directors include: Alex Archer with Real Broker, Andy Beaven with Wright Real Estate, Jenn Dudley with Title Excellence, Samantha Grimes with Chesapeake Real Estate Associates, Thornette Lee with Keller Williams Select, Mary Mabry with Keller Williams Select and Shontel Wilmer with Rosendale Realty.
For more news and information visit midshoreboardofrealtors.com.

title: Hypocrisy in arguments
author: Staff Writer
content:
Hypocrisy in arguments

 December 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 345
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Chad Hill, VP of Hill Hospitality is a study in hypocrisy. Mr. Hill fought to keep the $.10 charge for every bag needed for Talbot County residents, and now he's scrapping to NOT have his (mostly out of town) patrons pay an extra for $2, 3 or 4 dollars for their hotel rooms. It's a struggle to follow the logic.On Sept. 16, Mr. Hill argued in front of the Easton Town Council that voting to give the merchants the freedom to decide if they wanted to charge 10 cents per bag for paper bags (not plastic) was not a good thing for "the collective," a word he used numerous times in his statement. Apparently, Mr. Hill struggled to recognize that a repetitive fee, ongoing in perpetuity, is not just 10 cents but adds up ongoing, and arguably would most certainly be more than the $2, $3 or $4. This is a hardship on people struggling to make ends meet in Talbot County.
Yet when it impacts his hotel business, of mostly out of county people, Mr. Hill is concerned that "Two or three or four dollars is huge to slap on top of somebody's hotel bill. … Let's be careful not to be flippant that that doesn't make a difference. It makes a huge difference."
The hypocrisy is glaring.
Star Democrat Dec 5, 2024, quote from the article:
"Chad Hill, vice president of Hill Hospitality in Easton, was one of the 'open-minded' representatives that spoke Tuesday. But Hill expressed that any increase in accommodations tax, which is passed onto the customers, will be substantial.
"Easton is a very low occupancy market, and it is a very, very … rate-sensitive hotel market,' he said. 'Two or three or four dollars is huge to slap on top of somebody's hotel bill. … Let's be careful not to be flippant that that doesn't make a difference. It makes a huge difference."
Hill, along with others, said they would like to see "transparency" and specifics of what the accommodations tax collected by the county funds more than just the marketing in general."
MARY EILEEN RUSSELL
Claiborne 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Maryland gas prices drop another 4 cents last week
author: Staff Writer
content:
Maryland gas prices drop another 4 cents last week

 December 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: State News 
 
 524
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Average gasoline prices in Maryland have fallen 3.9 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $2.88 per gallon Monday, according to GasBuddy's survey of 2,167 stations in Maryland. Prices in Maryland are 24.0 cents per gallon lower than a month ago and stand 31.4 cents per gallon lower than a year ago. The national average price of diesel has increased 0.6 cents in the last week and stands at $3.478 per gallon.The drop in Maryland prices compared with the increase in average prices nationwide lead to a warning to check prices before filling up.
"With oil prices continuing to move sideways, gas prices may hold near recent levels in the coming week," said Patrick De Haan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy. "With oil prices continuing to move sideways, gas prices may hold near recent levels in the coming week. As families travel for the holidays, this volatility at the pump serves as a great reminder to check prices before filling up to save as much as 25 to 50 cents per gallon — a trend that will likely persist into 2025."
According to GasBuddy price reports, the cheapest station in Maryland was priced at $2.53 per gallon Sunday while the most expensive was $3.49 per gallon, a difference of 96.0 cents per gallon. The lowest price in the state yesterday was $2.53 per gallon while the highest was $3.49 per gallon, a difference of 96.0 cents per gallon.
The national average price of gasoline has risen 3.1 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.01 per gallon today. The national average is down 2.6 cents per gallon from a month ago and stands 9.2 cents per gallon lower than a year ago, according to GasBuddy data compiled from more than 11 million weekly price reports covering over 150,000 gas stations across the country.
Historical gasoline prices in Maryland and the national average going back 10 years:
Dec. 23, 2023: $3.19 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.10 per gallon)Dec. 23, 2022: $3.06 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.09 per gallon)Dec. 23, 2021: $3.29 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.28 per gallon)Dec. 23, 2020: $2.35 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.26 per gallon)Dec. 23, 2019: $2.47 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.55 per gallon)Dec. 23, 2018: $2.29 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.31 per gallon)Dec. 23, 2017: $2.42 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.44 per gallon)Dec. 23, 2016: $2.29 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.28 per gallon)Dec. 23, 2015: $2.00 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.01 per gallon)Dec. 23, 2014: $2.52 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.36 per gallon)
Neighboring areas and their current gas prices:
Baltimore: $2.82 per gallon, down 2.3 cents per gallon from last week's $2.84 per gallon.Washington, D.C.: $3.13 per gallon, down 2.7 cents per gallon from last week's $3.15 per gallon.Hagerstown: $2.91 per gallon, down 8.4 cents per gallon from last week's $3.00 per gallon.
"We've seen a second consecutive weekly rise in the national average, driven by price cycling that led stations in the Great Lakes region to restore their margins to normal levels ahead of millions of motorists traveling for Christmas," said De Haan. "In the Great Lakes, last week's price hikes will likely be rolled back as stations resume undercutting each other."

title: Major subdivision approval moves Bay Bridge Marina development forward
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Major subdivision approval moves Bay Bridge Marina development forward

 December 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Business 
 
 371
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Bay Bridge Marina LLLP received preliminary and final major subdivision approval for a proposal to create commercial lots and residential duplexes at Pier One Road in Stevensville Dec. 12.The applicant is proposing a major subdivision to create five new commercial lots and 28 duplex lots on a 40-acre property within the Airport Protection and Kent Island Gateway zoning districts on the western edge of Kent Island, just south of US 50, according to Doug Summers, associate planner.
Located within the Chester-Stevensville Growth Area, the property is also designated as an enterprise zone and priority funding area, Summers said.
The site is located completely within the critical area with intensely developed area designation and is partially located within the 100-year flood plain, he said.
The typical 300-foot shore buffer was reduced to zero by the Planning Commission in 1989. No steep slopes, woodlands, or endangered wetlands or species are located in the vicinity, Summers said.
The property will be served by public water and sewer.
With the existing beach club and restaurant, the project is posed to be an "attractive mixed-use community that really blends in well with adjacent properties," according to Alan Hyatt, counsel to Bay Bridge Marina LLLP.
The project has undergone several iterations over its years of planning, he said.
The property will not have public roadways but easements and maintenance expenses will not fall to the public, Hyatt said.
The Department of Public Works is in support of the proposal, determining that existing and proposed road designs meet the public road standards for the pavement sections, according to Hyatt, Utilities will be privately owned, with no utility easements required.
Environmentally speaking, the project will include a significant number of plantings as well as new stormwater management techniques, Hyatt said.
At public comment Jay Falstad of the Queen Anne's Conservation Association encouraged the Planning Commission to insist all development plantings be native species.
"Planting native is important for promoting local biology," he said.
The commission approved Bay Bridge Marina's preliminary and major subdivision request, finding it consistent with the Queen Anne's County 2022 Comprehensive Plan and zoning and subdivision regulations.
The commission also agreed with the applicant's request for the elimination of 35 feet frontage requirements for nonresidential lots for improved traffic flow, pedestrian connections and overall site design. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Potential Chesapeake Beach Club hotel receives major site plan approval
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Potential Chesapeake Beach Club hotel receives major site plan approval

 December 27, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 353
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — On Dec. 12, major site plan approval was granted by the Queen Anne's County Planning Commission to Chesapeake Bay Beach Club LLC for its proposal to construct a four-story, 32-room hotel with a bathhouse on Marina Club Road in Stevensville.Located on Kent Island south of Route 50, southeast of the Chesapeake Bay Bridge, the proposed hotel project will cover 2.1 acres on Marina Club Road in Stevensville, according to Rob Gunter, principal development review planner.
The project was last presented to the Planning Commission in April for concept plan approval in which allocation for the project's public water and sewer was also granted.
Along the south side of the proposed 25,727-square-foot hotel will be an attached 868 square foot bathhouse.
The rear of the hotel will include an outdoor area of a pool, terrace, lawn areas, outdoor seating, fire pit and outdoor fireplace.
Located in the Airport Protection and the Kent Island Gateway Zoning District within the Chester-Stevensville Growth Area, the entire area is located within the Chesapeake Bay Critical Area and is designated as an intensely developed area, as well as a modified buffer area.
The site is within the Chester-Stevensville Growth Area and is located in a priority funding area and Queen Anne's County's designated enterprise zone.
An existing office building will be removed and parking reconfigured to accommodate the site plan, Gunter said.
The project provides an excess of 31 parking spaces on-site and is proposing to enter into a shared parking agreement with the Chesapeake Bay Bridge Marina.
Developer Dereck Janes noted it was already not uncommon to have near zero parking availability on site on weekends.
The appearance of a full parking lot can have an effect on business, with potential customers taking their business elsewhere, Janes said.
All dimensional and zoning district standards have been met, Gunter said, and the Planning Commission granted major site plan approval, with findings including the proposed use would not increase traffic hazards and was consistent with the Comprehensive Plan.
The hotel's name Wilson's Cove is in honor of the late John Wilson, the original developer of the Chesapeake Bay Beach Club, according to Kevin Shearon of DMS and Associates. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: We'll soon see how high the bar is on taxes
author: Staff Writer
content:
We'll soon see how high the bar is on taxes

 December 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Columns 
 
 775
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Next month the Maryland General Assembly convenes in Annapolis for a 90-day session.All indications are the discussions, deliberations and decisions on the state budget will be drawn out and divisive.
The reason is simple.
Recently the General Assembly's bipartisan Affordable Spending Committee received a most sobering report on the state's current and projected fiscal conditions.
The report included some of the worst state budget revenue and expense projections since the state endured pandemic lockdowns.
The committee staff is currently projecting a budget deficit of $3 billion. That amount is even larger than the one a reported several weeks ago, which was then $2.7 billion.
All the debate on the budget will include a wide range of key players with starkly different and strongly held opinions on the best way to address projected short term and long-term deficits.
At this point, the most likely options include spending cuts, fee increases, tax increases, revisions to the Blueprint for Maryland's Future (the Kirwan Plan) and maintaining or increasing the flow of federal dollars into Maryland.
With a new Republican president and Republican majorities in both houses of Congress, it is almost a given that federal dollars flowing into Maryland from jobs, and funding of huge infrastructure projects such as the Red Line mass transit expansion in Baltimore and Amtrak tunnel rebuild, also in Baltimore, will run dry.
One exception is final bipartisan Congressional and White House approval of full federal funding for rebuilding and replacing the Key Bridge in Baltimore. Beyond that one-time massive level of federal aid, such outlays are gone at least for the next four years and maybe forever.
Despite all the above news, Gov. Wes Moore has repeatedly said he has a "high bar" for tax increases. He more recently stated that he supports revisions to the Kirwan Plan including, but not limited to, delays in the current schedule for full implementation.
Moore has also said regularly that Maryland must attract more higher paying jobs to Maryland and must stem the number of high-income taxpayers leaving Maryland.
To do that, Moore has issued executive orders prefaced with the following messages:
"Maryland has an opportunity to change the trajectory of the downward decline that our state's economy has experienced over the past several years. For Maryland to win the decade, we must be clear-eyed about the impediments to growth, develop strategies to deliver short-term and long-term sustainable success, and create the climate that is necessary for businesses and talent to grow and relocate in our state."
His executive orders create a Governor's Office of Business Advancement, a Maryland Coordinated Permitting Review Council, a Certified Sites Program and a Governor's Economic Competitiveness Subcabinet.
His orders also provide for a government-loaned executive program; an all-of-government approach to supporting priority industries and sectors; the Department of Commerce to coordinate economic development, marketing, and branding efforts with local governments; directing a comprehensive review of the Business Tax Credit; Financial Assistance and Incentive Programs; and a review of Certain Business Licensing Programs.
Maryland Senate President Bill Ferguson has been less direct in his opinions on tax increases.
Ferguson has said, "We are going to have to look at revenues in certain areas because when we look at the budget overall, the gap cannot be accomplished by cuts alone." Ferguson has echoed Moore's position that a decision on tax increases will have a high bar for his support.
The current views of Moore and Ferguson put them at odds with two high ranking and influential leaders in the House of Delegates — Majority Leader David Moon and Appropriations Committee Chair Ben Barnes.
Both are unapologetic progressives who believe strongly that substantial state tax increases are long overdue. They oppose suggestions to delay or revise the implementation of schedules or mandates in Kirwan, including mandates opposed by some local school boards.
Del. Barnes took a page from the messaging book of Gov. Moore and Senate President Ferguson by saying he has a "very high bar for any rollback of education reforms."
I predict when all is said and done, the Democratic super majorities in the General Assembly along with Gov. Moore will reach agreement on and approve a mixture of spending cuts, tax increases, fee increases and revisions to Kirwan.
I also predict the Republican minorities in the General Assembly will continue efforts already underway to strongly oppose tax increases.
As always, the minority will have its say, and the majority will have its way.
The General Assembly's regular session ends in April. Barring any subsequent special sessions, only then we will know how Gov. Moore chose to define a high bar on tax increases.
Eventually, we also will know how that choice impacted his political future that many believe includes a run for president, assuming he is reelected to a second term as governor. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Maryland's state budget debates, tax policy discussions, fiscal projections, and economic strategies involving government agencies and political leaders. While there is mention of legislative processes (Local Government), the core content centers on economic management, budget deficits, and business-related policy decisions.

title: Local residents embark on Eden Town Brewing, the first Caroline County brewery
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Local residents embark on Eden Town Brewing, the first Caroline County brewery

 December 31, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 687
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Caroline County's first brewery is under construction, and it's being led by two local residents and business owners.Matt and Sarah Dahl are bringing Eden Town Brewing Company to the corner of Eighth and Gay streets in Denton. Ground was broken earlier this year, and Matt Dahl says he hopes the brewery will open sometime in 2025.
The more than 8,000-square-foot project is an exciting one for the Dahls and also their first major business venture.
"It's kind of one of those things you talk about but it never happened," Matt Dahl said. "It kind of just kept coming up. Sarah, my wife, she had had her eye on this property for a while. She was like, 'That would be like the perfect place to do one.'"
After living in North Carolina for five years, they moved back to Denton, Sarah Dahl's hometown, where they reside now with two sons, James and Luke. But their time in the South left a lasting impression — particularly due to the brewery scene.
"Where we lived in Raleigh, there were breweries everywhere," Matt Dahl said. "And people loved going to them. It was kind of the heyday of breweries.
"We moved up here and said, 'Oh, it would be cool if we could build a brewery in Denton.'"
Eden Town Brewing harkens back to the town's previous name before it was shortened to Edenton, then Denton. It will have a brewing production facility and a brewmaster, Matt Dahl said, along a large taproom, patio and event space.
He hopes they can work with local food trucks on a rotation basis or even find a full-time partner.
The property was bought from the owner of the former Nuttle Lumber warehouse. The Dahls had to go through a zoning amendment process with the town before construction could begin.
Denton Mayor Abby McNinch said they presented at several Planning Commission and Town Council meetings, adhering "to all our planning and zoning requirements as any other business would."
"I am excited. They are great people," McNinch said of the Dahls. "They've done their research well, they have. They're not doing this lightly."
Matt Dahl said while other potential properties for the brewery wouldn't need the zoning changes, placing the business in town was a priority for him and his wife.
"One of our primary motivations was to bring something to town," he said. "There's already a lot of stuff out on the highway. So this is in town. Even if it was going to take longer, we'd rather have it be in town."
McNinch said she appreciates that aspect of the venture and the fact that the Dahls are town residents who care about the community as a whole, not just starting a business.
The brewery will be in close proximity to Denton's Market Street, which is host to many local businesses, including popular restaurants. Matt Dahl envisions the brewery anchoring the side of town across from the Market Street hub once it opens.
Denton's mayor is excited for the possibility of growth in the area near Gay Street. Eden Town Brewing has the makeup of a "cornerstone project" for what McNinch says is an "underdeveloped" part of town.
"To bring an area alive again is really exciting," McNinch said. "And yes, that it's walkable. It will highlight an area of our town that hasn't been highlighted in a long time."
"One of the things that we are very proud of is our sense of community," the mayor continued. "And I think that the model that they've presented, and how it's not just a place to go drink beer, but the whole concept, it's going to be great for that community aspect, I think."
Matt Dahl said the brewery will have a wide range of options available, including beer, cocktails, wine and non-alcoholic beverages. Thus far, reception from locals has been great, he said.
"The town, council (and) the town staff have all been super supportive and excited about it," Dahl said. "We really have had nothing but positive feedback on the idea. Now we just have to keep that excitement going for another year until we're actually open."
To stay up to date on Eden Town Brewing Company's progress, visit edentownbrewing.com. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the opening of a new local brewery, detailing its business operations, community impact, and economic development aspects. While local government involvement and community life are mentioned, the primary subject is the business venture itself.

title: Acero 506: curating personalized gifts for the Eastern Shore
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Acero 506: curating personalized gifts for the Eastern Shore

 January 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Business 
 
 466
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Dayana Ocampos is in the business of bringing joy to the communities around her.Ocampos, owner of Acero 506, said her jewelry and gift store is an avenue for creativity and personalized gifts for everyone in the Eastern Shore.
Acero 506 has opened its doors to the public. Residing on Elliot Street, this new store provides curated gifts and jewelry to all those searching for one-of-a-kind items for their loved ones.
Ocampos, native to Costa Rica, moved to the Eastern Shore from New Jersey with her husband Brayam Herrera and young daughter about four years ago. Back in Costa Rica, Herrera and she were auto mechanics and had a shared love of working with their hands.
Ocampos said it was always a dream of hers to open her own business where she can connect with and talk to tourists and community members alike.
"I love talking to people. I love making connections with people," Ocampos said. "I've always worked in occupations that center people and service to fulfill their needs. I feel that I've been called to share and help curate objects that bring people together."
Herrera said his wife, as an artist and a creator, goes above and beyond for all her customers.
"It's really impressive for me what she got going on," Herrera said. "A couple years ago, she made and accomplished a goal, and everything came with a lot of effort, of course, but it turned out to be bigger than I thought. She's been working really, really hard to have this, and she's so happy to have it. It's her first business here, and it's not easy. It's really, really, really tough, really hard, a lot of work. But she made it. And now she has this store, and she deserves it."
According to Herrera, Ocampos started making customized gifts a couple of years ago. She began with research and quickly put her knowledge to action.
After a few years, what was once a hobby developed into a full-fledged business that quickly outgrew her workplace in their home.
Now with an established location for her business, Ocampos has been met with an array of support from her community.
Victoria Gomez Lozano, deputy director for the Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center, said supporting Latino-owned businesses on the Eastern Shore is a core mission of the center. For Gomez Lozano, as the Latino population continues to grow, it has become more and more important to support economic growth within the community.
"First of all it was an honor that ChesMRC was invited to the Acero 506 inauguration," Gomez Lozano said. "It was a pleasure and important for ChesMRC to be there because that is an accomplishment of our mission, 'empower people from different cultures to become successful and engaged members of our community.' Dedication and hard work shows us a great story of success." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.
