title: Critchlow Adkins cuts ribbon on new offices in downtown Easton
author: Konner Metz
content:
Critchlow Adkins cuts ribbon on new offices in downtown Easton

 January 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Business 
 
 297
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Critchlow Adkins Children's Centers held a ribbon-cutting ceremony Wednesday afternoon for its brand new central office building in downtown Easton.Critchlow Adkins is a nonprofit childcare program that offers preschool, before- and after-school care, and summer camp programs. Located at 15 S. Hanson St., the new office serves as Critchlow Adkins' main center for community outreach, grant work and behind-the-scenes operations.
Executive Director Cristy Morrell says the central building will be a "hub" for its five child care centers across the county — two in Easton and one each in St. Michaels, Trappe and Cordova.
"Being centrally located in downtown Easton is a big deal," Morrell said. "This is where all of the background, fundraising, community outreach, happens, right here."
More than 50 community members and leaders helped cut the ribbon Wednesday, including Easton Mayor Megan Cook and Town Council President Frank Gunsallus.
The nonprofit's main officers were previously located on Washington Street next to the site of the former Safeway. In August, the town approved a 33-unit townhome development at that site, which led Critchlow Adkins to look for a new home, Morrell said.
"With the upcoming construction, we realized that wasn't going to be a great place for us," Morrell said. "And we were renting at the time and started poking our nose around, and we found this amazing building, and we were able to purchase it."
Morrell said she's excited for Critchlow Adkins to host board and committee meetings in the new offices and to bring staff from all of the centers together in one place.
"We have our forever home here on 15 S. Hanson," Morrell said. "And it was a building that was in fabulous condition, we just kind of changed the paint colors, changed some carpeting and rugs and put our own little stamp on it." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a nonprofit organization's operational expansion, including a new office location, funding, and community outreach. While it mentions childcare services (education), the primary context is the organization's business operations and real estate decisions, aligning with the Business/Economy category. The mention of the 'Business' section in the original publication further supports this classification.

title: Mid-Shore home sales, prices up in 2024 from 2023
author: MID-SHORE BOARD OF REALTORS
content:
Mid-Shore home sales, prices up in 2024 from 2023

 January 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MID-SHORE BOARD OF REALTORS | Section: Local News 
 
 598
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Overall, the housing market on the Mid-Shore was solid in 2024, noted Mid-Shore Board of Realtors President Michelle Abplanalp.Nationally, 2024 provided interesting highlights. For example, the share of first-time buyers who are single women rose to 24%, a 5% increase in one year.
Another interesting discovery: first-time home buyers' median age is now 38, the oldest recorded in the annual survey. Factors that could account for this include student loans debt, home prices and marrying and having children at a later age. Only 27% of buyers have children under 18 at home.
All-cash buyers accounted for 26% of the home transactions in 2024. It is likely that these buyers are those with relatively high incomes, who feel secure in their own personal economic situations.
Nationally, Realtors are seeing more multi-generational homes being purchased. Seventeen percent of buyers purchased multi-generational homes in 2024, the highest rate recorded. This is up from 12% in 2021.
Affordability is a high priority for 36% of buyers. Affordability is a major constraint for moderate-income buyers. With home prices rising and interest rates projected to remain around 6% or 7% through 2025, many buyers could be priced out.
Turning to the Eastern Shore and focusing on the five counties of Caroline, Dorchester, Kent, Queen Anne's, and Talbot, we see increased home prices, more homes sold in 2024 and homes sold relatively quickly.
The average home price increased in four of the five counties.
Caroline County's average home price in 2024 was $319,165 compared to 314,874 in 2023.Dorchester County's average home price in 2024 was $300,210. This is a 1.46% decrease compared to the $304,646 average price in 2023.Kent County's average home price for 2024 was $443,078, up 10.11% compared to the year-end average price in 2023 of $402,413.Queen Anne's County's average home price in 2024 was $607,558, an 8.23% increase over 2023.Talbot County's 2024 average home price was $856,997 showing an 8.55% increase compared to 2023 of 789,471.
Even with the low inventory and higher interest rates, there were more homes sold in 2024 in every county. A total of 2,641 homes were sold in the five-county area. This is an increase of 7%, or 175 homes, compared to 2023.
In Caroline County, 345 homes sold in 2024, 37 more homes than in 2023.Dorchester County had 544 homes sold in 2024, five more than in 2023.Kent County had 315 homes sold in 2024; seven more than in 2023.Queen Anne's County had 869 homes sold in 2024, 64 more than in 2023.Talbot County had 568 homes sold in 2024, 62 more than in 2023.
Overall, it took 45 days to sell a home, only six more days on average compared to 2023.
Homes in 2024 in Caroline County sold on average in 47 days, four days fewer than in 2023.Dorchester County homes took six days longer to sell, or 57 days on market, in 2024 compared to 2023.Kent County homes took 44 days on average to sell, three days longer than in 2023.Queen Anne's County's 2024 homes sold in 36 days, one day longer than in 2023.Talbot County homes sold on average in 41 days in 2024, the same as in 2023.
Abplanalp noted, looking forward, uncertainty makes it hard to predict where interest rates will end in 2025. Home buyers are unlikely to see any substantial decrease in rates, even if the Federal Reserve does cut rates, she said, but that should not stop buyers because it is still a wonderful time to buy.
The Mid-Shore Board of Realtors' mission is to advocate for its members and the public to preserve the right to own, transfer and utilize real property.
For more information, visit midshoreboardofrealtors.com. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on real estate market trends, home sales data, pricing changes, and economic factors affecting buyers, which directly relate to Business/Economy. While Local Life could marginally apply due to regional focus, the economic analysis of housing markets makes Business/Economy the stronger match.

title: There is nothing certain about Maryland's budget
author: Staff Writer
content:
There is nothing certain about Maryland's budget

 February 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Columns 
 
 687
 Words 

 Read News Document

 On Jan. 15, Gov. Moore presented his proposed $67.3 billion state budget to the General Assembly.His proposed budget includes the following:Approximately $2 billion in spending cuts.Approximately $1 billion in new revenue from select tax code changes and fee increases.Additional select tax code changes.A state initiative comparable to the new federal Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) that will identify $50 million in savings that can be accomplished by implementing greater efficiencies in state government operations and programs.The proposed budget includes the following tax changes:Maintain an income tax rate of 5.75% for those earning over $300,000 annually.Increase an income tax rate to 6.25% for those earning up to $500,000 annually.Increase income tax rates to 6.50% for those earning $1.2 million or more annually.Add a 1% surcharge on capital gains for households earning more than $350,000 annually.A flat 4.7% tax rate for Maryland singles earning less than $100,000 annually.A flat 4.7% tax rate for married Marylanders filing jointly earning less than $150,000 annually.Doubling the standard deduction from the current $2,700 for single taxpayers and $5,450 for head of household, a surviving spouse and taxpayers filing jointly.Double the state take on sports betting from 15% to 30%.Raise the tax on casino table games from 15% to 20%.Increase the tax on recreational cannabis from 9% to 15% (effective in 2028).Eliminate the inheritance tax.Lower the estate tax threshold from $5 million to $2 million (except for agricultural property).A 75-cent fee for retail deliveries by companies with $500,000 or more in annual earnings.Increase the fee for vehicle emission inspections from $14 to $30.Double the late fees for vehicle emission inspections from $15 to $30.Limit the trade-in credit on car sales, which lowers the amount that can be taxed on a car purchase, to sales of no more than $15,000.Phase in higher vehicle registration fees in two years instead of the previously approved three-year schedule.Add a fee for motorists who pay their registration fees annually instead of biennially.
For existing or new businesses, Moore proposes to cut the corporate tax rate from 8.25% to 7.99% by the beginning of fiscal 2028.
This proposed change anticipates legislative approval of combined reporting for corporations headquartered in Maryland.
That is not a given despite the fact that combined reporting has been and is a top priority for progressive members in the General Assembly and progressive advocacy organizations. Preventing combined reporting has been and is a top priority for Maryland businesses and businesses advocacy organizations.
Last but not least, Moore proposes tapping the state's "rainy day fund" for about $500 million, while leaving more than $2 billion in the fund.
That is a draw down that maintains the current balance requirements for that fund.
All these proposals as well as others will be subject to intense discussions and deliberations between now and April 7. The only certainty is April 7 is the last day for the General Assembly to approve a balanced budget and send it to the governor.
There are almost countless "what if" scenarios that could occur between now and then.
I suggest they include:
What if the General Assembly reduces or eliminates the governors' proposed budget cuts?
What if the General Assembly adds or increases the governor's proposed spending levels coupled which requires their approval of a funding source for that new or increased funding?
What if Gov. Moore uses line-item vetoes if either occurs?
What if the General Assembly overrides those vetoes?
What if the proposed tax increases result in "wealthy" residents leaving the state like it occurred when roughly 30% of Maryland's millionaires left the state after the income tax rate on more than $1 million of income was increased from 5.5% to 6.25%?
What if low and middle-income taxpayers leave Maryland because of the projected fee increases which will offset any proposed modest income tax revisions?
What if combined reporting is approved and businesses move their headquarters to other states?
What if the $50 million in savings from the initiative to identify and implement greater efficiencies in state government operations come in lower than expected or not at all?
What if, when all is said and done, Wes Moore's actions lead to negative impacts from Maryland voters and the media on his re-election and pursuit of a national office? 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Maryland's state budget proposal, tax policy changes, and economic implications, which directly relate to Business/Economy. While there is mention of legislative processes and state government operations, the core content revolves around fiscal policy, taxation, and economic planning rather than governance structures or public safety issues.

title: Are Trump's tariffs illegal? Lawsuits expected to challenge constitutional, legal authority
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media
content:
Are Trump's tariffs illegal? Lawsuits expected to challenge constitutional, legal authority

 February 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media | Section: National 
 
 1512
 Words 

 Read News Document

 President Donald Trump's new blanket tariffs against Canada, Mexico and China are likely to face legal challenges as groups representing farmers, manufacturers and other businesses worry about their impacts and an international trade war.American consumers also are facing higher prices from the tariffs on top of post-pandemic inflation — with poorer households facing the brunt of the duties' regressive nature.
Trump imposed 25% tariffs against Canada and Mexico and a 10% tariff against China on Saturday, invoking the 1977 International Emergency Economic Powers Act. Trump cited the flow of illegal drugs, in particular fentanyl, into the U.S. from Mexico, China and Canada for issuing the aggressive tariff regime.
This is the first time a president has utilized the economic powers act to impose tariffs with past uses centered on freezing, restricting or seizing foreign financial assets.
That sets up a legal fracas over executive powers and who gets to set tariffs Trump or Congress and how that works.
"The Trump tariffs are illegal," said Tristan Snell, an attorney and former New York prosecutor who investigated Trump University and is critical of the U.S. president.
"He does not have the unilateral authority to amend trade agreements with Canada and Mexico. He needs congressional approval — and he does not have it. The tariffs should be challenged in court — and overruled by Congress. Now," Snell said in a statement.
The Progressive Policy Institute also argues Trump's tariffs push via the emergency powers law is unconstitutional because Congress has authority over "taxes, duties, imposts and excises."
"No single individual, president or not, should have the power to create his or her own tax system out of nothing," the institute said, referencing Trump's talk of replacing income taxes with tariff revenue and traditional tariff procedures that include oversight and public comments.
Peter Harrell, an adjunct senior fellow at the Center for a New American Security, expects lawsuits to ask federal courts to weigh whether Trump can use the emergency powers law for tariffs.
Harrell said the courts could require Trump to try to put the tariffs in place via existing trade laws or via Congress.
That "would be consistent with IEEPA's history and practice," Harrell said.
"Arguments against IEEPA tariffs are particularly strong with respect to Trump's proposed 'universal tariff,' which courts should scrutinize under the Supreme Court's emerging 'major questions doctrine'," Harrell writes in an issue brief.
The major questions doctrine stems from recent Supreme Court decisions that restrict the executive branch and its agencies from powers not more specifically authorized by Congress.
William Alan Reinsch, senior adviser at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, said tariff opponents will point to congressional powers and oversight over tariffs via Article 1 Section 8 of the U.S. Constitution: "Congress shall have Power To lay and collect Taxes, Duties, Imposts and Excises."
There also will be arguments that Trump cannot unilaterally change international trade deals involving the U.S. and the three countries.
In the other corner, Trump backers will say presidential emergency laws give him executive power to impose the unprecedented tariffs.
Trump's new tariff regime will increase costs for U.S. households by $830 this year, could cost 344,000 jobs and take a 0.4% bite out of U.S. GDP, according to the conservative Tax Policy Foundation. Prices for food, energy, raw materials, industrial and consumer products are expected to increase if the trade war comes to fruition Tuesday when Trump's tariffs go into place.
Critics on the left also say tariffs are regressive in nature and will hit poorer and working class households more than the wealthy.
"They are regressive because, in their role as a form of sales tax, they tax only goods, and less affluent families spend twice as much of their income on goods … as rich families,' according to an analysis by PPI.
FINANCIAL HARDSHIPS
The American Farm Bureau Federation, a leading agriculture group, is "concerned" Trump's universal tariffs against Canada, Mexico and China will "create financial hardships for U.S. farmers and ranchers who are already operating on very thin or negative margins."
Farm Bureau President Zippy Duvall voiced those concerns in a Jan. 31 letter to Trump, who announced blanket 25% tariffs on Canadian and Mexican imports and 10% tariff on goods from China,
"Approximately 85% of potash fertilizer is sourced from Canada, along with other fertilizer products and energy supplies. Increases to the cost of these necessary products, with spring planting soon starting across rural America, would be a difficult and untimely burden on American farmers," Duvall said in his letter to Trump.
He also said "over twenty percent of U.S. farm income is based on agricultural exports" with $174.5 billion in 2024.
Canada, Mexico and China announced retaliatory tariffs against U.S. exports in response to Trump's move.
On Monday, Trump and Mexico President Claudia Scheinbaum announced a month delay with the tariffs on Mexico. They said Mexico will send 10,000 troops to the U.S. border. Trump said he spoke with Canada Prime Minister Justin Trudeau Monday morning and had another call scheduled Monday afternoon.
"Last year, the U.S. exported over $30 billion in agricultural products to Mexico, $29 billion to Canada and $26 billion to China — our top three markets by value combined for half of total agricultural exports," Duvall said, who wants Trump to consider some exemptions to his tariff push.
"A targeted approach, rather than a blanket tariff, or exemptions on necessary and critical products like fertilizer and fuel could be ways to minimize negative repercussions," he said.
Other business groups also oppose Trump's tariffs and looming trade war.
"Tariffs are not the answer," reads a statement from the U.S. Chamber of Commerce.
"The president is right to focus on major problems like our broken border and the scourge of fentanyl, but the imposition of tariffs under IEEPA is unprecedented, won't solve these problems, and will only raise prices for American families and upend supply chains. The chamber will consult with our members, including main street businesses across the country impacted by this move, to determine next steps to prevent economic harm to Americans," U.S. Chamber of Commerce Senior Vice President John Murphy said in a statement. "We will continue to work with Congress and the administration on solutions to address the fentanyl and border crisis."
UPENDING SUPPLY CHAINS?The National Association of Home Builders and National Association of Manufacturers are also worried about Trump's tariffs.
"A 25% tariff on Canada and Mexico threatens to upend the very supply chains that have made U.S. manufacturing more competitive globally. The ripple effects will be severe, particularly for small and medium-sized manufacturers that lack the flexibility and capital to rapidly find alternative suppliers or absorb skyrocketing energy costs. These businesses—employing millions of American workers—will face significant disruptions. Ultimately, manufacturers will bear the brunt of these tariffs, undermining our ability to sell our products at a competitive price and putting American jobs at risk," said NAM President Jay Timmons.
The auto industry is especially at risk from the tariffs and trade war with supply chains and production and assembly plants cutting across North America.
NAHB Chairman Carl Harris said Trump's tariffs contradict his executive order telling federal agencies to find ways to lower costs for housing and other items.
"More than 70% of the imports of two essential materials that home builders rely on—softwood lumber and gypsum (used for drywall)—come from Canada and Mexico, respectively," Harris said.
"Tariffs on lumber and other building materials increase the cost of construction and discourage new development, and consumers end up paying for the tariffs in the form of higher home prices. NAHB urges the administration to reconsider this action on tariffs and we will continue to work with policymakers to eliminate barriers that make housing more costly and prevent builders from boosting housing production," Harris said.
The national business groups stopped short of saying they would join lawsuits challenging the legality of the tariffs against the United States' top three trading partners.
TRUMP: 'SOME PAIN'
On Sunday, Trump said there could be some economic "pain" from the tariffs and looming trade war but defended his course of action.
Here is Trump's social media post in response to worries over the tariffs:
"The "Tariff Lobby," headed by the Globalist, and always wrong, Wall Street Journal, is working hard to justify Countries like Canada, Mexico, China, and too many others to name, continue the decades long RIPOFF OF AMERICA, both with regard to TRADE, CRIME, AND POISONOUS DRUGS that are allowed to so freely flow into AMERICA. THOSE DAYS ARE OVER! The USA has major deficits with Canada, Mexico, and China (and almost all countries!), owes 36 Trillion Dollars, and we're not going to be the "Stupid Country" any longer. MAKE YOUR PRODUCT IN THE USA AND THERE ARE NO TARIFFS! Why should the United States lose TRILLIONS OF DOLLARS IN SUBSIDIZING OTHER COUNTRIES, and why should these other countries pay a small fraction of the cost of what USA citizens pay for Drugs and Pharmaceuticals, as an example? THIS WILL BE THE GOLDEN AGE OF AMERICA! WILL THERE BE SOME PAIN? YES, MAYBE (AND MAYBE NOT!). BUT WE WILL MAKE AMERICA GREAT AGAIN, AND IT WILL ALL BE WORTH THE PRICE THAT MUST BE PAID. WE ARE A COUNTRY THAT IS NOW BEING RUN WITH COMMON SENSE — AND THE RESULTS WILL BE SPECTACULAR!!!" 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Trump's tariffs, legal challenges, economic impacts, and constitutional debates over trade authority. While it involves national policy, the core subject is economic policy and its ramifications for businesses, trade, and the economy, making 'Business/Economy' the most precise category.

title: 'Enormous hardship': Trump’s tariffs on Canada threaten ‘crisis’ for community newspapers, small towns
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media
content:
'Enormous hardship': Trump’s tariffs on Canada threaten ‘crisis’ for community newspapers, small towns

 February 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media | Section: National 
 
 1321
 Words 

 Read News Document

 U.S. President Donald Trump's sweeping 25% tariffs on Canada could be "devastating" to newspapers, especially community publications in small towns.That is according to newspaper groups and publishers reacting to Trump's Feb. 1 announcement of universal 25% tariffs on imports from Mexico and Canada and 10% tariffs on Chinese goods.
Newspapers and other businesses and industries fearing adverse impacts of the universal tariffs could join lawsuits challenging Trump's unprecedented use of International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA) to impose the duties. Trump is invoking the tariffs in response to the flows of illegal drugs, especially fentanyl, into the U.S.
In a Jan. 31 letter to Republican congressional committee chairs, Martha Diaz Aszkenazy, chair of the National Newspaper Association, worries 25% tariffs on Canadian newsprint will create "enormous hardship" for newspapers, especially smaller community publications.
According to the News/Media Alliance and Wisconsin Newspapers Association, 80% of newsprint, the paper product used by newspapers and other publications, is produced in Canada.
"All tariffs bring some measure of hardship to those affected but a 25% increase in the cost of newsprint will be devastating to America's small newspaper publishers that are already strained by the recent pattern of punitive twice-a-year postage increases and higher printing costs due to a trade action against importers of aluminum printing plates. This action will drive many small publishers serving rural communities out of business and will not serve the purpose of correcting perceived trade imbalances between Canada and the United States," said Diaz Aszkenazy, who is publisher of the San Fernando Sun.
She said there is not enough U.S. production capacity to fill the void.
NNA has more than 1,600 members nationwide.
"Canadian sourced newsprint has been an essential component in allowing small publishers to stay in business. A 25% spike in costs will merely lead to unaffordable costs to publish as there is not enough domestic supply for our members to turn to," she said in the letter to Senate Commerce, Science and Transportation Committee Chairman Ted Cruz, R-Texas, and House Energy and Commerce Committee Chairman Brett Guthrie, R-Kentucky.
A prolonged trade war and newsprint tariffs could create a dire situation, newspaper groups warn.
"Higher prices and limited supplies are creating a crisis for small-town and rural newspapers. This will result in job losses and less access to news coverage. Some community and rural newspapers may have to permanently shut their doors, leaving news deserts. Once a paper shuts down, it does not come back," said the News/Media Alliance in an issue brief about the Trump tariffs.
The News/Media group has 2,200 members nationwide.
Diaz Aszkenazy has similar concerns.
"Our surveys are indicating that most newspapers are contemplating layoffs, reduced publication days or page sizes, and even the closing of the company entirely. In many small towns, our newspapers are not only the critical link to civic activity but are the most viable means for local business marketing," she said in her letter.
"Small towns will feel the effects for many years if the tariffs continue because they will lose their local newspapers," the NNA letter continues.
National and state newspapers groups, including the Wisconsin Newspaper Association, are urging members, readers and local businesses to contact their members of Congress to press Trump to exclude newsprint and other items from his tariffs or to pass legislation restricting the trade war.
WNA said in an issue alert that Trump's legal authority to impose sweeping tariffs is "questionable" and newspapers groups could join litigation to delay or stall their implementation.
The White House said in a statement Saturday that Trump is utilizing the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA), which has never been used before to impose tariffs.
Using the Economic Powers Act could allow Trump to avoid more lengthy trade regiments or the need for congressional authority to impose the tariffs.
But it could also be challenged in court, according to Peter Harrell, an adjunct senior fellow at the Center for a New American Security.
Harrell said expected tariff litigation will ask federal courts to weigh whether Trump can use the emergency powers law for tariffs.
The 1977 law has previously been used to seize foreign assets related to wars, human rights abuses and national security concerns. The Biden administration most recently invoked the law to block financing for Israeli settler groups it said was responsible for violence against Palestinians in the West Bank. Trump is reversing that action.
"Forcing Trump to rely on trade statutes — or to go to Congress to seek new authorities — would be consistent with IEEPA's history and practice, and with Congress's long-standing practice of delegating trade power to the president only subject to more extensive procedural requirements. Arguments against IEEPA tariffs are particularly strong with respect to Trump's proposed 'universal tariff,' which courts should scrutinize under the Supreme Court's emerging 'major questions doctrine'," Harrell writes in an issue brief.
The major questions doctrine stems from a 2022 Supreme Court decision that restricts the executive branch and its agencies from "resolving questions of 'vast economic and political significance' without clear statutory authorization," according to a 2024 analysis by Samuel Buckleberry Joyce for the Stanford Law School.
Legal experts said Trump's tariffs will test bounds of presidential powers under the 1977 emergency power law.
"The U.S. Constitution plainly grants the power to impose tariffs to Congress, not the president: 'The Congress shall have Power To lay and collect Taxes, Duties, . . . To regulate Commerce with foreign Nations' (Article 1, Section 8). However, Congress has delegated extensive authorities that allow the president to impose tariffs if certain statutory conditions are met," said William Alan Reinsch, senior adviser for economics program and Scholl chair in international business for the Center for Strategic and International Studies.
Trump tried to put a 30% tariff specifically on newsprint during his first term. That was blocked by the U.S. International Trade Commission.
Agriculture, manufacturing, small business and other groups also oppose the Trump tariffs, worrying about higher costs on top of post-pandemic inflation, a trade war with Canada, Mexico and China already announcing retaliatory tariffs and lost jobs.
On Monday, Trump and Mexico President Claudia Scheinbaum announced a month delay with the 25% tariffs on Mexico.
Scheinbaum said. Mexico will send 10,000 troops to the U.S. border. Trump said he spoke with Canada Prime Minister Justin Trudeau Monday morning and had another call scheduled Monday afternoon.
A number of industries and other groups could challenge the Trump tariffs in court.
The American Forest & Paper Association (AF&PA), which represents paper mills, is also concerned about the impacts of a tariff and trade war with Canada and Mexico.
"The American Forest & Paper Association supports free and fair trade practices, and we rely on Canada and Mexico as key trading partners. In 2024 alone, total two-way trade for pulp and paper products with Canada was over $14 billion and total two-way trade with Mexico was over $5 billion. These tariffs have the potential to seriously disrupt the U.S. forest products industry's complex, cross-border supply chains that employ more than 900,000 people," said Heidi Brock, president and CEO of the industry group.
"We strongly encourage the Canadian and Mexican governments to quickly come to the negotiating table to address concerns raised by the U.S. Government. It is imperative we return to normal free and fair trade soon to avoid longer term disruption to U.S. pulp, paper and packaging manufacturing operations. We look forward to working with the Administration to provide our industry's perspective and important data to inform these consequential discussions," Brock continued.
On Sunday, Trump pushed back against criticism of his tariffs, including on Canadian imports.
"We pay hundreds of Billions of Dollars to SUBSIDIZE Canada. Why? There is no reason. We don't need anything they have. We have unlimited Energy, should make our own Cars, and have more Lumber than we can ever use. Without this massive subsidy, Canada ceases to exist as a viable Country. Harsh but true! Therefore, Canada should become our Cherished 51st State. Much lower taxes, and far better military protection for the people of Canada — AND NO TARIFFS!," Trump said in a social media post. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the economic impact of Trump's tariffs on Canadian newsprint, affecting newspapers and industries. It discusses trade policies, legal challenges, and economic consequences, aligning with 'Business/Economy.' 'National News' is a secondary fit due to the presidential policy aspect, but the core issue is economic.

title: Delmarva Power bills shock customers
author: Jane Bellmyer jbellmyer@cecilwhig.com
content:
Delmarva Power bills shock customers

 February 7, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jane Bellmyer jbellmyer@cecilwhig.com | Section: News 
 
 1027
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Most homeowners expect their utility bills to be higher in the winter because of the cost of staying warm; but not doubled.However, that's what a lot of customers of Delmarva Power found when opening their January bills.
Ashley Meekins compared it to a game of chance.
"It's a roulette game," Meekins said of the bill for her three-bedroom, one bathroom ranch house for a family of six in North East. "I switched my light bulbs to LED, switched my shower head, I unplug the washer and the dryer, I got a new refrigerator."
Her Delmarva Power bill was more than $400.
"It doesn't matter what I do," she said. "It didn't change our electric bill."
Pam Peters heats her North East area home with a wood stove. Peters said a customer service person told her to turn off the fans associated with her wood stove as a savings measure.
"I don't have fans," she said. She never uses the dishwasher, line dries her clothes and her washing machine is a year old.
"Last year, my bills were $145 to $245," Peters said. Her January bill was $542. "They tell me the next one is $500."
Joanne Meadows is a single mom in a one-bedroom apartment in Darlington, Md.
"My bill basically doubled. It was $150, now it's $300. I can't afford a doubled bill," Meadows said. "I don't know how they expect someone to survive."
"I feel like we're all being punished," Peters said.
All across the Delmarva Power coverage area — which includes parts of Delaware and Maryland — customers are sharing their utility bill sticker shock. A Facebook group titled "Delmarva Power Victims" has more than 4300 members describing bills that increased exponentially. On that page one member shared a photo of his bill that rose from $653 to $942; with $398 of that billed for delivery.
Customers say calls to the utility indicate that the cold temperatures are to blame. Zach Chizar is a spokesman for Delmarva Power.
"What we're seeing is that comparably, systems worked 80% more in December than it did in November," Chizar said of the marked increases. "It was significantly colder than during the period last year."
"The increase is likely due to the cold," Chizar said. "Whatever system you have will have to work harder."
According to Chizar, there are a number of factors affecting customer bills including surcharges, fees and delivery costs.
"Using a third party provider can change the bill," he said.
Tori Leonard, spokeswoman for the Maryland Public Service Commission, said that agency is monitoring the situation.
"The Commission is certainly aware that DPL customers are seeing bill increases — our Consumer Affairs Division has noted a big jump in the number of complaints regarding high bills," Leonard said Thursday. "We would point out that recent cold weather is a significant factor — systems have to work increasingly harder the colder it is, which increases usage, particularly in older homes that may not be well-insulated. Almost half of Delmarva's customers use electric heating (adding) that percentage may be even higher in Cecil County."
Constant YieldHowever, the likely culprit is a new method the utility uses to charge its customers.
"The rates change on a month by month basis," Chizar said. "The Maryland Public Service Commission updates its rates monthly."
Similar to Constant Yield, a formula used by the Maryland Department of Assessments and taxation to set the tax rates each year for Cecil County and its eight incorporated municipalities, Delmarva changes its rates each month per the PSC under its "Bill Stability."
"It's a checks and balances to ensure we aren't taking in more money than we are obligated," he said, but added there's a two-month lag in the billing for that formula. "If we go over we give a credit."
Constant Yield tells a town or county the tax rate to use to collect the same amount of revenue it collected the current tax year. Each can then decide whether to stay with the constant yield, or raise or lower its tax rate. Bill Stability does the same for the utility.
Chizar said that Bill Stability formula will give customers an average $6 credit on the next billing cycle.
Many of the bills posted to the Delmarva Power Victims Facebook page point to wording on the bills: "Reading Unavailable." Chizar would not comment on how the meters for each customer are read. He did say that some meters were read incorrectly.
"But it's not a widespread or known issue," he said. Customers can monitor their usage through an online account with the utility. "Estimated readings are posted online but the bill is accurate."
Another post indicates a person whose home is currently unoccupied was billed $500. The post indicates that the thermostat was set in the home just enough to keep pipes from freezing. Delmarva officials said that they would not discuss individual bills with the Cecil Whig.
Chizar said customers should contact Delmarva to get help through budget billing but also to see what can be done to lower the amount of energy being used.
"Budget billing is a great way to avoid surprises," he said. "We can also send out high usage alerts by text or email."
EmPOWER is an energy efficiency and green energy initiative from the Maryland General Assembly, which was updated last year and requires utilities to "add new incentives to help Marylanders make the switch from fossil fuel-powered heating and appliances to efficient, electric alternatives" according to the EmPOWER website.
Delmarva Power offers energy audits and other programs that provide energy saving materials such as weather proofing, low flow shower heads and energy efficient light bulbs to help customers lower energy usage.
Several people on the "Delmarva Power Victims" Facebook page noted they have solar panels on their homes and still received high bills.
There is now a petition being circulated and officials at the local levels, state and federal levels are getting involved.
Meanwhile, Chizar is urging customers to call them at 1 (800) 375-7117 and make arrangements to set up a payment plan. There is a plan that allows for a 24-month payment plan and non-payment of the February bill will not result in a disconnect. Anyone that goes get disconnected can apply to have the reconnection fees waived.
"Our representatives are here to help them understand their bill," Chizar said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Delmarva Power's billing practices, customer financial strain, and utility rate changes, which directly relate to business/economic issues. While public safety and local government are tangentially mentioned (e.g., customer service, regulatory agencies), the core issue revolves around utility economics and consumer impact.

title: Start saving early for a comfortable retirement
author: GLENN MOLLETTE
content:
Start saving early for a comfortable retirement

 February 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: GLENN MOLLETTE | Section: Columns 
 
 536
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The plight of the average American is about the same. We would have more if we had saved more.In 2022 the average median retirement savings for American households was $87,000. As of 2024, 25% of all American non retirees have no retirement savings. (Guardian Life Insurance)
We seldom see the big picture when we are in our early 20s. There is so much to do such as obtaining a desired degree, marrying, buying a house, starting a family and essentially getting started in life. Very few, if any of us, had a mentor who sat down with us and said, "Here is where you can be if you start now."
Few 18-year-old high school seniors has anyone writing numbers on the chalkboard for them.
When I say numbers, I'm talking about what you can have in dollars if you start now. No one told me when I was 18 what I could have in 50 years if I could just put $1,000 into the right stock or investment fund during my 18th year. That amount would be about $117,000 at an annual average interest rate of 10 percent.
One thousand dollars is not easy for most 18-year-old high school seniors to put their hands on, but it would be so worth it to any and all farther down the road in life. Let's say you put $1,000 in a Roth IRA at 18-22 years of age. These are the years that many Americans are spending $100,000 to $200,000 on college. Year 1 you invest $1,000 with the prospects of its being $117,000 when you are 68. At age 19 you invest $1,000 with the potential of it being $106,000 in 49 years. At age 20 you invest $1,000 with the potential of it being $97,000 in 48 years. At age 21 you invest $1,000 with the potential of it being $88,000. In four years, you have potentially secured your financial future with an anticipated piggy bank loaded with $408,000. The majority of Americans do not have $400,000 to draw from in the retirement years.
Let's say you keep up a trend of saving money until you are 68 by continuing to save $100 a month. Your projected nest egg could be about $1,270,000. This is because you started young and stayed with a faithful savings plan. Up your monthly savings to $300 per month, and you can anticipate about $3,171,181.28.
Obviously, interest rates will vary, but over the last 50 years the stock market has averaged making 10% per year.
Too many people wait until their 30s or even 40s to think about retirement. So much more can be accomplished when the process is started early.
There is more to life than money. We can't take it with us. We can make the lives of our children and grandchildren a little easier if we can teach them that a little effort started early will bring about a big return down the road.
CNBC reported President Joe Biden had a net worth of $9 million. If he had only invested $1,000 a month from his generous political earnings during his 50-year career, he would be sitting on $13,966,902.35. Biden will be fine but it goes to show you that all of us could do better. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on retirement savings, investment strategies, and financial planning, which directly relate to Business/Economy. While it touches on educational aspects (e.g., financial literacy), the core content centers on economic principles and personal finance.

title: Chesapeake Fire & Ice Festival brings economic boost to Easton in slow months
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Chesapeake Fire & Ice Festival brings economic boost to Easton in slow months

 February 12, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 647
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — For the fifth year in a row, Easton will host the Chesapeake Fire & Ice Festival on Feb. 14 and Feb. 15.The Easton Economic Development Corporation, which puts on the annual festival, believes the event will help with the economic shift that typically happens after the holidays.
"So in any town between the end of the Christmas shopping season and then the real pickup of tourism in May, it's pretty flat," said Holly DeKarske, executive director of Easton Economic Development Cooperation. "So events like ice festivals have been created in multiple towns during this time to try to drum up some traffic and get people down to eat, get down people down to shop."
The Fire & Ice event, presented by Preston Automotive Group, is a free, family-friendly, two-day festival featuring a trail of ice sculptures, some of which are interactive, and a slew of other programming.
"There are over 60 ice sculptures that are spread around town, from the Market at Dover Station, to downtown, to Talbot Town (Shopping Center), to the Academy Art Museum," DeKarske said.
The first night of the festival will have a Valentine's Day block party featuring live musical performances, fire pits, live ice carvings and a ice bar with beverages from Delmarva Craft and Lyon Rum in the Fire Pavilion, located at 41 South Harrison St., from 5 p.m. to 9 p.m.
The event will feature a new attraction this year, Ice Lab's paintball station.
"Ice Lab is gonna set up a little target shooting gallery, single shoot with paintball guns. It is at a gigantic ice target," DeKarske said.
Downtown of Easton will feature icy art from the carvers at Ice Lab and music.
There will be ice skating at 11 S. Harrison St., free for all ages, on both days of the festival. Cascading Carlos will be juggling fire in Thompson Park from 5 p.m. to 8 p.m. on day one and noon to 4 p.m. on day two.
On Saturday, Feb. 15, there will be a children's Ice House at the Waterfowl Building, located at 40 S. Harrison St. The house will feature free craft projects, games, hot chocolate and more.
There will also be free live musical performances from Anna Burgess, DJ E Shore, Poppy Blue Eyes and Jayla Elise.
Local restaurants and retailers will offer specials, exclusive cocktails, sales and limited-edition treats throughout the weekend, according to Easton EDC.
For the stores and restaurants that will offer sales during the event, it will give them a chance to get more customers in for the weekend and spike sales during the quietest economic time of the year.
"It could be the release of, people are getting in their spring line," DeKarske said. "Some people are running sales to clear out some of their winter clothing that they have that type of stuff. And then our restaurants have different specials going on with special drinks they created just for the event, or special meals or appetizers, that type of thing."
Easton EDC expects around 8,000 people to come to town for the event this weekend.
"The data that we pulled from this, we bring in about 8,000 people over that day and a half," DeKarske said. "So that's a huge impact from a normal day. It also brings in hotel stays. We have a lot of people coming in to stay at the local hotels and spending the weekend. So they're here to visit, not just Easton, but they'll go check out the rest of the county."
Easton EDC believes the event will continue to grow each year because organizers will add something special and different each year.
"We just continue to try to add a little something special, different to it each year and increase the format and reach of it," DeKarske said. "Making sure that we're reaching all the outer points of our Main Street district and our arts and entertainment district."
For more information on the event head to discovereaston.com. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the economic impact of the Chesapeake Fire & Ice Festival on Easton's local businesses, tourism, and community. Key details include business promotions, increased customer traffic, hotel stays, and the event's role in boosting the local economy during a slow period. While there are elements of community events and entertainment, the primary emphasis is on economic development and business activity.

title: Ink spot: Tattoo shop coming to Delaware college town after decades-long prohibition
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content:
Ink spot: Tattoo shop coming to Delaware college town after decades-long prohibition

 February 12, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 620
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The city of Newark, which is home to the University of Delaware, soon will be getting its first-ever tattoo shop.On Monday, city council granted a special-use permit to tattoo artist Brittnie Lopez, ending a decades-long prohibition on tattoo shops.
"I'm glad we're on the same page, and it's going to be a fun journey," Lopez said.
Lopez plans to move her business, B13 Tattoos, from Wilmington to a basement storefront at 170 E. Main St., the building that also houses Frolic, Oishii Ocean and Occupy Studio.
She said most of her clients are University of Delaware students, so moving the business to Newark makes sense.
"They can walk to their appointment if they wanted to; they don't have to schedule around their work schedule and get a ride and all that," Lopez said. "I'm trying to just be more convenient for everybody."
A Glasgow High School graduate, Lopez enjoys spending time on Main Street and patronizing the downtown businesses.
"I'm familiar with the area. I love the people," she said. "I mean, you can't beat a college town."
Lopez has been trying to relocate to Newark for several months, but first she needed city council to amend the zoning code.
On Monday, city council added body art establishments — a term that encompasses both tattoo and piercing shops — as an allowable use in certain commercial zoning districts.
Each body art establishment requires a special-use permit, meaning that the business owner needs permission from city council to open a tattoo or piercing shop. The permit can be denied or revoked if council determines that the business would be a detriment to the community.
The law requires that a body art establishment be located at least 300 feet from another body art establishment and at least 200 feet from an elementary, middle or high school.
Another requirement is that body art establishments must operate on an appointment-only basis to avoid the shops turning into a hangout spot and to eliminate spur-of-the-moment tattoo decisions.
Though some council members had expressed reservations about allowing tattoo shops during a previous discussion in November, both the zoning change and Lopez's special-use permit were approved 6-0 on Monday.
Lopez is currently renovating the Main Street shop and hopes to open in March.
She said her business has always operated on an appointment-only basis, which helps her customers feel comfortable. Most of her clients are women, and she works hard to make her shop a safe space.
"The traditional way of a tattoo shop, you walk in there and there's big, muscular men with needles and covered in tattoos, you know, the typical stereotype," she said. "Honestly, we're just girls. We just want something cute, something dainty, something to remember our college years by."
Attitudes toward tattoos are modernizing and for younger generations, they can be a form of therapy, Lopez said.
"I look at it as a meditation, a soothing getaway without booking a flight or getting on a cruise ship,"she said. "It's our mini vacation that we kind of just carry with us wherever we go."
Tattoos are a way of remembering something you're going through, or a way to distract yourself from it, she added.
"It's a different kind of pain, and it's a pain that we pay for, and we keep coming back," Lopez said. "It's kind of crazy, but we love it."
Lopez has been a tattoo artist for seven years.
"I'm covered in tattoos, and that's how I learned, by tattooing myself," she said. "Anything that I can reach on my body, I've tattooed."
Lopez specializes in small tattoos, often floral designs or handwriting.
"It's quick, easy, you're never in my shop longer than an hour, max," she said. "Tattoos are impulsive, and we want a whole bunch of them. So the small ones are easier for people that want a little getaway." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a tattoo shop's opening, emphasizing business operations, zoning changes, and economic activity. While local government procedures are mentioned, the core subject is the business venture and its implications for the community.

title: Attorney general's housing lawsuit will backfire
author: RAJSHREE AGARWAL
content:
Attorney general's housing lawsuit will backfire

 February 13, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: RAJSHREE AGARWAL | Section: Columns 
 
 709
 Words 

 Read News Document

 It's no secret that, to quote an early internet meme, "the rent is too damn high." Maryland ranks as the sixth-most expensive state in the country, with a median monthly rent of $2,277.In such cases, it is important that our political and legal leaders focus not on finding a scapegoat but on actually fixing the problem.
On Jan. 15, Maryland Attorney General Anthony Brown filed a lawsuit against a property management software and analytics company that Maryland property owners use to, among other things, help determine the value of their rental units.
His suit has faced significant criticism from a broad coalition of Maryland residents, including economists, housing experts and civil rights advocacy groups. And for good reason.
Software doesn't drive up rents. It is merely a tool to analyze the supply and demand in local housing markets and make recommendations based on that analysis.
Blaming software when rents rise is akin to blaming your local meteorologist every time it snows.
Brown's lawsuit ignores fundamental principles from Econ 101 and the importance of "information diffusion" for markets to operate efficiency, when everybody has all the relevant facts.
Imagine a man is having a yard sale. He finds an old baseball in the attic with a signature that reads "Cal Ripken Jr." Who's that? He doesn't know. Probably just some neighborhood kid. $1 seems like a good price. And sure enough, it sells almost immediately.
Or recall the Seinfeld episode in which George Costanza overpays for a car because the dealer tells him its previous owner was Jon Voight. George assumes he means the Hollywood star, but a quick glance at the old registration reveals that the car actually belonged to a dentist named John Voight.
In both cases, the lack of relevant information led to distorted prices.
The best way to avoid that is to make sure all market participants know what they're buying or selling and how much other people are willing to pay for it. When it's harder to access that information, it forces buyers and sellers alike to rely on guesswork. You might come out ahead in a particular transaction (like George's car dealer or the guy who bought the baseball), but on a larger scale and a longer timeline, inefficiency in markets leads to the misallocation of resources. And that leaves everyone worse off.
This principle seems obvious, but seems to be missed by Brown, and also by the U.S. Department of Justice, and several attorney generals in other states who initiated lawsuits since last August against the same property management software company and expanded it to include rental management organizations for collusion and price gouging.
It's true that rental managers who use the software often end up charging similar rents for similar units. But that is because the software is providing a view into the underlying factors that determine rent.
This is similar to two people standing 10 feet apart from the person holding up a sign, and giving the same answers on what they read. It is not an evil conspiracy but equal access to the relevant information. The lawsuit's solution is akin to gouging their eyes out.
These reckless lawsuits don't just hurt the property management software and the rental management organizations by taking up their valuable time and energy. They hurt renters too.
Diffusion of relevant information diffusion doesn't only make prices higher — it makes prices more responsive. If other rental managers are overcharging, it creates a lucrative opportunity to undercut them. And a good software algorithm would advise just that. In fact, research suggests that landlords who use pricing software are more likely to lower rents as market conditions improve.
Brown accuses the software of "making it hard for Maryland renters to put a roof over their heads." But the algorithms are not the enemy. If the goal is lower housing costs, the solution is to increase supply by building more housing.
Government leaders may want to consider loosening zoning laws, repealing rent control ordinances (which discourage new construction in key markets like Montgomery County), and streamlining the permitting process. These common-sense solutions will address the root causes–the software is just a mirror held up to the broken housing market.
Concealing the evidence rather than addressing the problem is like a mechanic who turns off your check engine light without bothering to fix your car. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on economic principles, housing market dynamics, and the impact of legal actions on market efficiency. While it mentions a state attorney general's lawsuit, the core discussion revolves around economic policies, software's role in pricing, and market supply-demand factors, aligning most strongly with Business/Economy.

title: New Burger King expected in Easton in spring
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
New Burger King expected in Easton in spring

 February 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 196
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A new Burger King is coming to U.S. Route 50 in Easton.According to an email from Burger King's public relations team, the restaurant is expected to open in Easton this spring. The email stated that the new restaurant will replace the establishment's current Easton location on 8192 Ocean Gateway, which is between Jiffy Lube and Walgreens.
The new restaurant is currently under construction. It will be located at 8518 Ocean Gateway, which is just north of Royal Farms.
Easton Town Planner Lynn Thomas said the new Burger King received site plan approval from the Easton Planning Commission and should offer an improved design.
In August 2021, the project received subdivision approval from the Planning Commission. The Commission voted to approve the restaurant's site plan, architecture and parking waiver request during a meeting the following month. According to meeting minutes from the September 2021 meeting, architect Robert Zappulla said plans for the new restaurant's look took inspiration from Easton's downtown. He said they wanted to make it look like a Burger King was placed in an existing building in Easton.
Thomas said he does not know what Burger King's plans for the location on 8192 Ocean Gateway are.

title: Egg prices hit record highs and are expected to go higher
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media
content:
Egg prices hit record highs and are expected to go higher

 February 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media | Section: Local News 
 
 1161
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Nick Rodgers knows the pain of record-high egg prices as much as anyone.Rodgers is co-owner of Main Street Overeasy, a popular breakfast and lunch restaurant in Bozeman, Montana.
Rodgers said he buys eggs by the case. And he buys lots of cases.
"We get 150 eggs in a case," Rodgers said.
He said last year a case cost $60.
"This year, they are now $127 per case," Rodgers said.
That doubling of prices added an additional $1,300 in egg costs to the Montana restaurant's narrow weekly bottom line.
"We have pretty narrow margins. That is rough," Rodgers said.
In response, the Bozeman eatery has added a 95-cent extra charge on dishes with eggs.
Other restaurants have raised prices because of higher eggs prices. Earlier this month, the Waffle House breakfast chain initiated a 50-cents-per-egg surcharge on its dishes.
In Cheyenne, Wyoming, Mike Moriarty owns the Epic Egg restaurant. He's feeling the pain.
"Our egg costs have risen over 200% since February 2024," said Moriarty, who also has Epic Egg locations in Colorado.
The eatery has put a temporary 8% extra charge on egg dishes.
"At this time, we have implemented a temporary surcharge on egg entrees to help offset excessive egg costs instead of updating and reprinting menus," he said.
STICKER SHOCKEgg prices have almost doubled since January 2024, according to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics and St. Louis Federal Reserve Bank.
They reported the average price for a dozen eggs as $4.95 in January. That is up $2.52 in January 2024.
But consumers across the U.S. are seeing egg prices higher than the $4.95 average. Some stores are running low on less-expensive eggs, leaving shoppers with prices more in the $6 and $7 per dozen range.
A persistent and impactful bird flu outbreak that started in 2022 has resulted in close to 160 million birds culled, according to the U.S. Department of Agriculture.
There were more than 308 million egg-laying hens in the U.S. in 2022, according to the Egg Producers Council. In 2023, there were 9.4 billion broiler chickens and 218 million turkeys processed nationally, according to USDA.
Dan Karney, an economics professor with Ohio University, said egg prices could continue to rise this year with the continued impacts of the highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI).
"The USDA's prediction is that egg prices will increase by 20.3% during 2025, and egg price increases could get as high as 45.3% within the year," Karney said.
Expensive eggs are part of hotter-than-expected inflation confronting President Donald Trump, who promised to lower prices during the 2024 presidential campaign.
January inflation figures show high prices are still a challenge, with consumer prices 3% higher and wholesale prices 3.5% higher than a year ago. Both were higher than expected by economists.
Trump has also acknowledged his push for tariffs, including 25% levies on aluminum and steel, could raise prices.
Overall, U.S. prices are up 24% from the end of 2019, before the COVID pandemic's resets and ensuing inflation, according to Bureau of Labor Statistics.
That makes it tough for restaurant owners to raise prices on customers, Rodgers said.
"I don't want to put more on the customers than I have to," he said.
Karney said market conditions drive egg prices, and that the Trump administration can look at policies and monitoring of farms to help cut into outbreaks.
But Trump's and Elon Musk's austerity and expected GOP deregulation pushes might not lend themselves to more government oversight of farms, critics of the administration contend.
"Action on bird flu will require fully staffed, fully funded federal agencies, with a broad and urgent mandate to increase on-farm testing and PPE (personal protective equipment), as well as vaccine development and distribution," said Rebecca Wolf, senior food policy analyst for Food & Water Watch.
The progressive group worries about job cuts and other rollbacks at the USDA and other agencies, as well as the further proliferation of large factory farms.
'HUGE NUMBERS'Animal welfare activists are concerned that large-scale poultry farms help proliferate the bird flu outbreaks with their scale and conditions.
There have been bird flu outbreaks and mass cullings at large U.S. farms with hundreds of thousands of birds, as well as ones involving 2.6 million, 1.8 million and 1.4 million chickens, according to the USDA.
"You are dealing with a huge number of animals," said Zach Strong, director and senior attorney for Animal Welfare Institute's farmed animal program.
Strong said America's larger "factory farms" can potentially be breeding grounds and more at risk for the avian flu "largely because of the higher number of animals in confined settings."
AWI and other animal welfare advocates also want more attention paid to how millions of chickens and turkeys are being culled.
Strong said one preferred method entails shutting down and sealing ventilation and air systems inside large hen houses until the birds die from overheating.
The ventilation shutdown process can sometimes take hours.
That has resulted in some farms completely sealing ventilation systems and using heaters to turn up the hen house temperatures to 120 to 130 degrees to cull the poultry.
"It's horrific," said Amber Canavan, vegan campaign project manager for People for Ethical Treatment of Animals.
She worries about large farms fostering the outbreak with their large capacities and conditions.
"These are absolute breeding grounds for disease," said Canavan, hoping that more Americans look at vegan food options, including for eggs and protein.
The U.S. produces more than 90 billion eggs annually, with Americans eating more than 280 eggs (more than 23 dozen) annually per capita, according to the Egg Producers Council and Statista.com.
Strong said some farms are using nitrogen foam to cull chickens, which works faster and can be less painful.
He noted the poultry farmers have been financially reimbursed for chickens and turkey culled.
An analysis by Sentient Policy in January found poultry and egg farmers, including some large agri-businesses, have received $1.46 billion in avian flu reimbursements from the U.S. government.
'A BIG PROBLEM'Austin Spies, who has a farm with 1,000 egg-laying hens in Preston, Maryland, said his family's operation has not had any bird flu outbreaks or cullings.
Spies said he and his brother shift their chicken flock's pasture around every couple of days (at most) to help their health.
"They're not over top of their manure. That can be a big problem," he said.
Spies said the rotational grazing entails temporary fencing and moving the birds.
"I think it's becoming more popular," he said.
Some farmers using rotational and more traditional, smaller farming models are using guard dogs to protect against foxes and other predators.
Back in Montana, Rodgers said he also has some experience with poultry and egg farming. He said the challenge to the rotational model is how to do something like that in large-scale farms.
Moriarty said farming rules in states such as Colorado are not helping prices or the replenishment of flocks.
"In addition to the bird flu issues, Colorado has mandated 100% cage-free eggs, which has decreased egg supply (and is) driving prices up," he said.
Spies said he and other farmers continue to navigate post-pandemic inflation, including for feed.
He said the price of chicks has increased, with other farmers looking to replenish flocks and increased interest in backyard farms.
"I heard it's doubled," the Maryland farmer said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on rising egg prices, inflation impacts, restaurant cost challenges, and government economic policies. While agriculture and bird flu outbreaks are mentioned, the core theme revolves around economic factors, market dynamics, and business implications.

title: State should hit brakes on mileage user fees
author: DAVID REEL
content:
State should hit brakes on mileage user fees

 February 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 851
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Since the Maryland General Assembly convened for a 90-day session last month, the state budget has been the focus of intense attention, an intense focus that generally occurs later in the session.Projected state budget deficits have driven early debates on spending cuts, tax increases, personal income and business tax adjustments, fee increases and "rainy day" fund transfers.
Given the challenges in reaching consensus on the governor's proposed $67.3 billion budget, and majorities in the House of Delegates and the Senate, these debates have been and will continue to encounter unexpected twists and turns.
Last week, Maryland Senate President Bill Ferguson speaking about a new challenge said lawmakers will likely have to look for "several hundred million more dollars" in additional cuts or taxes to cover anticipated decreases in federal funds coming to Maryland.
Despite these challenges, a balanced budget as mandated by the state constitution will most likely be approved by the General Assembly and sent to the governor for his approval just before or at midnight when the General Assembly adjourns on April 7.
If that does not happen, the governor will need to call for a special session for a budget approval for the first time since 2012.
Another state budget issue that will be challenging but which has not yet received much attention is long-term funding for the state's $21.2 billion six-year transportation trust fund.
This fund provides capital investment funding for the Maryland Aviation Administration, Maryland Port Administration, Maryland Transit Administration, Motor Vehicle Administration, State Highway Administration and The Secretary's Office, as well as Maryland's investment in the Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority.
Currently, almost a third of the transportation trust fund's annual revenue comes from a 46.1-cent per gallon gas tax, a tax that is automatically adjusted based on the rate of inflation.
There are increasing concerns that even with future annual automatic gas tax rate increases, it is not a long-term reliable revenue source for the transportation trust fund.
There are three driving trends leading to the gas tax reliability concerns: less gas consumption due to improved fuel efficiency of new gas-powered vehicles, increasing use of electric and hybrid vehicles, and less driving by those working from home who seldom or never drive to or from work.
The Eastern Transportation Coalition (ETC), a partnership of 19states and the District of Columbia focused on connecting public agencies across modes of travel to increase safety and efficiency. is proposing mileage-based user fee.
ETC has already done a four-month user fee demonstration pilot in Maryland with voluntary participation of more than 170 drivers.
In their analysis of the Maryland pilot results, the ETC concludes, "in general," drivers would have paid the same amount with a milage-based user fee as they would have with the gas tax.
They do not elaborate on how they define "in general."
The response to the ETC proposal from the Maryland Department of Transportation is "MDOT continues to partner with the Eastern Transportation Coalition on the work that the coalition is doing to learn more about the feasibility of MBUF as a sustainable transportation funding option for the future, but has no next steps planned at this time."
I suggest the transportation department's non-committal for next steps at this time is very appropriate.
There are a wide range of unanswered questions on the ETC demonstration pilot results specifically and the MBUF concept in general, that need to be addressed before user fees are given serious consideration as an alternative to a gas tax.
How reliable are ETC conclusions that mileage-based user fees and gas tax driving costs are close to equal?
Are those conclusions applicable statewide in Maryland, especially on the Eastern Shore where long commutes to Annapolis, Washington and Baltimore are common?
If the goal is increasing revenue for the transportation trust fund, why replace one revenue source for another with no net gain on revenue?
Will 170 drivers reporting positive pilot demonstration with a user fee experience from voluntary driver surveys generate enough political support for legislative approval of a statewide user fee when there are over four million licensed drivers in Maryland?
What are the projected long-term trends on sales of gas efficient vehicles?
What are the projected long-term trends on sales of all electric vehicles?
What are the projected long-term trends on sales of hybrid vehicles?
What are the projected long-term trends on work from home workers?
Complicating matters on this issue is another gas tax related proposal reducing the mass transit operating expense subsidies paid from the state transportation trust fund.
Under current law, 50% of the transportation trust fund goes to pay those subsidies since fares cover less than 10% of the total operating costs of mass transit systems.
The question is: will the General Assembly and governor approve a new mandate that at least 35% of the operating costs of a mass transit system must be covered by fare revenues, and just as with the gas tax, fares must be adjusted regularly based on the rate of inflation.
Until all of the above questions are answered, going slow on any replacement of the current gas tax system with a mileage-based user fee system is necessary, prudent and realistic. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on state budget challenges, transportation funding mechanisms, and fiscal policy debates, which align with Business/Economy. While Local Government is related to state operations, the core discussion revolves around economic policy, tax structures, and budgetary decisions rather than direct governance or public safety issues.

title: Gas prices down from last week, last month, last year
author: Staff Writer
content:
Gas prices down from last week, last month, last year

 February 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: State News 
 
 491
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Average gasoline prices in Maryland have fallen 8.8 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.09 per gallon Monday, according to GasBuddy's survey of 2,167 stations in Maryland. Prices in Maryland are 17.0 cents per gallon lower than a month ago and stand 28.4 cents per gallon lower than a year ago."While most of the country has experienced a relatively quiet week for gas prices, the West Coast has seen rapid increases— a trend that should slow in the coming days," said Patrick De Haan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy. "Although the surge remains isolated to the West for now, refinery maintenance will soon begin in other regions, and with the transition to summer gasoline blends underway, prices in most areas are likely to start rising in the weeks ahead."
The national average price of diesel has increased 0.8 cents in the last week and stands at $3.632 per gallon.
According to GasBuddy price reports, the cheapest station in Maryland was priced at $2.77 per gallon Sunday, while the most expensive was $3.85 per gallon, a difference of $1.08 per gallon. The lowest price in the state yesterday was $2.77 per gallon while the highest was $3.85 per gallon, a difference of $1.08 per gallon.
The national average price of gasoline has risen 2.2 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.11 per gallon Monday. The national average is unchanged from a month ago and stands 16.5 cents per gallon lower than a year ago, according to GasBuddy data compiled from more than 11 million weekly price reports covering over 150,000 gas stations across the country.
Historical gasoline prices in Maryland and the national average going back 10 years:
February 17, 2024: $3.38per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.28per gallon)February 17, 2023: $3.29per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.38per gallon)February 17, 2022: $3.55per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.51per gallon)February 17, 2021: $2.60per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.57per gallon)February 17, 2020: $2.37per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.44per gallon)February 17, 2019: $2.28per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.31per gallon)February 17, 2018: $2.53per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.52per gallon)February 17, 2017: $2.28per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.28per gallon)February 17, 2016: $1.74per gallon (U.S. Average: $1.71per gallon)February 17, 2015: $2.27per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.26per gallon)
Neighboring areas and their current gas prices:
Baltimore: $3.04 per gallon, down 12.3 cents per gallon from last week's $3.16 per gallon.Washington, D.C.: $3.24 per gallon, up 4.4 cents per gallon from last week's $3.20 per gallon.Hagerstown: 3.26 per gallon, up 0.9 cents per gallon from last week's $3.25 per gallon.
"The national average has inched higher, driven primarily by sharp gas price increases on the West Coast, where refinery maintenance and outages have created a ripple effect in neighboring states, pushing prices higher in many communities," said Patrick De Haan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy. "Meanwhile, oil prices remain subdued in the low $70s as President Trump works on a potential peace deal between Russia and Ukraine— an event that, if realized, could have significant implications for oil markets in the months ahead."
