title: Delmarva Power customers attend event seeking answers for high bills
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Delmarva Power customers attend event seeking answers for high bills

 February 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 576
 Words 

 Read News Document

 STEVENSVILLE — Filing into the Kent Island Library meeting hall, disgruntled, frustrated and confused power customers sought information on rising bills during a public meeting held by Delmarva Power Tuesday.In light of recent electric bills increases, the open house gave customers the opportunity to discuss with one-on-one consultation forums about accounts, as well as payment plans, budget billing and energy efficiency programs, according to Amber Burruezo, regional communications manager for the power company.
"We want to be transparent and communicate with customers," Burruezo said.
Delmarva Power customers across the Eastern Shore are reporting dramatic increases in their utility bills, with some seeing their charges double or triple despite the company's October prediction of an estimated 3% rate hike.
Delmarva Power, a subsidiary of Illinois-based Exelon Corporation, provides electric service to 208,000 Maryland customers.
At the event energy engineer Dave Tancredi, presented resources and assessments on energy usage savings. He sais little things can add up to impact increases in electricity, including a simple hot water leak.
The 2024-2025 season has also seen colder temperatures than in prior years, which Tancredi said could impact power bills. The number one issue the engineers see at customer homes is heat pumps, he said.
Temperature settings can also affect an electric bill, according to Tancredi. He recommended setting the thermostat to 78 degrees in the summer and 68 degrees in the winter.
Delmarva Power offers programs such as home energy evaluations, and customers can compare their rates with their neighbors at the Delmarva Power website.
Attending the event as a customer, Jim Hynson, a former Delmarva Power employee of 30 years, noted how the company has changed. Delmarva Power is now an Exelon company, along with Pepco Holdings.
Overall, Hynson said he was satisfied with the information he received and remembered Delmarva Power fondly as a company to work for.
Other customers were less satisfied with the event, expecting more overall discussion on the bill rate increases.
"What metric is Delmarva using to decide what's affordable?" asked Amanda D'Onofrio of Centreville, who noted as a military spouse, cost of living allowances couldn't keep up with the rates.
D'Onofrio considered the event merely a covering of energy savings basics that most people were familiar with. She felt the company neglected larger questions including regulating energy monopoly.
Delmarva putting forth installment plans and cutting late fees does not address the underlying issue that customers are simply unable to afford their bills, D'Onofrio said. She wanted to see freedom of choice for consumers and an increase in transparency.
Jan Debrew of Stevensville considered her electric bill "extreme" and couldn't fathom why it had recently skyrocketed. Debrew stated she had a friend on the western shore with a different provider and a much larger house but a lower electric bill charge. "It should be at least equal," she said.
Debrew was hopeful to utilize new tactics to reduce the bill, noting she didn't consider herself to have other options for providers in the area.
Lucy Mitchell, of Chester, said the event was "somewhat helpful" to get an explanation of her $700 electric bill breakdown. Mitchell learned what pools the most electricity in a home, but she was already performing "low hanging fruit" energy savings, and at 80 years old, she was not in the market for high-end items such as new windows and installation.
According to Burruezo, about 30 to 40 customers RSVP'd for individual consultation ahead of time. The event had been rescheduled from Feb. 12 due to inclement weather.
More information about Delmarva Power can be found at delmarva.com. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Delmarva Power customers addressing rising utility bills, company responses, rate hikes, and economic impacts on consumers. While there is a local event aspect, the core issue revolves around business practices, economic fairness, and consumer economics rather than government operations or public notices.

title: St. Michaels hears presentation on houseboat vacation rentals
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
St. Michaels hears presentation on houseboat vacation rentals

 February 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 575
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST.MICHAELS — Flohom, a company that provides vacationers the chance to stay on houseboats, presented the company's plans for St. Michaels to government officials.Flohom and St. Michaels Marina owner Michael Morgan have discussed putting one or two Flohoms in the marina.
"I run a strict place. Everyone knows my style," Morgan told the town's commissioners at a meeting Wednesday. "I was timid at first, but then a heard their rules and the type of clientele that they have. If I thought this would displease my customer base, I wouldn't even have entertained it. I think it's a neat concept."
The Flohom presentation showed how the boats are built, how the company was started, and what types of rules and regulations are enforced within the company.
Customers are not permitted or allowed to drive the Flohom boats at all, so they remain docked in the same place.
To eliminate excessive noise, Flohom monitors the sound of anyone that stays in the houseboats. If the sound gets too loud, the guest will receive a text message asking them to lower their noise level. Noise monitors do not listen or record conversation but monitor the sound decibels in the home.
Flohom staff members look to dock in places where guests can walk or drive a short distance to get breakfast or lunch and attend different town events.
"I'm new to this as well," Morgan said. "I'm willing to take the chance on it because I think it would be a unique thing for the town, it would be another option for people to come and stay and do something in St. Michaels. Not to mention the accommodation tax"
Commissioners and town residents had multiple questions for the company and for Morgan.
Commissioner David Wojiechowski questioned if Flohom would have to pay accommodation tax, and if so, if all other boats or yacht should pay the same accommodation tax if they stay overnight.
"It is an overnight rental competing against our hotel rooms," Wjiechowski said. "So if this gets approved and pays an accommodation tax, then all 200 slips that are overnight should pay an accommodation tax."
Morgan said that other slips would not be subject to accommodation tax.
Flohom staff confirmed the company does have a plan to bring business to St. Michaels after going through the proper protocols. But the company has an interest in exploring the town and gauging reception first.
"This is just an initial presentation," Jerry South Co-Founder of Flohom said. "Were not sure if this is something that requires a vote. We wanted to be very proactive and come in and say, 'hey, this is what we are doing.'"
Flohom doesn't need a approval from the town council just yet. The company first must go in front of the town's Planning Commission to ensure plans abide by the town's zoning policies.
"The use that they are proposing tonight would not be allowed with our current codes," Town Administrator Rob Straebel said. "So it would require a zoning change that would most likely go in front of the Planning Commission, then come back to the commissioners for discussion.
"So the presentation is just to see if there is enough support to move forward with consideration of a zoning change to potentially allow this."
St. Michaels residents also wanted to know if Flohom can give the houseboat model an historic look instead of a "business look."
Flohom officials confirmed they can remodel the boats to give them a historic look.
This report was updated to clarify how accommodation tax could be applied. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

While local government processes are discussed, the core subject is the business model and its economic impact.

title: Trump can break laws, but not laws of economics
author: RICK SCHIMING
content:
Trump can break laws, but not laws of economics

 March 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: RICK SCHIMING | Section: Columns 
 
 657
 Words 

 Read News Document

 "Madmen in authority, who hear voices in the air, are distilling their frenzy from some academic scribbler of a few years back."This quote by the famed British economist John Maynard Keynes helps us understand Donald Trump's fascination with tariffs. For all practical purposes, Trump is a mercantilist, following the scribblings of a discredited group of economists from the 18th century.
Mercantilists had a few basic ideas about how a nation could become wealthy. A nation should accumulate as much gold and silver as they could through trade and exploitation. A nation should strive to restrict imports from other nations as much as possible to achieve a positive balance of trade.
Mercantilists viewed the world as a zero-sum game where the only way for your nation to win was for other nations to lose. The goal of the nation was to be as self-sufficient as possible, producing as many goods and services within its own borders as possible. Colonies were especially helpful in providing goods and services, and especially raw materials, to the mother country.
Trump truly is an unrepentant mercantilist. He has a fascination with gold. He is always talking about a golden age for American. His Trump Tower condo, Mar-a-Lago, and now even the Oval Office look like they were decorated by King Midas. He even sells gold sneakers.
Like all mercantilists, Trump is deeply disturbed by trade deficits. He sees them as theft perpetrated on the U.S. economy by other nations, requiring punitive tariffs on the offenders.
He also is captivated by the idea of colonies. Canada, Panama, Greenland and now even Gaza are viewed by Trump as possible colonial acquisitions.
The problem is that days of mercantilism as a rational understanding of how the world works are long over. We now know better. Believing in mercantilist thought today is the economic equivalent of being a member of the Flat Earth Society.
Basic economic principles tell us that nations should no longer strive to be self-sufficient. The goal now for each nation is to do what they do best and trade for the rest. Trump can break a lot of laws, but he can't break the laws of economics.
The sensible and efficient thing for us to do is to produce those goods and services in which we have a cost or technology advantage and then use those goods and services to trade with other nations for the goods and services in which they have a production advantage.
When trade occurs, it is not a zero-sum game but rather an exchange in which both trading nations win. Indeed, expanded global trade since World War II has enriched wealthy and poor nations alike. This trade expansion has proven to be one of the greatest international anti-poverty programs the world has ever seen.
So, what would be the economic impact of Trump's continual obsession with mercantilism and tariffs?
We will certainly see higher prices in the U.S. for a whole variety of imported goods and services. The Fed will be reluctant to lower interest rates if inflation increases. U.S. tariffs are a tax on U.S. consumers. Even worse, it is a regressive tax with lower income families feeling a greater burden of the higher prices.
U.S. production will slow as our companies face less demand for our products internationally as other nations will impose tariffs on our exports. Higher unemployment will result. The U.S. economy could face the worst of all possible worlds: higher prices and higher unemployment rates. Clearly, no one wins a trade war.
The best-case scenario?
Tariff policy becomes in the second Trump term like infrastructure week was in the first term — lots of talk but ultimately little meaningful or sustained action. Unfortunately, this scenario seems increasingly unlikely now as new tariffs on steel and aluminum have been announced and other reciprocal tariffs are in the works.
But whether it is the best case or the worst case or somewhere in between, Trump is the proponent of a discredited academic theory that puts our economy in peril. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article analyzes Donald Trump's economic policies, focusing on mercantilism, tariffs, and their economic implications. It discusses core economic principles, trade dynamics, and financial impacts, aligning directly with the Business/Economy topic. While it touches on political figures, the central theme is economic theory and policy rather than politics or news events.

title: More nuclear power in Maryland? Probably yes
author: DAVID REEL
content:
More nuclear power in Maryland? Probably yes

 March 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 835
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Forty-five years ago this month, a nuclear reactor at the Three Mile Island electric power generating station in central Pennsylvania experienced a partial nuclear meltdown.It is the worst accident involving nuclear power generation in American history. On the International Nuclear Event Scale it is rated as a Level 5 event — an "accident with wider consequences".
One of those wider consequences was a dramatic and long-lasting shift on the public perception on the safety and feasibility of nuclear power plants, even with post TMI design and operating improvements for new plants.
Despite those improvements, some concluded that the TMI accident and how it was mismanaged initially marked the beginning of the end of nuclear power as a source for electric power in America.
Ultimately, the accident did not result in the demise of the U.S. nuclear power industry, but it did halt its historic growth.
Fast forward to today.
Unexpected and extraordinary increases in electric bills are a huge issue throughout Maryland.
They are generating extensive media coverage and widespread expressions of public concern and even outrage.
The levels of media coverage, public concern and public outrage on electric bills are greater than that generated by proposals under consideration in the General Assembly to revise state taxes, increase state fees and cut state spending in order to balance the state budget.
Former U.S. Sen. Everett Dirksen once said: 'When I feel the heat, I see the light."
Presently, the heat is being felt by elected public officials at all levels of government including members of the General Assembly.
Based on that heat they are increasingly open to a wide range of electrical generating options that could result in lower electric bills.
One option was succinctly captured in a recent headline for a Capital News Service article — "Craving more energy, Maryland looks to nuclear power."
That "craving" recently has led to a four-bill package of legislation in the General Assembly.
One of the bills proposes a procurement framework to support the development of both traditional nuclear power plants and small modular reactors in Maryland.
If and when that occurs, any new traditional reactors would join the Calvert Cliffs nuclear power plant in Calvert County.
Owned and operated by Baltimore based Constellation Energy since it became operational in 1975, Calvert Cliffs is Maryland's only traditional nuclear power plant. It is also the largest nuclear power plant on the East Coast. It generates about 40% of all electric power used in Maryland, an amount equal to that generated and imported from outside of Maryland.
Support for increased use of nuclear power in Maryland is not universal.
Jorge Aguilar, a regional director at Food and Water Watch, a national environmental advocacy organization, has said, "Maryland should be alarmed that state leaders want to build out these astronomically expensive and dangerous nuclear plants in Maryland to meet the state's energy needs. These plants would be expensive to build and produce hazardous nuclear waste. Maryland should be pushing the grid operator to approve renewable energy projects faster. I think Maryland leaders really need to double down on truly clean energy, like wind and solar, as well as batteries. Not nuclear."
That message is likely to resonate with many of the progressive members in the General Assembly. It is not likely to resonate with the Freedom Caucus in the State House.
That caucus is suggesting the following changes in Maryland's energy — reopen closed coal-fired electric generating plants, keep open currently open coal-fired electric generating plants scheduled for closure, stop "EmPOWER Maryland" fees on electric bills, repeal or revise the state law that requires higher margins of clean energy to be used statewide and reduce spending $180 million dollars on a state climate department.
While this approach of the Freedom Caucus may be helpful in increasing public awareness of the caucus and their proposed energy agenda, it will not move the needle with the governor or the steadily increasing numbers and power of progressive legislators in Annapolis.
Regardless of the levels of support or opposition to more nuclear power, there are two realities that will determine its impact on higher electric bills for now and in the future.
The first reality is the 90-day General Assembly session ends on April 7, 2025.
Between now and then, the Governor and General Assembly leaders will be fully engaged in efforts to secure consensus and a majority of votes on a balanced state budget.
The second reality is, even with new policies on approving and encouraging greater use of nuclear power, the schedule for building and opening new nuclear power plants is a long one.
The period from proposal, approval, building, and opening can range from six years to 12 years. Construction time alone for the Calvert Cliffs plant was seven years.
Accordingly, nuclear power will not provide immediate or short-term lower electric bills.
What is urgently needed is the governor and General Assembly leadership to reach agreement on all the underlying causes of higher electric bills and then reach agreement on short-term and long-term solutions.
On the question of more nuclear power plants in Maryland, the answers are — probably yes, but not a given, and most certainly, not soon. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Maryland's legislative efforts to address rising electricity costs through nuclear power development, highlighting economic implications, energy policy debates, and fiscal considerations. While environmental concerns are mentioned, the core discussion revolves around energy generation's economic impact and state budgetary decisions.

title: Recession risk: Could Trump's tariffs sink the stock market and U.S. economy?
author: Mike Sunnucks
content:
Recession risk: Could Trump's tariffs sink the stock market and U.S. economy?

 March 6, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks | Section: Business 
 
 1271
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Is U.S. President Donald Trump risking a recession with his tariffs?Joosep Seitam, co-founder of a New York-based e-commerce firm, is worried about that.
"There is a risk of recession. When companies swallow higher costs and consumers pull back in the face of higher prices, economic growth can slow down," said Seitam, whose company IceCartel.com sells jewelry online.
He worries about the impact on U.S. farmers and small businesses from Trump's tariffs on Canada, Mexico and China and additional looming global tariffs slated to go into place April 2. Trump said Friday more specific tariffs against Canada could be enacted before next month.
"Small businesses are hurt the most by such policies. They lack the ability to absorb price hikes costs while also not having the influence to negotiate better terms," Seitam said. "When their costs increase due to tariffs, they increase prices or cut costs elsewhere. This means layoffs or reduced expenditure on growth."
STOCKS PLUNGEWall Street is also worried about the Trump tariffs and their potential for higher prices, disrupted supply chains and trade wars.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed down more than 1,000 points for the week on Friday and has lost 2.8% since Trump took office in January.
The S&P 500 closed down 2.85% for the week on Friday and is down 4.6% since Trump's return to power, according to Google Finance.
The Nasdaq lost more than 506 points for the week, shedding 2.7% of its value. The tech-heavy index is down 7.9% since Trump's return to the White House.
Overall, U.S. stocks are down 5.5% since Trump return to power.
Tariff fears extend to main street businesses and consumers' inflationary weary pocketbooks. Farmers, publishers, manufacturers, retailers and hosts of other businesses and industries are faced with higher prices for raw materials, parts and products and higher costs to enter international markets via reciprocal levies.
"Tariffs are a tax on imported goods and will undoubtedly lead to higher prices. Businesses who use products that have tariffs applied will either need to find another supplier or pay the higher price," said Eric Belasco, an economist and head of the agricultural economics and economics department at Montana State University.
He said consumers will see higher retail prices and businesses higher costs for raw materials and other inputs.
"For example, farmers buy fertilizer from Canadian firms and those prices will go up if tariffs are applied. Many industries have also established their supply chains through NAFTA where components are made and produced interchangeably between these countries," he said.
UNCERTAINTY REIGNSTrump has retreated some with his sweeping 25% tariffs on Mexico and Canada after stocks on Wall Street plunged.
Trump is kicking the can for a month on North American tariffs on automakers and products and materials under the U.S. Mexico Canada Agreement (USMCA). That could help farmers and other businesses.
But some other products and materials still face the stiff U.S. levies and the current exemption only lasts 30 days.
Trump also has 20% tariffs in place on China and promises even more tariffs against other countries in April.
The uncertainty and tariffs' upward pressure on prices and potential downward pressure on economic growth has Wall Street investors, farmers, businesses and inflation-weary consumers spooked.
"Trump's tariffs will make groceries, electronics, cars, and gas more expensive. Not everything will go up in price right off the bat, but industries that rely on imported tech may see higher costs and be forced to cut jobs," said Jeep Stale, managing partner at Raisewell Ventures (a San Francisco-based, tech-focused investment firm).
The current tariffs against Canada, Mexico and China were invoked by Trump under an emergency powers law citing the flow of fentanyl into the U.S.
Trump's one-month extensions don't seem to be helping investor and economic confidence with the market 'animal spirits' selling off stocks and indicating a potential slowdown. Stress and lack of clarity about tariffs is depressing business sentiments and essentially freezing capital spending, mergers and acquisitions and hiring decisions.
"Uncertainty is always a cancer for a macroeconomy," said Chris Jones, an economist and economics professor at the University of South Florida. "Expectations drive the capital planning decisions of firms. You have to have some sense for what the future is going to hold."
Jones said the tariffs' impacts on the U.S. economy likely depends on their length and reciprocity from other countries.
But he does see the possibility of a 'stagflation' scenario with high price and slowed economic growth.
The Atlanta Federal Reserve Bank's GDPNow gauge now pegs first quarter economic growth at -2.4%.
The new indicator was released Wednesday and improved from -2.8% on Monday.
The U.S. has not had a negative quarter of economic growth since 2022 in the midst of 40-year highs with inflation.
'TRANSITORY'Trump and his economic acolytes such as Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick and Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent have used terms such as "disturbance", "short-term interruption", "disruption" and "price movements" while pushing back against fears of tariffs' driving up still persistent post-pandemic inflation.
"We could get a one-time price adjustment," Bessent told the Economic Club of New York. "Nothing is more transitory than tariffs if it's a one-time price adjustment," he continued.
The Biden administration was previously faulted for calling post-pandemic inflation 'transitory.'
On Thursday, Trump blamed "globalist" companies and countries for trade imbalances still touting tariffs as a way to bolster manufacturing and resource production, railing against Canadian imports, in particular, including lumber key to home building.
Republican lawmakers supportive of Trump have said the current tariffs are meant as leverage to push Mexico, Canada and China to curtail fentanyl flows.
"And that's President Trump's goal: Use these tariffs as important leverage to get the Canadians and the Mexican governments working with us to stop this scourge of fentanyl," U.S. Sen. Steve Daines, R-Montana, told Fox Business Wednesday
But Trump and Lutnick have also pressed tariffs as a way for domestic manufacturing and job growth. Lutnick talked about more U.S. factors utilizing robots during a Thursday interview with CNBC.
Daines and the president's camp have also touted the $1.7 trillion in domestic business investments since Trump returned to power and have promised tax and regulatory cuts and increased oil and gas drilling.
That's what Wall Street and businesses expected from a second Trump term as opposed to trade wars and tariffs on the country's three largest trading partners.
WARNING SIGNSBut there are also other economic warning signs in Trump's first months in office.
U.S. households currently carry a record $18.04 trillion in debt, according to the New York Federal Reserve Bank.
The Conference Board's consumer confidence index also dipped in February with persistent inflation and egg prices at record highs and expected to go even higher due to bird flu outbreaks and mass poultry cullings.
A new report from PriceWaterhouseCoopers also worries the tariffs will drive up already rising auto and home insurance premiums if prices for auto parts, appliances and home repairs materials are more expensive.
U.S. employers also reported more than 172,000 job cuts and layoffs in February, the highest since 2020 during the COVID-19 pandemic, according to Challenger, Gray & Christmas.
February layoffs are up 245% from January with some of the cuts stemming from Trump and Elon Musk's Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) austerity efforts impacting government agencies and contractors, according to the Challenger report.
Jason Brown, an investment and stock market analyst and founder of The Brown Report and Power Trades University, said he's already seeing an economic slowdown, including from the employment and procurement impacts of DOGE.
But he doesn't see a sustained economic slump.
"I don't think we are going to see a recession," said Brown, who is based in Michigan.
He understands Trump's long-term play of addressing trade inequities and bolstering domestic manufacturing. "I think long-term, it's going to be good for the economy," Brown said, while also acknowledging the current landscape.
"I think short-term, it's going to be pretty painful." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Trump's tariffs and their economic impacts, including stock market declines, business concerns, inflation, and recession risks. While agriculture and national news are tangentially related, the core subject is economic policy and market dynamics under the Business/Economy category.

title: U.S. adds fewer jobs than expected in February; Trump’s first month sees 32% job-gain drop from last year
author: Staff Writer
content:
U.S. adds fewer jobs than expected in February; Trump’s first month sees 32% job-gain drop from last year

 March 7, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: News 
 
 206
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The U.S. economy created fewer jobs than expected in February — President Donald Trump's first full month in office.The U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics reported 151,000 jobs were created in February.
Economists had expected 170,000 jobs being created in the U.S. last month. There were fears the new job number could have come in even lower.
Still, the February job gains are the lowest for the month since 2019 during Trump's first term in office.
The new job gains under Trump are lower than February employment gains during the Biden administration, which averaged 476,500.
Last year saw 222,000 February job gains, according to BLS.
In February 2023, there were 306,000 jobs added. In 2022 and 2021, the February figure was 869,000 and 509,000 jobs, respectively, according to BLS.
Trump's February job gains are down 32% from last year and 68% from the Biden average.
The jobs data comes as stock markets have fallen this week on fears over President Donald Trump's tariffs on Canada, Mexico and China and additional tariffs coming against other countries in April.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average is down 1,300 points this week with Trump's tariffs and continued inflation and record household debt worrying consumers, investors and businesses.
The U.S. unemployment rate edged up 4.1% in February, according to BLS. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on U.S. job creation data, economic performance under Trump's administration, and market reactions to tariffs, all central to Business/Economy. While it touches on national political figures, the core content is economic indicators and market impacts.

title: State's proposed hidden tax would take big bite
author: MARY D. KANE
content:
State's proposed hidden tax would take big bite

 March 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARY D. KANE | Section: Columns 
 
 730
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Your favorite local restaurant — where they know your name and usual order — is struggling to make ends meet. The owner works 70-plus-hour weeks, employs 20 of your neighbors and operates on a razor-thin 4% profit margin. Now imagine this small business being hit with a new 2.5% tax on their accounting services, payroll processing, marketing, web and IT support — essential services they can't function without.The owner faces an impossible choice: raise menu prices, cut staff hours or reduce the quality of ingredients. There's no fourth option to simply absorb thousands in new costs.
This isn't hypothetical. It will happen if lawmakers pass HB 1554/SB 1045, imposing a 2.5% tax on business-to-business services, including accounting, IT support, consulting and landscaping, among many other services. While framed as a business tax, the reality is these costs flow to consumers.
The ripple effect touches every industry. When your auto repair shop pays more for accounting services, your repair bill increases. When your hairstylist pays more for scheduling software, your haircut costs more. When your child's day care center pays more for payroll processing, your child care rates go up. These aren't luxury services — they're everyday necessities for Maryland families already stretched thin by inflation.
This couldn't come at a worse time. Maryland already ranks among the least competitive states for business:
46th in the Tax Foundation's State Business Tax Climate Index.Third highest cost of doing business and 31st for business climate overall (CNBC Top States for Business).41st for percentage job growth and 44th for net migration by state.
Meanwhile, our neighbors offer a far better climate:
Virginia: First for business climate; 28th for tax climatePennsylvania: 17th for business climate; 35th for tax climateDelaware: 34th for business climate; 18th for tax climate
Despite this dismal picture, instead of making Maryland more competitive, lawmakers are rushing through a last-minute tax increase with minimal debate — as a quick fix for the state's growing budget deficit.
And it's happening as Maryland's economy stalls. Growth — not new taxes — is the best way to close budget gaps, create jobs and strengthen communities. Yet this bill does the opposite. It discourages investment, punishes local businesses and makes Maryland even less attractive for growth.
Consider the real-world impact of these proposals, as shared by local business owners facing higher costs and tougher decisions:
A small med tech company in Baltimore producing lifesaving technology will pay more than $50,000 a year extra in business-to-business service taxes.A family-owned restaurant group in Frederick would face higher IT, marketing, payroll and accounting costs than one in Wilmington, Delaware — where there's no sales tax at all.
An engineering young entrepreneur with a successful brand consulting business will struggle to retain clients as the tax makes marketing services more expensive, while also facing higher costs for the essential services she depends on.
For businesses operating on 3% to 5% margins, these extra costs mean the difference between hiring an employee or cutting back.
Virginia doesn't tax these services. Delaware has no sales tax. Why would Maryland put its businesses at a disadvantage?
Small businesses will bear the brunt. Unlike large corporations with in-house accounting and IT, small businesses must outsource these functions. The local auto shop, day care and family-owned restaurant can't absorb this new tax.
Consumers will feel the pinch too. When a restaurant pays more for accounting, that cost gets passed on to your meal. When an accounting firm pays more for IT support, they raise their rates, increasing costs across the board. This 2.5% tax multiplies into even higher prices for Maryland families.
We understand Maryland's budget challenges. But solving today's deficit by creating tomorrow's economic problems is shortsighted. Sustainable revenue comes from fostering a business-friendly environment — where companies want to grow, invest and create jobs.
Every dollar a small business spends on new taxes is a dollar not invested in growth. Some will delay hiring. Others will postpone expansion. Some may relocate to business-friendly states nearby. Is that what Maryland needs?
Before lawmakers vote, they should consider the real-world impact: the restaurant server whose hours get cut, the recent graduate who doesn't get hired, the family watching prices rise.
Maryland deserves policies that strengthen communities by supporting small businesses — the backbone of our economy. Instead of creating new burdens, we should be removing barriers to growth.
Small business owners across Maryland are watching closely. And so should every consumer who cares about jobs, opportunity and the cost of living in our state. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a proposed state tax on business services and its economic impact on small businesses, highlighting issues like tax burdens, business competitiveness, and economic growth. While local government legislation is mentioned, the core issue revolves around business economics and fiscal policy.

title: Supreme Court denies fishing case
author: HANNAH COMBS hcombs@kibaytimes.com
content:
Supreme Court denies fishing case

 March 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: HANNAH COMBS hcombs@kibaytimes.com | Section: Local News 
 
 801
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court has denied a hearing for a coalition of Maryland fishing associations and charter boat operators seeking to overturn new striped bass fishing restrictions. But for Captain Robert Newberry, chairman of the Delmarva Fisheries Association, the legal battle is far from over."It's not good that we were denied the hearing in front of the Supreme Court, but this is far from over. We are in it to win it! We will be announcing our next move within a week," Newberry said, emphasizing that no other group in the state has fought as hard on this issue as the Delmarva Fisheries Association, the Maryland Charter Boat Association, and supporters like Brian Nesspor and Ken Jefferies.
The coalition had filed an emergency petition with the Supreme Court to block the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission's (the Commission) new restrictions, arguing they imposed "drastic, unwarranted, and illegal limitations" on striped bass fishing in the Chesapeake Bay and along the Atlantic coast. The March 4 petition claimed the regulations violated the U.S. Constitution and threatened the livelihoods of small fishing businesses.
Newberry learned of the decision from the Supreme Court just a week after filing. An explanation of the denial is expected to be forthcoming, he said.
The case follows months of legal disputes in lower courts, where the plaintiffs sought to halt the Commission's 2024 striped bass management plan, known as Addendum II. The plan, approved in January by a 14-2 vote, reduced commercial quotas, shortened fishing seasons, and limited recreational anglers to catching just one striped bass per day instead of two.
Maryland and New Jersey voted against the measure, but Maryland ultimately implemented the restrictions under pressure from the Commission and federal agencies. The Maryland Attorney General's Office acknowledged in a letter that failing to comply could trigger a federal moratorium on all striped bass fishing in state waters.
Assistant Director and Fisheries Manager at the Maryland Department of Natural Resources, Michael Luisi, warned the Commission that reducing Maryland's charter boat clients' catch to one fish per day would "put people out of business."
Documents filed by the plaintiffs argue that the Commission disregarded these warnings, relying on uncertain projections about fish-spawning trends while neglecting the immediate economic harm to family-run businesses. Newberry expressed frustration with Maryland officials, particularly Governor Wes Moore and Attorney General Anthony Brown, for not standing with the seafood industry.
"It is extremely perturbing that Governor Moore and Attorney General Brown turned their backs on us," Newberry said. "They are willing to spend millions of taxpayer dollars defending Maryland against alleged constitutional violations by President Trump, but they ignore the constitutional violations affecting the seafood industry."
Industry leaders say the damage is already evident.
"The economic impact is undeniable," said Brian Hardman, president of the Maryland Charter Boat Association. "We've seen a 75-85% decline in business, boats being sold off, and captains leaving the industry. The Commission rushed through regulations without considering the devastating impact on local livelihoods."
Hardman added that "2025 numbers are continuing to decline at the same rate or worse," citing the unprecedented sale or listing of 53 charter boats since 2024. He also noted that 43 charter boat businesses have shut down, with 11 more on the brink of collapse.
The legal challenge centers on alleged constitutional violations, including the 10th Amendment's prohibition on federal overreach, the 5th Amendment's protection against government takings without just compensation, and the 14th Amendment's due process clause. The plaintiffs also contend that the Commission, originally established as an advisory body, has unlawfully assumed regulatory powers without proper state and federal oversight.
The Commission defended its decision, emphasizing the need for conservation measures to prevent further declines in striped bass populations.
"The science may be imperfect, but the consequences of inaction could be severe," a Commission spokesperson said. "We understand the economic hardship this creates, but the long-term health of the fishery must come first."
Critics, however, argue that the Commission's data is inconsistent. Its own projections have fluctuated, estimating a 97% chance of population recovery in 2023, only to drop to 15% in 2024 before rebounding to 50% in 2025. Plaintiffs claim the estimated 240 million striped bass in U.S. waters far outweigh the annual fishing removals of approximately six million.
The Supreme Court previously declined to hear an emergency appeal in May, citing a lack of prior appellate review. The plaintiffs returned to the high court after exhausting their options in the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, which dismissed the case in February on the grounds that the plaintiffs sued the Commission rather than the state of Maryland.
With the 2025 fishing season set to begin in May, the petitioners had hoped the Supreme Court would issue an injunction restoring previous fishing limits while the legal battle continues. Without relief, they warn that more charter businesses will shut down, further damaging Maryland's historic fishing industry. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on legal battles over fishing regulations impacting small businesses, economic consequences for the seafood industry, and constitutional challenges affecting livelihoods. While environmental conservation is mentioned, the core issue revolves around economic impacts and business survival.

title: Trump's 200% wine, spirits, Champagne tariffs could wipe out imports, raise prices for domestics
author: Mike Sunnucks
content:
Trump's 200% wine, spirits, Champagne tariffs could wipe out imports, raise prices for domestics

 March 13, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks | Section: Business 
 
 1093
 Words 

 Read News Document

 U.S. President Donald Trump's threatened 200% tariffs on French Champagne along with wines and spirits from the European Union will squash imports, hurt smaller U.S. distributors, restaurants and bars, and likely drive up prices with domestic offerings facing less competition.That is according to Karl Strochmann, an economist at New York University, executive director of the American Association of Wine Economists and a leading analyst of the $107 billion U.S. wine market.
On Thursday, Trump threatened the 200% tariffs after the EU slapped 50% tariffs on American-made whiskeys and bourbons.
The latter came in response to Trump's 25% tariffs on steel and aluminum imports from Europe, Canada and other markets.
Strochmann said 200% Trump tariffs will dramatically reduce wine selections and likely make what's still available in the U.S. more expensive.
"It will almost certainly all but end wine imports from the affected countries (EU countries)," he said. "Since France and Italy are our largest wine import partners, the selection of wines will be affected as well."
In addition to reduced selections at bars and restaurants, the tariffs could adversely affect U.S. distributors who specialize in foreign wines and spirits, he said.
"Tariffs of 200% on wine imports from the EU will have a massive impact on U.S. wine importing and distributing companies, particularly small ones that specialize in artisanal wine from Europe," Strochmann said.
The wine-focused economist said previous 25% U.S. tariffs on European wines from 2019 to 2021 saw higher prices, including for domestic wines (especially reds) because of diminished competition.
"Prices might grow because the absence of French, Italian, and Spanish wine might lower competitive pressure," Strochmann said.
'HOSTILE'
Trump said Thursday he was sticking by his push for tariffs, saying they will help rebalance trade inequities and encourage domestic manufacturing and production. He also promised to punch back when other countries respond to U.S. tariffs.
'The European Union, one of the most hostile and abusive taxing and tariffing authorities in the world, which was formed for the sole purpose of taking advantage of the United States, has just put a nasty 50% tariff on whiskey. If this tariff is not removed immediately, the U.S. will shortly place a 200% Tariff on all WINES, CHAMPAGNES, & ALCOHOLIC PRODUCTS COMING OUT OF FRANCE AND OTHER E.U. REPRESENTED COUNTRIES. This will be great for the Wine and Champagne businesses in the U.S.," Trump said on his Truth Social platform, announcing the levies Thursday morning.
Champagne is only produced in France, but there is a growing sparkling wine market in the U.S. and other countries.
The Wine & Spirits Wholesalers of America said Thursday the Trump tariffs will hurt suppliers, wholesalers and retailers and raise prices for U.S. consumers.
"The cost of dining out with a bottle of wine or enjoying a cocktail made with an imported spirit will rise significantly. As a result, fewer consumers will frequent bars and restaurants, which will ultimately impact the hospitality sector, reducing job opportunities and wages," WSWA President and CEO Francis Creighton said in a statement.
Imported wines and spirits make up 30% of the U.S. marketplace by volume and 35% by revenue, according to the industry group. France and Italy account for as much as two-thirds of U.S. wine imports, according to other industry reports.
"A tariff on imported wine and spirits will directly impact American workers," Creighton said. "Rising costs will cause some consumers to stay at home, hurting the bartenders, servers and other bar and restaurant workers who depend on customer traffic for tips and shift hours."
Trump has touted eliminating taxes on tips as part of his economic agenda.
RETAILER, CONSUMER SHIFTSSmall business owners in the wine and spirits space are waiting to see if the Trump tariffs come to fruition.
Teresa Soule, who co-owns The Office Lounge and Liquor Store in Livingston, Montana, with her husband, Cory, isn't sure when consumers would feel the impact of Trump's threatened tariffs if they become reality.
She said that depends on when distributors run out of existing inventory and start bringing in potentially tariffed imports.
Soule said in Montana liquors are distributed by the state while wine and beer is distributed by private wholesalers.
"It might not affect us for a year," she said if current inventories are ample. Other products could see quicker price changes related to tariffs, Soule said.
She said heavy tariffs will reduce wholesale purchases from stores like hers.
"We might not order it," Soule said of potential higher prices.
The Soules have been in the wine and spirits business for almost two decades. She expects customers to shift to less expensive brands, including American products, if the prices of European brands skyrocket.
"I think that they are going to buy what they can afford," Soule said.
Across the country, Kevin Leahy owns Coastal Isles Wine Bar with his wife, Shauna, in Punta Gorda, Florida.
He sees Trump's tariffs drumbeat as a part of broader U.S. strategies.
"I think it is a negotiating tool to get other countries to the table," Leahy said.
Trump imposed 20% tariffs against China and imposed and then delayed 25% sweeping tariffs on Canada and Mexico, citing the need to curtail the flow of fentanyl and other illegal drugs into the U.S.
Trump argues other tariffs — including against Canada and the European Union — are needed to address trade imbalances and respond to levies against U.S. exports.
"I think that makes sense," Leahy said, of Trump's promises of reciprocal tariffs.
The Florida boutique wine bar offers unique selections with approximately 70% of them imported, said Leahy, acknowledging the potential impacts.
He said if a 200% tariff goes in place against products from Europe it would likely shift consumer demand.
"Who's going to buy wine for 200% more?," Leahy said.
WALL STREET WORRIESTrump's trade wars continue to worry Wall Street with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down more than 1,000 points the trading week ending March 14. The Dow is down more than 3,000 points the past 30 days, according to Google Finance.
The Dow was up more than 674 points Friday recouping some recent losses.
Investors and businesses worry about tariffs resulting in higher prices and a potential economic slowdown or recession.
The Nasdaq was up more than 450 points Friday but is down close to 2,700 points the past 30 days. The S&P 500 is down 7.8% the past month through March 14 even after Friday's 2.13% gain.
Trump was asked about small business worries about tariffs and trade wars Thursday.
"They are going to be so much richer than they are right now," said Trump, who went on to list planned U.S. investments by some of the largest corporations such as Meta/Facebook, Apple and General Motors.
Trump credited tariffs and proposed extensions of tax cuts passed during his first term for those corporate investments. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Trump's proposed tariffs on wine and spirits, analyzing their economic impact on imports, prices, businesses, and market competition. It includes expert opinions on trade policies, industry effects, and financial market reactions, aligning directly with Business/Economy topics. While it involves national policy, the core discussion is economic rather than general news.

title: Stock market not a catastrophe
author: Staff Writer
content:
Stock market not a catastrophe

 March 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 195
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The WSJ article written by Chip Cutter and Lauren Thomas sounds like something I would read on a Democratic National Committee newsletter. The authors quote the "horror" expressed by business executives at a recent meeting behind closed doors and behind President Trump's back. Their source was a business professor from Yale. Someone from a progressive indoctrination center was their source? While companies are putting their billions on the table this "school teacher" source gets onto the front page of the WSJ? I'm assuming the comments from a source from Yale are unbiased, ha ha. Maybe the authors should speak with sources from the companies putting up billions to invest in America.Yale and Professor Sonnenfeld most probably invested nothing. By the way, the stock market has been overvalued for some time so a 5%-10% drop is not the catastrophe being written about. Companies do not make long-term decisions based on what a president says over a two-month span. What long-term decisions were made over the last four years that made these business leaders so comfortable? How much did these business leaders invest with confidence in DEI and with the prospect of higher corporate taxes?
RICH ADRIAN
Easton

title: Gas prices jumped 9 cents in Maryland last week
author: Staff Writer
content:
Gas prices jumped 9 cents in Maryland last week

 March 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: State News 
 
 537
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Average gasoline prices in Maryland have risen 9.1 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $2.99 per gallon today, according to GasBuddy's survey of 2,167 stations in Maryland. Prices in Maryland are 9.9 cents per gallon lower than a month ago and stand 50.8 cents per gallon lower than a year ago. The national average price of diesel has decreased 5.0 cents in the last week and stands at $3.558 per gallon.According to GasBuddy price reports, the cheapest station in Maryland was priced at $2.67per gallon Sunday while the most expensive was $3.59 per gallon, a difference of 92.0 cents per gallon. The lowest price in the state yesterday was $2.67per gallon while the highest was $3.59per gallon, a difference of 92.0 cents per gallon.
The national average price of gasoline has fallen 1.3 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.02 per gallon Monday. The national average is down 10.6 cents per gallon from a month ago and stands 42.4 cents per gallon lower than a year ago, according to GasBuddy data compiled from more than 11 million weekly price reports covering over 150,000 gas stations across the country.
Historical gasoline prices in Maryland and the national average going back 10 years:
March 17, 2024: $3.50 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.44 per gallon)March 17, 2023: $3.29 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.43 per gallon)March 17, 2022: $4.18 per gallon (U.S. Average: $4.28 per gallon)March 17, 2021: $2.84 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.88 per gallon)March 17, 2020: $2.22 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.19 per gallon)March 17, 2019: $2.56 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.54 per gallon)March 17, 2018: $2.54 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.54 per gallon)March 17, 2017: $2.30 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.29 per gallon)March 17, 2016: $1.97 per gallon (U.S. Average: $1.96 per gallon)March 17, 2015: $2.43 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.41 per gallon)
Neighboring areas and their current gas prices:
Baltimore: $2.97 per gallon, up 13.8 cents per gallon from last week's $2.83 per gallon.Washington, D.C.: $3.14 per gallon, down 3.2 cents per gallon from last week's $3.17 per gallon.Hagerstown: $2.82 per gallon, down 9.5 cents per gallon from last week's $2.91 per gallon.
"As concerns over tariffs and policy uncertainties grow, gas prices have continued to decline across much of the country, raising the possibility that the national average could slip below $3 per gallon and approach some of the lowest prices seen in years," said Patrick De Haan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy. "However, this decline shouldn't necessarily be celebrated, as it comes with strong warning signs. When the economy slows, gasoline demand drops— along with demand for other refined products like diesel and jet fuel. We've already seen some signals that the months ahead could be challenging. All of this suggests that gas prices are likely to remain low for now. However, if economic conditions improve, gas prices could eventually follow suit and start rising again."
GasBuddy is the authoritative voice for gas prices and the only source for station-level data. GasBuddy's survey updates 288 times every day from the most diverse list of sources covering nearly 150,000 stations nationwide, the most comprehensive and up-to-date in the country. GasBuddy's averages, graphs, maps and historical pricing data covering the U.S. and Canada is available 24/7 at http://prices.GasBuddy.com. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

These elements directly relate to economic indicators and market dynamics, making 'Business/Economy' the most accurate classification. title: Small businesses bracing for Trump tariffs, potential trade wars and 'flexibility'
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media
content:
Small businesses bracing for Trump tariffs, potential trade wars and 'flexibility'

 March 20, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media | Section: Business 
 
 1098
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Candace Kiersky is waiting and trying to figure out the path forward.She's also trying not to worry.
Kiersky owns Skagit Valley Larder — a wine bar and cheese shop in downtown Mount Vernon, Washington.
The town, which is known for its tulips and annual tulip festival, is about 50 miles from the Canadian border.
Like other small businesses across the country, Kiersky is waiting to see what happens with U.S. President Donald Trump's tariffs and what they might do to her costs, pricing, inventories and supply chains.
Trump has threatened 200% tariffs against wines, champagnes and liquors from France, Italy and other European Union countries.
That came after the EU imposed a 50% tariff on American bourbons and whiskeys. That was in response to Trump's 25% tariffs on steel and aluminum imports. The EU announced Thursday it was pushing off the start of its tariffs on bourbon and whiskey and other U.S. goods until mid-April. They were slated to go into the place at the start of the month.
It is just one battle front in Trump's promised trade wars with more fights expected April 2 with the U.S. administration promising reciprocal tariffs for duties levied on American products.
Kiersky's business — which also includes a wine club and classes — would feel the brunt of Trump's threatened 200% tariffs on European wines and French Champagnes.
She said 70% of her stock is from Europe and 30% are domestic wines. Like others in the wine space, Kiersky said many of her customers prefer imported wines. "French wines are quite a bit more evolved," she said.
Kiersky is not sure what Trump tariffs will be put into place, and for how long and which ones the president might threaten but never impose or impose and then pull back.
"I'm actually waiting to see what actually comes to fruition," she said.
She's not alone with other businesses and suppliers throughout the wine and spirits space trying to figure out the impacts of Trump's trade wars.
Imported wines and spirits make up 38% of the U.S. marketplace, according to the Wine & Spirits Wholesalers of America.
The industry group opposes Trump's 200% tariffs. There are also worries the tariffs will eliminate European wines from the U.S. market, allowing domestic producers to raise prices because of less competition.
Like other wine shops, bars and restaurants and liquor stores, Kiersky is trying to figure out paths forward if the tariffs happen.
Her current inventories include wines from France, Italy, Spain and Austria.
She will be seeing what distributors have in stock before the tariffs start hitting prices and what she can order.
"Buyers like me are going to be looking to distributors and asking 'what do you have already here,'" Kiersky said.
Kiersky expects to see some distributors and retailers order French and other European wines to try to get them in the U.S. before the new duties are levied.
She's also looking at creating a new European wine club featuring imported bottles that get into the U.S. before the tariffs are potentially enacted.
"I might do something that could get boxes out to people with the European wine we might have on hand," Kiersky said. "Some hidden gems."
Canadians upset with Trump's tariffs and his jabs that their country should become the 51st U.S. state have also been vowing to curtail travel to the U.S. and rescue their purchases of American products. That could impact tourism, including areas just across the border.
Trump's promised tariffs and trade wars are prompting other businesses to look for innovative and creative hacks. Trump contends the tariffs will help spur domestic industries including winemakers.
But they are also rattling investors, consumers and business confidence.
The National Federation of Independent Business (NFIB) Small Optimism Index fell in February, and small business uncertainty levels are their highest since 1974, according to the national group.
And that was before Trump's latest trade and tariffs volleys toward Canada and the European Union earlier this month. He's already imposed 20% blanket tariffs on Chinese goods.
"Uncertainty is high and rising on Main Street, and for many reasons," said NFIB Chief Economist Bill Dunkelberg in a statement March 11, citing small business concerns about inflation and labor conditions.
Consumer confidence has also slipped significantly, according to the University of Michigan's Survey of Consumers.
UM Economist Joanne Hsu said consumer sentiment is worsening across income, political affiliations and geographic regions.
"Many consumers cited the high level of uncertainty around policy and other economic factors; frequent gyrations in economic policies make it very difficult for consumers to plan for the future, regardless of one's policy preferences," Hsu said in a statement on the preliminary March sentiment figures.
Stocks are down the past 30 days, as Wall Street and investors also worry about Trump's trade path and a potential economic slowdown.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average is down more than 1,440 points and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq are off 5.75% and 8.9%, respectively, the past 30 days as of the end of trading Friday, according to Google Finance.
Trump vowed to stick with his tariffs, touting their use by former President William McKinley. He argued the tariffs will help address trade imbalances and inequities.
"April 2nd is Liberation Day in America!!! For DECADES we have been ripped off and abused by every nation in the World, both friend and foe. Now it is finally time for the Good Ol' USA to get some of that MONEY, and RESPECT, BACK. GOD BLESS AMERICA!!!," Trump said in a social media post Friday morning.
But then during comments from the Oval Office, Trump also said there could be some "flexibility" with his promised reciprocal tariffs.
"..The word flexibility is an important word," Trump said. "Sometimes it's flexibility. So there'll be flexibility, but basically it's reciprocal."
He's also pushed back on worries that tariffs will raise prices, disrupt supply chains (including for automakers, publishers and home builders) and hurt U.S. exports.
Trump and other White House officials contend tariffs skeptics are globalists opposed to their populist agenda.
"The United States of America is going to take back a lot of what was stolen from it by other countries and, frankly, by incompetent U.S. leadership. We're going to take back our wealth and (we'll) take back a lot of the companies that left," said Trump in another post.
But Kiersky said the 200% tariffs on wine and French Champagne imports from the EU will hit a host of businesses and jobs — ranging from European vineyards and American distributors to wine shops, bars and restaurants. The U.S. is the largest wine market in the world totaling $107 billion, according to a 2024 report from BMO.
"Imported wines create more jobs on this side of the ocean than it does in Europe," she said. "It affects so many people." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the impact of Trump's tariffs and trade policies on small businesses, supply chains, and economic stability, directly relating to Business/Economy. While National News could marginally apply due to political context, the core discussion centers on economic implications for businesses.

title: Townhouse listing in D.C. draws widespread attention
author: TJ MACIAS The Bradenton Herald
content:
Townhouse listing in D.C. draws widespread attention

 March 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TJ MACIAS The Bradenton Herald | Section: Real Estate 
 
 306
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Even though a particular townhouse in Washington, D.C., has yet to grace the real estate market, the residence is making waves thanks to its extremely creative listing."Welcome to Watkins Alley, where modern design meets the perfect location in the heart of Capitol Hill! This stunning four-level townhome offers 3 bedrooms, 3.5 bathrooms, and a PERSONAL ELEVATOR — because luxury should always be effortless," the listing on Zillow describes.
Sure, the features of the home are spectacular all on their own, but thanks to some cool thinking and craftsmanship, attention has been drawn to the $1.2 million listing. The likeness of the rooms throughout the home, along with its exterior, has been captured in miniature with Legos.
The photos feature the kitchen area, a bedroom, bathroom and more, all of which have Lego versions of them.
Mini building models aside, other features throughout the 2,448-square-foot house include:
Open-concept layout.Chef's kitchen.Four levels.Huge primary suite.Two private balconies.Wet bar.Wine fridge.
The home caught the attention of Zillow Gone Wild, a famous Facebook page that highlights unique houses on the market all across the country, and people adored the creativity and hard work that went into the listing.
Layout of the home Photos courtesy of Andrew Huddleston
"I spent more time looking at these photos to see how the Lego model looks vs the actual photo and going back and forth," one person said. "Whoever came up with this, did a great job at catching my attention more than usual."
"We're a Lego family & this is so cute! I wish I had that gene that made me able to do this. Might just need to put my son on it instead," another chimed in.
"I can barely spell Lego, I'm so impressed. Well done!" someone noted.
"That is so well done!!" one person expressed.
"Do we get both houses?" another asked.
The listing is held by The Denny & Leyla Team. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Talbot Chamber of Commerce awards dinner honored business officials in Talbot County
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Talbot Chamber of Commerce awards dinner honored business officials in Talbot County

 March 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 489
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ROYAL OAK — The Talbot County Chamber of Commerce honored Thomas Mitchell as Businessman of the Year and Beth Anne Dorman as Businesswoman of the Year at the 2025 Best in Business awards dinner at the Oaks Waterfront Hotel on Wednesday evening.Business Man of the Year Mitchell of Momma Maria's Mediterranean Bistro talked about Trappe and his late wife during his comments after accepting the award.
"My hat says let's make Trappe great again," Mitchell said. "My wife lost her battle to Alzheimer's, we wanted to do something to honor my wife so we opened up Momma Maria's. We ended up basically buying the whole town. It turned out to be a great story, and the restaurants are doing well."
Business Woman of the Year Dorman, president and chief executive officer of For All Seasons hopes to continue to provide service in the Mid-Shore for years to come.
"It's an honor because there is a great privilege in being able to serve Talbot County and being able to bring really essential services that folks don't need to think about but are available," Dorman said. "My hope is that folks continue to pay attention to the services that are needed to make us the healthiest community possible."
One hundred and eighty people attended the dinner to see multiple businesses and business officials honored for their business efforts in 2024.
"Tonight is about celebrating the dedication and hard work of our local businesses," said Amy Kreiner, president and CEO of Talbot Chamber of Commerce. "Those who drive our economy and enrich our community in countless ways."
Kreiner highlighted some of the Talbot County Chamber of Commerce accomplishment to end 2024.
"We welcome 74 new members last year, bringing our total now to 641 at the end of 2024," Kreiner said. "Last year, we hosted 16 ribbon cuttings, 13 mixers and replaced a golf tournament with a clay shoot, which turned out to be a successful thing."
Here is a list of business and award winners honored and Talbot County Chamber of Commerce award dinner:
Young Professional of the Year: Leah Copper Easton Utilities.Nonprofit of the Year: Chesapeake Center Inc.Chamber Champion: Gordon Fronk, Joseph W. McCartin Insurance.Small Business of the Year: Salon Inspire.Large Business of the Year: Total Home Performance.Businesswoman of the Year: Beth-Anne Dorman, For All Seasons.Businessman of the Year: Thomas Mitchell, Momma Maria's Mediterranean Bistro.
MILESTONE AWARDS
20 Years in Business: Paquin Design Build Inc.25 Years in Business: BDK Inc., Steward Writing and Communications, Rentals to Remember.30 Years in Business: Prince Limousine, Campbell's Boatyards and Yacht Sales.35 Years in Business: CASA of the Mid-Shore, Kleppinger Electric Co.40 Years in Business: RAUCH Inc., Junior Achievement of the Eastern Shore.55 Years in Business: Critchlow Adkins Children's Centers.60 Years in Business: Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum, Cutts and Case Shipyard, The Crab Claw.90 Years in Business: Konsyl Pharmaceuticals.100 Years In Business: Avery Hall, Talbot County Free Library.110 Years in Business: Easton Utilities.115 Years in Business: The Peoples Bank.225 Years in Business: The Star Democrat.

title: Gas prices rose slightly in Maryland last week
author: GASBUDDY
content:
Gas prices rose slightly in Maryland last week

 March 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: GASBUDDY | Section: State News 
 
 493
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Average gasoline prices in Maryland have risen 1.5 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.00 per gallon Monday, according to GasBuddy's survey of 2,167 stations in Maryland. Prices in Maryland are 0.4 cents per gallon lower than a month ago and stand 55.5 cents per gallon lower than a year ago. The national average price of diesel has decreased 0.9 cents in the last week and stands at $3.549 per gallon.According to GasBuddy price reports, the cheapest station in Maryland was priced at $2.75 per gallon Sunday while the most expensive was $3.65 per gallon, a difference of 90.0 cents per gallon.
The national average price of gasoline has risen 6.3 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.08 per gallon today. The national average is down 1.6 cents per gallon from a month ago and stands 42.5 cents per gallon lower than a year ago, according to GasBuddy data compiled from more than 11 million weekly price reports covering over 150,000 gas stations across the country.
"For the first time in over a month, the national average price of gasoline has risen, driven by the final step in the transition to summer gasoline across wide portions of the country," said Patrick De Haan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy.
Historical gasoline prices in Maryland and the national average going back 10 years:
March 24, 2024: $3.56 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.51 per gallon)March 24, 2023: $3.27 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.41 per gallon)March 24, 2022: $3.80 per gallon (U.S. Average: $4.24 per gallon)March 24, 2021: $2.83 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.86 per gallon)March 24, 2020: $2.12 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.05 per gallon)March 24, 2019: $2.64 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.62 per gallon)March 24, 2018: $2.63 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.60 per gallon)March 24, 2017: $2.29 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.29 per gallon)March 24, 2016: $2.02 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.01 per gallon)March 24, 2015: $2.39 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.42 per gallon)
Neighboring areas and their current gas prices:
Baltimore: $2.99 per gallon, up 1.7 cents per gallon from last week's $2.97 per gallon.Washington, D.C.: $3.12 per gallon, down 1.9 cents per gallon from last week's $3.14 per gallon.Hagerstown: $2.89 per gallon, up 7.0 cents per gallon from last week's $2.82 per gallon.
De Haan said the increase this past week has nothing to do with politics or tariffs.
"(The increase) is instead the result of seasonality, and is something that happens almost every year," he said. "Concerns over refinery maintenance have been muted so far this year, largely due to broader concerns about the U.S. economy, and demand remains soft. However, for those in the northeastern U.S. who have enjoyed relatively low gas prices compared to the national average, the final step in the transition to summer gasoline is still a few weeks away. Once it occurs, they too will likely see prices rise. For areas that have already completed the switch, ongoing economic uncertainty will likely prevent further major increases — for now." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on rising gasoline prices in Maryland, analyzing economic trends, market data, and factors affecting fuel costs. This directly relates to Business/Economy as it involves price fluctuations, consumer impact, and market analysis. While National News could be a secondary fit due to broader economic implications, the primary context is economic data.

title: Sophisticated yet approachable is concept behind new Betterton beachside restaurant
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Sophisticated yet approachable is concept behind new Betterton beachside restaurant

 March 27, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 589
 Words 

 Read News Document

 BETTERTON — Situated where the Bay meets the Sassafras River, the restaurant of the same name will be opening late spring.Over the years the property at 12 Ericsson Avenue had its share of owners with unique visions, from an Irish-themed bar, to a beachside restaurant with quick-service menu items and karaoke night, but this one could be the boldest yet.
Beginning in June, Chef Paul Edward and his wife, Caroline Benkert, will offer dinner nightly, a prix fixe menu to "20 souls" Wednesday through Saturday at 6:30 p.m. at Sassafras.
Edward explained, "Whatever is caught that day we're going to prepare. This early spring, we are looking forward to Chesapeake blue crab, spawning rockfish, foraged morels, forest herbs and greens and rhubarb and asparagus."
He mentioned he has local watermen, hunters and farmers helping him prepare this food and complete his vision for the establishment.
"Our focus will be wild caught seafood from the Bay, water fowl during hunting season, foraged fruits and vegetables and hyper-seasonal produce from local farmers," Edward said.
He has ambitious plans for his cuisine. Having just put down the gravel in the parking lot, already downstairs there is fresh fish hanging, a humongous yellow-fin tuna and jumbo fluke dangling from rope, cooling.
A quick glance around the chef's work area, tells you everything will be freshly made and prepared using homemade spices and herbs. He even makes his own kombucha, a fermented drink containing probiotics that may support gut health and improve digestion. Even the flour and corn flour is not store-bought.
Edward reflects on a time in the distant past, how people prepared food before modern conveniences and heavy processing methods.
"I think back to the time when fish was roasted over fire and corn was made into batter and baked over coals and the smoke of oak perpetually perfumed," he said.
He and Benkert will deliver these types of meals in elegant fashion to no more than 20 diners in a supper club setting, an old idea, revitalized after COVID-19 lockdowns when people looked to connect again through food and cozy atmosphere.
Diners step into a rustic yet tasteful setting that feels familiar with old, well-kept homes on the Eastern Shore. The floors are wood from this area, but burned in a Japanese style. There is a fireplace now, then the long chef's table, (where the bar used to be) with fine, vintage china purchased from a Crumpton auction which creates the familiar feel of a waterfront home.
Edward describes it as "modern Chesapeake cookery."
With 20 years experience owning the BlueBird-Baltimore, winner of the "Best of Baltimore" Readers' Poll for cocktails in 2018, 2020, 2021 and 2022, they are excited for this next project, a restaurant based on their understanding of food, nutrition and optimal health. Edward said he has ideas similar to Modern Stone Age Kitchen, to which owner Bill Schindler, is a friend and will be one of his first dining guests.
The property overlooks the beach, and as people are drawn to the Bay when the weather gets nicer, Edward and Benkert are hoping to build a consistent clientele.
"Our guests will experience the Chesapeake Bay, this ancient and beautiful body of water, through an intimate feast unlike any they've had before."
April dates are now available, with May reservations open soon for a first peek at the intimate Chef's Counter. Six seats will be open for a prix fixe, multi-course seafood forward menu. At an additional charge, are abbreviated alcoholic and non-alcoholic beverage pairings or a quaint menu of potations by the glass.
To learn more or make a reservation visit https://www.restaurantsassafras.com/. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the opening of a new restaurant, detailing its business model, local partnerships, and culinary philosophy. While it touches on local community aspects and dining experiences, the primary emphasis is on the establishment as a business venture.

title: Queenstown Bank unveils Cambridge branch plans at event
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Queenstown Bank unveils Cambridge branch plans at event

 March 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 242
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Queenstown Bank unveiled its plans to build a permanent location in Cambridge during its annual Farmers Appreciation Lunch Thursday."I have always had a desire to bring the Queenstown Bank culture of banking down to Dorchester," said Queenstown Bank Chief Risk Officer and Chief Administrative Officer Tracy Whitby-Fairall after unveiling a rendering during the event to show what the branch will look like.
Whitby-Fairall said the branch will be located at the old Dairy Queen on U.S. Route 50. She said the company is still in the planning stages of the project.
"We have received concept approval from the city," she said. "We are in final stages of final approval for the building."
Currently, the bank has a temporary Cambridge branch location on the corner of Dorchester and Maryland avenues. Whitby-Fairall said Queenstown Bank knew it would be at that location temporarily.
"Now to show our commitment to the county, we have purchased the lot to build a permanent location here in Cambridge," she said. "(We're) super excited to bring the Queenstown banking style back to a local hometown area as we do throughout the Shore from Queen Anne's, Caroline, Talbot and now Dorchester."
During the event, Queenstown Bank President and CEO Kevin Cashen said the bank has made a "big commitment" to Dorchester County residents with this project. He said the bank expects to break ground on the permanent Cambridge branch in late summer or early fall.
"We look forward to being here," he said.
