title: Expert: Gas prices may have hit peak for year
author: GAS BUDDY
content:
Expert: Gas prices may have hit peak for year

 April 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: GAS BUDDY | Section: State News 
 
 486
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Average gasoline prices in Maryland have fallen 6.4 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.19 per gallon Monday, according to GasBuddy's survey of 2,167 stations in Maryland. Prices in Maryland are 21.5 cents per gallon higher than a month ago and stand 48.7 cents per gallon lower than a year ago. The national average price of diesel has decreased 4.8 cents in the last week and stands at $3.546 per gallon.According to GasBuddy price reports, the cheapest station in Maryland was priced at $2.81 per gallon Sunday while the most expensive was $3.79 per gallon, a difference of 98.0 cents per gallon.
The national average price of gasoline has fallen 8.2 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.13 per gallon Monday. The national average is up 7.8 cents per gallon from a month ago and stands 46.9 cents per gallon lower than a year ago, according to GasBuddy data compiled from more than 11 million weekly price reports covering over 150,000 gas stations across the country.
"For now, the good news is that gas prices typically reach their yearly peak around April 10, so we may have already witnessed 'peak pain' at the pump for 2025," said Patrick De Haan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy. "As refiners near the end of seasonal maintenance and supply begins to rise — and with the changeover to summer gasoline nearly complete — it's increasingly likely that gas prices have already hit their high for the year."
Historical gasoline prices in Maryland and the national average going back ten years:
April 14, 2024: $3.68 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.60 per gallon)April 14, 2023: $3.59 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.65 per gallon)April 14, 2022: $3.67 per gallon (U.S. Average: $4.06 per gallon)April 14, 2021: $2.76 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.86 per gallon)April 14, 2020: $1.95 per gallon (U.S. Average: $1.82 per gallon)April 14, 2019: $2.73 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.83 per gallon)April 14, 2018: $2.69 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.71 per gallon)April 14, 2017: $2.41 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.41 per gallon)April 14, 2016: $2.09 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.10 per gallon)April 14, 2015: $2.38 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.38 per gallon)
Neighboring areas and their current gas prices:
Baltimore: $3.17 per gallon, down 8.0 cents per gallon from last week's $3.25 per gallon.Washington, D.C.: $3.16 per gallon, down 4.8 cents per gallon from last week's $3.20 per gallon.Hagerstown: $3.22 per gallon, down 2.8 cents per gallon from last week's $3.24 per gallon.
"After oil's sharp drop over the last couple of weeks — driven by concerns over the impact of U.S. tariffs and OPEC+ restoring production faster than expected — gasoline prices have posted a notable weekly decline, with nearly every state seeing prices fall," said Patrick De Haan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy. "While I do expect gas prices to continue trending lower, any abrupt change in the current tariff situation could eventually bring the decline to a halt." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on gasoline price trends, market analysis, and economic factors affecting fuel costs. It discusses supply-demand dynamics, seasonal maintenance, OPEC+ production, and tariff impacts - all core economic indicators. While related to energy (environment), the primary context is economic forecasting and market behavior.

title: New business tax not fully thought through
author: DAVID REEL
content:
New business tax not fully thought through

 April 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 772
 Words 

 Read News Document

 On the last day of the 2025 Maryland General Assembly session, a majority of General Assembly members and Gov. Moore finally agreed on a $68 billion state budget package.The agreement includes approximately $2 billion in budget cuts, and a wide range of new taxes, tax increases, new fees and fee increases.
Taken together, the tax and fee changes are projected to generate approximately $1.8 billion in new state revenue.
One new tax that is the largest single source of projected new state revenue is a 3% business-to-business sales tax for services provided by information technology providers.
Current projections are this new tax will generate approximately $482 million in new revenue.
The key words here are current and projections.
Achieving a balanced state budget for an entire fiscal year may be wishful thinking.
There is no guarantee if and when all the revenue from the new IT services sales tax will come in as projected.
Del. Ben Barnes, chair of the House Appropriations Committee, was asked if he was confident about the projected revenue from this new sales tax.
He did not answer the question directly. Instead, he said, "We are super confident that the final budget compromise turns a massive structural deficit into a positive structural balance."
It remains to be seen if that super confidence will hold until the end of the upcoming fiscal year.
Complicating matters is that between now and July 1 of this year, the Maryland comptroller's office will have to issue regulations to implement the new IT service sales tax.
Senate Budget and Taxation Committee Chair Guy Guzzone has already acknowledged, "It's very complicated [the new IT service sales tax] and the comptroller will be figuring out how exactly that implementation occurs."
Maryland Senate President Bill Ferguson has said that he expects there will be a bit of a delay in the implementation of the regulations.
The budget bill compromise includes a trigger for a special session to address the impact of any future Trump administration decisions that further reduce the historic and substantial flow of federal dollars into Maryland.
Largely missing during all the debate and deliberations on Annapolis leading up to the approval of this new IT service sales tax was greater consideration of what-if questions.
What if greater consideration would have been given to estimates from the Cybersecurity Association of Maryland, that this new tax could result in IT service companies leaving Maryland?
What if this scenario is already being confirmed?
Maryland State Del. Brian Crosby is the owner of an IT services firm formerly based in Maryland. During a recent speech on the House floor, he told his House colleagues in anticipation of this new IT service sales tax being approved, he had already decided to move his IT service business from Maryland to Virginia.
When asked later about how the new sales tax could impact his business, Crosby said, "All I can say is that within a year, we'd be bankrupt."
Jacob Stokes, president of a 50-employee IT and software development company based in Columbia echoed that sentiment. He has said, "We're going to have to leave the state. That's our only option."
What if greater consideration had been given to concerns raised by the Maryland Chamber of Commerce? The Chamber has suggested, "Once Maryland starts taxing services, whether it's tech, legal, marketing or accounting, it becomes easier to expand these taxes to other sectors down the line."
They further suggest, "Today, it's tech services. Tomorrow it could be any other service upon which Maryland businesses and consumers depend."
What if greater consideration had been given to reports on all the businesses that have already have or are considering transferring their incorporation from Delaware due to what they perceive to be a hostile business climate there?
The current list includes Facebook, Walmart, AMC, Madison Square Entertainment, Pershing Square Capital Management, Simon Property Group, Dropbox, Meta, Trip Advisor and Roblox.
What if final action on any tax legislation would be contingent upon the Maryland comptroller providing legislators a report with details on the regulations and compliance standards for any new taxes, tax increases, new fees and fee increases?
That would help avoid the consequences of accepting the thinking of former U. S. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi: "We have to pass the bill so you can find out what's in it."
What if this new IT service sales tax, coupled with legislative leaders rejecting Gov. Moore's proposal to reduce the corporate net income tax, derails Moore's goal to reverse Maryland's sluggish economic growth by reducing tax and regulatory burdens on businesses?
Going forward, Maryland is best served when every policy decision maker in Annapolis has a commitment and an opportunity to consider what-if questions which in turn helps ensure no final decisions are made using a deeply flawed "ready-aim-fire" approach. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Maryland's new business tax, revenue projections, and its potential economic impact on IT companies. While local government actions are mentioned, the core issue revolves around tax policy and its effects on business operations, making Business/Economy the primary topic.

title: 'Devastating': Small businesses sue Trump over tariffs
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media
content:
'Devastating': Small businesses sue Trump over tariffs

 April 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media | Section: News 
 
 1058
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A group of small businesses — including a wine and sake importer, industrial manufacturer and fishing gear and tackle e-commerce firm — are suing President Donald Trump over his tariffs, challenging his use of an emergency law to impose taxes on imports.Texas-based Liberty Justice Center filed a federal lawsuit in the U.S. Court of International Trade on Monday on behalf of five small businesses impacted by Trump's "Liberation Day" and other tariffs.
The lawsuit challenges Trump's authority to invoke tariffs under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA).
Trump is the first U.S. president to invoke tariffs under the 1977 emergency powers law.
The lawsuit argues Trump lacks the authority to issue his across-the-board, worldwide tariffs without approval by Congress.
Trump has cited flows of fentanyl (an illegal synthetic opioid) into the U.S. for imposing 20% tariffs against China and threatening Canada and Mexico with 25% levies.
Trump cited trade deficits for his "Liberation Day" country-by-country tariffs. The tariffs were originally as high as 49% but have been reduced to 10% during a 90-day pause instituted by Trump after worries about financial markets.
'NO ONE PERSON'
The Liberty Justice Center argues longstanding trade deficits don't constitute an emergency and some of the countries in Trump's tariffs don't even have trade surpluses with the U.S.
"IEEPA does not authorize the President to impose across-the-board tariffs—it does not even authorize tariffs at all; and even if the IEEPA did extend such power to the President, that would be an unconstitutional delegation of Congress's power to impose tariffs," the Texas group said in a statement.
"No one person should have the power to impose taxes that have such vast global economic consequences," said Jeffrey Schwab, senior counsel at the Liberty Justice Center. "The Constitution gives the power to set tax rates—including tariffs—to Congress, not the President."
Trump is imposing a 145% tariff on China (with current exemptions for smartphones, computers and other electronics and technology components). There are also 25% U.S. tariffs on imported cars, auto parts, aluminum and steel imposed under separate trade protocols.
"If starting the biggest trade war since the Great Depression based on a law that doesn't even mention tariffs is not an unconstitutional usurpation of legislative power, I don't know what is," said Ilya Somin, co-counsel a law professor, at George Mason University.
China has imposed 125% tariffs on U.S. goods in response to the Trump import taxes.
The White House pushed back against the lawsuit.
"Never Trumpers will always oppose him, but President Trump is standing up for Main Street by putting an end to our trading partners—especially China—exploiting the U.S. His plan levels the playing field for businesses and workers to address our country's national emergency of chronic trade deficits," said White House spokesman Harrison Fields.
'TARIFF CHAOS'
The small business owners who are part of the suit say the tariffs are raising costs and hurting their operations.
"This is devastating to our ability to operate and support the farmers and producers we work with around the world," Victor Owen Schwartz, owner of VOS Selections, which imports wines, spirits and sakes.
Trump previously threatened 200% tariffs on European wine and liquor imports but has not followed through on that.
Conventionally, U.S. administrations have gone through more lengthy trade regimens, that require additional approvals, to institute tariffs.
Dan Pastore, president and co-founder of FishUSA Inc., a Pennsylvania-based e-commerce firm specializing in fishing tackle and gear, said his company sources its products from markets such as South Korea, Kenya, China and Canada and has had to hold up production flows because of the tariffs and their uncertainty.
"Instead of focusing on growing our business, creating more jobs in our region, and developing new products that our customers want, we are spending countless hours trying to navigate the tariff chaos that the President is causing for us and all our vendors," said Dan Pastore, President and co-founder of FishUSA. "It takes years working with factories to design and build our products, and we cannot just shift that business to the U.S. without starting the whole process over again."
Other plaintiffs include Utah-based Genova Pipe which makes piping and relies on Asian resin imports.
"With limited domestic sources, we rely on imports to meet our production needs. The newly imposed tariffs are increasing our raw material costs and hindering our ability to compete in the export market," said Andrew Reese, president of Genova Pipe, which also has manufacturing plants in Washington, Michigan and other U.S. states.
Earlier this month, the New Civil Liberties Alliance also sued the Trump administration over the tariffs on behalf of a Florida business owner also challenging the use of presidential emergency powers.
'MAIN STREET, NOT WALL STREET'
Trump and his economic advisors argue the tariffs will settle longstanding trade inequities and bring manufacturing to the U.S.
The White House said in a tariffs announcement that current trade inequities have "undermined critical supply chains; and rendered our defense-industrial base dependent on foreign adversaries."
The tariffs fight is also pitting Trump's push for continued American hegemony over the international economy versus a more globalist system with multinational supply chains and the ever-increasing economic importance of China.
"I'm proud to be the President for the workers, not the outsourcers; the President who stands up for main street, not Wall Street; who protects the middle class, not the political class; and who defends America, not trade cheaters all over the globe," Trump said earlier this month defending his tariffs regime.
The United Auto Workers union backs Trump's auto manufacturing tariffs hoping they will boost domestic productions.
The pro-Trump America First Policy Institute also backs the tariffs.
"President Trump made a clear and strong statement on 'Liberation Day': countries will no longer take advantage of the American market with unfair trade practices that have hollowed out our manufacturing base, depressed wages, and threatened our national security," said Robert Lighthizer, chair of AFP's Center for American Trade.
'DIFFICULT TO CHALLENGE'
The U.S. Constitution gives Congress the power over tariffs and taxes. But the legislative branch has increasingly deferred to the executive branch over trade policies.
There are efforts by Trump critics in Congress to take tariffs back. Trump has promised to veto a bill if it passes.
Some legal analysts agree with the challenges. Others see the court deferring to executive power related to the emergency powers law.
"It would appear that the power the president utilized to impose tariffs under IEEPA is very nearly absolute and difficult to challenge," said Achyuth Anil, an international trade policy researcher with the University of Sussex in Britain. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on small businesses challenging Trump's tariffs and the economic implications of presidential emergency powers. The core issue revolves around trade policies, tariffs, and their impact on businesses, which directly aligns with 'Business/Economy.' While 'National News' is relevant due to the federal government's role, the primary context is economic policy.

title: Denton becomes first American Discovery Trail Town, hopes to draw tourists
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Denton becomes first American Discovery Trail Town, hopes to draw tourists

 April 25, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 627
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The American Discovery Trail has made a landmark of Denton.The town has been designated as the first town in the American Discovery Trail, a coast-to-coast path across the USA connecting people with rural and urban areas, wilderness, desert, mountains and forests.
"I think the American Discovery Trail is unique. It's amazing," Peter Schoettle, American Discovery Trail secretary, said. "The United States, we're blessed with a number of phenomenal outdoor trails. The American Discovery Trail is unique in that it's from coast to coast ,from the Atlantic to the Pacific. No other trail does that."
In the beginning of April, Denton held a ceremony to announce the trail town designation at the town's welcome center.
The American Trail Society came up with the idea for the program to allow towns to become American Trail Discovery towns.
"We started this program of saying, 'let's give more recognition to some neat little towns along the way,'" Schoettle said. "This would benefit the towns, and it would benefit the trail, and so we announced this program of becoming a trail town."
While the process of being claimed as a trail town was not easy, Denton worked hard to get it done.
The first step Denton completed was forming a committee dedicated to the trail.
"Originally, we produced a proclamation a couple years ago, and I think as a staff and as a council, I think we thought that's all we had to do," said Scott Getchell, town administrator. "But they came back a couple years ago and said they that we needed to adopt a resolution stating that we are a trail town."
After adopting a resolution, the town also needed to complete a memorandum of understanding and an application to be approved as an official trail town.
"When they complete those steps, we give them the award, or the title of American Discovery Trail Town," Schoettle said. "And Denton is the very first in the whole country, and so that's amazing. I mean that's unique. Being first, it's like winning a gold medal in the Olympics."
One of the main reasons the program was started is to highlight smaller towns and bring tourism to those areas.
"I think it's fabulous," Schoettle said. It's a win-win situation. I really hope it helps put Denton on the map. They're a great town, and when hikers plan on doing the Discovery Trail, they will say, 'Well, wait a minute, I should plan to stay overnight in Denton.'
"They will use their restaurants, use their hotels or motels, and give them a little economic boost and more publicity. So, I hope they get a lot more visitors."
Denton believes the exposure from the American Discovery Trail will help local businesses.
"Long term, I think it's great," Getchell said. "It's going to take a little while to take off I'm sure, but I think long term, were going to be known around the country as being a trail town. People that do a lot of hiking and things like that, they're going to be mapping our town as a place, as a resource on their journey... We spoke to different businesses and they're put up stickers on the doors so somebody walking through here knows that that's a trail town business."
While the American Trail Society created the program for towns, Schoettle believes Denton deserves all the credit for its initiative to get everything in the application process done.
"I think the town deserves a lot of credit," Schoettle said. "You always need volunteers to do these things. Scott Getchell, the town administrator was a key player. Abby McNinch, the mayor, and the town council, they passed that resolution more than a year ago. That was a big step forward that showed this town really wants to get known and supports the trail, they deserve all the credit." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Denton's designation as an American Discovery Trail Town, emphasizing tourism-driven economic benefits for local businesses, infrastructure efforts, and the town's strategic initiative to boost regional commerce. While local government involvement is mentioned, the core theme revolves around economic development and tourism impact.

title: False bravado on tariffs threatens Talbot County
author: JIM BRUCE
content:
False bravado on tariffs threatens Talbot County

 April 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: JIM BRUCE | Section: Columns 
 
 422
 Words 

 Read News Document

 President Trump's abrupt announcement of tariffs of 145% on Chinese imports provoked them to impose retaliatory tariffs of 125% on U.S. goods exported to China.This jeopardizes our $300 million in exports to China from Maryland's 1st Congressional District, including from all of Talbot County and the rest of the Eastern Shore.
China is hardly blameless on tariffs, but the tragedy for our farmers and businessmen is that our president and our congressman brought on themselves this latest threat to the future exports of Talbot County and the Eastern Shore. Worse, Trump's foolish bravado on tariffs is turning to desperation.
Recall that just after President Trump levied a massive 104% import tariff on Chinese goods, he bragged on April 9, at a mega-fundraiser, "These countries are calling us up, kissing my ass to negotiate deals on tariffs. They are dying to make a deal… [saying], Please, Sir, make a deal. I'll do anything, Sir."
Trump thus portrayed initiating a call to the U.S. to negotiate tariffs as a demeaning, obscene act by our trading partner. This mocking and senseless incivility to all our trading partners, including China, explains why China's commerce ministry said on the next day that China is open to dialogue with the U.S. on tariffs, but it must be based on "mutual respect." Doubling down on the insult, Trump then insisted that the Chinese president must call first for negotiations to begin.
You need not be an expert in tariffs to know that the importance of respect — saving face — is deeply embedded in Chinese culture. Any real U.S. negotiator on any subject would know this. It further confirms that Trump hatched his chaotic and amateurish tariff plan on the fly without careful planning.
China has called, not to urge the U.S. to negotiate the tariffs, but for the U.S to capitulate and "completely cancel" Trump's reciprocal tariffs. While Trump says that President Xi has called him and trade negotiations with the Chinese are underway, China denies it, calling it "fake news."
Trump is learning just how dependent our economy is on trade with China for, to name a few, sales of Boeing jets and rare earth metals for our high-tech industries.
What's at stake for Talbot County is no small matter. In 2022, our farmers and businesses in Maryland's 1st Congressional District exported over $300 million in goods and services to China. China's retaliatory tariffs of 125% now imperil our exports. Yet our Congressman Andy Harris simply endorses Trump's turbulent tariffs, despite the threat to agriculture, e.g., soybeans, and other businesses in his district. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the economic impact of presidential tariff policies, trade negotiations, and their effects on local exports. While it mentions Talbot County, the core issue revolves around trade economics, business implications, and national-level policy decisions.

title: Groundbreaking ceremony held for Tides at River Marsh housing project in Cambridge
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Groundbreaking ceremony held for Tides at River Marsh housing project in Cambridge

 April 30, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 547
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Local and state leaders mingled on the lawn in front of the Hyatt Regency Chesapeake Bay Golf Resort, Spa and Marina Tuesday for a long-awaited groundbreaking ceremony.A gentle breeze blew over those gathered, a contrast to the headwinds the project has faced in recent years.
"This has been a long haul, but we've done it," Fairchild Properties President Charlie Fairchild said about Tides at River Marsh.
Fairchild Properties is the developer behind Tides at River Marsh, a residential community located on the Hyatt property that is expected to bring 619 new townhomes, villas and single-family homes to Cambridge.
Mentioning rising interest rates, Fairchild said it took three "long" years to get a shovel in the ground for this project. Hyatt General Manager Shane Nicolopoulos said the addition of these homes to the Hyatt property has been in the works for decades.
"And how awesome is this?" he asked. "We are so excited, and I'm sure you felt it driving into the resort and seeing the progress that has taken place so quickly."
Although the groundbreaking ceremony was held April 29, the developers and builders started work on the project Dec. 30, Fairchild said. Currently, 75 homes are under construction with a plan to build 150 homes in the first phase and another 150 homes in the second phase.
In an interview, Fairchild said he expects in the next four months, about 80% to 90% of the first phase of homes should be built. He said they plan to begin the second phase in about two months.
Once complete, the first two phases of the project are expected to bring in roughly $2.5 million in property taxes for the city, county and state. Fairchild said the city is projected to bring in $1 million on the 300 homes, the county is projected to bring in $1.2 million and the state is expected to bring in $300,000.
This increase to the tax base is particularly significant for Dorchester County as it faces a difficult budget process.
"One of the biggest problems we have with Dorchester County is our failure to increase the tax the base, which is shown this year with us having to increase the tax rates," Dorchester County Council President Lenny Pfeffer said. "And that's just what we need."
Fairchild said he expects the entire project of 619 houses to be completed in five years and be worth $300 million. He said approximately 40 houses have been sold so far, with the highest sale coming in at $580,000. Listing prices start in the low $300,000s for townhomes, at $400,000 for villas and at $450,000 and up for single-family homes.
The groundbreaking ceremony brought local and state officials to the Hyatt, including Maryland Housing and Community Development Secretary Jake Day, Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico), Del. Tom Hutchinson (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) and Cambridge Mayor Lajan Cephas.
Day said he is excited for families to move into these new homes, invest in the community and contribute to the economy.
"It's an incredible thing, and it's precisely what we need to be doing in every corner of this state," he said.
Hutchinson said his mantra as a state delegate is "to make a beautiful place to live even better."
"Oh my, have you made a beautiful place to live even better," he said to the developers and builders. "Congratulations." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

While local government officials are mentioned, the core subject is the housing project's economic significance and real estate development.

title: Things to remember if buying or selling this spring
author: MID-SHORE BOARD OF REALTORS
content:
Things to remember if buying or selling this spring

 May 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MID-SHORE BOARD OF REALTORS | Section: Real Estate 
 
 524
 Words 

 Read News Document

 If someone is buying or selling this Spring, they may have noticed a few new ways of doing things since the last time they went through this process, noted Michelle Abplanalp, president of Mid-Shore Board of Realtors.There are several real estate changes that went into effect in August related to showing homes and compensation.
For buyers, a written buyer agreement is now required. Buyers and their Realtors will need to reach an agreement regarding how the agent will be paid for their services and put it in writing before seeing a home. "However, don't get hung up on signing this agreement," Abplanalp said. "This agreement can be specific. It can be to see one specific home, it can be for one day or one week, whatever you negotiate."
Before signing this agreement, buyers should ensure it reflects the terms they have negotiated with their Realtor and that they understand exactly what services will be provided and how much these services will cost, the Board of Realtors said.
The buyer agreement must include four items:
A specific and clear disclosure of the amount or rate of compensation the agent will receive or how this amount will be determined must be stated.
The compensation rate must be objective and stated as an amount, a flat fee, a percentage, or an hourly rate. The compensation cannot be open-ended.
The agreement prohibits the Realtor from receiving compensation for services from any source that exceeds the amount or rate agreed to by the buyer.
The agreement must note that the Realtor fees and commissions are fully negotiable and not set by law.
These written agreements apply to both in-person and live virtual home tours but do not apply to open houses or inquiries about services. The home seller may agree to offer compensation to their Realtor, or the seller can offer to assist with closing costs or home inspections.
For home sellers, the offers of compensation (when a seller or a seller's agent shares compensation with a buyer's agent) cannot be shared on Multiple Listing Services. MLSs are local marketplaces used by both buyer and seller agents to share information about homes for sale. Offers of compensation are still an option but are now communicated off the MLS should a home seller choose to pay the buyer's agent fee.
Sellers may consider doing this as a way of marketing their home or making their listing more attractive to buyers.
Per Abplanalp, whether buying or selling, the Realtors compensation or fees remain fully negotiable and are not set by law. Realtors have agreed to abide by the Realtor Code of Ethics and to provide clear and transparent discussions with their clients about compensation.
"What's important to know is these practice changes provide consumers on both sides of a residential transaction with additional choice and transparency," Abplanalp said. "It helps to have this discussion upfront so there are no misunderstandings. I have found that my clients appreciate knowing what I will do for them, what services I provide, and at what cost."
The Mid-Shore Board of Realtors mission is to advocate for its members and the public to preserve the right to own, transfer and utilize real property. For more information, visit midshoreboardofrealtors.com. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Townhomes go up at Lakeside at Trappe
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Townhomes go up at Lakeside at Trappe

 May 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 184
 Words

 EASTON — Residents of Trappe may have seen some new construction at the Lakeside at Trappe residential development.The development has started construction on new townhomes and single family homes. They have been seeing good sales, according to developers.
"I think the sales are doing well, there continues to be quite a bit of interest in the project and continuing to make plans to complete the first phase of construction," said Robert Rauch, owner of Rauch Inc., Lakeside's developer.
The Trappe Planning Commission heard and approved the building plans for the further construction of the Lakeside at Trappe residential development at their Dec. 17 meeting.

The townhomes are actively selling between $339,990 to $369,990, Rauch said. On Lakeside at Trappe website, new single family homes are priced between $439,990 and $514,990.
Rauch could not confirm when exactly the construction will be complete or when the new units will be open.

title: Two potential dispensaries compete to open in Easton
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Two potential dispensaries compete to open in Easton

 May 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 295
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Two potential cannabis dispensaries are racing to secure final approvals from the Easton planners, but only one will be able to be built, at least in the location the business plans.Both potential locations sit near each other in the former bank locations near the Giant and Walmart on Elliott Road. State law will require one of the two dispensaries to find another spot.
"It was described at our hearing as something of a race to the finish at this point," said Lynn Thomas, town planner, in an interview. "The one issue that is at play for both of them is part of the state law requires minimum separation between other cannabis dispensaries.
"They obviously are right across the street from one another, so whoever gets their final approval first is going to prevent the other from opening at that location."
According to the Maryland Cannabis Administration, dispensaries are required to be 1,000 feet away from each other.
The applicant for 8223 Elliott Road is BGFY LLC and the applicant for 8171 Elliott Road is Driller Ventures LLC, Thomas said in an email.
Both business were approved for special exception by the town on different dates.
According to the town planner, BGFY LLC received its special exception on Dec. 17. A subdivision application for this property is currently under review, which would create a new parking lot surrounding the dispensary. Following the completion of the subdivision, the business will also need to submit applications for building permits.
According to Thomas, Driller Ventures LLC received a special exception on Jan. 25. The business' next step in the process is to apply for building permits.
The town planner states, "to my knowledge, we have not yet received any such applications."
The Star Democrat could not reach Driller Ventures LLC or BGFY LLC for comment. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on two businesses competing for dispensary approvals, regulatory requirements, and zoning issues. While local government processes are mentioned, the core subject is business operations and economic activity.

title: National small business week slated for May 4 through 10
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
National small business week slated for May 4 through 10

 May 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 369
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — National small businesses week is slated for the first full week in May.May 4 through May 10, the Talbot County Chamber of Commerce encourages all residents to support small businesses in Talbot County.
"Nowadays it's so easy, Amazon, and Instacart and all this stuff in the age of lone click shopping, supporting small business I think is more important than ever," said Amy Krenier, president of Talbot County Chamber of Commerce.
"I think it's an important choice for our residents to make in order to keep our Eastern Shore communities vibrant, thriving. In a small community, business owners aren't just business owners, they're our neighbors," she said.
Talbot County has 1,478 established businesses and 4,537 Non-employer establishments, according to Census data. Non-employer establishments would be considered contractors, freelancers, consultants and entrepreneurs.
According to the U.S. Small Business Administration, a small business determined based on both numbers of employees and the average revenue. Many local businesses fall in this category, local economic authorities said.
"They're community leaders, they're our friends," Krenier said. "You can get things so easily nowadays, shipped right to your door. But, what you can't get is, that feeling you get when you walk into a store and they know your name and they know your order or you see people around you know, the person's your kids soccer coach or lacrosse coach."
Cassandra Vanhooser, the county's director of economic development and tourism, credits county residents for their "great entrepreneurial spirit."
"We have so many great things going on," Vanhooser said. "Small Business Week gives a chance to really celebrate that entrepreneurial spirit and the can-do-it attitude that our businesses have. It's just incredible.
"I think what our small businesses bring to our community, they really formed the foundation of our business community. So it's it's hugely important."
Kreiner and Vanhooser both want residents to remember to support small business not just one week, but every week.
"Supporting small businesses is supporting our community, it's supporting our way of life," Krenier said. "It's what keeps our whole community strong, connected, vibrant and you're strengthening your relationships.Everybody's sad when one of our businesses goes out, well that's because it meant something to people. Even if it wasn't where you shopped, It meant something to us." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on National Small Business Week, emphasizing the importance of supporting local businesses, their economic role, and community impact. title: 'Beautiful moments deserve beautiful flowers': Three Little Buds Floral blooms
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
'Beautiful moments deserve beautiful flowers': Three Little Buds Floral blooms

 May 9, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Business 
 
 443
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Believing that "beautiful moments deserve beautiful flowers," Molly Busick, of Church Hill, is the owner and lead designer of downtown Centreville's new florist. Filling Liberty Street with the scent of fresh flowers and cheerful community in time for the season's first First Friday, Three Little Buds Floral held a ribbon cutting ceremony May 2.After 13 years as a registered nurse, Busick took a leap to follow her passion for design and into an entirely new field and Three Little Buds started in 2022 as a full-service floral design studio focused on weddings and events.
With her background in nursing and healthcare management, Busick said connection and caring for others has always been at the forefront of her heart, and combining that with a love of design, Three Little Buds was born.
"For as long as I can remember, I've been drawn to design, the beauty in details, the power of a well-crafted space, and the emotions it evokes when it all comes together," she said.
As a family affair, Three Little Buds' namesake comes from the family's three girls, and Busick's husband Craig serves as the right-hand man, she said.
Inspired by the natural beauty of flowers, a love for people, and the joy of being part of life's biggest moments, the foundation of Three Little Buds is "rooted" in creativity and precision, ensuring that each piece is a reflection of an individual's unique vision.
"It's been both a challenge and a joy, and one of the greatest gifts has been showing our three daughters that it's never too late to chase your dreams," Busick said.
Three Little Buds is proud to source seasonal blooms from local flower farms whenever possible, while also working with wholesaler Delaware Valley to bring in unique flowers from around the world, she said.
Owning a business is not always a bed of roses, but putting the "rose" in Rosie the Riveter, Busick is blazing a path forward for women entrepreneurs.
"This industry is tough. It takes grit, grace, and a whole lot of hustle. But I wouldn't trade it for anything. I'm beyond grateful to be here, building something beautiful, one little bud at a time," she said.
The florist shop is designed as a cozy place to feel at home and includes a flower bar where customers can create their own bouquets as well as various apparel and gifts, according to Busick.
"Whether it's a wedding, birthday, celebration, or farewell, flowers mark meaningful moments in life and I feel honored to play a small role in helping people express love, joy, and remembrance through our designs," she said.
Three Little Buds Floral is located at 100 N. Liberty Street. More information can be found at threelittlebudsfloral.com 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Molly Busick's new florist business, Three Little Buds Floral, detailing her entrepreneurial journey, business operations, and community impact. While local life and arts/culture elements are present, the core theme aligns with business/economy due to emphasis on entrepreneurship, market presence, and commercial activities.

title: Shop ‘till you drop: Could Trump upend, reset the age of the insatiable American consumer?
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media
content:
Shop ‘till you drop: Could Trump upend, reset the age of the insatiable American consumer?

 May 9, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS APG Media | Section: Business 
 
 1083
 Words 

 Read News Document

 No one spends like Americans.Could U.S. President Donald Trump change that with his tariffs regime?
By leaps and bounds, the U.S. is by far the world's largest consumer market totaling $19 trillion annually, according to federal data.
America has 4% of the world's population but more than 31% of consumer spending, according to the World Bank. Consumers account for two-thirds of the behemoth U.S. economy.
Trump is an unlikely messenger for a pullback on Americans' vociferous consumer appetites.
Trump has long been a standard bearer for American capitalism; marketing and hawking everything from Bibles, watches and vodka to sneakers, ball caps and golf gear to his MAGA aficionados. The Trump Organization's hotels and golf courses depend on tourism and spending by the affluent.
But his tariffs aimed at bringing back manufacturing to post World War II levels in the U.S. and to 'Buy American' could also raise prices and reduce supplies of globally sourced consumer goods such as toys, clothing, footwear and jewelry.
Trump has quipped that Americans might not miss some imported items, especially from China which currently sees a 145% tariff from Trump on most goods.
"You know, somebody said, 'Oh, the shelves are going to be open,'" Trump said, from the White House last month. "Well, maybe the children will have two dolls instead of 30 dolls. So maybe the two dolls will cost a couple bucks more than they would normally."
Trump followed that up during an NBC interview alluding to American consumerism.
"I'm just saying they don't need to have 30 dolls. They can have three. They don't need to have 250 pencils. They can have five," Trump said.
A pullback of U.S. consumer spending would be a sea change for hosts of industries and supply chains.
The U.S. accounts for 3% of the world's kids.
But America buys 40% of the world's toys (most of which are manufactured in China).
That's just the tip of America's ravenous consumer appetite.
Pick a consumer category — cars, boats, cosmetics, wine, fragrances — and the U.S. is likely the largest market globally.
The next closest overall consumer market is China at $7 trillion despite having more than four times the population as the U.S.
American consumer spending has been insatiable and almost limitless compared to the rest of the world.
Trump's tariffs regime — and current trade war with China — has already dampened consumer confidence.
The Conference Board and University of Michigan have both reported significant dips on consumer sentiment since Trump took office and announced his tariffs aimed at bolstering U.S. manufacturing and settling past inequitable trade scores.
The former's consumer gauge shows expectations at a 13-year low.
"Consumer confidence has deteriorated in the early months of 2025," said Piyush Puri, founding partner of Mercurius Media Capital (MMC), a California-based consulting firm.
Puri said there is "pervasive pessimism" about jobs, income and financial situation in sentiment surveys. "At the same time household debt is at record highs," Puri said.
The New York Federal Reserve Bank reports American household debt sits at a record $18 trillion. That is up from $14 trillion at the end of 2019 before the COVID-19 pandemic and its ensuing inflation wave.
Puri said he can see consumers putting off bigger purchases — such as cars which face 25% levies for imported vehicles and auto parts — and turn to bargain brands for everyday items.
Deidre Popovich, a business professor at Texas Tech University, also sees consumers bargain hunting and comparing prices.
But she doesn't foresee a marked, societal pullback from American consumerism.
"It's tempting to think that tariffs will 'reset' American overconsumption but behaviorally, that's unlikely. U.S. consumer culture is built on habit loops, emotional spending, and identity-driven purchases," Popovich said. "Tariffs may change what people buy, or where they shop, but the general desire to consume isn't going anywhere."
She said consumers at large are displaying "financial dissonance."
"This behavior reflects deeply ingrained consumption habits along with a psychological response to stress," she said, noting continued U.S. consumer spending despite record debt loads and economic skepticism before and after Trump's election. "More specifically, when people feel anxious or uncertain, spending can become a way to assert control or maintain a sense of normalcy."
But others see potential for "new normals" with shopping, especially from more cash-strapped households, as Trump persists with his tariffs and other countries respond with their own levies.
Some Americans could also potentially awaken to spending habits and how many material things they actually need.
George Carrillo, CEO of the Hispanic Construction Council advocacy group, said if tariffs result in higher prices, slower growth or both (i.e. stagflations) that could "influence more conscious consumption habits, as shoppers weigh the necessity of every purchase."
"While America's role as a global consumer powerhouse isn't disappearing overnight, tariffs and mounting financial strain are undoubtedly nudging long-standing behaviors in a new direction," he said.
Consumers, especially working class and middle income households are already stretched with prices up 24% overall since February 2020 and before the COVID-19 pandemic and its ensuing inflation wave.
Consumer watchdog Michael Podolsky said American shoppers have already been frustrated by price hikes following Trump's tariffs announcement and the "lack of transparency" regarding pricing in general.
"Skepticism toward brands is growing among shoppers, with some believing companies are using price hikes as an opportunity rather than a necessity," said Podolsky, CEO and co-founder of PissedConsumer.com.
Trump personally called Amazon chairman Jeff Bezos last month to complain about a report the e-commerce giant could list tariff costs next to some prices. Amazon said the disclosure idea was just being considered and would not come to fruition.
"The instances with price increases due to tariffs may soon lead to heightened public frustration as well as continue reshaping purchasing habits, with more consumers refusing the products affected by tariffs," Podolsky said. "Some shoppers report that they have already delayed purchases or canceled services altogether."
Trump was elected, in part, due to voters' frustrations with high, post-pandemic prices during the Biden administration.
Trump contends inflation has cooled, including with gas prices averaging $3.15 per gallon (down 13% from a year ago), according to AAA.
But Puri said if product categories and store shelves have fewer options, that will allow the remaining product makers, including from the U.S., to potentially raise prices with less competition.
Carrillo said Trump's trade pushes have thrown consumers and small businesses for a loop.
"The president initially promised relief from rising costs, but tariffs have taken us on a roller-coaster ride, forcing Americans to adjust to the reality of higher prices while being asked to 'stay patient,'" Carrillo said. "Adding to the frustration, the administration has shown resistance to companies like Amazon making the impacts of tariffs more transparent to consumers." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Trump's tariff policies and their economic implications on consumer behavior, trade dynamics, and market trends. It discusses business impacts, consumer spending patterns, and economic indicators, aligning most closely with Business/Economy. National News is a secondary consideration due to its political context but lacks the economic depth of the primary topic.

title: Federal lawsuit fights striped bass restrictions
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Federal lawsuit fights striped bass restrictions

 May 13, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 623
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ROCK HALL — Striped bass season begins on the Chesapeake Bay May 16 amid mounting tensions between fishing industry groups and regulatory agencies.A federal lawsuit has been filed in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia by fishing industry organizations bordering the Atlantic Ocean and its inland waterways.
Adding to the regulatory conflict, an executive order from President Donald Trump aiming to restore local fisheries' freedoms could potentially overturn the Fisheries Commission's previous regulations.
Previous lawsuits, persisting problems
Captain Rob Newberry, chair of Delmarva Fisheries Association, and Brian Hardman, chair of the Maryland Charter Boats Association, are leading the charge against current Maryland state regulations, particularly those concerning striped bass.
In March, their previous lawsuit against the Fisheries Commission reached the Supreme Court, which denied a hearing of the case.
"The fight is far from over," Newberry said. He claims the commission and state agencies are shortening the fishing season, reducing the size of removable fish, lowering commercial quotas and limiting recreational fishers on charter boats to one fish per day.
The new federal lawsuit expands beyond state agencies to include the U.S. Department of the Interior, U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, U.S. Department of Commerce, National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission and several environmental groups and natural resource agencies along the coast.
The suit targets agencies including the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission, which coordinates conservation and management of coastal fish species in 15 states along the Atlantic.
In a press release, Newberry expressed frustrations shared by many in the fishing industry. "For too long, our industry has allowed this obscure Interstate Compact (ASMFC) founded in 1942 to help furnish the food supply behind the war effort, to transform itself into a power-hungry partnership with massive support from federal government agencies which apparently think that fish are more important than people," he said.
The coalition of plaintiffs includes the Delmarva Fisheries Association.
Executive Order
On April 17, Trump signed an executive order titled "Restoring American Seafood Competitiveness," vowing to end the monopoly of foreign seafood exports and make the U.S. the world's dominant seafood producer. The order also calls for investigation of the same policy makers that Newberry's coalition is suing.
Regulatory agencies maintain that restrictions are not intended to harm commercial fisheries but to preserve them.
At numerous conferences, including the most recent, these agencies cited insufficient Atlantic striped bass populations based on Marine Recreational Information Program data from computer models. Their restrictions, they say, aim to address this shortage.
Many in the fishing industry dispute these claims. Newberry said striped bass stock across the entire Mid-Atlantic region "has never been more plentiful."
Captain Willy Hatch, president of the Cape Cod Charter Boat Association, questioned the scientific methods used to determine stock shortages.
"One major flaw in the claimed science behind this regulation is the NOAA's Marine Recreational Information program being used to estimate recreational and for-hire catch data, which has been found to be grossly overestimating recreational catch," Hatch said.
Economic impactMarc Berger, head of the East Coast Fishing Coalition, warned about broader economic impacts of fishing regulations.
"These actions threaten not only the present viability of our businesses but also the long-term sustainability of the for-hire sector of the fishing industry," Berger said. "The ramifications extend beyond our industry, impacting hotels, restaurants, tackle shops and other merchants relying on our operations to sustain their livelihoods."
North Carolina Watermen United expressed similar sentiments: "We stand in solidarity with our fellow watermen in our opposition to the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission."
The group noted fishermen are struggling within the bounds of regulations on several species, including southern flounder, red drum, striped mullet and spotted trout.
"The socio-economic hardships put on not only our captains, crew, and families but our entire coastal communities when agencies continue to handcuff these watermen is immeasurable," the organization stated. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a federal lawsuit challenging fishing regulations that impact the commercial fishing industry's operations and economic viability. While environmental conservation is mentioned, the core conflict revolves around regulatory policies affecting business interests, economic sustainability, and industry-government tensions. The mention of executive orders, economic impacts on coastal communities, and industry lobbying aligns most strongly with Business/Economy.

title: Chestertown chocolate shop continues under new owner
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Chestertown chocolate shop continues under new owner

 May 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Business 
 
 321
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A cherished staple of the downtown Chestertown landscape, Bespoke Chocolate is beginning a delicious new chapter with the recent sale and transfer of ownership.The cozy, fragrant storefront that has long delighted locals and visitors will keep doing so under new owner, Kurt Douglass, Chestertown resident of almost five years.
Douglass appreciates what the previous owner brought to the establishment and will carry on that tradition of handcrafted treats and heartfelt service.
"We will maintain the same passion for quality and community that helped make the business a local treasure," Douglass remarked.
The continuance of the business is great news for many, he stated. Over the years, the shop has built a loyal following, becoming a must-visit destination during strolls around town and a favorite stop during the holidays, First Fridays, and summer festivals, Douglass mentioned.
News of the sale sparked a wave of support from the community, he said, with customers expressing relief, joy, and excitement and filling social media feeds. He said the shop's inbox was full with congratulations and shared memories.
Douglass appreciates the loyal support. "Customers cherish their signature truffles to seasonal specials, offerings which reflect both craftsmanship and care— earning praise not just for the sweets, but for the welcoming atmosphere. The continued presence of the chocolate shop is a sign that Chestertown's heart beats strong with small-town resilience and sweet traditions."
Douglass will maintain that essence while making a few small changes in the coming months; thoughtful, incremental modifications—guided by customer input and suggestions from the shop's dedicated Chocolatiers Club members.
"These changes aim to enhance, not replace, the magic that has always defined the experience," Douglass said. "In the words of one longtime customer, 'It's not just about chocolate. It's about care, craft, and community.' We're thrilled to see it continue to thrive."
The chocolate shop's story continues—rooted in tradition, inspired by community and ready for what's next.
Stop by to check out what is happening at 207 S Cross St./ website: https://www.bespokechocolate.net/. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

While it mentions community impact, the core subject is the business's continuity and management change, aligning most directly with 'Business/Economy.' title: Department of Commerce unveils new Montana brand in Miles City
author: Hunter Herbaugh Miles City Star
content:
Department of Commerce unveils new Montana brand in Miles City

 May 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Hunter Herbaugh Miles City Star | Section: News 
 
 700
 Words 

 Read News Document

 While the World Famous Bucking Horse Sale hit full stride in Miles City on Friday, it wasn't the only thing taking off, as the Montana Department of Commerce unveiled a new brand for the state on the first full day of the event. Coming as the first new brand for the state in over a decade, the new look is aimed at embodying the spirit of the state and its people, encapsulating the entirety of Big Sky Country from east to west.The event was held with all the fanfare it could muster, with Miles City and Custer County representatives standing alongside Department of Commerce leadership and Gov. Greg Gianforte, who is swinging through Miles City for his annual trip to the Bucking Horse Sale and his yearly 56 County Tour.
Unveiling the new brand, DOC Chief Marketing Officer Mitch Staley said the launch of this new look is aimed at honoring Montana's character and history, and letting the rest of the world know it as well.
"It's a realignment with what has made Montana what it is with the brand that our state uses to promote the great things, the people and our stories — not only here in Montana, but all across the country and the world," Staley said. "This brand helps to represent us to visitors who come here, it will help us attract new businesses by promoting our economy, and also, it helps promote and uplift the businesses that are here already."
While promoting business is a major aspect of this new look for Montana, a large part of it is also aimed at the people, be those the people currently living in the state or those looking to come in and call it home. Gianforte emphasized this during his comments, saying his hope is that the new brand will get even those who have lived here all their lives to go out and rediscover what makes Montana special.
"For the first time in 16 years, we're re-introducing Montana to the world, and we're doing it by shining a spotlight on the people who make this place so great. Our new brand centers on the stories of real Montanans; of family ranches and veterans, small business owners, families and community leaders. Their voices, their experiences, their Montana."
And of course, there's no other appropriate way to introduce a new Montana brand to the world than with a classic truck. Unveiled during Friday's launch, the new brand was emblazoned on the side of 1968 Chevy C-10 pick-up. The design is inspired by Montana's classic license plate, with a horizontal line in the colors of the setting sun breaking into the silhouette of rugged mountains to one side, representing the western side of the state, transitioning into a flat line that then rises into the visage of hills and cap rocks at the other end, representing the eastern side of the state, all set to a sky blue background.
As Staley describes it, the truck is a billboard on wheels advertising the state.
"This truck will be at all of our booths across the state Through the summer, we'll have several events... It's really a way to get this in front as many Montanans as we can rather than have one billboard, one static ad somewhere," he said.
The new brand also includes a new website aimed at improving the travel experience through Montana for visitors and residents alike, including updated road maps.
Meanwhile, Gianforte described the brand as not only a testament to the state and its people, but also, in his personal opinion, a testament to the dream that Montana represents.
"Montana is recognized globally as America. It really is the heart of America. We have incredible outdoor adventure opportunities, but even more important are the people of Montana; the grit, the independence, the work ethic," he said. "This brand is about telling the story of the people of Montana in a way that not only brings people here to visit, but, maybe, they come here to pursue the American dream."
The new brand, along with the truck, will be hitting the road this summer with a schedule of appearances set to be posted to the Department of Commerce website in the near future, according to Staley. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the Montana Department of Commerce's new state brand initiative, emphasizing economic promotion, business attraction, and state marketing strategies. While local government entities are involved, the core purpose revolves around economic development and branding for business/industry.

title: Markets vote daily on Trump's trade policy
author: RICK SCHIMING
content:
Markets vote daily on Trump's trade policy

 May 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: RICK SCHIMING | Section: Columns 
 
 738
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In a sense, each business day is election day for the U.S. economy. Holders of U.S. stocks, U.S. Treasury bonds and U.S. dollars around the world make their trades and cast their dollar votes based on how they feel about the strength and sanity of US economic policy and the health and stability of American democracy.While widely publicized and widely followed, the U.S. stock market is the narrowest view of the health of the economy, essentially a vote on the future health of about 5,000 corporations that are listed on the major stock exchanges (NYSE and NASDAQ). The average daily dollar trading volume is around $300 billion. A falling stock market indicates that investors believe that profits will decline in the future for these corporations due to falling demand for their products and/or rising costs of production.
Less reported and less well-known, the US Treasury bond market and the foreign exchange currency market provide a more important and meaningful vote on the state of the economy. The dollar votes cast in these markets are huge compared to the stock market. The Treasury securities market has a daily trading volume of nearly $1 trillion while in foreign exchange market, the average trading volume in dollars is over $6 trillion.
Let's first look at the market for U.S. Treasury securities. The 10-year bond has long been the most widely held and safest financial asset worldwide because it has been backed by the absolute guarantee of the U.S. government never to default on this obligation. Typically, in times of economic distress around the world, investors increase their demand for these bonds, which raises their price and lowers their interest rate.
The foreign exchange market is where foreign currencies are traded daily. Investors around the world buy and sell U.S. dollars for their own respective currencies. A rising U.S. dollar internationally means that foreign investors want to hold dollars because of the strength and stability of the economy. A strong dollar reflects the role of the dollar as the central reserve asset and means of payment in the world economy.
In short, when the U.S. is seen as strong economically, U.S. Treasury interest rates fall and the value of the dollar rises. When the U.S. is seen as weak, Treasury interest rates rise and the value of the dollar falls.
What has happened in these markets recently? Investors worldwide are fleeing all U.S. assets (stocks, Treasuries, and the U.S. dollar). This reflects an increasing distrust of our future economic health in the face of chaotic policy choices. Faith and confidence in the U.S. economy is disappearing as tariffs and other poor policy choices by the Trump administration slowly but surely erode international confidence in the United States.
For someone who wants to be seen as a winner, Trump is losing almost every day in the stock, US bond and foreign exchange markets. Trillions of dollar votes by investors around the world are being cast against Trump's stewardship of the economy and his economic policies.
Unfortunately, he isn't the only one who loses. We all do.
Higher interest rates for Treasuries means both costlier interest payments on the national debt leading to fewer federal funds available for other priorities and to bigger federal budget deficits in the future. Higher interest rates on Treasury bonds dictate higher interest rates across the US economy. Anyone paying interest on any debt is hurt by weakness in the US Treasury market.
A weaker US dollar internationally also costs US consumers. A weaker dollar means that it costs us more dollars for us to buy goods and services from overseas. This puts even more inflationary pressure on our economy especially when combined with the inflationary pressure of increased tariffs.
The worst-case scenario of higher and wider tariffs? Falling stock prices, higher bond rates and a weak U.S. dollar could slow economic growth, increase unemployment and raise inflation. In other words, stagflation. The latest GDP figures already show a shrinking economy since Trump took office in January.
These big three financial markets are casting their dollar votes against Trump and his reckless and incoherent stewardship of the economy. When Trump moves to increase tariffs, these markets tank. When he backtracks on his tariff policies, the stock market soars. Doesn't this say volumes about the stupidity of his trade policies?
It is a humiliating defeat for him and a loss for all of us. Unless or until his policies change for the better, the resulting pain to US consumers will continue. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on financial markets, economic policies, and their impacts on the U.S. economy, including stock markets, Treasury bonds, and currency exchanges. It analyzes Trump's trade policies and their effects on economic indicators, making 'Business/Economy' the most precise category. 'National News' is a secondary candidate due to the political context, but the core content is economic analysis.

title: Waterfowl Festival concerned about losing funding
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Waterfowl Festival concerned about losing funding

 May 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Business 
 
 583
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — After President Donald Trump proposed eliminating the National Endowment for the Arts, organizations like the Waterfowl Festival began to worry about their future.According to the festival's Executive Director Deena Kilmon, more than just the future of the festival is at stake. Without expected funding, the maintaining the historic armory building, continuing the William A. Perry Scholarship Program, and fundraising for wildlife and habitat conservation are uncertain, Kilmon said.
The festival, one of Talbot County's largest economic drivers, has been in operation since 1971.
"We had independent auditors tell us that about 30,000 people were downtown during the festival last year," Kilmon said. "You have the thousands of community residents that just enjoy all the free stuff, you know, the music and the parties, and then we have about a thousand volunteers that come over, which includes about 200 student volunteers every year."
According to Kilmon, last year's festival filled all the hotels in Talbot County and three surrounding counties. "Every restaurant was full Thursday, Friday, Saturday night. No one had any room anywhere, so we don't know the ultimate economic impact, but we know it's large," she said.
The Waterfowl Festival applied for several grants this year in fear federal and state art funding gets cut.
Those grants include the Maryland Historic Trust Grant to target crucial repairs on the Armory building, fix ADA accessibility issues, and simply maintain the historic building that hosts nonprofit organizations for a small fee and is open to the public at no cost.
Easton Mayor Megan Cook said it's important for the Waterfowl Festival to remain in the town and she would like to keep the organization as the steward to the building.
"It would be great to keep them in the Armory because that building anchors our downtown, and since it is such a community space, it's important to keep it open to the community," Cook said.
"Waterfowl have been the stewards of that building for a number of years, they take great care of it. You know, it would be a tragedy, a true loss for the town if that building went dark," Cook later said.
The Maryland Heritage Areas Authority grant would allow the Waterfowl Festival to re-open the stage and host even more artists and speakers.
"Those are all the things we would love to do if we could bring the building up to modern safety standards," said Kilmon. "But again, that's outside of our mission of supporting conservation and wildlife habitats across the nation. That's what we do for real, but this is just something that we feel like as stewards of the building, it's the right thing to do."
The festival will learn about its state and federally funded grants by the end of the fiscal year in June. In the meantime, Waterfowl Festival staff are preparing to make changes.
Currently, children do not have to pay to attend the festival or participate in many activities like soap carving and the fishing derby. That may change if the grants are not awarded.
The festival has raised over $6 million for conservation and wildlife preservation over the years and supported secondary education for student volunteers known as "duck sitters." Last year, the festival raised $24,000 for scholarships, awarding each student $2,000.
Kilmon said a one-year deficit would not kill the festival, but if it continued, they'd have to take extra measures.
"You know, we'd have to start, I hate the word downsizing, but what I'll say is, making the footprint of the festival smaller, right? And offering less free opportunities for education," Kilmon said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the Waterfowl Festival's economic impact as a major driver for Talbot County, detailing funding concerns, grant applications, and potential financial changes. While Arts & Culture is relevant due to the festival's connection to the National Endowment for the Arts, the primary emphasis is on economic implications, grants, and community financial stability.

title: The big pour: Cambridge Waterfront Development Inc. promenade makes progress
author: Lily Tierney
content:
The big pour: Cambridge Waterfront Development Inc. promenade makes progress

 May 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: News 
 
 429
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Last week, Cambridge Waterfront Development Inc. did its first "big pour," according to Treasurer Frank Narr.The concrete base for CWDI's promenade was poured May 10, a visible sign for the community that progress is underway. The project aims to develop the waterfront similarly to Baltimore's Inner Harbor.
Progress has been slower than many hoped as CWDI has faced significant headwinds.
Tensions between the developer and the City of Cambridge came to a head when the city filed a lawsuit in May of 2024 over a transfer agreement. The lawsuit was dismissed without prejudice a few months later, and the city and CWDI entered a memorandum of understanding to address issues that were not included in the lawsuit settlement.
"And, you know, honestly, that has actually kind of been a blessing in disguise," said CWDI Board President Angie Hengst about the lawsuit. "It has allowed us to open up those doors of communication with the county and city even more," Hengst said.
The city and county managers now sit on the board of CWDI, which has helped bridge divides between the development project with the community. "It is really great to have their constant input," Hengst said.
Narr has been with the project for over 30 years and cares deeply about making sure it is done right. For Narr, it isn't about finding partners who can simply fund the project, but finding partners who care about the mission.
That mission aims to foster community engagement, economic growth and further development projects in Cambridge. "It really needs to be a place where everyone in our community feels there's a place for them," Narr said. "And so continuous access to the waterfront, public open space, no gates, no walls, nothing that would say you're not welcome."
Narr acknowledges that the negative backlash CWDI has received from the public has been tough, but he chooses to focus on what is in his control. "There's times when people question, 'Why are you still doing this? You must be getting a benefit from this,' and I'm thinking, 'No it's my commitment to my community to make sure we get what we deserve and we get what will make us all proud,'" Narr said.
Now that they've overcome the litigation hurdle, the main challenge CWDI faces, like many nonprofit organizations at the moment, is funding. "I think that's really our biggest challenge right now," Hengst said.
The promenade is slated to be finished by the end of summer and CWDI is holding a meeting on May 20 to deliver updates to the County and City Council and is open to the public.
