title: Wonder food hall brings 21 restaurant concepts under one roof in The Grove at Newark
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content:
Wonder food hall brings 21 restaurant concepts under one roof in The Grove at Newark

 July 20, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com | Section: State News 
 
 476
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A new dining concept that opened in The Grove at Newark this week aims to put an end to arguments over where to go for dinner."You're in the mood for Chinese. I really want Italian. We're not battling to see where we're going to go today," explained Kris Gobeil, regional director for Wonder food hall. "We can all go to one place, we can get our food together and we can truly enjoy the food together, which is the whole point of hospitality."
Wonder brings together 21 brands with separate menus all under one roof and prepared in one kitchen. Options include pizza, pasta, Mexican, Chinese, Middle Eastern, Thai, Mediterranean, poke, burgers, wings, cheesesteaks, salads, barbecue and more.
There is also a variety of price points, from a $6.70 burger and $10.45 burrito to a $26 sea bass entree and a $37 steak.
"We really want to get rid of the concern of choices," Gobeil said. "We want people to have one area that they can go to, so that way everybody can get what they're looking for out of one location."
While there are a handful of tables for dine-in customers, the business focuses mostly on delivery and pick-up orders.
The 3,500-square-foot building along the center road through The Grove is almost entirely dedicated to the large kitchen necessary to cook the wide variety of menu items. The small front-of-house area consists of four tables, two kiosks for ordering, a small counter and racks where pickup orders will be placed.
While Wonder has developed many of its own brand concepts, it also licenses brands and menus from established chefs and restaurants, including celebrity chef Bobby Flay and Texas barbecue restaurant Tejas.
Wonder started in New York City and has rapidly expanded. The Newark location is the company's 53rd location and its first in Delaware.
The Newark location is open from 11 a.m. to 9 p.m. daily, though Gobeil noted the company could consider late-night or breakfast hours later.
Gobeil said Wonder is excited to join the growing roster of businesses at The Grove, formerly known as College Square Shopping Center.
"What better location? I mean, look around here," he said. "Not only do we have residential, but we also have some great shops around us. It's really just about being a part of a community."
Several other businesses are slated to open in The Grove soon, including Nifty Fifty's, a 1950s-themed diner; The Picklr, an indoor pickleball club; Lefty's Alleys and Eats, an entertainment center featuring bowling, axe throwing, Top Golf simulators, Krazy Darts, a 6,000-square-foot arcade and a restaurant; and Med Spa.
Cold Stone Creamery and Turkiye Kebob House opened earlier this year. Other additions in the past few years include Smoothie King, Crunch Fitness, Del Pez Mexican Gastropub, First Watch, Raising Cain's, NovaCare Rehabilitation, Jersey Mike's Subs, Bonchon Korean Fried Chicken, Leslie's Pool Supplies and Compass at The Grove, a 306-unit luxury apartment complex. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Artificial intelligence threatens free internet
author: MICHAEL DAVIS
content:
Artificial intelligence threatens free internet

 July 23, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MICHAEL DAVIS | Section: News 
 
 431
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Artificial intelligence will eliminate the free internet. Unless something changes, we can kiss all the free, online stuff goodbye. This identifies the problem. Unfortunately, solutions are currently unknown. This poses a threat to the information age as we know it and even to an informed democracy.The free internet is an illusion. It may appear free, but almost everything is funded by advertising. This is true of free podcasts, travel sites, weather sites, music sites, videos, medical information sites and shopping sites. To quote Claude.AI, "… free websites require … enormous resources for servers, bandwidth and staff. Without advertising revenue … it's nearly impossible to sustain these services."
AI will reduce the number of views generated on advertising-funded websites. Let's say you are taking a trip to Atlanta. An easy AI program can go into all the airline flight data and find you the cheapest one-way flight with added leg room leaving from BWI after 10 a.m. It can also book you a car. It will tell you about the weather in Atlanta.
Finding a hotel and calling the hotel to make a reservation? Done. It will download to your phone your favorite podcasts, videos and music playlists for inflight entertainment. It will send you a summary of that day's national and local news. In a few minutes after you ask AI to do this, you'll get all the information in One Big Beautiful Email. You need not look at a single website nor their ads.
However, advertisers need actual people, not computers, bots nor web browsers, to "see" the ads. Unpopular websites cannot attract advertisers or get paid subscribers. Popular websites rely on ads to pay for podcasts, travel sites, weather sites, music sites, etc. Many people pay for sites to receive perks, but most of us tolerate ads to gain online information for free.
Usage data varies from site to site, but some trends are showing up. The Wall Street Journal reported that Google AI is causing a dramatic drop in ad views on news publishers' websites. The New York Times reported a drop in viewers to their websites due people using AI programs. Loss of live viewers means loss of ad revenue. Sites will have to charge for what used to be free access, creating another gap between the rich and the poor.
Meanwhile, our government is closing more websites, for example those that provided free medical advice. Information we need to live is being commercialized. Whether due to AI, or government cuts, our access to vital online information that sustains an informed democracy suffers when there is no "free" online information market. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on AI's impact on internet advertising revenue models, business sustainability of free online services, and economic implications for access to information. While 'Technology' is related, the core issue revolves around economic systems and business models rather than pure tech innovation. title: 'Made with love': Chris' pizza pop-ups taking off
author: Lily Tierney
content:
'Made with love': Chris' pizza pop-ups taking off

 July 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: News 
 
 399
 Words 

 Read News Document

 OXFORD — Chris Mckelvy tossed his freshly made dough up in the air and caught it with ease, stretching it with each toss and catch, eventually letting it settle on the flour-covered steel table top in the back of the historic Oxford Market.The Oxford Pizza Company, founded by Mckelvy in 2023, holds pizza pop-ups on Mondays from 5 to 7 p.m. and Fridays from 5 to 8 p.m. out of the market.
The Oxford Market has been owned by John and Kate Mckelvy since 1995, the year their son, Chris, was born. For 30 years, the Mckelvys have been providing the town with homemade food that is freshly prepared and "made with love."
Chris Mckelvy is following in his parents footsteps, preparing his pizza's with high quality ingredients and a homemade dough fermented for at least four days.
He first got into the pizza business by selling his homemade frozen pizzas at the market. He was inspired to make the frozen pizzas because he wanted to find a use for freezer space that sat empty.
But after seeing some success from the frozen pizzas, he began honing his craft, investing in his business and started the pizza pop-ups.
Mckelvy said when he first started, he would sell around 10 pies on a Friday night. Now, the daily sales volume equals what was previously sold over an entire weekend.
"Basically every ounce of money I make goes right back into buying better equipment and progressing the pizza business," he said.
This includes the purchase of a new portable pizza oven, which will enable Mckelvy to hold his pop ups at local events and partner with other restaurants and stores.
Recently, he partnered with the Tilghman Island Country Store to host pop ups and sell his frozen pizzas. The pizza pop-ups at the Country Store will begin in August, and the frozen pizzas will be available Sunday.
But Mckelvy is not abandoning the market he grew up in. He has plans to expand there as well, hoping to create a seating area with bistro lights. He said there's a possibility of serving small plates, beer, wine and, of course, pizza.
Mckelvy wants customers to know they are a one-stop shop and are there to serve the people.
"If someone wants something from us either the market or pizza, we are willing to go out of our way to get people what they want," Mckelvy said.
"We're here for the people," Mckelvy said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Questions about state competing
author: Staff Writer
content:
Questions about state competing

 July 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox

 Words

 The recent announcement of $50 billion worth of investments into Pennsylvania by a variety of technology companies raises the question for Maryland residents of where does our state stand in the competition to attract new private investment.According to news reports, both of Pennsylvania's senators and its governor have spent meaningful time working to make the state attractive to AI investors, energy expansion and other pillars of private economic growth. Apparently Pennsylvania efforts have been successful.
Meanwhile, without similar media reports it's woefully unclear what Maryland leaders have done or are doing to make our state attractive to private capital. In fact, with Maryland's threatening budget deficit and Wes Moore's focus on presidential ambitions it's difficult to see how we can compete with Pennsylvania or any other state for future capital commitments.
It's good the Ravens are competitive with the Steelers, but it's more important that Baltimore does not appear to be holding a candle to Pittsburgh in a competition for private enterprise.
ART CECIL
Easton

title: Only bi-lingual law firm in Kent County celebrates 1 year
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Only bi-lingual law firm in Kent County celebrates 1 year

 April 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Business 
 
 489
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — The First Friday event of April brought friends, neighbors and visitors to downtown Chestertown. Some of those stopped by the law offices of Campbell and Furneisen to celebrate the company's one-year anniversary.Partners Bridget Campbell and Ivette Furneisen were both nominated for Eastern Shore's 2024 Women to Watch. And according to their website, Furneisen is "one of very few Spanish-speaking lawyers on the shore, and possibly the only native Spanish-speaking. It contines, "Furneisen has quickly gained a reputation as a friend to Hispanics and other immigrants in the area, helping with traffic and family court, visas, and applications for citizenship."
Furneisen said this anniversary is a significant celebration due to that distinction.
Over sparkling beverages and catering courtesy of Happy Chicken, and while balancing conversation with friends and well-wishers, Furneisen shared why she feels like her work is more vital than ever.
It started, she said, 15 years ago. In her home country of Spain, she was working for a nonprofit doing immigration work. She extended that realm of her expertise by studying law at George Mason University. Ultimately, she and her husband, who worked for American Airlines, discovered Kent County.
Now a year in to running her own practice advocating for Spanish speakers, she expressed concern for her clients, some of whom had been detained by immigration police being caught in offenses such as traffic violations.
These incidences, she said, are why she decided to pursue law further.
"Everyone deserves representation. It doesn't matter if you're rich or poor," Furneisen stated.
She takes a lot of cases from the public defender's office for those who normally could not afford a lawyer.
"Now, I can be an advocate for them. And not just in the courts. I really care," she said.
The other half of the firm is Bridget Campbell. She handles family law, real estate, business formation and other practices.
Like her legal partner, Campbell is grateful to be representing Kent County. With both of them working jointly, they cast a wide net of services.
Some of the most rewarding work is representing children as a best interest attorney, Campbell said. It is her job to advocate for children, give them a voice, and from those assessments, persuade the judge to act in the children's best interest.
This involves talking to the parents, the therapists and the children, being present for them in their time of need, Campbell said. As a mother of three boys, this is very near to her heart., as she reflects on her time studying law at Villanova, before attending Washington College.
Originally born in Pennsylvania, she has established roots here after studying law at Villanova and attending Washington College. She is president of the Kent County Humane Society, dedicated to promoting animal welfare, "preventing unnecessary pain and suffering for domestic companions in the community."
Both attorneys sees themselves reaching beyond their law profession to help those in need.
"Ivette and I find a way to give back to the community every way we can," Campbell said.

title: New Brewery coming to Denton in the fall
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
New Brewery coming to Denton in the fall

 July 29, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 399
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Eden Town Brewing Company hopes to finish construction in August and open in the fall.A dream from husband and wife combo Matt and Sarah Dahl brought Edens Town Brewing Company to Denton. According to the business website, Matt and Sarah dreamed of building a family business in Denton for many years.
"My wife was born and raised here in Denton. We lived in North Carolina for a while, which is where I'm from, and down there, there's lots of breweries," Matt Dahl said. "We saw how much people loved breweries as a place to just come and get a beer or just hang out with friends and family.
"So, we moved back up here, we knew that Denton didn't have a brewery. The more research we did, we realized really that there's not that many breweries in the entire region. We saw what breweries did for the towns that did have them. It's becomes an attraction. So that's really what we're hoping this brewery is going to bring people into Denton."
The brewery plans to serve multiple different types of beer, including India pale ales, pale ales, pilsners, lagers and much more. They will also provide cocktails and wine.
"We want to have something for for everyone," Dahl said. "Not everyone likes every type of beer, so you got to have a variety."
Eden Town will also partner with Caroline's in Denton to provide a full service food truck. Dahl loved the idea of partnering with a local business to provide food.
"We love it because that's why we're doing it," Dahl said. "We' haven't even opened yet, and we have all already created a partnership with another business here in town that I think is going to help both of us."
In addition to an in-house brewery that guests will be able to see from the tap room, Eden Town Brewing will also have an event room.
"This is an area that people will be able to rent. If they have a private party, we have to close it off," Dahl said. "If they've got a kind of larger party, we can open this door up, and they can have part of the yard."
Eden Town Brewing Company has land that can be utilized for bigger events and for making the brewery a family friendly place were people can bring their kids to play. Owners also plan to sell Eden Town Brewing Company merch.

title: The sweet life: Delaware couple fulfilling dream with bakery
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content:
The sweet life: Delaware couple fulfilling dream with bakery

 July 31, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 780
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Run by a husband-and-wife team, a small bakery and lunch restaurant on North College Avenue has been quietly building a following since January despite being open only one day a week.This fall, The Cut Bakes is planning to expand to three days a week.
"Honestly, it's been great," said Maureen Anderson, who owns the business with her husband, Matthew. "We really do have awesome regular customers, and every single week, there's more people."
Located next to Drip Cafe, The Cut Bakes sells a variety of baked goods, including its popular cinnamon roll focaccia, danishes, cookies, brownies, coffee cake, cake jars and loaves of bread.
The lunch menu changes often, but popular dishes include the Cuban sandwich, roasted chicken sandwich, fried chicken and cheesesteak.
"It was really important for us to be a from-scratch bakery with things that are made fresh everyday," Maureen said. "Everything I have for sale today, I made this morning. I think Newark really needed a place like that."
The business also caters to people with a variety of dietary restrictions, including gluten-free, dairy-free and vegan.
"This is very much an extension of our home, and how it would feel to literally come over to our house for breakfast one day," Maureen said. "That's what we really wanted in the space, was for it to be warm, welcoming and genuine."
The name, The Cut Bakes, comes from two different phrases, she said. The culinary term "cut in" means to add cold butter into dry ingredients, and "in the cut" means off the beaten path.
Both Matthew and Maureen have been cooking for most of their lives. He studied culinary arts at Howard Vo-Tech and Walnut Hill College in Philadelphia, and then worked as a chef in several restaurants. After inheriting her grandmother's love of baking, she went to school to be an art teacher but instead starting working in cafes and bakeries.
They met in 2011 while working at Cantwell's Tavern in Odessa. Later, they worked together at Drip Cafe, Matthew serving as executive chef and Maureen serving as pastry chef.
Several years ago, they decided to branch off on their own. They organized supper club events in Wilmington, took catering orders, made custom cakes and sold baked goods at craft fairs and farmers markets, including Newark Natural Foods' weekly farmers market at Newark Shopping Center.
"Once we had the kids, we were like, if we're going to be grinding and working all these hours, then we need to be doing it for ourselves," Maureen said.
In the beginning, they worked out of rented space in a commercial kitchen. Late last year, they took over the storefront at 60 N. College Ave. The previous tenant was Roja & Verde Taqueria, run by Drip Cafe owner Greg Vogeley. When that restaurant closed, Vogeley offered to sublet the space to the Andersons.
"Having this actual physical location has been the biggest weight lifted off our shoulders," Matthew said. "Now it's all about growing the brand and making sure we're doing what we need to do to stay in the game."
During the week, they use the kitchen for catering and bakery orders. They also host occasional pop-up dinners featuring other local chefs.
"We're making a little creative space for people who are in the same boat that we were three or four years ago that are just looking for a space to try out a concept before they take that leap into leasing a space," Maureen said.
The couple is still deciding whether to keep growing the business at the current location or aim to eventually move to a different location and pivot toward a more breakfast-focused menu at some point in the future.
"We love Newark," Maureen said. "This is where our kids go to school, this is where we work, this is where we live. We're very much invested in the community."
For now, they enjoy the flexibility of being able to set their own hours in order to balance raising their young kids with growing the business.
"In a society that tells us that we need to just grind, grind, grind, and make money and make money, and that's all that is of value, I feel like it's important not only for people in the community to see us thriving in this way, but our kids to see us really going out on a limb and going 10 toes down into something that's been a dream of ours for a long time," Maureen said.
Currently, The Cut Bakes is open Saturdays from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m. Starting in mid September, the hours will change to Wednesdays, Thursdays and Fridays from 9 a.m. to 2 p.m. The business is also at the Newark Natural Foods farmers market from 9:30 a.m. to 2 p.m. every Sunday. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a couple's entrepreneurial venture as a bakery owner, detailing business operations, expansion plans, and community impact. While there is a local angle, the core subject is the business itself, making Business/Economy the most precise category.

title: Easton Economic Development Corporation introduces new strategic plan
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Easton Economic Development Corporation introduces new strategic plan

 August 6, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Local News 
 
 286
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — At Monday's Easton Town Council meeting, the Easton Economic Development Corporation Board of Directors Chair Tom Klein gave an update and introduced a new strategic plan.The EDC is a department within the Town of Easton that was established in 2013 to "drive economic vitality, smart redevelopment and business creation," according to its website.
The Easton EDC's 2026/2028 strategic plan aims to boost economic growth, promote tourism, engage the community, and secure sustainable funding to position Easton as a vibrant, inclusive and thriving destination, Klein said.
The EDC elected a new executive committee in April, which quickly moved forward with initiatives including developing a strategic 100-day plan. A subcommittee was assigned to develop the plan, which serves as a roadmap for the next three years.
The plan is designed to guide the EDC in setting priorities and staying focused on key objectives.
"I do want to say that the plan is really a roadmap for us. It's not locked in stone, but it's going to get us from where we are now, to where we want to be over the next three years," Klein said.
The strategic plan is linked to the town's comprehensive plan, ensuring that the objectives, priorities and goals of both documents are in sync, particularly in the chapter on economics.
The process in putting together the plan included collecting input from stakeholders and customers through various means, including surveys.
Klein said they are looking for further funding opportunities.
"So we are working with our fundraising committee, continuing to do sponsorship recruitment as we have done. We do a lot of annual sponsorships and event sponsorships, but also looking at other ways to develop other funding options," Klein said.
The new strategic plan can be found on the town's website. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Denton Restaurant Week brings success to businesses
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Denton Restaurant Week brings success to businesses

 August 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 260
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Last week, Downtown Denton Main Street held its first restaurant week. Restaurant owners called it a success."I think pretty much every night of the week that we were open for it, we saw more customers, and even with the cheaper menu items, we saw better sales all week," Chef Ken Zellers, owner of Carolines in Denton, told the Star Democrat on Friday.
Jessica Willoughby, director of Downtown Denton Main Street, said the thought of doing a Restaurant Week came from research.
To get more people into restaurants, Main Street designed a game for residents and visitors to play with a chance for a prize if the resident visited all participating restaurants.
Each restaurant handed out stamp cards, and for every restaurant a participant ate at, they received a stamp. The prize was a free customized fire pit from Blue Line Metal Works.
Zellers said his restaurant gave out more than 50 cards during the course of the week.
"We started with only 18 cards, and after the first night, we had to get some more," he said.
No restaurants The Star Democrat was able to contact had any cards left when the week was over.
The restaurants in downtown Denton that participated were Pizza Empire, Caroline's in Denton, El Chupacabra, Craft Bakery & Cafe, Market Street Pub and Shore Gourmet.
Shore Gourmet Manager Jennifer Sipala said that from Monday to Thursday, they received a big boost in customers.
While restaurant week was success, some restaurants in Denton said sales did slow down the week after. To keep customers coming, they said they will offer more promotions. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Delaware company aims to tap into the ‘aquifer in the air’
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content:
Delaware company aims to tap into the ‘aquifer in the air’

 August 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 513
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A Delaware company is preparing to start shipping new equipment that, quite literally, creates drinkable water out of thin air."We have developed an energy-efficient separation of water from air," said Bryan Barton, president of Newark-based AirJoule. "This platform will not only transform and revolutionize HVAC and dehumidification, but will finally unlock the aquifer in the air – an abundant resource of water."
AirJoule, which was founded in 2018, opened a 42,000 square-foot facility on Shea Way in the Delaware Industrial Park off South Chapel Street last year.
The AirJoule system contains an advanced sorbent that pulls water vapor out of the air and then uses a dual-vacuum chamber to collect the water.
The system is powered by waste heat from a data center or other industrial facility.
One AirJoule unit the size of a shipping container can produce approximately 350 gallons of water a day while using only a quarter of the energy of traditional dehumidification technology.
Barton said AirJoule is ideal for areas of the Middle East and other places where water is scarce. Data centers and other industrial facilities that need water can use AirJoule units to harvest that water, allowing them to open in places that they wouldn't have been able to before.
"I can see this as enabling whole industries in parts of the world that previously could not develop because there was water scarcity," Barton said. "We're a planet of 8 billion people now, and we're just going to continue to grow. And so how do you grow into a desert when there's no water? That's the reality the world faces right now."
AirJoule has a partnership with GE and is working on integrating its technology into HVAC systems. In humid climates, up to 80 percent of the energy used in air conditioning is related to dehumidification, and AirJoule could reduce that, Barton said.
The company is also working with the military on using AirJoule products to produce water for troops on deployment.
The Newark facility, which employs 35 people, is AirJoule's engineering headquarters and will handle the initial manufacturing. The company hopes to open additional manufacturing facilities around the globe as it grows.
Last year, the company received more than $1 million in state incentives to locate in Delaware.
"This facility brings with it cutting-edge technology, but also brings, most importantly, jobs, investment and longterm potential for growth," County Executive Marcus Henry said. "These are skilled jobs in research, manufacturing and assembly, exactly the kind of opportunities we want to grow in this New Castle County region. But the ripple effect of investment like this, I believe, extends beyond the walls of this building. It supports our local supply chain. It draws in talent and entrenches our position as a destination for forward-looking companies that are shaping our future here in New Castle County."
Barton said Delaware was attractive because of the engineering talent available here.
"New Castle County in particular, is one of the largest per capita concentrations of engineers in the country," he said. "And from that, we can have the pleasure of recruiting and retaining the top talent that's needed to be successful as a company." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Steeple chase: Premiums up, coverage down for churches
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS Adams MultiMedia
content:
Steeple chase: Premiums up, coverage down for churches

 August 12, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS Adams MultiMedia | Section: National 
 
 841
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Insurance costs have skyrocketed since before the pandemic.That includes for churches and other houses of worship that are being financially squeezed on multiple insurance fronts.
Insurance premiums have risen for churches 20% nationally and as much as 60% in areas vulnerable to hurricanes, according to those familiar with the insurance landscape and industry reports.
Other churches are seeing higher deductibles or are losing coverage altogether.
"Insurance premiums continue to rise in many sectors, while coverage options continue to decline. This cycle has led to an ongoing and worsening insurance crisis for churches and other houses of worship, but also homeowners, businesses, and everyone in between," said Van Carlson, CEO of SRA 831(b) Admin, an Idaho-based risk management firm.
"The market is being squeezed between a multi-front problem of rising premiums, insurance companies leaving markets and new exclusions being added. At the same time, churches often have fewer financial resources to respond to this changing environment," Carlson said.
He is seeing instances of some churches going without insurance and others shutting down operations because they cannot afford premiums.
CLIMATE CHANGEThe challenges facing religious institutions are part of a wider problem of higher insurance premiums.
Homeowners insurance premiums are up more than 67% nationally since 2019, according to Ohio-based Matic Insurance Service Inc.
Car insurance rates have jumped more than 45% across the U.S. in that same time, according to Florida-based FinanceBuzz.
The increases have been even more in certain parts of the country such as those impacted by hurricanes, tornados and wildfires where more intense and more destructive storms and extreme weather are causing more damage, driving up premiums.
Post-pandemic inflation (with overall U.S. prices up 26% since 2019) and now President Donald Trump's tariffs on auto parts, raw materials and country-specific imports put upward pressure on repair and replacement costs.
Scott Figgins, senior vice president for Indiana-based Brotherhood Mutual Insurance Co., a leading insurer of Christian churches and ministries nationally, said wind, hail and other storms as well as wildfires "are continuing to generate above average numbers of claims", driving up property insurance premiums, including for churches and other nonprofits.
"Elevated storm losses and wildfires are still driving rate increases in areas exposed to severe weather," he said.
Figgins said from 2012 to 2021 the annual average for catastrophic losses was $44.1 billion.
"Since 2020, the average is $83.5 billion," he said.
Carlson said churches have unique challenges that can be problematic on the property insurance front.
"For religious groups in particular, they often have extremely high risks that are hard to insure," he said.
"Churches can be large and expensive to repair, most religious buildings and organizations are open to the public with little or no due diligence," he said. "All of these factors are risks that insurers often either need to charge more to cover, or may even be unwilling to cover entirely."
NUCLEAR VERDICTSFiggins and Carlson said churches see unique insurance challenges related to other polices.
Figgins said that is in "large part to the growing concern in the world reinsurance market for nuclear verdicts coming out of sexual misconduct exposure."
Churches and other faith organizations can carry insurance policies related to misconduct by clergy and others.
"Churches are increasingly looking for liability insurance, especially related to misconduct," Carlson said, pointing to a group that specializes in covering Roman Catholic parishes and archdioceses.
He also said there are alternative tax and financing paths to insurance policies for churches and other groups that can look at to help cover repair costs. Those include self-insurance funds.
Figgins said umbrella, commercial auto and general liability insurance polices have been "rapidly rising" due to large jury verdicts in abuse and misconduct cases.
"In 2020 the average jury verdict reached an all-time high of $2.5 million, a 37% increase over 2019 and a 274% increase over 2010," he said.
Between 2004 and 2023, the Catholic Church paid out more than $5 billion in damages related to sexual abuse cases, according to the Center for Applied Research in the Apostolate at Georgetown University.
That makes for a tough insurance landscape for churches and other houses of worship.
"There is significant reduction in capacity for higher limits of coverage and what is available is seeing large price increases," Figgins said.
A number of churches, denominations and religious groups either declined or did not respond to requests for comment about their insurance landscape.
'DELAY, DENY, DEFEND'Ted Patestos, founder and CEO of Houston-based Tiger Adjusters (which provides insurance services to policyholders working on claims with providers), said some in the insurance industry have moved toward a business model of denying more claims while inflation and more intense weather from climate changes are driving up costs and premiums.
"Delay, deny, defend," Patestos said of the mantra of some insurance providers.
He said state insurance regulators are in "a bind" because if they try to come down too hard on the industry or try to dictate operating and financial terms larger, more stable insurance companies will just pick up stakes and leave states and regions.
Patestos said more extreme weather events strain the bandwidth of insurance claims processing.
He said that churches, nonprofits, small businesses and households who pay higher deductibles run the risk of "paying a premium without real insurance." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on rising insurance premiums and financial challenges faced by churches, tied to economic factors like inflation, market trends, and climate change impacts. While environmental factors are mentioned, the core issue revolves around insurance markets, economic pressures, and financial systems, aligning most directly with Business/Economy.

title: Tax bill should increase paychecks
author: Staff Writer
content:
Tax bill should increase paychecks

 August 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 216
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Since my appointment as the Mid-Atlantic regional administrator at the U.S. Small Business Administration in April this year, I have traveled the Mid-Atlantic Region meeting small business owners in all facets of industries – from a hair salon in Denton, Maryland, to ship repair and maintenance provider in Suffolk, Virginia, to a dairy farm in Pennsylvania. Whether I'm in a rural area in West Virginia or an urban area in Delaware, one thing remains the same – taxes are one of the top issues for small businesses.The One Big Beautiful Bill extends the 199A passthrough deduction, which will generate $750 billion in economic growth and create over one million new Main Street jobs. There are an estimated 86,000 firms in Maryland which could be eligible for the deduction, or about 41 percent of all firms.
In addition, the bill boosts take-home pay for the typical hardworking family. It is estimated to increase wages in Maryland from $4,700 to $8,400 and protect 116,000 full-time equivalent jobs over the next four years if the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act had been allowed to expire.
The bill delivers tax cuts to working families and job creators. The SBA stands ready to empower entrepreneurs to start and grow their small businesses. Visit www.sba.gov to learn more about the SBA.
JIM SPENCER
SBA Mid-Atlantic 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Gas prices drop to average of $3.08 per gallon
author: GAS BUDDY
content:
Gas prices drop to average of $3.08 per gallon

 August 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: GAS BUDDY | Section: State News 
 
 482
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Average gasoline prices in Maryland have fallen 6.1 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.08 per gallon Monday, according to GasBuddy's survey of 2,167 stations in Maryland. Prices in Maryland are 3.6 cents per gallon lower than a month ago and stand 26.7 cents per gallon lower than a year ago. The national average price of diesel has decreased 1.9 cents compared to a week ago and stands at $3.671 per gallon."The national average is nearly unchanged from a week ago, with gasoline prices continuing to hover in the same territory where they've spent much of 2025 so far — in the low-$3-per-gallon range — as oil prices remain anchored in the $60s," said Patrick De Haan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy.
According to GasBuddy price reports, the cheapest station in Maryland was priced at $2.69 per gallon Sunday while the most expensive was $4.79 per gallon, a difference of $2.10 per gallon.
The national average price of gasoline is unchanged in the last week, averaging $3.09 per gallon today. The national average is down 4.6 cents per gallon from a month ago and stands 27.9 cents per gallon lower than a year ago, according to GasBuddy data compiled from more than 11 million weekly price reports covering over 150,000 gas stations across the country.
Historical gasoline prices in Maryland and the national average going back 10 years:
August 18, 2024: $3.35 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.37 per gallon)August 18, 2023: $3.79 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.84 per gallon)August 18, 2022: $3.89 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.90 per gallon)August 18, 2021: $3.05 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.17 per gallon)August 18, 2020: $2.24 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.17 per gallon)August 18, 2019: $2.54 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.60 per gallon)August 18, 2018: $2.80 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.83 per gallon)August 18, 2017: $2.30 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.33 per gallon)August 18, 2016: $2.07 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.14 per gallon)August 18, 2015: $2.53 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.67 per gallon)
Neighboring areas and their current gas prices:
Baltimore: $3.06 per gallon, down 7.8 cents per gallon from last week's $3.14 per gallon.Washington, D.C.: $3.25 per gallon, down 5.3 cents per gallon from last week's $3.30 per gallon.Hagerstown: $3.03 per gallon, down 1.8 cents per gallon from last week's $3.05 per gallon.
"Price cycling markets once again led the biggest weekly price changes, with Ohio and Florida seeing a cycle and higher prices last week, while Michigan posted the largest drop and could be due for another jump in the cycle sometime this week," Haan said. "For the majority of motorists in non-cycling states, gas prices will likely remain near current levels as we head toward Labor Day. However, it's worth watching developments around a potential peace deal between Russia and Ukraine. If such an agreement materializes, it could send oil prices lower on expectations that sanctions against Russia might be eased, effectively boosting global oil supply." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Walmart in Denton receives upgrade
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Walmart in Denton receives upgrade

 August 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: Caroline 
 
 251
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — The Walmart in Denton recently celebrated the remodeling of the store with a ribbon-cutting ceremony.The ceremony included multiple donations to local nonprofit organizations and recognition for long-term Walmart associates.
"At Walmart, we make it our priority to ensure that our customers' shopping experience is as smooth and enjoyable as possible," said store manager April Holmes. "We're incredibly excited to showcase the renovations and improvements made to our store to our committed and supportive community of shoppers, as well as our dedicated team members and leadership team."
The Walmart remodeling is a part of multiple Walmarts around the world receiving upgrades. Some upgrades include extended departments, new items, wider aisles and privacy check-out areas.
Walmart in Denton specifically received upgrades with a newly renovated associates lounge and updates to its pharmacy and vision centers.
During the event, a $4,000 donation was presented to Men for Change, and a $3,000 donation was made to His Hope Ministries.
In addition to the remodeling, a mural was created by artist Gabrielle Wilidheart.
Wilidhaert described the mural: "Sunset in the countryside is a magical hour. Golden light sweeps across farm fields as animals graze peacefully. People unwind, grateful for another day well spent. Perched on a hill above the Choptank River, Denton embodies the best of rural living. Cornfields and chickens are living tributes to the farmers who shaped our community. A man and his dog enjoy the simple joy of evening fishing on the dock, a popular pastime."
The Walmart Supercenter is located at 610 Legion Road in Denton.

title: Mo's Seafood in Eastpoint up for auction
author: LIV BARRY obarry@chespub.com
content:
Mo's Seafood in Eastpoint up for auction

 August 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LIV BARRY obarry@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 247
 Words 

 Read News Document

 According to signs plastered across the establishment's windows, the Mo's Seafood in Eastpoint is officially up for auction.Although the restaurant's Google page lists the Eastpoint seafood house as "temporarily closed," the auction signs mark a death knell for the long-running seafood staple.
The location was partially decimated by a fire in March 2024 that spread from the kitchen to the roof; two people were trapped in the blaze and had to be rescued by fire officials, but were ultimately unharmed.
According to a CBS News report after the fire, the damage to the restaurant was "moderate" and it was not immediately clear how long it would take the spot to reopen.
As of 2025, the location never reopened its doors for customers. In the top righthand side of the building, there are still boarded windows from the fire damage.
The Eastpoint Mo's Seafood was one of three others in a local franchise, previously operating alongside other Mo's in Little Italy, White Marsh and Towson.
Any mention of the Eastpoint location on Mo's Seafood's website was quietly removed after the fire, although it is unclear when the changes were made.
Following the fire, neither the company nor owner made a public statement about the state of the restaurant.
The Mo's Seafood Facebook page, which represents all four of its locations, has not been updated since April 2021. When called, the phone number listed on the Eastpoint restaurant's Google profile immediately gives a busy signal.
Mo's Seafood owner Mohammed Manocheh was not immediately available for comment. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Mo's Seafood restaurant being auctioned after a fire led to its closure, highlighting business failure and economic impact. While local life aspects are present, the core story revolves around business operations and economic consequences.

title: Popular Pennsylvania restaurant moving to Rising Sun
author: Jane Bellmyer jbellmyer@cecilwhig.com
content:
Popular Pennsylvania restaurant moving to Rising Sun

 August 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jane Bellmyer jbellmyer@cecilwhig.com | Section: News 
 
 592
 Words 

 Read News Document

 OXFORD, Pa. — Pam Benjamin made a fresh pot of coffee behind the counter at the Miss Oxford Diner while Robert Barlow worked in the kitchen on a breakfast order.Later, the couple would head to Rising Sun to continue transforming what had been Hatcher's Restaurant on East Main Street into Sunrise Grill.
"We were bouncing things around," Benjamin said of the name for the restaurant. "I thought it should be Sunrise Grill because it fits the town and makes you think of breakfast. But the 'grill' brings in an idea of dinner."
Benjamin and Barlow have been operating Miss Oxford Diner for 22 years. Benjamin, a Cecil County native who grew up near Cecil County Dragway in Rising Sun, said although the diner is packed with so much nostalgia the 1950s era layout is limiting.
"We can't seat parties of 10 to 12," she said of the diner at 233 South Third St.
Word got to the couple that Hatcher's closed in May along with Bog Turtle Brewery. Hatcher's only operated for a little more than a year, while Bog Turtle had celebrated its fifth anniversary in March. Both were under the same ownership.
"We should think about moving," Benjamin said of the discussion the couple had. "We talked to the landlord in July and things moved very fast."
Benjamin said that Rising Sun town officials have been very helpful.
"The town and the area has been very, very accommodating and welcoming," Benjamin said. "The town's been very easy to work with."
Rising Sun Mayor Travis Marion said this fast transition is proof that the town has come into its own after years of a building moratorium and efforts since to revitalize Main Street.
"The opening of Sunrise Grill is another proud milestone in that journey, showing just how quickly new businesses want to be part of Rising Sun's success story," Marion said.
Since the building had been renovated extensively to change from Sue's Restaurant to Hatcher's, Benjamin said there wasn't much to do except change the name and add a little paint and a few other appliances in the kitchen.
She said the menu at Sunrise Grill will be very similar to what customers — many who are from Rising Sun — have been choosing at Miss Oxford Diner.
"We want to bring good, home cooked food to the area," she said. That means breakfast favorites such as biscuits and gravy, eggs Benedict and even avocado toast. "Our pancakes are phenomenal and we have French toast that is like none other."
Barlow said they have connected with Stafford Farms in Elkton to provide locally grown meats and will add new items to the menu. Those new items include steak and pork chops.
There's a big sign on the building at 9 East Main St. in Rising Sun searching for employees.
"We're trying to hire part time workers — teens — as many as we can," Barlow said. Interviews are starting for the many positions needed included kitchen and servers. Because they plan to obtain a Cecil County Liquor License, Barlow said servers will have to be at least 18.
Sunrise Grill will open in October, about a week after Miss Oxford Diner closes. Closed on Tuesdays, it will be open Monday and Wednesday through Saturday 7 a.m. until 9 p.m. and from 7 a.m. until 3 p.m. on Sundays.
"We're really excited," Barlow said. "The community has really reached out to us."
Marion said Rising Sun is just as happy.
"We're excited to welcome them to our community and to our Main Street family," the mayor said.
Anyone interested in a job at Sunrise Grill should call Barlow at 484-886-7169. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a restaurant's relocation and business expansion, highlighting entrepreneurial decisions, community impact, and economic activity. While there are mentions of local government and community engagement, the core subject is the business transition and its economic implications.

title: Competition, a tenet of capitalism
author: Staff Writer
content:
Competition, a tenet of capitalism

 August 23, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 137
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Food trucks are convenient, diverse and, in my experience, provide food options in underserved areas. I worked in a hospital setting with a 30-minute lunch break. The walk to the main hospital was five minutes with an in-line wait of at least 10 minutes — all to purchase cheap, unwholesome and boring food.Do the math — there is now 10 minutes left to eat. So I am a food truck fan.
The takeaway from the StarDem article was the statement "we need to be mindful of our brick- and-mortar stores, we don't want to do anything to compete with them."
So this is about favoritism toward brick-and-mortar stores? I thought competition was a basic tenet of capitalism and healthy competition was to the benefit of the consumer.
So the only thing brick-and-mortar stores should fear is food itself.
SHARON HARRINGTON
Easton 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Hot or not?: Trump touts U.S. economy but businesses are leery of what lies ahead
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS Adams MultiMedia
content:
Hot or not?: Trump touts U.S. economy but businesses are leery of what lies ahead

 August 25, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS Adams MultiMedia | Section: Business 
 
 1108
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Is the U.S. economy hot, cooling or somewhere in between?President Donald Trump and his acolytes say the U.S. economy is humming, citing rising stock markets, big promised corporate and foreign direct investments and lower gasoline prices.
"We have the hottest country on Earth. We have the hottest economy on Earth," Trump said earlier this month.
"We have hundreds of billions of dollars falling in from tariffs …One year ago we were dead as a door nail. Now, we have the hottest country," Trump continued.
The White House touts $8.7 trillion in announced or promised U.S. investments since Trump took office in January from corporate titans such as Apple, NVDIA and IBM as well as countries such as United Arab Emirates, Saudi Arabia, Japan and Qatar.
Trump's always-vociferous critics counter that the cost of housing, child care and groceries are still high compared to before the resets of the coronavirus pandemic, and they worry about the president's very-malleable tariffs regime driving up prices and straining supply chains.
Some economists and analysts see the potential for slower growth and hiring combined with higher prices from tariffs and post-pandemic inflation. Some employers are also looking to artificial intelligence and robotics to take over some workers' duties.
A new forecast from Capital Economics released Aug. 25 foresees 690,000 new jobs created in the U.S. over the next 12 months, 64% less than the jobs created in 2024, according to reports by the Telegraph and Business Matters. That comes after major revisions trimmed recent government jobs growth numbers.
'HOLDING PATTERN'In the middle and on the frontlines of the economy, some businesses loaded up on inventory and materials from China and other importers to help stave off some of the impacts of Trump's tariffs.
Other business owners are in a wait-and-see mode for the impacts of the tariffs and other Trump economic policies with job growth slowing and wholesale prices coming in higher than expected in July.
"A lot of people are really in a holding pattern with spending," said Nathan Green, CEO of Next Level Radio. The Maryland-based company provides radio and music content to hotels, casinos and other venues in 29 U.S. states.
Green sees some more careful spending among both businesses and consumers.
"People are just not sure if the other shoe is going to drop," Green said.
Melissa Katrincic, co-founder and CEO of Conniption Gin in Durham, North Carolina, has also been navigating the Trump landscape.
The downtown distillery sources its juniper berries for its gins from Albania and Bulgaria. Trump has imposed a 10% tariff on Albania while Bulgaria is part of the European Union, which is currently subject to a 15% U.S. tariff rate under the most recent deal with Trump.
Katrincic said her distillery gets its bottles and glassware from China.
"We source from China for a custom bottle design," she said. "We over-purchased at the end of 2024 knowing there could be a lot of uncertainty."
Trump kicked the can until November with trade negotiations with China. The current U.S. tariff rate on Chinese imports is 30%. Trump's use of emergency powers to invoke some of his tariffs faces legal challenges.
Katrincic is keeping tabs on tariffs as well as broader trends such as consumer spending, travel, inflation and social connections.
She is hoping to see a rebound in "ritualistic pauses" such as having a drink after work or before a special event, noting how those activities were lost during the COVID-19 pandemic.
TRAVEL TRENDSThe summer tourism season has seen a similarly mixed picture.
Diane Medler, executive director of Discover Kalispell in Montana, saw a drop in tourism activity in the spring and early summer but was more optimistic about the rest of summer and into the fall. The Kalispell area is home to Glacier National Park and has other outdoor attractions.
"We do anticipate more road trippers throughout the summer and into fall," she said.
Medler has seen a "steep decline" in Canadian tourists. Trump's tariffs and previous jabs of making Canada the 51st state have made him unpopular north of the border impacting tourism to the U.S.
Like other tourism groups, the Montana organization has been putting an emphasis on attracting visitors from nearby markets.
Consumers and businesses are still impacted by post-pandemic inflation.
U.S. prices are up 26% from the end of 2019 and before the COVID-19 pandemic, according to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics.
U.S. households are carrying a record $18.39 trillion in debt, according to the New York Federal Reserve Bank.
"We are placing a heavy emphasis on drive market traffic, specifically Montanans who are looking to explore closer to home, as well as Spokane and Seattle," Medler said.
Annette Brown, chief marketing officer at Visit Temecula Valley in California, said her group has seen continued healthy visitations from Canadians.
"For the remainder of this year, we've paused all international PR and marketing efforts, except for Canada, where we're still seeing demand that justifies continued investment," she said.
Brown also sees more road trips.
"This year, driving vacations, or road trips, are a prominent trend. Many travelers are opting for road trips to have greater flexibility for exploration and to avoid the costs and potential hassles of air travel," she said.
'PROCEED CAREFULLY'As of close of Thursday trading, U.S. stocks markets are up for the year with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up more than 7%, the S&P 500 is up more than 10% and the Nasdaq is up more than 12%, according to Google Finance.
Stocks jumped Friday after Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell indicated the central bank was getting ready to cut interest rates.
Trump has been pressuring Powell and the central bank to cut rates.
Powell has been reticent to cut rates citing uncertainty about tariffs. On Friday, Powell indicated that sentiment is changing during remarks in Jackson Hole, Wyoming, at the annual meeting of U.S. and global elites.
"The stability of the unemployment rate and other labor market measures allows us to proceed carefully as we consider changes to our policy stance," Powell said.
The U.S. jobless rate is currently 4.2%. Gas prices stand at $3.16 per gallon on average nationally (as of Monday, Aug. 25), according to AAA Fuel Gauge Report. That is down from $3.35 per gallon a year ago and the record-high $5.02 per gallon set in 2022.
Wall Street reactively negatively to Trump's higher tariffs pushes but then rallied when the president eased the U.S. stance, retreated or "taco-ed" (Trump always chickens out) as part of negotiations, according to University of Michigan economist Justin Wolfers, a Trump critic.
"The stock market is not the economy, but if you listen carefully, the stock market can be informative, " Wolfers said in a social media analysis. "Every time Trump leans into his economic instincts — threatening tariffs, undermining the Fed, or destroying institutions, stocks tank. Every time he tacos, they bounce back." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on U.S. economic policies, business reactions to tariffs, stock market performance, and corporate investments under Trump's administration. Key themes include economic forecasts, trade negotiations, and business sector challenges, directly aligning with the Business/Economy topic.

title: St. Michaels prepares for tourism drop, but the businesses are ready
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
St. Michaels prepares for tourism drop, but the businesses are ready

 August 27, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: Headlines 
 
 137
 Words 

 Read News Document

 When you think of St. Michaels, you often think of tourists coming to see the town's many sights.While walking around the streets of St. Michaels Wednesday, I talked to multiple business owners about the tourism season and how they prepare for the fall and winter months, when there are fewer tourists around.
They told me about plans that allow them to prepare for those slower months. But no matter how much they rely on tourists, it's support of the community that keeps them open, they said.
With the support of the local community, St. Michaels businesses will be just fine through the fall and the winter. You can read about how business owners prepare in my story below.
Also in today's newsletter: Cambridge hires for multiple positions, rabies is found in Caroline County and more.
Thanks for reading.
— Ahmad Garnett

title: St. Michaels businesses prepare for tourism drop in the fall
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
St. Michaels businesses prepare for tourism drop in the fall

 August 27, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 377
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — The summer tourism season comes to an end after Labor Day. For multiple businesses in St. Michaels, it could mean a slow down in business.Businesses in St. Michaels are preparing for the fall and winter months by cutting back on some costs.
"It's something that we know is coming every year," Craig Schury, owner of Pemberton Pharmacy & Gift St. Michaels, said. "This year has been a little more difficult than most, so we're prepared. We pair down our staff a little bit and we try to keep our merchandise pretty tight. If we control those cost, we know we can be alright."
According to some business owners in St. Michaels, this year's tourism season has not been as good as previous years. While data specific to this year's tourism in St. Michaels is not yet available, domestic tourism nationally has seen a slow down.
According to Bank of America, their aggregated card data showed softer lodging, tourism and airline spending in 2025.
Some St. Michales businesses plan shift merchandise to fit with upcoming seasons in hopes of keeping revenues up.
"We have less families in the fall, more couples, more anniversaries, more getaways, baby moons once the kids are back in school," said Courtney James, manager for The Preppy Redneck store.
"So, it's a different vibe in that a lot of people stop on their way to the beach in the summer and they have more families. Boating season also goes into October. So, a lot more people when it's cooler come out on their boats, um, which is a different vibe too. Each one brings kind of a different vibe."
While the shift in merchandise and savings is key for business, the one major factor business owners hope to continue to see during the fall and winter months is support from the local community.
"It's paramount," said Jay Hudson, owner for Blue Heron Coffee. "We're here for the community, so having the community support throughout the winter means the world. I look at the community as more of the sustainable business model, they're here every day, so their support means all the world. Tourism kind of comes and gos, but to have the community support, not just through the winter, just in general, means the world to a business." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: QAC Economic and Tourism Development welcomes Manufacturers Roundtable
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
QAC Economic and Tourism Development welcomes Manufacturers Roundtable

 September 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Business 
 
 362
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WYE MILLS — Local manufacturing representatives gathered to hear about available resources and opportunities to connect during a Manufacturers Roundtable with the Queen Anne's County Economic and Tourism Development at Chesapeake College Aug 28.Collaboration is the key to economic and workforce success, and QACETD welcomed manufacturers, county officials and regional partners for open dialogue on training initiatives, grant resources, technology adoption, supply chain resilience, and policy support as well as a tour of Chesapeake College's Advanced Manufacturing Program.
Serving as the voice of manufacturers across industries and regions of the state, Maryland Manufacturing Extension Partnership is a nonprofit focused on growing and strengthening Maryland manufacturers.
Maryland MEP Executive Director Mike Kelleher said finding, recruiting and keeping qualified talents is the number one challenge faced by manufacturers.
There is no one-size-fits-all for training and Maryland MEP has a number of programs to support honing qualified talent and helping companies apply and find services and programs, including specific to rural manufactures, he said.
"It is important to improve the skills of the people," Kelleher said.
Providing a glimpse into what manufacturing officials are seeing out in the field, open discussion shared challenges in recruiting and marketing the availability of quality local jobs especially for a younger generation, as well as a lack of affordable housing and transportation.
QACETD Workforce Development Administrator Connie Dean stressed the power of connecting local business with local youth.
The county's Workforce Development supports opportunities for youth on-the-job training and experiences, especially those in technology and trade industries and since the implementation of high school career coaches, workforce development has increased the number of students in "career focused internships," Dean said.
Understanding students can't get interested about an industry they don't know about, this year, the department is moving forward to bring local industries to the students, with more career fairs and field trips to visit manufacturing areas in person, Dean said.
Partnering with QACTV, the department also highlights business and local field opportunities with career awareness videos to present in schools and online at QACTV.com.
Encouraging local industries to get involved with workforce development, "It's important to let people know what the business is," she said.
More information about QAC Economic and Tourism Development can be found at choosequeenannes.com. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.
